<div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are Cwichelm, King of Wessex</h1> <p>Anglo-Saxon England, c. 640</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "asking-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "asking-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p>The great fire roars, washing the hall with heat and golden light. Torches dance in the corners. Laughter echoes off tall, timbered roof. You breathe deeply, smelling meat and bread and woodsmoke, <<linkappend "savoring these hall joys - the fruits and the seeds of victory.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include asking-link1>><</linkappend>> From your high seat above the mead benches, you watch in silence - the young men posturing and boasting, testing their prestige and the mettle of their comrades, nettling and heckling, hoping for a fight, the older men quieter on the benches, like great stones in the river, worn smooth by the storm of swords.</p> <p>You watch your daughter and your wife move gracefully down the hall, <<linkappend "filling mead horns,">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include asking-link3>><</linkappend>> exchanging quiet words with the warriors. You note with approval the way they navigate the hierarchies and subtle currents of rivalry. Your daughter gives a small twist of fine gold, a pendant, to your oldest friend, Aschere. She stands in conversation with him for a long time. Next in her path is her uncle’s son, Osric. He's an insolent youth whose mother’s family has been pushing him into competition with your own sons. Fortunately, he’s as strong as a newborn lamb. His arms and neck are bare - a comic contrast to the heavy gold rings on old Aschere's arms. Poor Osric won’t last long, and your daughter ’s right to make him wait, to let the rest of them see her making him wait. She talks with Aschere for a very long time, refilling his mead horn twice - smiling sweetly, laughing softly, beautiful and gold-adorned. You see Osric struggling for calm, trying not to hear her or look at her … and failing miserably. The boy’s incapable of anything. That is good.</p> <p>Your eldest son, Cenwalh, sees what’s happening. He raises his voice and calls down the table to the Osric: “Hey, Osric! I know you didn’t really kill that Welsh goat thief! Or his friends. I saw them yesterday…” Your daughter quietly moves to fill Osric's mead horn at last, but has to apologize because her cup has run dry. You can’t completely suppress a grin behind your beard. She leaves to fetch more as the two youths begin to argue. When Osric tries to stand up, you nod to the old man at your feet. He’s ready. He plucks the strings of his harp and a startlingly loud voice issues from his bony frame: <<linkappend '“Listen! We have heard of the Spear-Danes, long ago, of the royal princes’ deeds of glory…”'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include asking-link4>><</linkappend>> The hall falls silent. Totally silent. Their eyes shine in the firelight as they forget, for a time, their own petty quarrels, lost in the tales of old.</p> <p>Now you can relax and think. Your wife, a Mercian princess, is Christian. You are not. She has a priest who holds mass for her and her retinue. Some of your people have been joining them. Your daughter has converted, following her mother's example. Over the years, the pope has sent you rich gifts from Rome. <<linkappend "Should you become Christian?">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include asking-link5>><</linkappend>> Other kings have, in Kent and Northumbria. Massive stone churches have risen in their kingdoms. Preists record their laws and gifts in books that will last forever. Forever? <<linkappend "Nothing is forever. Fate goes as it will.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include asking-link2>><</linkappend>> This hall is strong. Your sons are strong. The warband is as united as any warband can be. What can the Roman Christ do for your kingdom, or for you?</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>This is where English is born - as a language and as a national identity. When the Roman legions withdrew from their province of Britannia early in the fifth century, the native Celtic Britons were attacked by their warlike Gaelic-speaking neighbors in Scotland and Ireland. After centuries of Roman rule, the Britons weren't used to fending for themselves. So they called in Germanic mercenaries: the Angles, Saxons, and Jutes. As the <em>Anglo-Saxon Chronicle's</em> entry for the year 443 tells it:</p> <p>"King Vortigern [a British king] gave them land to the south-east of this land on condition that they fought against the Picts. They then fought against the picts and had victory wherever they came. Then they sent to Angel; ordered them to send more aid and to be told of the worthlessness of the Britons and of the excellence of the land."</p> <p>The old "Why buy the cow when you can get the milk for free?" situation? Over the next few centuries, an <em>Angla-lond</em> took shape, inhabited by an <em>Anglisc</em> people. The native Celtic-speaking Britons were pushed to the western fringes in Wales and Cornwall (and please don't make the mistake of calling one of them English ... not a good way to make friends). This is why the language we are speaking here today is a Germanic one, not a Celtic one.</p> <p>By the way, our modern English language preserves traces of Germanic paganism we use every day: Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. Those English names come from the old gods: Sun, Moon, Tyr, Woden, Thor, Frig. So that explains the "d" in Wednesday: "Woden's Day." What happened to Saturday? I think the Romans got that one (Saturn).</p> <hr> <p>Did you already know the story of that weird "d" in Wednesday?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Yes, everyone knows about that.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Ok, sorry. I'm boring.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "No! It makes sense now!">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Cool. Etymology is fun.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>I have disappointing news. We have fallen in with some bad company in this branch of our time travel journey. Very bad company, indeed. Our fellow travelers are Nazis. Adolf Hitler's fascination with an an "Aryan" master race led him to celebrate the early medieval history of Germanic peoples. This is why he loved Wagner's operas about the Nibelungenlied - Sigurd and the dragon and valkyries and all that.</p> <p>You know how the bad guys in the old Indiana Jones movies are always Nazi archaeologists? Well, the Nazi regime did support scholars whose research focused on this corner of history. Hitler, like his frenemy, Stalin, saw the value of history as a propaganda tool in the identity politics propping up his regime and justifying its horrors. So he made sure people who wrote history were doing it his way.</p> <p>Sadly, white supremacist psychos have carried on Hitler's passion for Germanic history, especially Norse myth and legend. It has left a sickly aura of racist fanaticism and thuggish ignorance around this part of the historical landscape. It's an unfortunate reality. Let's do our best to avoid these traveling companions, and carry on exploring early Germanic history without them. It's a fascinating place. Let's not let a bunch of evil Nazis and their ignorant toadies spoil it for us, eh?</p> <p><img src="images/nazi-prop.jpg" alt="nazi propaganda posters" width="100%"></p> <p>Nazi propaganda drew heavily on the themes and aesthetic of Hitler's ideas of a White master race. As he put it in <em>Mein Kampf</em>: "Everything we admire on this earth today—science and art, technology and inventions—is only the creative product of a few peoples and originally perhaps one race [the Aryans]." It's just so boring. Let's leave this group in the dust and move on.</p> <hr> <p>Have you ever encountered this history appropriated by icky racists?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "No.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Lucky you. That's good to hear.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Oh, for sure.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>It is so frustrating! This is such exciting terrain in our historical landscape. I hope that with the passage of time, these icky associations will fade. We'll see.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt: </span>Do you convert to Christianity? How does your decision impact your position as king, and the community of elite warriors in your hall? Does it make your kingdom stronger or weaken it?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Political factors including kin rivalries and relationships with neighboring kingdoms</li> <li>Economic factors such as the prosperity of your kingdom and its trade relations with its neighbors</li> <li>Your wife's priest and his relationships with others in your political circle and the community more widely</li> <li>People's pagan practices and the stance of pagan religious leaders regarding this new religion</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Converting the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms |bede]]</li> <hr> <li>[[King Hrothgar |hrothgar]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Sutton Hoo ship burial |suttonhoo]]</li> <hr> <li>[[About the arrival of Christianity in Anglo-Saxon England |naismith]]</li> <hr> <li>[[What we can and can't know about Germanic paganism |orton]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-k]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? Portal |Rome2]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><p>This game was created by Abigail Queen using the Twine interactive fiction platform and the SugarCube story format. References:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://twinery.org/" target="_blank">Twinery.org</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.motoslave.net/sugarcube/2/docs/" target="_blank">SugarCube2</a></li> <li><a href="http://www.motoslave.net/tweego/" target="_blank">Tweego Compiler</a></li> <li><a href="https://manonamora.itch.io/twine-sugarcube-guide" target="_blank">SugarCube Guide by ManonAmora</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLlXuD3kyVEr5JmCL3GbEAd0jPsDVcuge7" target="_blank">SugarCube2 tutorials by Dan Cox</a></li> </ul> <p>Images are open source educational files or free downloads from the following creators:</p> <ul> <li>From <a href="https://pixaby.com" target="_blank">Pixaby.com: </a>Momentmal, lunar-sea-art, AlanFrijns, ELG21, FaceGuy</li> <li>From <a href="https://unsplash.com" target="_blank">Unsplash.com: </a>annie-spratt, Max Tcvetkov, Sabina Sturzu, Leonardo Ramos, Jason Hogan</li> <li>Others to be posted...</li> </ul><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a philosopher</h1> <p>Alexandria, c. 200 BCE</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "alex-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "alex-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Alexandria is a paradise. All day, you've drifted contentedly around the library, lost in contemplation and study, composing a new philosophical treatise and antcipating the counter-arguments of your rivals. All your life, you’ve been fascinated by knowledge and ideas. You’ve dabbled in physics, medicine, mathematics, poetics, ontology and metaphysics. Lately, you’ve been thinking more about politics. You’ve even begun writing a short treatise on the ultimate purpose of life.</p> <p>This evening, you're reclining on your couch, in a cloud of sweet music and savory aromas. This <<linkappend "symposium-style dinner party">><<include "alex-link2">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> has become a kind of weekly ritual for your group of philosophical comrades. You're sharing some of your new ideas about human virtue, and what it means to live a good life. Your best friend and longtime romantic partner heckles you mercilessly. He insists that since our minds do not exist after death, this whole question is a waste of time - and therefore not virtuous. You accuse him of being reductionist and intellectually lazy. He accuses you of being unrealistic and sophistical, wasting your time on an academic farce with no purpose beyond stroking your own ego and averting boredom.</p> <p>This argument can, and actually does, go on and on between the two of you, on an almost daily basis. He is a devoted adherent to Epicureanism. While you're not exactly <em>against</em> the teachings of Epicurius, you think the philosophy incomplete and naive. You yourself find Zeno's Stoicism more elegant and fulfilling. So, there's really no way the two of you will ever settle this debate on the purpose or value of human life. Still, it's not a bad way to spend the evening. Again.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Along with Latin, Greek was a language used by educated people throughout Europe for over two millennia. From the days of republican Rome through the days of the Scientific Revolution, educated people could communicate using Latin and/or Greek, even if they didn't know each other's native languages. If you think about it, that's very powerful! So we aren't too surprised that many Greek words continue to float around in our everyday lives. Here are just a few examples.</p> <ul> <li>Lots of scientific concepts and terminology, like heliocentric</li> <li>Lots of political concepts and terminology like politics, democracy, aristocracy, oligarchy</li> <li>Gymnasium</li> <li>Symposium</li> <li>Olympics</li> <li>Cosmos</li> <li>Chronological</li> <li>The name of the town Eureka</li> </ul> <hr> <p>Which other language has had a major impact on modern English?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Arabic">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>No.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "French">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>That is correct!<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>The Victorians created some loveable and obdurately naive representations of Ancient Greek sexuality. In Victorian versions of Greek myths, Zeus "married" females and "befriended" males (obviously the Greeks meant sexual encounters). They depicted the great poet Sappho of Lesbos as the headmistress of a school for girls (in fact, her poetry expresses erotic love between women). Victorian notions of sexuality were rigidly, almost pathologically binary, and their desperation to fit ancient Greek literature into that framework become comic at times.</p> <p><img src="images/alma-tadema-sappho.jpg" alt="women in Greek dress in a theater listen to young man playing a lyre" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Lawrence Alma-Tadema, "Sappho and Alcaeus" (1881)</p> <hr> <p>How did Victorians view homosexuality?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "As an incurable disease requiring the afflicted individual to undergo rigorous treatment or be separated from polite society.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>It does sound plausible, but this isn't quite correct.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "As uncontrolled heterosexual desire rather than a separate sexual orientation.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>Yes. Today, Victorian culture has a well-earned reputation for conflicted and repressive attitudes toward sexuality.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What are some features of your ideal political system?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>How do you respond to your partner's criticism that there really is no good system of government because power corrupts?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your personality, upbringing, education, socio-economic status</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Epicureanism |epicurus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Stoicism |epictetus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[People |theophrastus]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Homosexuality in Ancient Greece |homosexuality]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are an African artist</h1> <p>Florence, Italy, c. 1620</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "art-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "art-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p><<linkappend "You sit bowed over your papers and brushes, silent and motionless, lost in thought.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include art-link1>><</linkappend>> You're at peace here in the busy workshop run by your friend, <<linkappend "Artemisia Gentileschi, at the court of the Grand Duchess Christina of Tuscany.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include art-link4>><</linkappend>> It's a busy place, ringing with the sounds of creation: grinding pigmants, mixing paints, cutting canvas, hammering frames, the clink of brushes on cups, a ceaseless flow of voices chattering, muttering, laughing, shouting to the servants whose feet are never still.</p> <p>The whole palace is busy. Grand Duchess Christina is the sun in a heliocentric system, and great folk orbit around her. You enjoy the conversations and the controversy they bring to court, the letters and treatises read aloud and debated for hours. They argue about everything from the stars to the scripture. Recently, you heard them arguing about the Indians of the New World, mapping out differences between Indians and Europeans, between the English, the French, the Germans, the Italians, between Florentines and Venitians, Sicilians and Romans. Soon, they were comparing Moors and Indians and Arabs and, inevitably, <<linkappend "Africans.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include art-link2>><</linkappend>> Eyes began to slide your way, and people edged away from you until you were standing in an empty space and your face began to burn.</p> <p>Now, staring at the blank paper, your cheeks heat up again, remembering the feeling. You remember, too, hearing about about Spanish priest who condemned his own countrymen for their cruelty toward the Indians. Artemisia has the book in the workshop. You've seen the images De Bry created and <<linkappend "felt their power.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include art-link3>><</linkappend>> Protestant heretics have been doing the same, making woodcuts and pelting every city north of the Alps with evil portraits of the pope. Those images, too, had power ... which means <em>you</em> can have power.</p> <p>So what can you create to fight against that system whose grasp you felt in court? The system of the world these learned men are imagining, which will place some people in slavery and some in liberty, simply because of where they were born or what they look like? The system that suddenly made you feel like an alien in the place you call home? You hear Artemisia's voice and look up. Maybe she can help with this project. Or maybe it's something you will need to do alone.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>As we've seen in these "pet the zombie" interludes, language changes over time, carrying bits of history along with it. Then, that history-infused language fills up our heads, coloring our outlook on the world and even our feelings about ourselves and others. This is our last role play unit. We'll close the zombie petting zoo with profanity.</p> <p>Why do we use profanity? Swear words are like little explosions of emotion. That's their real purpose. And that's why their semantic content can be so malleable - "fuck" can mean sooooo many things, right? And it can be employed in so many different contexts. But what's the use of a word with so many meanings? Seems kind of pointless. Not quite. With swear words, it's the word's <em>energy</em> rather than its exact denotation (or even wider connotation) that has value as a means of communication.</p> <p>In the Renaissance, profanity began to change, keeping pace with people's changing worldview. Before the Renaissance, in the Middle Ages, people's worldview was profoundly religious. So medieval profanity had to be religious to carry a sting, to deliver the little emotional <em>zing</em> swear words have to deliver in order to "work." Walking into a fourteenth-century market town and yelling, "By God's wounds!" would have flattened the crowd. Horrified silence. But if you yelled "Fuck that shit!" in the same fourteenth-century town, people wouldn't bat an eye. Bodily functions were no big deal. Fuckbythenavel and Fuckbutter were actual medieval surnames. Gropecunt and Fuckingrove were place names of record. Because "fuck" and "cunt" weren't regarded as particularly strong language. Medieval people saw sex and death on the regular. They took kids to watch public executions. No big deal. But witches and heretics? <em>That's</em> a big deal and we will burn them as soon as we find them. So, it makes sense that medieval swear words relating to bodily functions didn't pack much of a punch. They were maybe a little <em>salty,</em> but not strong. Swear words relating to religion, though, were powerful. Blasphemy was an actual crime.</p> <p><em>Sidetrack: This is a little like the way kids' movies have changed in the last century. 1970s Warner Bros and Disney cheerfully included smoking, racism, and violence in kids' movies, but they would have flipped out at telling kids about same sex romantic relationships. In the 2020s, the opposite standards apply to kids' movies.</em></p> <p>Today in the 2020s, saying, "Oh my God!" goes unnoticed, but saying, "Oh, fuck!" will raise some eyebrows. You can probably say "damn" or "hell" at Christmas dinner, but not the "f word." It would have been <em>the reverse</em> for medieval people. For instance, in 1528 in the manuscript below, an English cleric recorded his opinion about his boss: "O d fuckin abbot." The cleric (a church officer!) was fine with writing the f-word, but drew the line at writing out "damn," because that was just going too far. "Fuck" was salty, "damn" was dirty. And, by the way, that particular abbot <em>did</em> have a reputation for literally fucking, so... </p> <p><img src="images/profanity.jpg" alt="manuscript page" width="80%"></p> <p>So, back to the Renaissance... By, 1600 when actors strode across Shakespeare's stage yelling things like, "S'blood!," (politely short for "God's blood"), viewers were shocked and titilated (just as we expect to be when we watch HBO). (Fun fact: This is the first word spoken on stage by Iago, the most evil of all evil Shakespeare villains!). In 1600, where our semester ends, blasphemy was still pretty strong language (still illegal, actually). People expected it at the playhouse, just like we expect f-bombs on HBO.</p> <p>So here comes the "undead history" feature: archaic profanity that just won't die. Ever heard someone say, "Darn!"? Well, it's a contraction of "'Tarnation!" which comes from "'Tarnal!" which was short for "By Eternal God!" And "Zounds!" is a short form of "By God's wounds!" We don't hear those too often today, but sometimes.</p> <p>Interested in the way our language continues to evolve today? Check out <a href="https://www.urbandictionary.com/" target="_blank">Urban Dictionary</a> and have fun!</p> <hr> <p>Which Shakespeare insult do you like best?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>In the not-so-distant decade of the 1980s, someone named Joan Kelly was traveling this road through the history of the Renaissance. And as she traveled, admiring the spectacular art and the humanism, and marveling at the birth of science, she wondered, "What about the women?" In 1984, she published an article called "Did Women have a Renaissance?" and it tore through academia like a fire bomb. She answered her question with a definite, "no," and went on to radically reorient and reanimate scholarly approaches to medieval and renaissance history, as well as the entire (relatively young in 1984) field of women's history. It was one of those finger of God, <em>Deus ex Machina</em>, "Let there be light!" moments. A beautiful thing.</p> <p>Here's a representative quote from Kelly's landmark article: "All the advances of Renaissance Italy, its proto-capitalist economy, its states, and its humanistic culture, worked to mould the noblewoman into an aesthetic object: decorous, chaste and doubly dependent - on her husband as well as the prince." <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What kinds of imagery, symbolism, and text will you use? How do you imagine people will respond?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>Describe one of your pieces in detail, and explain what impact you hope it will have.</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your relationship with Duchess Christina and with Artimesia Gentileschi</li> <li>Your family situation and connections with the community</li> <li>Your economic status</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[An African boy is enslaved |equiano]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The origins of anti-black racism |bondage]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Gender and slavery |eltis]]</li> <hr> <li>[[European descriptions of African women |morgan]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance Portal |Renaissance]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you've just joined the Assyrian army</h1> <p>Mesopotamia, c. 800 BCE</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "assyria-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "assyria-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row scenario"> <p>You saw the smoke a day before arriving at the city. Now you see that it doesn’t rise from the city itself, but from the imperial camp coiled around its walls. The road to the camp is broad and well-traveled, busy with camels and horses, soldiers and travelers. A ribbon of dark riparian growth shows where a small river passes through the camp to skirt the city walls. You remember crossing the Euphrates a few weeks ago, the terror and awe, and then the feeling of relief and even pride at having mastered the great river. You’d never seen <<linkappend "anything like it.">><<include "assyria-link1">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>You’d never seen anything more than your poor, small village with its low, mud huts and its herds of skinny goats, until the army came a few months ago.</p> <p>They came to your village looking for taxes and conscripts for the imperial army. Some of the boys had fought and screamed. Some of their families had fought or tried to hide, and the rich ones had given everything they had to keep their sons home. And now here you are - not that you know where “here” is.</p> <p>You’re smart enough to realize that your life has almost no value to your commanders. You don’t necessarily want to go home (after all, it wasn’t much, and the sargeants here make a big show of executing deserters in memorably messy ways). Strangely, you value yourself. You have decided that you are more than meat to be fed into the imperial war machine. You want to survive. Maybe even move up in the world. <<linkappend "Power. Wealth. A future.">> <<include "assyria-link2">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> There’s opportunity, as well as horror and death, all around you here. What do you do?</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Some silly etymology related to this era</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <hr> <p>One of my favorite places is the Assyrian room in the British Museum. It's usually quiet and fairly empty (in contrast to the Egyptian or Roman exhibits, clogged with heaving masses of sweaty tourists). The Assyrian room is a temple. A holy shrine to so many things. Like brutal, hypocritical, racist imperialism? Meet our fellow travelers here in ancient West: nineteenth-century European imperialists.</p> <p><img src="images/stanley.jpg" alt="photo of Victorian-era man holding a rifle with Black servant nearby" width="50%"></p> <p>(Above: Victorian explorer Henry Morton Stanley with African servant in 1872)</p> <p>In their pith helmets and assertive mustaches, these intrepid and entitled explorers risked their lives and their fortunes to pirate ancient artifacts from the farthest reaches of their global empires and bring them back to private or public collections in Europe (like the Louvre in Paris and the British Museum in London).</p> <p><img src="images/denon-temple.jpg" alt="watercolor of ancient monuments" width="100%"></p> <p>The European science of archaeology was born here. It started with Napoleon's invasion of Egypt (British sphere of influence), when artists like Vivant Denon discovered magnificent ruins of an ancient civilization (above: Denon's impression of an Egyptian temple in 1807). It seemed to them that the indigenous Egyptians and their Ottoman rulers had no knowledge of or interest in these artifacts. Grave robbers had plundered the low-hanging fruit, the ruins were defaced by graffiti, goats were living in the temples, and nobody seemed to care. So the French began excavating and studying and transported many of these Egyptian treasures back to Paris. To French viewers, they were emblems of Napoleon's power. You can see the 13th-century BCE obelisks from ancient Egypt in the streets of Paris today (below).</p> <p><img src="images/luxor-paris.jpg" alt="obelisks in a city" width="80%"></p> <p>Here's a fun comedy routine about this issue.</p> <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/x73PkUvArJY?si=42C9LWUQJYnlQnCe" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe> <hr> <p>Nowadays, imperialism is out of fashion. Right out. Decolonization is the watchword, and many feel outraged that these ancient artifacts remain in the colonizers' hands. They believe they should be returned, with apologies, to the regimes currently in power in these locations. Do you agree?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Yes, obviously. It's ludicrous that the British museum in London continues to hold artifacts that belong to Syria.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>It doesn't seem fair, does it? Western nations should prioritize taking steps to redress and dismantle these legacies of colonial injustice.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "I do not agree because this issue is more complex. For instance, the regimes in these parts of the world have little connection to the civilizations that created the artifacts, and they are so unstable that the artifacts would be in real danger of damage or destruction.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>Fair points. Also, it's possible that a much smaller and less diverse group of people would go to see them if they were housed in, say, Aleppo or Baghdad?<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>How will you achieve personal success here at this siege, and boost your status within the military?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>In ten years, what will your life be like? If you're still alive? Will you ever go home? Why?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your past experience, skills, physical and intellectual abilities</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Assyrian Palace Art |friezes]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Black Obelisk of Shalmaneser III |obelisk]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Secondary source |mil-empire]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Assyrian siege warfare |assyrian-sieges]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a young scribe in Babylon</h1> <p>Mesopotamia, c. 1700 BCE</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "babylon-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "babylon-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row scenario"> <p>You are a young scribe in the <<linkappend "palace complex">> <<include "babylon-link1">> <</linkappend>> of Old Babylon. Life is miserable. You are bored and angry, exhausted from doing chores and trying to learn this impossible script while dodging beatings from your teachers and hazing from the older boys. Everyone tells you how lucky you are, how great your city's gods and king are. They love stories like the <<linkappend "Epic of Gilgamesh.">> <<include "babylon-link2">> <</linkappend>></p> <p>You don't buy it. Gilgamesh is an idiotic thug, like basically everyone who tells you what to do all day (which is a lot of people). Risking a major beating, you steal some clay tablets from the priests. In the weak light of the quiet hours before dawn, you start writing a new version of <em>Gilgamesh</em>. You hide the tablets in a niche under your sleeping mat. In your story, Gilgamesh gets what he deserves.</p> <p>One morning when you reach for your tablets, your heart freezes and time stops as your fingers find only empty space. <em>Wtf who took it they are going to kill me. If I'm lucky...</em> You look around and see a form hunched over in the dim predawn grey. You approach slowly. It's your best friend. He's holding your tablets, and he's crying. He hugs you and begs to join your Gilgamesh rewrite. Soon, others young scribes join - at first, just for fun, but soon it becomes a genuine conspiracy of revolution. They all have colorful ideas for revenge on the palace elite. You form a plot to overthrow the regime and seize power for yourselves.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>The name "Mesopotamia" is from Greek for "between" and "rivers." We can see a similar morphology in the word "hippopotamus:" Greek for "horse" of the "river. Etymology is fun.</p> <hr> <p>Which mythological animal has a Greek name related to those above?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "A creature that's half horse and half eagle">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>The hippogriff! Good work.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "A creature that's half horse and half man">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>That would make lots of sense. But this horse creature had its own Greek name: <em>Kentaurus</em>, or "centaur."<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>At a strategically vital location between the great Tigris and Euphrates rivers, it's no wonder that the city of Babylon reigned supreme in the region, serving as the administrative and economic hub for numerous empires as they rose and fell through the Bronze and Iron Age. The Hebrew Bible depicts Babylon as the epitome worldly vice, sin, greed, and ambition, a den of iniquity standing in stark opposiiton to the upright virtue of the Hebrew followers of Yaweh. Babylon became the original "sin city." This image persisted into the modern age as centuries of Christian writers and artists used Babylon to represent the antipathy of Christian virtue.</p> <p><img src="images/whore-babylon.jpg" alt="woman riding a dragon" width="60%"></p> <p>This image from a sixteenth-century German Bible represents the "Whore of Babylon" with her dragon. In the biblical book of Revelations, she is the mother of the Antichrist of Armageddon. By putting a papal crown on the woman, this Protestant artist has harnessed the old symbolism of Babylon to his own political agenda, creating an image that demonizes the Pope and the Catholic church, associating them with Antichrist, Satan, and worldly corruption.</p> <hr> <p>What's the equivalent of Babylon in the West today?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "New York City">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Or Paris? No, New York is better: finance, politics, diversity, transportation.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Las Vegas">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>The nickname of Sin City fits, but Vegas is missing Babylon's intrinsic geostrategic value.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What are your plans for the rebellion? How will you seize power? Or will you escape the city and settle somewhere else?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>When you create your new regime or society, what will it look like? What kind of laws or economy or system of government will you make?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your skills, knowledge, economic status</li> <li>The current political and economic situation</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The Royal Standard of Ur (c. 2500 BCE) |royal-standard]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Epic of Gilgamesh (c. 2200 BCE) |Gilgamesh]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Advice to a Scribe (c. 1880 BCE) |scribe-egypt]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Code of Hammurabi (c. 1790 BCE) |Hammurabi]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[A Scribe's Life |scribe-meso]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class notes.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-b]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a barbarian boy</h1> <p>Germania, 411</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "barb-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "barb-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p>You stalk down to the shore of the great river. You draw a deep breath and cast your line far out into the current. Too far. This is the worst place for fishing. And it's right next to the Roman road where anyone might see you - fishing like a lowborn slave. You put up your hood and scowl, blinking mist-drops from your eyelashes and feeling the cold seep into your toes. You've always loved fishing, even though your kin have been lords in this land for hundreds of years. <<linkappend "Your friends give you hard time about this low-born pastime, but you're used to their heckling and you can thrash any one of them, especially when you spar with wooden swords.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include "barb-link3">><</linkappend>></p> <p>This morning, fishing was an excuse to get out of the house. Your parents were arguing again, about you again, and you felt like your head was about to burst. When they do this, you usually flee with sword and shield to the fort to spar with your friends. But it's Sunday, and nobody will be there. You cast again, still scowling, but feeling better by the moment, watching the waves rise and swirl, listening to the cadence of the river's rush. Nearby, <<linkappend "the great fortress of Vindobona looms through the morning fog, dark and massive above the river.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include barb-link1>><</linkappend>></p> <p>You hear your parents' voices in your head: "Nobody builds like that any more. Where would we even get the stone?" You are so tired of hearing about "the good old days" when the power of Rome was real, when there was drinkable wine, fine cloth, clear glass, good iron tools and swords, a library, a real bath house, coins worth their face value. When people could travel a good, straight Roman road that didn't rattle a cart to tatters, shelter safety behind strong Roman walls, and find justice from a Roman magistrate. The days when people stayed and fought for the land of their ancestors instead of fleeing west every time the a horde of screaming savages appeared on the horizon... And on and on it goes. You shake your head to silence this rehearsal of their eternal, aimless grumbling. Who cares about yesterday? Old men. Not you. You want to know about tomorrow.</p> <p>Your mother wants you to spend a year or two at Vindobona learning to read and write, to navigate the imperial bureaucracy, building on your family's connections as members of the local elite. She knows the bishop and the legion's commissar, and could get you a place as a clerk for either one. The old imperial system is still the path to power, she says, as it was for her father in the auxiliaries and her brothers who serve the Roman magistrate, and her cousins in the church.</p> <p>You father wants you to focus on learning his trade. He's a smith. He says a smith's family will never go hungry or lose their seat in the council as long as men need swords and armor. Forget Rome. It's done. Mind the smithy, train with your comrades, and look to your own defences.</p> <p>You cast your line again - bootlessly, you know, but it doesn't matter. You're feeling a bit better. The rising sun has wrapped Vindobona in a nimbus of golden fog. You wish you were in the training yard with a blunted sword in your hand, dodging and thrusting. When you fight, all these doubts disappear and nothing can stand in your way. You want to be great general <<linkappend "like Fritigund or Alaric or Stilicho.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include barb-link2>><</linkappend>> The smithy is as dull as the scriptorium. Where do you really belong?</p> <p>Still scowling, you cast again and wonder, for the hundredth time, what your future holds.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Our English language comes from the family of Germanic languages spoken by the barbarian tribes. It takes shape as "English" in the early Middle Ages. When we look at these early English texts, it's fun to recognize early versions of words we still use today. But appearances can be deceiving. Sometimes, we think we recognize an ancestor of a modern English word, but it is actually unrelated - what linguists call a "false cognate." The old fashioned expression, "God speed!" is a great example. It looks like it means something like, "May God speed you on your journey." But instead, we find that the Old English word, <em>sped</em> meant "money," not "speed." The old expression, "God speed!" was originally a say of wishing someone good luck and good fortune: Something like, "May your venture be profitable." A similar example might be the old-timey phrase, "Wassail!" We generally think of this as a kind of toast, probably connecting to ale, which was a popular drink in medieval times. Maybe you've heard of a wassail cup. Well, people often did drink ale, but that's not the root of the word "wassail." Instead, it is a contraction of the Old English phrase, "Wæs ðu hæl!" meaning, "May you have health!" or "To your good health!"</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>When the Renaissance erupted across Europe and brought light to the "dark" Middle Ages, people decided that medieval architecture was hiddeous, lumpy, dark, clumsy. They began building in a new style emulating the aesthetics of Rome and Greece: clean lines, pillars, lots of light, arches, domes, order, harmony, <em>symmetry</em>. To them, medieval architecture was a hiddeous expression of barbarism and ignorance, an embodiment of the "dark ages" that separated their own enlightened age from that other enlightened age of classical times. They were going to put the medieval mess behind them and reconnect with Rome.</p> <p>And who killed Rome? Well, the barbarian tribes, the most notorious of whom were some sort of Goth: Visigoth, Ostrogoth, etc. So these Renaissance revisionists (let's call them that!) labeled the detested medieval architecture "gothic" as a pejorative expression of their loathing. To them, "gothic" meant "barbarian, savage, ugly, dark", in opposition to Rome's elegance and civilization.</p> <p>A few centuries later, people (mostly young women) started reading and writing ghost stories about vampires and haunted castles, and the aesthetic was very medieval: ruined abbeys and vaulted arches and stained glass. These thematic and aesthetic associations with medieval architecture earned the new literary genre the label of "gothic novel." And from gothic novel, you can pretty much pick up the connection to the "goth look" we're familiar with today.</p> <p><img src="images/salisbury-cathedral.jpg" alt="gothic cathedral exterior" width="50%"></p> <p>Above: Salisbury Cathedral in England (c. 1250) is a beautiful example of the gothic style.</p> <p><img src="images/gothic-psalter.jpg" alt="illuminated manuscript" width="50%"></p> <p>Above: Renaissance "moderns" applied the term "gothic" to medieval scripts too, like this psalter from England, c. 1300 (the Alphonso Psalter).</p> <hr> <p>In 500 years, how do you think people will view our own early 21st-century West?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "As a kind of golden age they can hardly imagine. The end of a long stretch of western ascendancy when people in the West enjoyed unparalleled luxury and freedom.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>This seems like a reasonable guess to me. Most western populations today enjoy a higher standard of living and more freedom than most people have in human history. Maybe it has been an anomaly. Or maybe it has set a new and higher standard for the future. But what about the non-western people of the world?<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "As a dark age of oppression and injustice, when the ruling elite used new technologies and global capitalism to weild unprecedented power over the masses and destroy global natural resources for profit.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>I wonder how this will turn out for all of us. New technologies have always posed risks as well as benefits. The historical record suggests that the vast majority of human societies have been divided by strata of rich and poor, powerful and weak. But does that mean it should always be this way? How much can new technologies change these "eternal" aspects of human society? Wait and see?<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>Will you follow your father's advice and work on becoming a smith? Or will you follow your mother's advice, and work toward a role in the Roman administration or the church? Or will you focus on the training yard and try to get some combat experience, hoping for a military career? What opportunities will this choice bring you in the future?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>What are some lucky or unlucky events that might shape your success in your chosen path? Is there any way to plan ahead to mitigate the impact of such luck or unluck?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your skills, tastes, aptitudes</li> <li>Your friends</li> <li>The political events such as Hun invasions or coups by the local elite</li> <li>The treatment you receive from church or administrative officials, and from your family and local leaders</li> <li>Your religious preferences (e.g., Germanic pagan, Arian Christian, Catholic Christian)</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Tacitus, Germania |tacitus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Jordanes, History of the Goths |jordanes]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Germanic tribes |green]]</li> <hr> <li>[[On the late empire's frontier |law]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? Portal |Rome2]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row beginhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>In the Beginning, There was Beer</h1> <p>You and your comrades have written a new history of the dawn of civilization. Open the branching pathways to explore it.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center space"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Gobekli Tepe Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/gobekli-tepe_natgeo.jpg" alt="neolithic people building a monolithic structure" width="50%"> <p>It's almost springtime in the hills of Anatolia when your migratory forager clan happens upon an interesting community. They have a permanent settlement with walls and homes and irrigated gardens. They have beer! ... Your group is invited to form a team and work on transporting the big stones. That evening, your band gathers around a fire and considers this decision. When it's your turn to speak, what do you say?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[I think that even though they were creating a community you still have to fend for yourself and I would rather not have to compete with people and just go somewhere else. |gt-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I want to be a part of this amazing project. The work is hard, but the labor is worthwhile. The feasts they staged to attract us and convince us to work (Archaeology Magazine) were tempting enough to get me on board. ... The detail in the faces of our gods (Tepe Telegrams) will live on and tell our stories when we are gone. |gt-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[She doesn't like where this new form of life is going. She's a free spirit. She just wants to travel. |gt-rewrite3]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I would pack up and head for the hills. As a forager, steady everyday manual labor would most likely make me restless. ... Stories and folklore in early settlements were more than likely extremely important in the societal impact of these beer loving settlements. After trading a couple of these stories with the community, we head off. |gt-rewrite4]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I hate my job in our new town. All I do all day long is make these stupid giant T-pillars “with a height of about 5.5 m it is” so hard to get all the way on top of them to make them look good and I’m sick of it. ... Not even the beer is enough to make me stay, and I love beer. |gt-rewrite5]]</li> <hr> <li>[[My girlfriend got really hooked on trying to create stories from these carvings so she's really adamant on staying. She told me long distance would never work ... and after I tasted beer it was really a no-brainer to stay. |gt-rewrite6]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Being able to work on these art pieces is something that is truly amazing and is a way for those in the future to know that we were here. |gt-rewrite7]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Of particular interest to me was the designs on the Tepe steles: there is a clear knowledge and working of advanced techniques and story being told here! |gt-rewrite8]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I would choose to pack up and leave. I do not want any part of it. If there are already signs of a growing dangerous environment |gt-rewrite9]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Why would we want to live in a stinky crowded village getting sick all the time when we could roam the plains and fill ourselves with wild grain and game |gt-rewrite10]]</li> </ul> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Babylon Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/ziggurat-ur.jpg" alt="ziggurat" width="50%"> <p>It's c. 1700 BCE in Babylon during the reign of Hammurabi. You are a young scribe ... You find yourselves plotting to overthrow the regime and seize power for yourselves. How will you do it? Or will you escape the city and settle somewhere else? What kind of laws or economy or system of government will you create?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li> [[Find a nice place to settle where there are no overwhelming laws and no harsh punishments or forces of payment for smaller things. We also plan on running a farm where we can teach more people how to read and write in exchange for help around the farm. |babylon-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[This retelling will show the people that we do not need to rely on the power of a single man but instead that it is the people themselves that should lead and control each other. |babylon-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[They even went as far as to make sure that the ships that are sailing are protected from any fault. This just shows how important this is to them and really starts to create a sort of civilized population and make their power over the waters even stronger. |babylon-rewrite4]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I would try to leave Babylon and flee to lower Egypt. ... if that failed I would try to learn how to make tools out of bronze in an apprenticeship anything to avoid being a solider. |babylon-rewrite3]]</li> <hr> <li>[[While our beatings are harsh and our teachers strict they are nothing to what those in the army deal with every day. Running is better, we could settle somewhere far from the city and run a better settlement. |babylon-rewrite5]]</li> <li>[[In order to have an actual revolution I would first need to be in a high position in the current political structure, or have friends in high positions in the current political structure or some I would need some kind of military presence... |babylon-rewrite6]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I could write plans of a rebellion and have them posted around the city so others could see. ... I could start teaching at these schools to spread word of the rebellion to my peers. |babylon-rewrite7]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Start the Role Play Game |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: In the Beginning</p> <p><img src="images/pyramids_leonardo-ramos_unsplash.jpg" alt="pyramids" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and secondary sources. <span class="bi">Use the copy button</span> to move this material into Canvas as the foundation of your role play assignment.</p> <p>If you want another look at the sources later, you can also find them in the Source Anthology on Canvas.</p> </div> <div class="row marginalia"> <div class="cite"> <div class="row copynotes" id="copybab"> <<if (def $brse1) and ($brse1 isnot
