$bhe3) and ($bhe3 isnot "")>><p><<print $bhe3>> (Hammurabi)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $bha3) and ($bha3 isnot "")>><p><<print $bha3>> (Hammurabi)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $bhe4) and ($bhe4 isnot "")>><p><<print $bhe4>> (Hammurabi)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $bha4) and ($bha4 isnot "")>><p><<print $bha4>> (Hammurabi)</p> <</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpybab()">Copy text</button> <p>List the sources you used. Use the "copy text" button to place these citations in a "Works Cited" section at the end of your role play response.</p> <div class="copynotes" id="copybabs"> <<if (def $brse1) and ($brse1 isnot "")>><p>“Royal Standard of Ur," British Museum, accessed [date], https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/W_1928-1010-3</p><</if>> <<if (def $bge1) and ($bge1 isnot "")>><p>“Summary: The Epic of Gilgamesh," Cal Poly Humboldt, HIST 104, Instructor: Queen, accessed [date]</p><</if>> <<if (def $bsee1) and ($bsee1 isnot "")>><p>"Papyrus Lansing," ed. William K. Simpson, Cal Poly Humboldt, HIST 104, Instructor: Queen, accessed [date]</p><</if>> <<if (def $bhe1) and ($bhe1 isnot "")>><p>"Code of Hammurabi," in Cal Poly Humboldt, HIST 104, Instructor: Queen, accessed [date]</p><</if>> <<if (def $bsme1) and ($bsme1 isnot "")>><p>Joshua Mark, "A Supervisor's Advice to a Young Scribe," World History Encyclopedia, accessed [date], https://www.worldhistory.org/article/2106/a-supervisors-advice-to-a-young-scribe/</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpybabs()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: In the Beginning</p> <p><img src="images/pyramids_leonardo-ramos_unsplash.jpg" alt="pyramids" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and secondary sources. <span class="bi">Use the copy button</span> to move this material into Canvas as the foundation of your role play assignment.</p> <p>If you want another look at the sources later, you can also find them in the Source Anthology on Canvas.</p> </div> <div class="row marginalia"> <div class="cite"> <div class="row copynotes" id="copygt"> <<if (def $gtgtpe1) and ($gtgtpe1 isnot ($gtrocksa4 isnot "")>><p><<print $gtrocksa4>> ("Stonehenge" or "Pyramids")</p> <</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyGT()">Copy text</button> <p>List the sources you used. Use the "copy text" button to place these citations in a "Works Cited" section at the end of your role play response.</p> <div class="row copynotes" id="copygts"> <<if (def $gtgtpe1) and ($gtgtpe1 isnot "")>><p>“Tepe Telegrams," The Göbekli Tepe Research Project, accessed [date], https://www.dainst.blog/the-tepe-telegrams/tag/t-pillars/</p><</if>> <<if (def $gtmgte1) and ($gtmgte1 isnot "")>><p>"Modeling Göbekli Tepe," World History Encyclopedia, accessed [date]. https://www.worldhistory.org/video/737/modeling-gobekli-tepe/</p><</if>> <<if (def $gtcurrye1) and ($gtcurrye1 isnot "")>><p>Andrew Curry, "Last Stand of the Hunter-Gatherers?" <em>Archaeology Magazine</em>, May/June, 2021, https://archaeology.org/issues/online/collection/turkey-gobekli-tepe-hunter-gatherers/ </p><</if>> <<if (def $gtrockse1) and ($gtrockse1 isnot "")>><p>“Building Stonehenge," English Heritage, accessed [date], https://www.english-heritage.org.uk/visit/places/stonehenge/history-and-stories/building-stonehenge/ </p> <p>“Pyramid Quarry," Ancient Egypt Research Associates, accessed [date], https://aeraweb.org/great-pyramid-quarry/ </p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyGTs()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<set $gtExplore1 to "">> <<set $gtExplore2 to "">> <<set $babylonExplore1 to "">> <<set $babylonExplore2 to "">> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row beginhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>In the Beginning, there was Beer...</h1> <p>So many firsts here: first beer, first wheel, first cities, first texts, first metallurgy, first empire. It begins in Mesopotamia with the Sumerians and Babylonians.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-sumer.jpg" alt="stylized mythological figure wielding weapons" width="80%">' "begin-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> <div class="row scenarios"> <div class="row transbox-arch"> <p>[[Forager at Göbekli Tepe |GT]]</p> <p>[[Scribe at Babylon |Babylon]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div clas="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are besieging the city of Rome</h1> <p>Rome, 215 BCE</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "cannae-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "cannae-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p><em>Note: This role play scenario is set in an alternative version of history. In reality, Hannibal's stunning victory at Cannae (216 BCE) was bootless because he failed to follow up, which enabled the Romans to regroup, rally their supporters, and oust Hannibal by forcing him to return home to defend Carthage. I have re-imagined this bit of history. Instead of post-Cannae paralysis, Hannibal lunges for Rome itself (a bit like Pyrrhus did, the century before). This is the setting for this role play scenario.</em></p> <p>You are a Carthaginian engineer in the army of Hannibal. He has teamed up with Celts in the north and the Numidians in the south. Your army has defeated legion after legion in northern Italy and dirven the Romans back to the city itself. The walls are 30 feet tall and 13 feet thick. You have a leading role in planning and carrying out the siege.</p> <p>You're just an engineer, but as you plan the minutiae of your siege machinery and tactics, you're thinking about the bigger picture of this war too. For instance, there are the Italians. For days, <<linkappend "busily working">><<include cannae-link2>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> amid the excitement and energy of a victorious camp, you've been oppressed by a strong sense that you've forgotten something. Like you forgot to get dressed and you're walking around naked. Or forgot to put away your scrolls and they're blowing away in the wind. And suddenly, while calculating the length of a ballista's main shaft, you looked up and swore out loud. It's the Italians. That's what has been nagging at your mind.</p> <p>So, Hannibal has brilliantly smashed every legion he's met across the peninsula, but the Italians themselves are still out there. Your army killed 50,000 Romans at Cannae last year. But does that mean you've conquered the land? Are the Italians really subdued? <<linkappend "Will they support their ally, Rome? Or will they embrace Hannibal as a liberator?">><<include cannae-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> You force your mind back to the ballista design problem. You spend the rest of the day crafting your engines of death, but your mind keeps returning to this problem of Rome's allies... </p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Ever hear of a Pyrrhic victory? Just before the Punic Wars, a Hellenistic general called Pyrrhus gave the Romans a very hard time indeed (a bit like Hannibal would do soon after Pyrrhus). History remembers Pyrrhus for his victory over the Romans at the Battle of Asculum in 279 BCE. He won, but his losses were so high that the victory was strategic setback. He had to quit and go home. So if someone says, "I got it done, but it was a Pyrrhic victory," they mean that their success was so costly that the whole endeavor was ultimately a failure.</p> <hr> <p>Did you already know all that?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Yep.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Sorry.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "No, it was new.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Awesome. It's fun to pick up new tid-bits.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>When Napoleon Bonaparte rose to power in revolutionary France, he appropriated Roman aesthetics and symbolism. He was a military dictator (the first modern dictator) with absolute power. But, given what had recently befallen the last absolute ruler of France, Napoleon prudently strove to present himself as something different, as a man of the people with a democratic mandate. Like the American founding fathers around the same time, Napoleon turned to Rome for well-known symbols of republican government: eagles, columns, legions, and such, laurel wreaths instead of a crown.</p> <p>One of the most famous portraits of the great Bonaparte makes use of the history of the Second Punic War, when Carthaginian general Hannibal Barca famously crossed the Alps with his army, including war elephants. If you look closely, you can see Hannibal's name scratched into the rocks of this Alpine pass, alongside Charlemagne's and Napoleon's.</p> <p><img src="images/david-napoleon.jpg" alt="Napoleon on horseback pointing" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Jacques Louis David, "Napoleon Crossing the Alps" (1801)</p> <hr> <p>So, what is Charlemagne's name doing on the rocks?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Just for fun, because he was an important French ruler.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>No, in a dictatorship, public spectacle (propaganda) is always more nuanced than that.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "To lay claim to Germany.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>Yep. This might sound crazy, but we're talking about Napoleon here, so crazy is on the table. First, Charlemagne was the first French emperor (Napoleon viewed himself as the new one). Charlemagne founded Carolingian Empire, which became the Holy Roman Empire, which included France <em>and</em> Germany and other odd bits of Europe. Charlemagne's wide imperial rule was sanctioned by the pope after Charlemagne crossed the Alps to save him from a gaggle of raucous barbarians called the Lombards (whom we will meet soon). Napoleon was hoping to do something quite similar ... only <em>bigger</em>.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What kinds of machines will you built to besiege Rome? Why? How will you use them? How do you imagine the Romans will defend their city?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>What do you expect will happen during or after the siege? What will the Italians do? The surviving Romans? What about the successor kingdoms in Greece, Egypt, and the Levant? What about mighty Carthage? Your southern friends in Numidia? The unruly Celts in the North?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Tools, technology, supplies available to you</li> <li>Typical siege machinery, strategies in the Hellenistic period</li> <li>Anticipate some defence moves from the Romans. It would never do to underestimate that crew...</li> <li>The bigger picture of international realtions around the Mediterranean.</li> <li>If Rome falls, what will take its place?</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Livy: Cannae and Zama |punic]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Punic Wars |warry-hellenistic]]</li> <hr> <li>[[A podcast... |bastards]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-c]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are in a coastal Northumbrian village</h1> <p>Northumbria, England, c. 800</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "defence-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "defence-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Icy wind sweeps across the ocean, lifting white caps from the surface of the sea and cutting through your wool sleeves to sting your skin, goading you into a trot as you near the shelter of home.</p> <p>Inside the house, it's smoky and warm. As your eyes adjust to the dim light, you see the others are here already. The big benches lining the table in the center of your long hall are full. You toss your cloak <<linkappend "to a slave">><<include defence-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> and say, “The new dog had trouble moving the ewes and the new thralls are fools. Is everyone here?” Nobody speaks. Since last week’s Danish raid on the neighboring village, you’ve all been on edge, constantly <<linkappend "scanning the horizon,">><<include defence-link3>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> jumping at the sound of a cry. You glance at the heap of blankets in the corner, where a couple of children sit close together, watching you with huge eyes. They were among the few to escape the raid and reach the safety of your village. Their parents were not so fortunate. You called this meeting to make a plan for when the Northmen come. Because they will. Your village is large, <<linkappend "stretching from the docks in the bay to the monastery on the hill.">><<include defence-link2>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> You sit down on the bench in your usual place next to your two oldest sons, and accept a horn of mead from your wife. You nod at your father, old but still strong, at the head of the table. Let him get things started</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Most of the time, Viking defence plans didn't work. Early in the Viking Age, the raiders won, carrying off captives for the slave trade and whatever treasure they could find. And around the tenth century, they started colonizing. Like the ancient Greeks, Vikings were highly successful seafaring colonizers. And like the Greeks, this habit created a wide diaspora of Viking cultural influence, including language change. They didn't always raid. They were traders first and foremost, and that involves communication. So Scandinavian loan words seeped into the langauages of the people they traded with and raided and pushed aside as colonizers. The modern English we speak today bears deep imprints from the Vikings, including the words egg, law, and knife.</p> <hr> <p>Where do you think our English word "slave" comes from?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "From the Latin word <em>servus</em>. Literate people in the Middle Ages wrote in Latin.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>So, that would make all kinds of sense. But Latin <em>servus</em> is not the ancestor of our English word <em>slave.</em> Instead, it comes from the word "Slav," as in the Slavic peoples of Eastern Europe who were the last Europeans to remain pagan, and therefore legally enslavable (since church policy forbad enslavement of fellow Christians).<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link 'From the Old English <em>þeow</em>, meaning "slave."'>><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Well, that's a great guess, since <em>þeow</em> is the most common Old English word for "slave." But it's not related to our modern Englith word <em>slave</em>, which actually comes from "Slav." The Slavic peoples of Eastern Europe were the last Europeans to remain pagan, and therefore legally enslavable (since church policy forbad enslavement of fellow Christians). So "Slav" evolved into our English word <em>slave</em>.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>Many people journeying through the history of the Viking Age (including the Vikings themselves, actually) are interested in the idea of female Viking warriors. One of the most popular characters in the Netflix show <em>Vikings</em> is a woman warrior (image below). How realistic is that?</p> <p><img src="images/viking-netflix.jpg" alt="woman warrior standing on battlefield" width="80%"></p> <p>Historians mostly (but far from unanimously) agree that there were no female Viking warriors. We base our knowledge of history on observable evidence and logic. We ask, "Based on the observable evidence as we currently have it, what is the <em>most probable</em> answer to this question?" And when we ask it that way, the answer is clearly, "No, there were no female Viking warriors as depicted in modern fictional accounts." Were women in Viking society capable of combat, and somewhat competent with weapons? That seems highly likely. Did they live the life of a Viking warrior as the men did? No. We say no because there is no evidence of such a thing. The Vikings wrote a lot about their Viking activities. They never mention a female warrior. They do frequently mention the idea of mythical and legendary female warriors (like valkyries). (Here's <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dEfdgeCWztW4hsu5U19ccV1tGocQr4Gu/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">an excellent scholarly article</a> about the textual evidence, if you're interested.) They were attracted by the idea of female warriors, just as we are today. But they never mention a real one.</p> <p>Nobody writing in the early Middle Ages mentions a real female Viking. It's the kind of thing the Vikings themselves probably would have mentioned, based on their interest in valkyries. It's the kind of thing their Christian haters would have mentioned, based on their zeal for demonizing Vikings (to a monkish chronicler, women fighting as men would be a excellent evidence of the Vikings' pagan depravity). Because of this lack of evidence, historians (mostly) give a negative answer to this question of Viking warrior women. But ... that could change, right? New evidence is discovered all the time. We'll see what the future holds.</p> <p>So, what about <a href="https://www.bbc.com/reel/video/p099hyk0/the-viking-warrior-who-turned-out-to-be-a-woman" target="_blank">the Viking Age Birka grave</a> in Sweden? In which female remains were found in a grave containing the burial goods of a warrior (sword, axe, horse, etc.)? <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1FXZFpu1AngrN8SU1esKVQPyqv6SDgppd/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Some leading archaeologists</a> interpret this burial as evidence that Viking warrior women did exist, as represented in the Netflix show. However, others point to numerous problems with this interpretation (for instance, the sad fact that the Victorian Era archaeologists who collected the remains and mapped the site did a very shoddy job of it, so that there's no way to know if those female bones were truly buried in a "warrior grave." (If you're interested, <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-1saIebK6NxfJWDe5WeJEB-64D3stB6g/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">here's an excellent recent article</a> about this very active and impassioned academic debate.) There are lots of Viking Age warrior graves containing male bones. The one exception at the Birka site may not really be an exception. (And there are <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ukl-8zLfnAW4B-XfgjcxCeK0mgLWsCGZ/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">intersex people buried with warrior goods</a> in early medieval Finland graves.) There's also the problem of cremation: Vikings often burned their dead rather than burying them, so it's possible that Viking women warriors were cremated instead of buried. But with no written evidence in favor, and the vast majority of the archaeological evidence against, it is reasonable to conclude that Viking warrior women are fictional. But not everyone agrees.</p> <p><img src="images/maud-valkyries.jpg" alt="valkyries riding horses in clouds" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Vikings, Victorians, and Netflix have all enjoyed the idea of Viking warrior women. Here's an exmple of the trend from 1890 England: "The Ride of the Valkyries" by William T. Maud.</p> <hr> <p>What's your opinion? Do you think there were Viking warrior women?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "No.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>This is also my interpretation of the evidence. There are people who disagree.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Absolutely.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>Many people agree with you! The evidence does not fully disprove this, so it's a possibility.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt:</span> Describe the plans you come up with. How will you defend yourselves from the raid you know is coming?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your family's socioeconomic and political status in the village</li> <li>Your skills, resources, tools</li> <li>The political structure of your community (such as its relationship with the monastery or the royal government</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[A Viking raid |dudo]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Battle of Maldon |maldon]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Arms and armor at the Battle of Maldon |brooks]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Slave Raiding and Slave Trading |slave-raiding]]</li> <hr> <li>[[A Most Vile People |vile]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-d]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Age Portal |Viking]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are Eleanor of Aquitaine</h1> <p>France, c. 1170</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "el-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "el-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p><em>Note: In reimagining the historical figures in this role play scenario, I have altered the dates a bit. They all lived in the twelfth century, and were active in France and Germany during Twelfth Century Renaissance. However, the their careers did not intertwine as much as this (fictional!) role play scenario suggests. Just FYI. Here are the real dates:</em></p> <ul> <li>Eleanor of Aquitaine: 1122 - 1204</li> <li>Hildegard von Bingen: 1098 - 1179</li> <li>Bernard of Clairvaux: 1090 - 1153</li> <li>Heloise: 1092 - 1163</li> </ul> <p>And now, back to the role play scenario.</p> <p>Sweet music swells around you, rolling off the massive, vaulted ceiling and lifting you toward heaven. You close your eyes and let the tears flow as your soul mingles with God and his saints and eternity. When you're aware of reality again, the voices are gone, replaced by the soft scuffle of many feet on stone as the nuns move on to the next task in their busy day. You open your eyes to a hundred colors of light streaming through the stained glass. For the thousandth time, you thank God for leading you here. And for sending Hildegard to earth: You must write to her again and thank her for sending <<linkappend "her newest composition.">><<include el-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>Your mouth curls into a wry smirk as you compare Hildegard's magic with the thin, discordant cacophony of King Louis’ court musicians. His royal halls were cramped and cold, stinking and crowded with ignorant fools - the knights with nothing to say but horses and dogs and killing. You and your ladies lost yourselves in song and story, in the world of King Arthur long ago, of Merlin and fairies and magic. A deluge of gold flowed from your hands into the purses of the minstrels and clerics who wrote and sang the songs. When you left the royal court at Paris and returned home to Poitiers, the best troubadours came too, following the flow of gold. For many, it was a homecoming. Since the days of your grandfather, Duke William X, Aquitaine has been a haven for troubadours and jongleurs and every wayward cleric bored with university life.</p> <p>You once heard a bastard son of your lover, Henry Plantagenet, decline a pre-packaged, high-status career in the church: “I prefer horses and dogs to books and priests.” The meat-headed fool. When they finally annulled your marriage to Louis, you broke free from men like Henry and his bastard. They tried to steal you back as you fled from Paris and marriage and queenship, homeward toward Poitiers. You rode dressed as a man but they still found you out ... it was close.</p> <p>From the safety of your mighty castle of Poitiers, surrounded by walls 15 feet thick and your own garrison, you wrote to Pope Eugenius: “I prefer books and priests to horses and dogs.” He let you establish a new monastic order. After all, you are the richest woman in Europe, with more land, castles, and knights than the king of France (your ex husband), and his arch-rival Duke Henry Plantagenet (one of your ex lovers) combined. You brought this vast inheritance to the Church as your dowry. The pope fell all over himself setting his seal to your new order’s charter as fast as he could, and he’s let you do as you please ever since.</p> <p>Deep in thought, you move slowly through the cavernous space toward the scriptorium. You need to write a letter. Pope Eugene has asked Bernard of Clairvaux to call for a Third Crusade. You remember his sermon a decade ago when, at the pope's behest, Bernard preached at Vézelay, calling for the Second Crusade. The crowd went mad, roaring "Deus vult!" and even the soft eyes of <<linkappend "your husband, King Louis, blazed with maniacal fervor.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include el-link2>><</linkappend>> Bernard's success had come at a cost though, when the crusade's failure blackened his reputation. And now the pope wants him to do it again, and Bernard has written to you to ask your advice. You know he's probably written to Hildegard too. You're genuinely curious about what she will say.</p> <p>You exit the shadowy cloister arch and cross a sunny courtyard dappled with sunlight and shadow, alive with birdsong. You need to find Heloise, <<linkappend "whose learning far exceeds your own.">><<include el-link3>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> She’s renowned for the depth of her knowledge, her rhetorical genius, and her mastery of dialectical logic. Her correspondence Abelard keeps her in practice. Heloise will be able to help you build your argument in the erudite, scholastic style Bernard will respect. Now, if you could only find her... </p> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>What does "chivalry" mean?</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <hr> <p>The Victorians absolutely loved the Middle Ages. They built in the gothic style that was becoming popular during Eleanor of Aquitaine's life. Probably the most famous example of this 19th-century gothic revival are the Houses of Parliament in London:</p> <p><img src="images/parliament.jpg" alt="houses of parliament" width="50%"></p> <p>They even <em>re</em>built old churches in the gothic style, whether the church was from that period or not (unfortunately erasing much fine romanesque and Anglo-Saxon architecture in their anachronistic zeal). As the children of Romanticism, Victorians were inclined to feel nostalgic for the simpler and more honest times of the Middle Ages, when (they imagined) people lived in harmony with nature and felt genuine passion for God (in contrast to their urbanizing, industrializing, machine-driven world). Victorian authors like Tennyson and Scott revived the old legends of King Arthur and his knights of Camelot. Artists of the Preraphaelite school did the same. Here are some notable (and splendid) examples.</p> <p>Waterhouse, "The Lady of Shalott" (1888)</p> <p><img src="images/waterhouse-shallot.jpg" alt="woman in a boat" width="50%"></p> <p>Draper, "Guinevere and Lancelot" (1895)</p> <p><img src="images/draper-guen.jpg" alt="women on a dias surrounded by flowers" width="50%"></p> <p>Dicksee, "La Belle Dame sans Merci" (c. 1900)</p> <p><img src="images/dicksee-dame.jpg" alt="woman rides warhorse as knight in full armor walks beside her" width="50%"></p> <p>Leighton, "God Speed" (1900)</p> <p><img src="images/leighton-godspeed.jpg" alt="woman addresses mounted knight" width="50%"></p> <p>Leighton, "The Accolade" (1901)</p> <p><img src="images/leighton-acolade.jpg" alt="woman dubs kneeling knight with sword" width="50%"></p> <hr> <p>Was there a "real" King Arthur?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Um ... that's a terrible question?">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Quite so. There was a real guy in fifth-century post-Roman England who did things like unite British resistance to Germanic invasion. His story later ossified as legend and then permutated into more legends. Was that guy "King Arthur?" There may be no valid answer that exact question.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Nah.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>Well, sort of... but there's more to it than a blanket negative. We'd miss quite a lot of interesting historical inquiry if we just go with a simple "no" here (though you're forgiven if you think that's not such a bad thing...).<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What is your monastic order like? What are its goals? What are some of its rules? How might your passion for chilvalric romance and the legends of King Arthur influence your monastic order's interpretation of Christianity and the monastic vocation, especially the role of women?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>What is your advice to Bernard of Clairvaux regarding a prospective third crusade? What are the results?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your sense of identity, both as an aristocrat and as a woman</li> <li>Your experience of life at court, in marriage, and on crusade</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The pope calls for crusade |crusade]]</li> <li>[[Codex Manesse |manesse]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Women and courtly romance |romance]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Living like a nun |nuns]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-e]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights Portal |Knights]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<set $Score to 0>> <<set $sword to false>> <<set $book to false>> <<set $bow to false>> <<set $chalice to false>> <<set $gold to false>> <<set $helmet to false>> <<set $lance to false>> <<set $lyre to false>> <<set $potion to false>> <<set $ring to false>> <<set $shield to false>> <<set $treasure to false>> <<set $armor to false>> <<set $horse to false>> <<set $beginCombat1 to "">> <<set $ironCombat1 to "">> <<set $greeceCombat1 to "">> <<set $hellenisticCombat1 to "">> <<set $rome1Combat1 to "">> <<set $rome2Combat1 to "">> <<set $vikingCombat1 to "">> <<set $knightsCombat1 to "">> <<set $peasantsCombat1 to "">> <<set $renCombat1 to "">> <<if $Password is "Beowulf">> <div class="container"> <div class="row starthero"> <div class="title-sub"> <h1>Welcome, Time Traveler!</h1> <p>Venture into the past. Make some history.</p> <p>To begin your role play adventure, enter into the text box below the "Player Name" you would like to use on this journey:</p><<textbox "$PlayerName" "" "Portals">> </div> </div> <hr> <p>If you're already done with this week's role play assignment, open [[Our History Rewrite]] to explore the new history you and your comrades have created. This is where it gets really fun... </p> </div> <<else>> <p>The password is incorrect. [[Go back. |Password]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a forester in the Black Forest</h1> <p>Swabia, in the Holy Roman Empire, c. 1100</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "for-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "for-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p>You wade through shadows, deep in the oldest part of the forest. Folk say this is where demons live, and giants, and wild men. Dapples of golden sunlight slide over you. Your are silent and slow, pausing often to listen. The cadence of your movements is that of a deer: step, pause, a few more steps, pause. It’s a pattern of sound that raises no fear in an animal who hears it. With the wind in your face, you could stalk nearly within arms length of a great antlered stag this way. But you’re not hunting now. You are going to check a wolf trap. You take in the sound and feel and light of the forest only with the surface of your mind. Most of your thoughts wrestle and with a problem, like a mastiff worrying a meaty bone, turning it this way and that. You’re crafting a plan, considering contingencies, weighing possibilities and fallbacks and timing and catastrophes.</p> <p>You have decided to kill <<linkappend "the margrave.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include for-link1>><</linkappend>> A lifetime in the forest has taught you the necessity of planning ahead and being prepared. And the wisdom of waiting. Like all wild things, you wait well. Your father saw to that, raising you as a forester from your earliest days, just as his father had taught him, and his father before him, in a line back into the mists of legend. You know every tree and rookery, every wolf pack and every bear. The forest may belong to the margrave today, <<linkappend "but it will always belong to you and yours.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include for-link4>><</linkappend>></p> <p>Sunlight illuminates a glade ahead. In the middle distance, your eyes pick out a straight, horizontal line, stark against the soft blending and twining of the forest shapes. It’s a thin flax cord you strung tight between two linden trees last week, and you're pleased to see it <<linkappend "still in place.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include for-link2>><</linkappend>> You duck under it carefully and look for the second, heavier rope that crosses the narrow game path up ahead. It’s not there, and you see a splash of blood, sticky and dark on the ferns. You stoop to feel it. You brush your fingers over the deep divots clawed into the earth of the trail. Wolf. You grin for a heartbeat before fear washes over you. You touch the amulet hanging around your neck - a ring and a satchet of holy objects, blessed by the old hermit outside your village. You stand up and shift your spear into position and give a low whistle. Your wolfhound appears at your side, almost silently. She follows close at your side as you step forward slowly, following the drops and splashes of blood. The pattern tells you the wolf is probably dead. Still, every nerve is strung tight, every sound makes you tense, but you relax when you see a patch of dark grey under a spray of fern. Your dog gives a low growl, but then relaxes. The wolf is dead.</p> <p>It's a big wolf, taller than your belt. Cold, but not yet stiff. You set to work, deftly stripping the pelt and folding it into a bundle. Fleas and ticks have moved from the skin - no longer warm with blood - to the surface of the fur. You ignore them. You need the pelt to show the margrave … <em>the margrave for now, anyway</em>. And the village will want to see the pelt too. You keep the forest safe from villagers, and you keep the village safe from the forest. You are the <em>luparius</em>, <<linkappend "the wolf hunter.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include for-link3>><</linkappend>> They say it was the great emperor Charlemagne who appointed your great, great, great grandfather as the first <em>luparii</em>. Since then, your family has kept this forest and hunted the wolves and brought their pelts to the emperor or his margrave.</p> <p>You look back at your dog, seeing again her resemblance to her grandfather, old Boar Bane. A few months ago, Boar Bane was gored to death by a boar the size of a bear, and it was the Margrave's doing. Boar Bane died in glory, the boar's blood in his jaws, as a good dog should. But your eyes sting and your neck burns as you remember. He was your friend and your father's friend, loyal through a dozen deadly encounters, and you burn for vengeance. Rage fills you as you remember how you told the margrave's huntsmen to leave that boar alone. Told them over and over. Told them the time wasn't right, that the margrave's dogs and retinue were young and untried. You remember how the margrave looked down from his horse, looked right <em>through</em> you as if you weren't there at all, spoke right over you and ordered the chase. Old Boar Bane paid the price.</p> <p>The priest and his friends at the monastery tell you that this margrave has chosen an anti-king to depose your emperor. The priest and monks don’t like the margrave or the anti-king (or the pope, you gather). They told you the margrave is a traitor who wants to make war on the emperor. But you’ve heard others at market day saying that the emperor is excommunicated, and we owe him no allegiance. That his bishops and monks are powerless to perform the sacraments. You think of your wife. She will have another child soon. What if she dies? Or the child dies? Will they be trapped forever in the cold nothing of purgatory because the priest can't bury them in the churchyard and say the blessing? It doesn't make sense. The priest and the monks say they can still give communion to the living and bless the dead. Those folk at the market say they can't. You don't understand it. But you do understand that the margrave is a traitor to the emperor. Maybe killing him will help, and avenge Boar Bane.</p> <p>Making your slow return home with the fresh wolf pelt tied in a bundle on your back, and Boar Bane's granddaughter at your heels, your mind returns to its planning. The margrave will hunt here soon. You will attend the hunt, telling the huntsmen where to find what they want - fox, bear, boar, wolves, deer. How will you make sure the margrave doesn’t survive the day’s sport? And make sure you are never suspected?</p> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Medieval people enjoyed a rich world of forest legends. Today, their stories continue to enthrall us (and to enrich film producers and streaming services). They told of werewolves and witches, wild men ("wodewose") and green men and outlaws like Robin Hood.</p> <p><img src="images/greenmen.jpg" alt="carvings of foliar heads" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: The "green man" motif (thematically linked to the medieval "wild man" or "wodewose") appears frequently in ornamental woodwork crafted by peasant artisans. These "buttons" on English cathedral vaulting and misericords from the pews are medieval examples.</p> <p>There were legends of a "wild hunt," that told of a supernatural hunter or hunting party pursuing human quarry (often a woman) through the forest. A twelfth-century entry from the <em>Anglo-Saxon Chronicle</em> reports that, "many men both saw and heard a great number of huntsmen hunting. The huntsmen were black, huge, and hideous, and rode on black horses and on black he-goats, and their hounds were jet black, with eyes like saucers." Among other things, the "wild hunt" motif probably encapsulates peasants' feelings about the aristocratic hunters who marauded through the forests on a regular basis, heavily armed and thuggish. (The nobility had their own constellation of forest folklore, involving things like faeries and dragons and unicorns.)</p> <p><img src="images/unicorn.jpg" alt="woman with lion and unicorn" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: This scene from the famous unicorn tapestries (Paris, c. 1500) reflects aristocratic ideas about forest magic and legend.</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <hr> <p>If you're enjoying this time travel journey through marvelous and magical world of medieval forest legend, you have plenty of company (like me). Many have traveled this path before us, and shaped the woodland vista we're enjoying right now. Fairy tales like Hansel and Gretel, Red Ridinghood, or Beauty and the Beast heavily influence what we're seeing here. The first people to commit these oral traditional narratives to writing as "fairy tales" were Madame d'Aulnoy and Charles Perrault in 17th-century France, and the Grimm Brothers in early 19th-century Germany. In each case, these writers took an active role in shaping the stories for their own purposes. More recently, Disney and Pixar have taken their turn, making the stories palatable to 20th- and 21st-century consumers, and profitable for themselves.</p> <p><img src="images/fairy-tale-movies.jpg" alt="movie covers" width="80%"></p> <p>But we are historians here! Have these fellow travelers ruined the view for us? Are our attitudes to the fairy tales so hopelessly muddled by all these previous re-tellings that the stories have no value to us as historians? When we look at actual medieval sources, we find very strong parallels with the fairy tales motifs. It's clear that they preserve elements of medieval folklore. But how can we find those medieval elements amid the untidy jumble of additions made by antiquarians and entertainers in the modern era? Should we even try? Well, that depends on who you ask.</p> <hr> <p>What do you think? Do the European fairy tales have value as primary sources about medieval history?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "No way. They are far too compromised, and we have other, more legitimate primary sources from the actual Middle Ages. We should rely on those instead.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>This is probably correct (although not everyone agrees). The fairy tales, as we have them today, do contain elements of medieval folklore and reflect peasant beliefs and lifestyles. <em>However,</em> the earliest texts we have are from the later seventeenth century. The Middle Ages properly ends c. 1500. If our texts were oral traditional poetry, like Homer's <em>Iliad</em> and <em>Odyssey</em>, or Germanic verse like <em>Beowulf</em> or skaldic poetry, that wouldn't be much of a problem, because the tectonics of oral traditional poetics are designed to resist change over time. Those complex systems of meter and aural effect work to preserve pre-textual literature intact over long periods of time. <em>Beowulf</em> survives only in a single 11th-century manuscript, but its linguistic features reflect a far earlier idiom of English, and for that and various other reasons, most scholars view it as a copy of an earlier, 8th-century poem. Thanks to methodologies developed by historical linguists and anthropologists and literary scholars of oral traditional poetics, we have the tools to use complex, composite texts like this judiciously and fruitfully. But these fairy tales are just simple prose. Nothing to preserve their content from significant permutations over the centuries. So I think you are right here: They are not very valuable (if at all) as primary sources about the Middle Ages, even though they clearly do reflect some commonplaces of medieval life and belief systems (like forests are dangerous and wolves are scary and nobody likes stepmothers).<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Yes, please!">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">><hr>While some scholars feel the same, the consensus among historians is more in the opposite direction: We cannot use the fairy tales as primary sources about medieval history. The fairy tales, as we have them today, do contain elements of medieval folklore and reflect peasant beliefs and lifestyles. <em>However,</em> the earliest texts we have are from the later seventeenth century. They change a good deal over time. The Middle Ages properly ends c. 1500, so texts from the late 17th century, 18th, and early 19th century can't tell us much (reliably) about medieval people. If these texts were oral traditional poetry, like Homer's <em>Iliad</em> and <em>Odyssey</em>, or Germanic verse like <em>Beowulf</em> or skaldic poetry, that wouldn't be much of a problem, because the tectonics of oral traditional poetics are designed to resist change over time. Those complex systems of meter and aural effect work to preserve pre-textual literature intact over long periods of time. <em>Beowulf</em> survives only in a single 11th-century manuscript, but its linguistic features reflect a far earlier idiom of English, and for that and various other reasons, most scholars view it as a copy of an earlier, 8th-century poem. Thanks to methodologies developed by historical linguists and anthropologists and literary scholars of oral traditional poetics, we have the tools to use complex, composite texts like this judiciously and fruitfully. But these fairy tales are just simple prose. Nothing to preserve their content from significant permutations over the centuries. So I think you are right here: They are not very valuable (if at all) as primary sources about the Middle Ages, even though they clearly do reflect some commonplaces of medieval life and belief systems (like forests are dangerous and wolves are scary and nobody likes stepmothers). If we did try to use them this way, our yield would be thin and unstable and poor quality. Sadly. Now, if we use the fairy tales to tell us about Renaissance and Early Modern periods, that's a whole different question, with a much more positive answer!<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What is your plan for killing this guy?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>What are the results of your choices? For you, for your community, or for the broader sweep of history?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your experience with the margrave</li> <li>Your experience with local church leadership</li> <li>Your family situation and economic status</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Books of the Hunt |ms-hunts]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Hunting "accidents" |hunt-death]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Sir Gawain and the Green Knight |gawain]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About hunting in the Middle Ages |orme]]</li> <hr> <li>[[About peasants, poaching, and foresters in early medieval Europe |goldberg]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-f]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a forager at Gobekli Tepe</h1> <p>Anatolia, c. 11,000 BCE</p> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "gt-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "gt-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row scenario"> <p>It's almost springtime in the hills of Anatolia when your migratory forager clan happens upon an interesting community. They have a permanent settlement with walls and homes and irrigated gardens. They have beer!</p> <p>They seem very busy with their livestock and crops and buildings. There's just so much <span class="em">stuff.</span> Junk everywhere. It all looks exhausting. And when they do have free time, they like to spend it working on an <<linkappend "insanely huge thing.">><<include gt-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> Massive walls and pillars, carved and painted with animals and human figures. You've never seen <<linkappend "anything like this.">><<include gt-link2>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>Over the next few days, other forager groups like your own start drifting into the area. They work together on the building project. Everyone seems to have a job - making ropes, preparing food, carrying rock, fetching water and firewood, carving stone, repairing tools, digging ditches. There's a powerful energy you enjoy, but also, people get bossy, pointing and commanding. Fights break out. Your group is invited to form a team and work on transporting the big stones. That evening, your band gathers around a fire and considers this decision. When it's your turn to speak, what will you say?</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Ever heard something (or someone) described as "antediluvian?" You probably already know that it means something very, very old, from the time before the Great Flood (as in, Noah's Ark): ante ("before") + deluvian ("the deluge"). It's an interesting bit of vocabulary to have floating around in the twenty-first century, a remnant of the fear and awe Bronze Age Mesopotamians felt for the power of the great rivers. The story of a great flood survives in Mesopotamian texts predating the Bible, like the Sumerian <em>Enuma Elish</em> and <em>Epic of Gilgamesh</em>.</p> <hr> <p>Later in history, in the Middle Ages, people developed elaborate theories about the beings destroyed by the Great Flood of the Bible. Sometimes, they imagined races of giants and fantastical creatures whose traces (and even descendants, sometimes) could still be found in remote corners of the landscape. It's basically what folks do today in:</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Ancient Aliens">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#zrespA">>And Joe Rogan interviews.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "The History Department">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Ha ha. No, we don't.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <hr> <p>In the Middle Ages, people wondered about Stonehenge: Who built it? Why? Sometimes, they imagined explanations. In some medieval stories about King Arthur and his knights, the wizard Merlin built Stonehenge as a memorial for a battle in the Britons' war with the Saxon invaders. Merlin used his magic to transport the stones from Ireland, and a friendly giant set them in place. Basically the same as <em>Ancient Aliens</em>.</p> <p><img src="images/stonehenge-wace.jpg" alt="manuscript illlustration of giant building stonehenge" width="50%"></p> <p>Here's a construction scene from a 14th-century manuscript (from <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/image/10486/merlin-constructs-stonehenge-roman-de-brut/" target="blank">World History Encyclopedia</a></p> <hr> <p>In a thousand years, if humans haven't blown up the Earth, do you think people will imagine that aliens built our twenty-first-century western civilization?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Probably. History repeats itself?.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#trespA">>Good guess. This trend of finding traces of ancient civilizations and feeling compelled to explain them is definitely not unique to our own age. Our ancestors seem to have been just as keen on this, so why not our descendants as well?<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "No. Our digital records will survive eternally, so future historians will understand everything about our lives.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#trespB">>Right. And they'll be totally accurate, too...<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>Do you want to stay and get involved because this is kind of amazing (plus, the beer)? Or do you want to pack up and head for the hills because following orders and doing manual labor is just not your style. Analyze the factors that determine your choice. What fears, desires, relationships, realities motivated you?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>Your group agrees with you and follows your advice. Predict some short term and long term outcomes of this choice for you as an individual, and for your community.</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li> Your gender, age, relationships, family situation </li> <li> Your skills, talents, strengths or disabilities </li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The pillars of Gobekli Tepe |Pillars]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[A model of Gobekli Tepe |GT Model]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Foragers and agriculturalists at Gobekli Tepe |GT Curry]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Building monoliths and pyramids |Rocks]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-gt]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Curry, "Göbekli Tepe: Last Stand of the Hunter-Gatherers?"</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Read this fascinating article about various recent theories on who built Göbekli Tepe and why: <a href="https://archaeology.org/issues/online/collection/turkey-gobekli-tepe-hunter-gatherers/" target="_blank">Archaeology Magazine.</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>What do archaeologists and historians know - and not know - about the construction and uess of Göbekli Tepe?</li> <li>What might this site have meant to different groups and individuals.</li> <li>The challenges of interpreting evidence about neolithic history</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtcurrye1" `$gt-currye1 ??
