You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-gt]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> <li>[[Back: Göbekli Tepe Scenario |GT]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>A model of Göbekli Tepe</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secpndary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>View this <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/video/737/modeling-gobekli-tepe/" target="_blank">video about the Göbekli Tepe site </a>from National Geographic.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>What it would have been like to live here or participate in the construction process</li> <li>What kinds of tools and technology were used</li> <li>Challenges and opportunities people would have encountered here</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtmgte1" `$gtmgte1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtmgta1" `$gtmgta1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtmgte2" `$gtmgte2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtmgta2" `$gtmgta2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtmgte3" `$gtmgte3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtmgta3" `$gtmgta3 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtmgte4" `$gtmgte4 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtmgta4" `$gtmgta4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h3>Primary Sources</h3> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The pillars of Gobekli Tepe |Pillars]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h3>Secondary Sources</h3> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[A model of Gobekli Tepe |GT Model]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Foragers and agriculturalists at Gobekli Tepe |GT Curry]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Building monoliths and pyramids |Rocks]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-gt]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> <li>[[Back: Göbekli Tepe Scenario |GT]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Epic of Gilgamesh</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>This is the earliest surviving work of literature. Written c. 2200 BCE in ancient Sumer, the epic poem follows the exploits of Gilgamesh, king of Uruk. Here is a brief summary: <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/e/2PACX-1vRba8D3UWfdCFzYcEGs4bHNqLyVVo5aKCok5oQofGqNR6zYX4uN402AgSA9_8mR5a4qJr5kWYgpeemf/pub" target="_blank">The Epic of Gilgamesh</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Material culture (i.e. technology, tools, materials that define everyday life)</li> <li>Political structure and ideology, especially ideals of justice and kingship</li> <li>Attitudes toward gods and nature</li> <li>Cultural norms relating to friendship and good behavior</li> <li>Beliefs and practices relating to gender and sexuality</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas.</p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bge1" `$bge1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bga1" `$bga1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bge2" `$bge2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bga2" `$bga2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bge3" `$bge3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bga3" `$bga3 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bge4" `$bge4 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bga4" `$bga4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The Royal Standard of Ur (c. 2500 BCE) |royal-standard]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Epic of Gilgamesh (c. 2200 BCE) |Gilgamesh]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Advice to a Scribe (c. 1880 BCE) |scribe-egypt]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Code of Hammurabi (c. 1790 BCE) |Hammurabi]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[A Scribe's Life |scribe-meso]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class notes.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-b]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> <li>[[Back: Babylon Scenario |Babylon]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<set $helotExplore1 to "">> <<set $helotExplore2 to "">> <<set $periclesExplore1 to "">> <<set $periclesExplore2 to "">> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row greecehero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Ancient Greece: Hoplite & Polis</h1> <p>Turning from Mesopotamia, we lauch out west across "the wine-dark sea", as Homer calls it. Arriving on the shores of Ancient Greece, we find ourselves surrounded by wonders: fabulous creatures like centaurs, legendary heroes like Achilles and Hector, the crafty and cantankerous Olympian gods, and ranks of hoplite warriors. The struggles between the superpowers of the ancient Greek world echo quite uncannily the global conflicts of our own twenty and twenty-first centuries: diplomatic failures, incompatible enemies, strained truces, impossibly complex alliances, the influence of popular opinion on the tides of war ... blood, in short, is what this week is all about.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/greek-combat.jpg" alt="black figure pottery illustration of ancient Greek warriors fighting with shield and spear" width="80%">' "greece-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> <div class="row scenarios"> <div class="row transbox-arch"> <p class="big">[[A rebel slave in Sparta |Helot]]</p> <p class="big">[[Pericles in Athens |Pericles]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: Ancient Greece</p> <p><img src="images/greece1.jpg" alt="warriors with spear and shield" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. $periclesnte3) and ($periclesnte3 isnot "")>><p><<print $periclesnte3>> (Nichols, <em>Thucydides</em>)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $periclesnta3) and ($periclesnta3 isnot "")>><p><<print $periclesnta3>> (Nichols, <em>Thucydides</em>)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $periclesnte4) and ($periclesnte4 isnot "")>><p><<print $periclesnte4>> (Nichols, <em>Thucydides</em>)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $periclesnta4) and ($periclesnta4 isnot "")>><p><<print $periclesnta4>> (Nichols, <em>Thucydides</em>)</p> <</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyPer()">Copy text</button> <p>List the sources you used. Use the "copy text" button to place these citations in a "Works Cited" section at the end of your role play response.</p> <div class="copynotes" id="copypericless"> <<if (def $pericleslyse1) and ($pericleslyse1 isnot "")>><p>Aristophanes, <em>Lysistrata</em>, in Perry, <em>Sources of the Western Tradition, Volume 1: from Ancient Times to the Enlightenment, Eighth Edition</em> (Boston: Wadsworth, 201</p><</if>> <<if (def $periclessoce1) and ($gtmgte1 isnot "")>> <p>Plato, <em>Apology</em>, transl. Walter Hamilton, in Bernard Knox, ed., <em>The Norton Book of Classical Literature</em> (New York: Norton, 1993)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $periclesfoe1) and ($periclesfoe1 isnot "")>><p>Thucydides, <em>History of the Peloponnesian War,</em> transl. R. Crawley, Internet Classics Archive, https://classics.mit.edu/Thucydides/pelopwar.2.second.html, accessed [date] </p><</if>> <<if (def $pericleswe1) and ($pericleswe1 isnot "")>><p>John Warry, <em>Warfare in the Classical World</em> (Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 2002)</p><</if>> <<if (def $periclesnte1) and ($periclesnte1 isnot "")>><p>Mary Nichols, <em>Thucydides and the Pursuit of Freedom</em> (New York: Cornell University Press, 2015)</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyPers()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Code of Hammurabi</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Hammurabi's law code, inscribed on a stele, is the oldest surviving law code. Hammurabi ruled his Amorite empire from Babylon c. 1792 - 1750. Open <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/e/2PACX-1vTuZm-Reo1EN6LYvA6S7p7FuGcWWcvby8POklVHllYDrTUcqNZQZ3u1sHezR49KfxjobmfzhBQq9kcU/pub" target="_blank">Hammurabi's Code</a> here.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Sources of conflict and methods of conflict resolution</li> <li>Material culture, technology, and economy</li> <li> <li>Ideas of justice and political ideology</li> <li>Family structure and gender norms</li> <li>Symbols of social status or hierarchy</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bhe1" `$bhe1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bha1" `$bha1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bhe2" `$bhe2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bha2" `$bha2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bhe3" `$bhe3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bha3" `$bha3 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bhe4" `$bhe4 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bha4" `$bha4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The Royal Standard of Ur (c. 2500 BCE) |royal-standard]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Epic of Gilgamesh (c. 2200 BCE) |Gilgamesh]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Advice to a Scribe (c. 1880 BCE) |scribe-egypt]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Code of Hammurabi (c. 1790 BCE) |Hammurabi]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[A Scribe's Life |scribe-meso]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class notes.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-b]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> <li>[[Back: Babylon Scenario |Babylon]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are King Harold Godwinson</h1> <p>England, c. 1066</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "defence-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "defence-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p>It is September 30, 1066. You stand very still, at the very end of the labyrinth of tunnels under <<linkappend "York Minster.">><<include hastings-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>In the small, dark room, treasure is heaped and coiled like a dragon, higher than your head: curving torques and hack silver and coin, ring mail and swords and helmets, all seeming to heave and move in the torchlight. It took twelve men to carry the gold bar at the bottom of the heap. Harald had brought it with him his days leading the <<linkappend "Verangian guard in Byzantium.">><<include hastings-link2>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> You can’t take your eyes off the shining metal. It’s not greed. You <em>have</em> money. You’re always the richest man in any group (kings not excepted). It was a long, long time ago when you stopped caring if people called you greedy or ambitious or selfish. You genuinely have no idea what it feels like to give a shit. Money is so fucking boring. But this isn’t money. This is power. This metal is <em>alive</em>, as if <<linkappend "the treasure had become the man himself,">><<include hastings-link3>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> as if the ghost of Harald Hardrada had risen from the mead benches of Valhalla to stand before you and stare you in the face - and you can’t look away.</p> <p>You clench your eyes shut and it hurts. You need to get some sleep. You let a long, slow expletive roll through your mind. Should you ask Harald what to do? Ha ha! What the hell. You open your eyes and find they're still fixed on the glowing, pulsing hoard. You speak to it: “Harald, I just wrecked you. Hard. And that Irish king too. And my worthless fucking brother, may he rot in Hell forever. I wish I could do it again right now. So, why aren’t you dead? Why are you still here? The skalds were singing about you in the camp just now. I heard them on my way. You're alive. Your gold should be alive like you. It should be up there in camp too, lighting up the night like your name, making men laugh and fight … and forget. But I locked it up here in the dark with the dead. And here it stays, because the Bastard has landed. They just told me. He's at Hastings. There is no time for gold-giving, for the breaking of rings.</p> <p>We have to march south. Now. Yesterday. Again. We just did this, like <em>just now</em> raced here 300 miles from London to wreck your shit. The Bastard will have dug in by now: motte and bailey, burning and raiding, scouting, planning, <em>always</em> with the fucking planning - endless contingencies in twisted perfection like the inlay on my sword hilt. He’s good. You know, <<linkappend "I was with him in Brittany a few years ago.">><<include hastings-link4>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> Raiding and hunting. My dogs are better, but he was good. Household knights, feudal levies, mercenaries, cavalry and archers, perfect timing, total control. And he’s here now. He's after my crown. What will I do, old man? Tell me, what will I do?”</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>The Norman Conquest of 1066 is when all of the lovely French enters our incredibly rich English language. For instance, it's why we say "cow" in the field (where the English peasants used the Old English word <em>cu</em>), but "beef" on our plate (where the Norman lords used the Norman French word <em>boef</em>).</p> <hr> <p>What other languages had a major impact on early English?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Latin">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Correct. As the language of the educated elite and the church, many Latin loanwords and expressions seeped into medieval English.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Old Norse">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><hr>That's right. When you get repeatedly wrecked (or more politely, "annexed" or "contacted") by the Vikings, your language bears a record of that trauma (or more politely, "cultural exchange").<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>The Norman Conquest of England is truly a turning point in history, especially for English-speaking people. Over the centuries, it has been represented and misrepresented in countless ways. Take Robin Hood, for instance. These stories often tell of a rapacious and haughty Norman aristocracy mistreating a conquered population of Saxon commoners. Medieval people <em>loved</em> Robin Hood. However, his fan base was distinctly working class - the peasantry. Robin Hood stories were basically drinking songs. And since peasants were illiterate, there are hardly any written sources about Robin Hood until later in the Middle Ages (centuries after the Norman Conquest with which he is so often associated today).</p> <p>The earlier medieval sources do contain enough sporadic references to songs about Robin to makes it clear to historians that these stories were the medieval equivalent of a hugely popular Netflix series. But they say nothing about the politics of Norman vs. Saxon, nothing about King Richard or Prince John, or even robbing the rich to give to the poor. Those are later additions. What seems to have made Robin Hood appealing to his medieval fan base was his talent for evading the authorities and making fools of them. He was known for kicking ass with peasant weapons, like a bow, and for his charismatic peasant sidekicks, like a miller's son and a forest hermit. (Robin also had a sword, because that's super cool). His nemesis was the local sheriff. The early folklore has no interest in national politics or social justice. The vibe is very "Somkey and the Bandit."</p> <p><img src="images/luttrell-archers.jpg" alt="archers target shooting" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Peasants practicing archery (Luttrell Psalter, England, c. 1330)</p> <p>So, was he real? Yep. But the "real, original" Robin Hood bore little resemblance to the guy in the stories medieval people loved so much. He was a Saxon noble called Hereweard the Wake. In the years after 1066, Hereweard and his band of outlaws waged a successful guerrilla resistance against the new Norman regime, operating out of a base hidden deep in the fens of eastern England (marsy, boggy wetlands). If there's any one person we can identify as the "real" Robin Hood, it's him.</p> <p>And so what? Does that mean the Robin Hood adored by medieval peasants is invalid or illegitimate in some way? Or the one Hollywood likes to show us today? I don't think so. It comes back to thinking carefully about the quesitons we ask of history. Instead of asking, "Was Robin Hood real?" or "Is this Robin Hood movie accurate?", maybe we should ask something like, "What did medeival people think of Robin Hood? What can those stories tell us about their lives and beliefs?" History can only answer the questions we ask of it.</p> <p><img src="images/robin-hood-film.jpg" alt="Robin Hood movie covers" width="100%"></p> <hr> <p>Which Robin Hood do you like best?</p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Russell Crowe in 2010">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>There are things to like there, I agree. But my favorite is Errol Flynn.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespA"><<link "The fox in the Disney one">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Yes!<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1:</span> What does the ghost of Harald Hardrada say? How does the old Viking counsel you to muster strength for the coming battle? How can you motivate men to fight? How should you set the pieces in motion in a way that will bring you victory?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>As you lead the forced march south, setting a crushing pace, making 40 miles a day with a brief stop in London to pull in fresh troops, what plans do you form for dealing with William at the coast? What orders do you issue as you travel? Is there a role for diplomacy as well as force? Can that treasure glowing in the bowels of York Minster do anything for you?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>The political situation and various claimants to the English crown</li> <li>Military considerations: Strengths and weaknesses of the English and Norman forces</li> <li>Ideals of kingship and military leadership in Anglo-Saxon England</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Viking poetry |skaldic]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Ring-giving |rg]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Battle of Stamford Bridge |snorri]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Bayeux Tapestry |bt]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Battle of Hastings |conquest]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Age Portal |Viking]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are Gui de Lusignan, King of Jerusalem</h1> <p>Near the Sea of Galillee, 1187</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "hattin-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "hattin-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p>You're dreaming of rippling meadows, shady glens, rushing brooks, of the pennants on your father's castle spiraling idly on a breeze. Of deer silently browsing in the shadows, fairies dancing in a ring, peasant wenches singing to their geese on the river bank. <<linkappend "The Poitou of your youth is cool and green.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include hattin-link1>><</linkappend>> It disappears in a blast of blazing sunlight and wind as hot as dragon's breath. Someone has opened the tent flap and they are talking to you. You force yourself to sit up and open your eyes but it takes a few moments to will yourself to hear them through the crushing heat of Palestine. After a decade in Holy Land, you still have to struggle to function in the heat. King of Jerusalem? King of Hell.</p> <p>Slowly, you realize they are telling you that <<linkappend "Saladin has taken Tiberias.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<include hattin-link2>><</linkappend>> A deep bark of laughter escapes your chest before you choke it back and maintain your poise. Ah, what the hell. You laugh loud enough to wake the dead. Then, you send for the others and while you wait, drinking warm, dirty water and savoring every sip as if it were a cool riesling from the castle cellars of Poitiers, you think about your options.</p> <p>Gerard de Ridefort is a fanatic, <<linkappend "especially since Cresson.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include hattin-link3>><</linkappend>> He's supported you so far because your interests aligned. He will want to attack. Raynald de Chatillon is as explosive. This whole thing is his fault, for breaking the truce you had negotiated with Saladin. He will want to attack ... probably. Raymond of Tripoli will want to ransom his wife. Perhaps ... if she's alive. She had held Tiberias with a small garrison, until now. The Hospitallers will want to do whatever the Templars don't want to do. And you, Gui de Lusignan, King of Jerusalem? What do you want to do? You want to go home. But you also want to be king of Jerusalem. You know it's suicidal folly to pursue Saladin toward Tiberias, into the hills at Hattin. That's obviously what he wants, for equally obvious reasons. He'll have the heights and the water, and you'll have no room to maneuver.</p> <p>Saladin tried this four years ago, and you refused to be tempted. You marched straight past his trap and returned safely to Jerusalem. But then Raynald and his Hospitaller allies accused you of cowardice, and even of a secret alliance with Saladin, (which is what Raynald himself had formed ...). They called it a cowardly failure and a disgrace, and deposed you from the throne of Jerusalem. For a time.</p> <p>So, here we go again. You set down the empty chalise and use these moments of solitude to think. As usual, Saladin has positioned you all <<linkappend "like pieces on a chess board.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include hattin-link5>><</linkappend>> You know it is idiotic to attack him at Hattin. He knows you know this. But (as he also knows), the others - Raynald and Raymond and Gerard and the rest - want to see you fail. They will push you to take the bait and enter the jaws of the trap, even though they know it's a trap. They will accuse you of cowardice and treachery again, forcing you into a doomed battle, into the hell of Hattin. Saladin knows what you are thinking, and what they will say. And he knows that you know that he knows.</p> <p>Saladin outnumbers you, <<linkappend "but that's normal.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include hattin-link4>><</linkappend>> The real problem is water. And your friends. They are a problem. You hear them outside, arguing already, as they near your tent. You close your eyes and savor one brief memory of home before the tent flap opens again.</p> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>The numbers we use today came to us through the Crusades. Europeans did much more than fight in the Holy Land during the High/Central Middle Ages (in fact, most crusade violence took place in Europe rather than the Middle East, and was directed at other Europeans, not Muslims). All this contact with the Muslim world fueled the Twelfth Century Renaissance, and brought European thinkers into contact with lost works from ancient Greece (Aristotle and Plato, crucially). It also showed them a new way to write numbers. By the end of the Middle Ages, this new Hindu-Arabic numerical system had replaced the old Roman notation.</p> <p>This new system was easier than Roman numerals, especially for expressing large numbers. In Roman times, numbers were rarely to express abstract concepts of incredibly huge or incredibly small amounts (as we often do in math today). Romans typically used numbers to represent discrete amounts of real, physical objects (like the number of soldiers in a legion, or the number of silver coins in the treasury). It would have been really hard (maybe impossible) to invent calculus in the 18th century if we were still using Roman numerals. They look cool, though, and we're still tossing them around today.</p> <hr> <p>How would you write the year 1776 (Declaration of Independence) in Roman numerals?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "MDCCLXXVI">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Right: M for 1,000, DCC for 500 plus 100 and 100, LXX for 50 plus 10 and 10, VI for 5 plus 1.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "XVIIMLLXXIV">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Try again ...<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>There's a fun movie involving these individuals (Saladin, Imad al-Din, Gui de Lusignan, Balian of Ibelin, Sybilla and Baldwin of Jerusalem, Tiberias, Raymond of Tripoli, Raynald of Chatillon, etc.). <em>Kingdom of Heaven</em> (2005) offers historically accurate depictions of many aspects of crusade warfare. The film does take some creative liberties with the characters' biographies and the chronology of events. And of course, with an eye to profit, it tailors the narrative and thematic orientation to appeal to 21st-century consumers (e.g., romance, ideas of freedom and equality), detracting somewhat from its historical authenticity.</p> <p><img src="images/kingdom-heaven.jpg" alt="movie cover showing actors and title Kingdom of Heaven" width="50%"></p> <hr> <p>Have you seen this one?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Yes!">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Great! It's a fun one, and not bad as far as historical accuracy goes (at least relating to crusade warfare).<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "No.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>If you're interested in this corner of history, it's worth viewing.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>So, what do you do?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>What are some results of your choice? For yourself, for the crusades, for history more broadly?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your political situation, especially rivalries with other crusader leaders</li> <li>The military strengths and weaknesses of yourself and your enemy</li> <li>Your sense of self, identity, duty, as a crusader and as a knight</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Crusaders take Jerusalem |sack]]</li> <hr> <li>[[An ideal knight |warewic]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Battle of Hattin in context |hattin]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Crusader warfare |crusader]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights Portal |Knights]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<set $alexExplore1 to "">> <<set $alexExplore2 to "">> <<set $cannaeExplore1 to "">> <<set $cannaeExplore2 to "">> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row hellenistichero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>The Hellenistic World</h1> <p>The conquests of Alexander the Great reshaped the ancient West, creating a degree of cultural and economic unity founded on the intellectual, technological, and military acheivements of the Greeks. As Alexander's successors squabbled in the east, a new power was rising in the west: Rome.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-alex.jpg" alt="black figure pottery illustration of ancient Greek warriors fighting with shield and spear" width="80%">' "hellenistic-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> <div class="row scenarios"> <div class="row transbox-arch"> <p class="big">[[A philosopher in Alexandria |Alexandria]]</p> <p class="big">[[Attacking Rome |Cannae]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: The Hellenistic World</p> <p><img src="images/greece1b.jpg" alt="ruins of circular columned temple" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: The Hellenistic World</p> <p><img src="images/greece1b.jpg" alt="ruins of circular columned temple" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and secondary sources. <span class="bi">Use the copy button</span> to move this material into Canvas as the foundation of your role play assignment.</p> <p>If you want another look at the sources later, you can also find them in the Source Anthology on Canvas.</p> </div> <div class="row marginalia"> <div class="cite"> <div class="row copynotes" id="copycann"> <<if (def $cannle1) and ($cannle1 isnot Use the "copy text" button to place these citations in a "Works Cited" section at the end of your role play response.</p> <div class="copynotes" id="copycanns"> <<if (def $cannle1) and ($cannle1 isnot "")>><p>Livy, <em>History of Rome</em>, transl. D. Spillan and Cyrus Edmonds, Project Gutenberg, https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/10907/pg10907-images.html, accessed [date]</p><</if>> <<if (def $cannwe1) and ($cannwe1 isnot "")>> <p>John Warry, <em>Warfare in the Classical World</em> (Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 2002)<</if>> <<if (def $cannre1) and ($cannre1 isnot "")>><p>something</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyCanns()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a young Helot woman</h1> <p>Sparta, 465 BCE</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "helot-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "helot-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row scenario"> <p>You are a young Helot woman. It’s 465 BCE, and another Helot rebellion is raging <<linkappend "across the Peloponnese.">><<include "helot-link1">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>Your people do this every couple of generations. It never works, but what the hell. What have you got to lose, really? As usual, Sparta’s allies have come trudging in to help the noble Spartans beat their slaves back into the ground. Again.</p> <p>But this time will be different. This time, the Helots have friends too.</p> <p>The moon looks monstrous as it floats up higher on the horizon - an angry red eye, leering through twisting columns and heavy layers of smoke. The Helots are burning the crops they’ve been growing for their masters. Occasionally the sound of screaming threads through the smoky air. You’re lying in the tall grass, your head resting in the curve of your lover’s arm. You feel so alive. Like you have never been alive before. Like his body is a portal to another world, and you have fallen through it. The world you left wasn’t real. This is the real world. You resist sleep, your eyes tracking the rise of the bloody orb of the moon.</p> <p>When the it reaches its zenith, you will meet with the Athenian rowers in the olive grove at the foot of this hill. Yesterday, Sparta sent Athens home when they came to help their “friends” crush the rebellion: “Thanks for coming, but <<linkappend "we don't want you here.">><<include "helot-link2">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> So the Athenians sailed off over the horizon … and then turned back to anchor here in the cove and send runners to find the Helot leaders. Your heart leaps as you think about what might happen now.</p> <p>You let yourself fantasize about a home without Spartans. A new polis will rise here. Your polis. What will its constitution be like? Which gods will it honor? What kinds of people will be free, and how free? <<linkappend "Will women be better off,">><<include "helot-link3">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> or will they still be ruled by the men? How will you repel Spartan attempts to regain control? (You know they’ll flee into the open arms of Persia, where they already have plenty of friends.)</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Today, if we call something "spartan," we mean it's simple, neat, no-frills, function-over-form. It's the opposite of luxurious or ornate. The word "laconic" is similar, usually denoting speech that's terse, spare, and to-the-point. "Laconic" is from Lacedaemon, the Spartans' home territory.</p> <hr> <p>Is your current dwelling spartan?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "This is what's known (politely) as euphemism. My current home is basically a cupboard, like Harry Potter under the stairs.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>All part of the halcyon bliss of undergraduate life. Enjoy.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Well, no.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Lucky you!<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>We've all heard of Helen of Troy, the most beautiful woman in the world, awarded to Paris, Prince of Troy, in a hilariously cheeky "be careful what you wish for" move by Aphrodite. But she wasn't Helen of Troy at all. She was Helen of Sparta ... and that was the problem, right? The story of Helen is exemplary of a wider trend in the ancient sources representing Spartan women as physically attractive (and, perhaps, dangerous?). Hollywood likes to tell the Paris-Helen story in a way that appeals to our modern tastes for romantic love. But Homer tells it quite differently. In the ancient poems, Helen <em>hates</em> Paris and does her best to make his life miserable - for instance, constantly calling him a coward and flirting <em>hard</em> with his big brother, Hector. Homer's version feels more in line with what we would expect from an abducted Spartan queen.</p> <p>Anyway, the story of Helen and the Trojan War was clearly a beloved and widely retold tale throughout ancient Greece. The most complete Trojan War narrative comes to us in oral-traditional verse composed by the (blind?) poet Homer c. 800 BCE. "Sing, Muse! Sing of the rage of Achilles..." The opening lines of Homer's <em>Iliad</em> are as familiar as the "In the beginning..." of <em>Genesis</em>. Indeed, the great epics of Homer, <em>The Iliad</em> and <em>The Odyssey</em>, are second only to the Bible in the longevity and depth of their influence on artistic and literary genius of the West for the past two millenia (and more). For long centuries, artists and poets and even political figures have drawn inspiration from the story of the Trojan War. The Roman poet Virgil used Homer's epics as a template for his own version a Roman origin story (<em>The Aeneid</em>). Medieval historians traced their own kings' lineages back to the plains of Ilium. (Thus, Britons came from a Brutus who fled Troy, for instance, and Thor was named for his native city of Troy.) Later, Hector, Helen, Achilles, and company appear on Shakespeare's stage, and these days, in Hollywood blockbusters. Probably my personal favorite is Dan Simmons' spec fiction novels <em>Illium</em> and <em>Olympos</em>, in which post-humans are Greek gods playing war games with their nano-engineered pet superhumans on a mockup of the Trojan War on Mars. Thank you, Homer, whoever you were.</p> <p><img src="images/odysseus-sirens.jpg" alt="men in ship, sirens diving" width="100%"></p> <p>Ancient Greek pottery showing Odysseus listening to the sirens' song</p> <p><img src="images/waterhouse-penelope.jpg" alt="men speaking through window as woman weaves" width="100%"></p> <p>Odysseus' wife, Penelope, tricking her suitors by weaving her father's funeral shroud all day (and unraveling it at night), by Pre-Raphaelite painter John William Waterhouse (England, 1912)</p> <hr> <p>The event that earns Paris the dubious "reward" of Helen is known as:</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "The Oedipus Cycle">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Good guess. That's a different Greek thing ... similar though, in its merciless, sardonic surrender to inexorabile Fate.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "The Judgment of Paris">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>Quite so. Never, <em>ever</em>, agree to serve as a judge in a beauty contest between Greek goddesses. Useful lesson in life.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What kind of polis will you craft after freeing yourselves from Spartan slavery? What will government and law look like? What about women? Will you have slavery?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>The Athenians don’t want women at the meeting. They say they gossip too much and will get everyone killed and should be at home. ("We don't <em>have</em> homes!" you want to scream at them.) What do you do? Do you leave quietly because you need revolution? Or do you stand your ground because you need this revolution?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your past experience, skills, physical and intellectual abilities</li> <li>Your family and personal relationships and community network</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Tyrtaeus (c. 625 BCE) |tyrtaeus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Xenophon (c. 380 BCE) |xenophon]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Helots in Sparta |cartledge-helots]]</li> <hr> <li>[[About women in Sparta |cartledge-women]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $horse is <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row ironhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Iron Age Empires</h1> <p>We're spending another week in Mesopotamia, but we'll also venture south into Egypt (pyramids!), and forge ahead through time into the Iron Age with the Hebrews, the Assyrian, and more of Babylon.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-assyria.jpg" alt="cavalry attacking with spears" width="80%">' "iron-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> <div class="row scenarios"> <div class="row transbox-arch"> <p class="big">[[With the Assyrian army |Assyria]]</p> <p class="big">[[The siege of Lachish |Lachish]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: Iron Age Empires</p> <p><img src="images/ironage.jpg" alt="chariot" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Hayes, <em>A History of Ancient Israel and Judah,</em> Second Edition (Louisville: Westminster John Knox Press, 2006)</p><</if>> <<if (def $lachse1) and ($lachse1 isnot "")>><p>Simon Anglim et al., <em>Fighting Techniques of the Ancient World, 3000 BC - AD 500: Equipment, Combat Skills, and Tactics</em> (New York: St Martin's Press, 2002)</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyLachs()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<set $elExplore1 to "">> <<set $elExplore2 to "">> <<set $hattinExplore1 to "">> <<set $hattinExplore2 to "">> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row knightshero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>The Age of Knights</h1> <p>A long time ago, historian Lynn White penned this oft-quoted remark about medieval knights: "Antiquity imagined the centaur; the early Middle Ages made him master of Europe." In the most basic sense, a knight is a dude on a horse. The French word for "knght," <em>chivalier</em>, simply means "horseman." But, obviously there's a lot more to being a knight than riding a horse. What about chivalry, tournaments, castles, courtly love and damsels (in distress?), King Arthur and Camelot, the crusades in the Holy Land? So much to explore!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-knights.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of knights jousting" width="80%">' "knights-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> <div class="row scenarios"> <div class="row transbox-arch"> <p class="big">[[The richest woman in Europe |Eleanor]]</p> <p class="big">[[King of Jerusalem |Hattin]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: The Age of Knights</p> <p><img src="images/hma.jpg" alt="knight" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page.
