"Crusaders")</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyKnights()">Copy text</button> <p>List the sources you used. Use the "copy text" button to place these citations in a "Works Cited" section at the end of your role play response.</p> <div class="copynotes" id="copykns"> <<if (def $knje1) and ($knje1 isnot "")>><p>“Sack of Jerusalem." Cal Poly Humboldt, HIST 104. Instructor: Queen. Accessed [date].</p><</if>> <<if (def $kngwe1) and ($kngwe1 isnot "")>><p>Weiss, J., Transl. <em>Boeve de Haumtone and Gui de Warewic: Two Anglo-Norman Romances</em>. Tempe: Arizona Center for Medieval and Renaissance Studies, 2008.</p> <</if>> <<if (def $knate1) and ($knate1 isnot "")>><p>Hooper, Nicholas, and Bennett, Matthew. <em>The Cambridge Illustrated Atlas of Warfare: The Middle Ages, 768 - 1487</em>. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1996.</p><</if>> <<if (def $knce1) and ($knce1 isnot "")>><p>France, John. "Crusaders and Settlers in the East, 1096 - 1291: Christian Attack, Muslim Response." Graff, J. and Curry, A., Eds. <em>The Cambridge History of War: Volume 2, War and the Medieval World</em>. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2020. Pp. 266 - 296.</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyKnightss()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Age of Knights Portal |Knights]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, your city is besieged by the Assyrians</h1> <p>Lachish, c. 800 BCE</p> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "lachish-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "lachish-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row scenario"> <p>The Assyrian army spreads like a lake of ants around the city of Lachish, smoke from its cooking fires rising up around you like the walls of a cage, wrapping you in a feeling of crushing, hopeless imprisonment. You focus on setting aside panic. The enemy is busy building siege engines and ramps and digging, raiding the countryside and practicing their maneuvers. More seem to arrive <<linkappend "every day.">><<include "lachish-link1">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>The city of Lachish is strong. But it’s also divided. Backed by the money and military of King Hezekiah at Jerusalem, the local elite have adopted the cult of Yaweh, pushing everyone to conform. Now the seething mass of death and destruction outside the walls has ignited the explosive resentments that divide the city’s population. Nomadic folk who fled into the city from the countryside have never had much good to say about city people - and vice versa. Slaves aren’t sure who’s scarier now - their masters or the Assyrians. Canaanites and Philistines, Egyptians and Hebrews have never trusted each other much (at all).</p> <p>Your family has lived in the area since the Great Flood. You come to the market here every week to trade wool and cheese and wild herbs and honey. You don’t hate the city like some of the other outsiders do, but your home is out there in the hills and your gods are not the great, unknowable Yaweh with his laws and scrolls and <<linkappend "priests and temple.">><<include "lachish-link2">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>One night, after drifting to sleep with your baby nestled under one arm, and your oldest son on the other side, you’re awakened by whispering voices. Your husband is sitting with a group of friends. One of them has just come back after spending a few days in the Assyrian camp. The city walls are strong, but most folk know how to find a way out when they want to. He’s heard what happens to cities who resist the empire. Wouldn’t it be better to surrender now, he says? It’s not our city, anyway. Silence, and then soft muttering. You can see some of their heads nodding in the dim moonlight. Your grip on the baby tightens, and it squirms, nuzzling for your breast. Your mind is racing.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>It may seem ood, sitting here in twenty-first-century North America, that an ancient Hebrew text first committed to writing c. 1,000 BCE, lives on in our everyday speech. But it's true. Phrases like these from the first widely-used English translation, the seventeenth-century King James Version, will be familiar to you (Old and New Testament examples included here):</p> <ul> <li>Sign of the times</li> <li>My brother's keeper</li> <li>Labor of love</li> <li>Turn the world upside down</li> <li>A drop in the bucket</li> <li>The root of all evil (From Jerome's Latin <em>Cupiditas radix malorum est</em> - note that it's not "money" or "gold," but the <em>desire</em> (<em>cupiditas</em>) for those things)</li> </ul> <p>There are older biblical Hebrew expressions floating around, oddly familiar to us here and now, but with origins several millennia and half a world away. "Hallelujah," for instance, is a compound from the Hebrew "praise" and "God." Similarly, "amen" is from Hebrew for "so be it." And this last one is less common, but I came across it in Steinbeck's <em>East of Eden</em> and a Mumford and Sons song (yes, I am old): "Timshel" in Hebrew meant "thou mayest," but the King James English renders it as "Thou shalt." Big difference, there!</p> <hr> <p>Judaism is the first of the "three great western religions." All three share origins here in the ancient Middle East. Which of the other two great western religions came next?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Islam">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Nope, Christianity appears next in the early first century CE. Islam arrives in the mid seventh century CE.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Christianity">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Right! Christianity is born in the early first century CE (in the Roman province of Judaea). Islam arises later, in mid-seventh-century Arabia.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>According to the Hebrew Bible, the patriarchs (Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob) produced twelve tribes of the Hebrew nation. By the time of the Assyrian siege of Lachish, those tribes had split into two kingdoms: Ten tribes were in the Kingdom of Israel, and two were in the Kingdom of Judah. Israel chose to resist Assyria. Long story short, nobody ever saw them again. They are remembered as "the ten lost tribes of Israel."</p> <p>But this isn't the end of the story. Surprisingly, the ten lost tribes of Isreal figure quite prominently in the history of the United States. It started in New York in the 1820s. Amid the evangelistic fervor of the Second Great Awakening, Joseph Smith experienced a vision. An angel named Moroni appeared and showed him golden tablets inscribed with a script Smith identified as "reformed Egyptian." Miraculously, Smith was able to translate the tablets. (Aside from a single friend of Smith's, nobody else has ever seen the original tablets or any other ancient examples of a "reformed Egyptian" script or language). The tablets contained passages from the King James Bible and foretold the coming of Christ. They also revealed the fate of the ten lost tribes of Israel: These tribes had come to the Americas and become the ancestors of the Native Americans. With these golden tablets, Smith founded Mormonism and the Church of Jesus Christ and the Latter Day Saints (LDS). It is a major world religion today. (Note that the academic community does not accept Smith's theory about the ten lost tribes of Israel as historical fact.)</p> <hr> <p>Considering the Mormons' belief that the Native Americans were the descendants of the ten lost tribes of Israel, how do you think the Mormons treated their indigenous neighbors while establishing a theocratic state in 19th-century Utah?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "They strove to convert the Native Americans to Mormonism.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Yes, Mormon missionaries actively cultivated positive relationships with neighboring indigenous communities with a focus on conversion. They also fought and violently displaced the tribes at various times.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Nineteenth-century antisemitism and racism disinclined the Mormons to view the Native Americans with any sympathy.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>True enough. For instance, they were fine with falsely blaming Native Americans for the infamous Mountain Meadows Massacre on 9/11, 1857.<</replace>><</link>></p> <hr> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What do you say to your girlfriends the next morning? What do you say to your husband? What will you do?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>What happens to you and your family? What happens to Lachish and the Kingdom of Judah? Does the new cult of Yaweh flourish?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your past experience, skills, physical and intellectual abilities</li> <li>Your family and personal relationships and community network</li> <li>Your socio-economic class</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Assyrian depictions of the siege |lachish-friezes]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Bible stories |bible-stories]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Archaeological and artistic evidence |lachish-evidence]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Ancient Israel and Judah |miller-israel]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Assyrian siege warfare |lachish-sieges]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are in love</h1> <p>A rural village, c. 1300</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "love-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "love-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p>It's summer solstice. <<linkappend "The St John's Eve bonfire roars up to heaven, loud and hot and glorious.">><<include love-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>>.</p> <p>You lounge in the shadows, avoiding the heat of the flames. Carefully cradling a cup brimming with good mead, you watch the one you love. Jostling against their friends, laughing and singing, they dance around the roaring bonfire. They're like a spirit, like a flame. You take another drink, feeling miserable and excited at the same time, desperate to make something happen before dawn. <em>Not much time.</em> Midsummer nights begin and end in a single breath. You've been in love with them for at least a year now, but barely exchanged a few words.</p> <p>You look away into the night and take another drink. <em>It's no good,</em> you think for the thousandth time. Even if you could manage to catch their attention somehow, then what? Lovers for a time? Or together forever? Impossible. Your families hate each other. The manor court rolls groan with the weight of your ancestors' names, taking each other to court for generations: property lines, insults and assaults, fraud, bad sales, theft, debt (on both sides), shirking boon work (again, on both sides). The parish church has heard an equally lengthy back-and-forth over the centuries: drunkenness, fornication, adultery, scolding, eating meat during Lent, blasphemy, witchcraft. It will never end. You sigh and let your chin drop onto your chest, resting your eyes from the blinding sight of your beloved. But you can still hear their voice: clear and exultant in song and laughter. Singing away the shortest night of the year.</p> <p>You take another drink and remember the <<linkappend "play at last year's somergames.">><<include love-link2>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>>. Their family played the Romans and Jews and devils, and your family played Christ and the disciples and the angels. The fight was epic, as usual. You run your fingers over the new scar on your forearm where one of their brothers "accidentally" stabbed all the way through your arm and out the other side with the hard ash-wood tine of his pitchfork. You played Jesus this year, and when they were nailing you to the cross, he sat his bare arse on your head (you take another drink, remembering ...). So, you grabbed the crown of thorns and stuck it in one of his hairy hams. Then he "accidentally" stabbed you with the pitchfork, repeatedly. It was pretty much the same at the Christmas play. One year, the priests tried to split you up so there were some from each family on each side of the Easter play. A smile comes across you as you remember, and a chuckle bursts out. They'll never try that again. Another year, when your family made the Noah parade wagon in the mystery play, a bunch of them put rotten eggs on a hidden plank underneath, so when the wagon rolled through the market square, it left a trail of stench and broken eggs behind. And then there was the fight at the May Day Robin Hood play last month... You sigh and drink again.</p> <p>Your cup feels so light. The fire's rage is cooling. You look east and see a glow on the horizon. <em>Not much time.</em> You get up and move toward the one you want.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Peasants may not have left much of a written record (except for the eternal neighborhood bickering preserved in manor court rolls). But they left traces in the words we use every day. Think about surnames, for instance. Many of our most common English names have their roots in the trades by which people were known in medieval times: Miller, Carter, Wheeler, Smith. There are also plenty of figures of speech from peasant life still in common use today. "Windfall," for instance: The forest was commonly owned by the lord, and peasants were not allowed to harvest forest resources (like wild game or timber) without permission. But when a storm blew down a huge tree, it was considered a common resource to be used by the village. The huge beams common in medieval buildings could only come from large, old trees. A "windfall" was when such a tree fell down, typically in a storm. It was a stroke of good luck for the community.</p> <p>You can see these huge beams, characteristic of medieval timber frame architecture, here on a barn and a a guildhall from fifteenth-century England</p> <p><img src="images/timberframe-barn.jpg" alt="timber frame interior" width="50%"></p> <p><img src="images/york-guildhall.jpg" alt="timber frame exterior" width="50%"></p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>History of the history</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What do you say to your beloved? What are they like? Why do you love them?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>How will you achieve some kind of romantic union with this person? How will you deal with the family problem? Is marriage possible? Or desirable?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your skills and economic situation</li> <li>Your gender and sexual orientation</li> <li>Your relationship with others in the community</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Scenes from peasant life |life]]</li> <hr> <li>[[From Chaucer's Canterbury Tales |miller]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Peasant life and relationships |penifader]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Medieval sexuality |sexuality]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <h1>Our History Rewrite</h1> <img src="images/open-book-fantasy.jpg" alt="open book with castle, forest, pegasus growing from pages" width="100%"> <p>Could history have happened differently? Would the present be different? What will the future hold? It's up to you!</p> <p>If you're done with this week's role play assignment, find the portal below and enter to see what everyone else has written. Play around with these alternative histories and be ready to discuss some of the following prompts when we meet in class. (Note: You need a password to open each of these portals. You will receive the weekly password in Canvas after submitting the role play response, and in class on Friday.)</p> <ul> <li>Compare the choices you and your classmates made. Evaluate similarities and differences.</li> <li>Consider the differences in outcomes for the individual and for their community or society. When did decisions and outcomes have similar impacts for the individual and their society? When were the impacts different? Why?</li> <li>Did you notice any recurring themes in the power dynamics that dictate individuals' choices and shape their interactions? These factors might include knowledge and skills, gender, socio-economic status, political context, ideology and belief, geography, environment and natural resources. Which were most impactful?</li> <li>Overall, explore some comparisons between the kinds of choices individuals faced in history and the kinds of choices we face today. What are some similarities? What are some difference? Why? What do you think the future holds for individuals in the West and for Western Civilization as a whole?</li> </ul> </div> <div class="row"> <h2 class="center">History Rewrite Portals</h2> <div </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Iron Age Empires |ironage-rewrite]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/ironage.jpg" alt="archer in chariot" width="50%">' "ironage-rewrite">><</link>> </div> <div babies" width="50%">' "rome1-rewrite">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/darkages.jpg" alt="acqueduct with Roman arches crossing |renaissance-rewrite]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/newworlds.jpg" alt="Queen Elizabeth wearing ornate clothing" width="50%">' "renaissance-rewrite">><</link>> </div> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row passageheader"> <ul> <li>[[Restart |Enter]]</li> <li>Western Civ I Role Play Game</li> <li>[[About]]</li> </ul> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <p>Please enter the password in this text box: <<textbox "$Password" "" "Enter">></p> </div> </div><<set $forExplore1 to "">> <<set $forExplore2 to "">> <<set $loveExplore1 to "">> <<set $loveExplore2 to "">> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row peashero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Medieval Peasants</h1> <p>Let's get our hands dirty with the medieval peasants! Were they, as the aristocracy believed, phenomenally dumb and bestial, caked with mud and hardly sentient? Of course not! The common folk of medieval society were a widely diverse and dynamic group of individuals and communities, often real weilding wealth and power. It's really no surprise that the nobility felt threatened by the commons - a fear manifested in their efforts to construct an elevated code of chivalry to define their own class, alongside a debased image of peasants as barely human.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-peas.jpg" alt="medieval infantry in battle" width="80%">' "peas-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> <div class="row scenarios"> <div class="row transbox-arch"> <p class="big">[[A forester in Germany |Forester]]</p> <p class="big">[[At a midsummer bonfire |Love]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: Medieval Peasants</p> <p><img src="images/peasants.jpg" alt="shearing sheep and reaping wheat" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and secondary sources. <span class="bi">Use the copy button</span> to move this material into Canvas as the foundation of your role play assignment.</p> <p>If you want another look at the sources later, you can also find them in the Source Anthology on Canvas.</p> </div> <div class="row marginalia"> <div class="cite"> <div class="row copynotes" id="copyfor"> <<if (def $forbe1) and ($forbe1 isnot and ($forppe2 isnot "")>><p><<print $forppe2>><p> (Goldberg, <em>Franks</em>)</p><</if>> <<if (def $forppa2) and ($forppa2 isnot "")>><p><<print $forppa2>><p> (Goldberg, <em>Franks</em>)</p><</if>> <<if (def $forppe3) and ($forppe3 isnot "")>><p><<print $forppe3>><p> (Goldberg, <em>Franks</em>)</p><</if>> <<if (def $forppa3) and ($forppa3 isnot "")>><p><<print $forppa3>><p> (Goldberg, <em>Franks</em>)</p><</if>> <<if (def $forppe4) and ($forppe4 isnot "")>><p><<print $forppe4>><p> (Goldberg, <em>Franks</em>)</p><</if>> <<if (def $forppa4) and ($forppa4 isnot "")>><p><<print $forppa4>><p> (Goldberg, <em>Franks</em>)</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyFor()">Copy text</button> <p>List the sources you used. Use the "copy text" button to place these citations in a "Works Cited" section at the end of your role play response.</p> <div class="copynotes" id="copyfors"> <<if (def $forbe1) and ($forbe1 isnot "")>><p>“Books of the Hunt." Cal Poly Humboldt, HIST 104. Instructor: Queen.Accessed [date].</p><</if>> <<if (def $forace1) and ($forace1 isnot "")>><p>"Hunting Accidents." Cal Poly Humboldt, HIST 104. Instructor: Queen. Accessed [date].</p> <</if>> <<if (def $forgge1) and ($forgge1 isnot "")>><p><em>Sir Gawain and the Green Knight</em>. Wilhelm, James J. Transl., <em>The Romance of Arthur: An Anthology of Medieval Texts in Translation</em>. New York: Garland, 1994.</p><</if>> <<if (def $forffe1) and ($forffe1 isnot "")>><p>Nicholas Orme, "Medieval Hunting: Fact and Fancy." Hanawalt, Barbara A., Ed. <em>Chaucer's England: Literature in Historical Context</em>. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 1992. Pp. 133 - 153.</p><</if>> <<if (def $forppe1) and ($forppe1 isnot "")>><p>Goldberg, Eric J. <em>In the Manner of the Franks: Hunting, Kingship, and Masculinity in Early Medieval Europe</em>. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2020.</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyFors()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Portal |Peasants]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: Medieval Peasants</p> <p><img src="images/peasants.jpg" alt="shearing sheep and reaping wheat" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Peasants |Peasants]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are Pericles</h1> <p>Athens, 414 BCE</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "pericles-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "pericles-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p>You are Pericles, and you didn’t die of plague in 429 BCE. It is now 414, and as <em>strategos,</em> you have kept Athens mostly on top of this conflict with Sparta and her Peloponnesian League. Just barely. But now Persia has built Sparta a navy. Shit. Soooooo predictable. What are we going to do about those knuckle-dragging fascists?</p> <p>So, that’s a problem. But the worst threat is inside the gates. The young men of Athens are going mad, pent up behind the Long Walls, dying of plague and longing for a real fight. They follow Alcibiades like sheep. Glamorous, rich, impossibly beautiful Alcibiades. <<linkappend "Depraved, lecherous, rebellious Alcibiades.">><<include "Pericles-link1">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> He was your student, your protege, once upon a time. But you serve the people, Alcibiades serves himself alone. Along with Socrates and a gaggle of dirty comic playwrights, he is uprooting everything you're fighting for, everything Athens stands for. They mock the gods and the city itself, tearing at the solidarity you've been nurturing during these long, bitter years of war with Sparta, screaching for war while you work for peace.</p> <p>Alcibiades mesmerizes the peope, with his proud aristocratic disdain for democracy, his lavish, fashionable, party life, his rash calls for escalation against Sparta. His latest idea is <<linkappend "an attack on Sicily.">><<include "Pericles-link2">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><</linkappend>> It's beyond idiotic. Utter madness - especially now that Sparta has its Persian-funded navy. But this is a democracy, and Alcibiades says whatever makes the crowd roar. They love him. Frankly, you’re not sure who is in charge any more - him or his worshipers.</p> <p>Tonight the city will gather to hear your annual funeral oration. You want to make this one count. You <em>need</em> to make it count, like that one at the beginning of the war that people still quote at symposia and the theater. What can you say this time to steer your city toward survival, and break the spell of Alcibiades?</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Athens' vibrant community of playwrights and artists worked with a rich common stock of traditional myth and legend, with which their audiences were familiar. These stories, heroes, and names still surround us today. Just look up, and you'll find constellations like Pegasus, Centaurus, and Cassiopeia, just to name a few.</p> <p>Sometimes we find it challenging to understand or appreciate what these myths meant to ancient people. Athens' own patron deity, the mighty Athena, provides a good example of this challenge. Athena was the goddess of war, wisdom, and crafts, protector of heroes like Herakles, Odysseus, Perseus, and Theseus (founder of Athens). So, wait, "crafts?" Like scrapbooking or quilting or basket weaving? Negative. Crafts as in technology. This is probably why Hephaestus, the smith god, had a thing for her. Athena was constantly helping her favorite humans by giving them ingenious tools and weapons or showing them tricks to achieve victory. It's no surprise that her protege, "wily Odysseus," was the guy who came up with the Trojan Horse idea. So, today, Athena's "craftiness" lines up with coding and engineering rather than quilting. She belongs with <em>Wired</em> and <em>Turing Magazine</em>, not <em>Better Homes and Gardens</em>.</p> <p><img src="images/athena-enceladus.jpg" alt="female figure fighting male with spear and shield" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: This scene shows Athena's combat with the giant Enceladus. When he finally took off running, she threw Sicily at him. (Attica, 6th century BCE)</p> <p>It's interesting to compare Athena with the other Greek god of war, Ares. Ares is a total psychopath and his children are all monsters. In some ways, Athena represents a more positive attitud toward war as a space for technological innovation and strategic advances. Ares, on the other hand, represents the bestial savagery of war. Is this a dichotomy we ponder today as well?</p> <hr> <p>The Roman equivalent of Athena was:</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Minerva">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Yes.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Juno">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Nope, this would be the Roman equivalent of Hera, wife of Zeus (or Jove, to the Romans).<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey (score +2).</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>Historians have often noted strong parallels between the Peloponnesian War of ancient times and the Cold War of the twentieth century. Both wars formed around the rivalry between two regional superpowers (Sparta vs. Athens, and the US vs. USSR). Both rivalries had ideological as well as economic differences at their core (democracy vs. oligarchy in the ancient world, and liberal democracy and capitalism vs. oligarchic communism in the modern world). Both wars were characterized by alternating periods of peace and tension, proxy wars, repeated diplomatic failures, and by complex networks of alliances linking smaller polities allied to each superpower. Both wars were prolonged by political as well as geopolitical factors. And in both cases, an outside "third power" added complexity to the core opposition between the two great powers (Persia in ancient times, and China in the twentieth century). And in both cases, we 21st-century Americans want to cheer on Team Democracy, but it's hard to do it wholeheartedly, because nobody comes away with clean hands. It's hard to point out the "good guy" in wars like this.</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div clas="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What will you say in your funeral speech this year? What's your new strategy for dealing with this war that never seems to end? How will you make it all appealing to your Athenian citizens (meaning, of course, the free adult men)?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>How will the city react? How will Sparta and Persia respond when they hear about it?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Athens' strengths and weaknesses at this point in the Peloponnesian War</li> <li>Ideals of patriotism and masculinity in Classical Athens</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Pericles' famous "Funeral Oration" |funeral-oration]]</li> <hr> <li>[[A popular, bawdy comedy about the Peloponnesian War |lysistrata]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Socrates' trial and execution |apology]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Military history of the Peloponnesian War |warry-sicily]]</li> <hr> <li>[[About Thucydides' account of Sicily and Alcibiades |nichols-thucydides]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="link"> <p>Aristocratic Athenian leader Alcibiades was popular for his personal beauty, wealth, wild lifestyle, and defiance of traditional authority. He destroyed Athenian democracy, ensured Athens' deafeat in the Peloponnesian War, betrayed Athens to fight for Sparta, betrayed Sparta and slept with the Spartan king's wife, and fought for Persia. He was a student and close friend of the controversial philosopher Socrates. Like Socrates, Alcibiades was tried and sentenced to death for basically desecrating the gods. While Socrates was convicted of atheism and "corrupting the youth," and famously sentenced to drink poison hemlock, Alcibiades was convicted of vandalizing statues of the gods (in particular, by breaking the phalluses off statues of their statues around the city). Unlike Socrates, however, Alcibiades fled Athens and was not executed.</p> <hr> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-6"> <p>A Roman copy of a Greek statue of Alcibiades</p> <img src="images/alcibiades.jpg" alt="statue of man's shoulders and head" width="50%"> </div> <div class="col-6"> <p>A Roman copy of a Greek <em>herma,</em> the type of guardian spirit" statue supposedly vandalized by Alcibiades and his followers on the eve of the ill-fated Sicilian Expedition</p> <img src="images/herma.jpg" alt="statue of man's head, genitals, and rectangular torso" width="50%"> </div> </div> </div> <hr> <p>In his 1787 "The Death of Socrates," Enlightenment painter Jacques-Louis David emphasizes Socrates' righteous defiance and the deep impact of his execution/suicide on the leadership of Athens.</p><img src="images/David-Socrates-1787.jpg" alt="socrates drinking poison, surrounded by grieving men" width="100%"> </div><div class="link"> <p><img src="images/map-peloponnesian-war.jpg" alt="map of Peloponnesian War" width="80%"></p> <p>This map shows the distance between the Greek colonies on Sicily and the main theater of the Peloponnesian War, centered in Greece and the Aegean. From Cole and Symes, <em>Western Civilizations,</em> Brief Fifth Edition (New York: Norton, 2020)</p> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Göbekli Tepe Pillars</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>See images of the carved artwork on the pillars of the Göbekli Tepe enclosures from c. 11,000 BCE. Open the link to view the images, along with archaeologists' commentary at the <a href="https://www.dainst.blog/the-tepe-telegrams/tag/t-pillars/" target="_blank">Tepe Telegrams</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Attitudes toward nature, animals, and humans</li> <li>Technology and tools used at the site</li> <li>The kind of work people did here</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtgtpe1" `$gtgtpe1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtgtpa1" `$gtgtpa1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtgtpe2" `$gtgtpe2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtgtpa2" `$gtgtpa2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtgtpe3" `$gtgtpe3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtgtpa3" `$gtgtpa3 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtgtpe4" `$gtgtpe4 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtgtpa4" `$gtgtpa4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h3>Primary Sources</h3> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The pillars of Gobekli Tepe |Pillars]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h3>Secondary Sources</h3> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[A model of Gobekli Tepe |GT Model]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Foragers and agriculturalists at Gobekli Tepe |GT Curry]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Building monoliths and pyramids |Rocks]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-gt]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> <li>[[Back: Göbekli Tepe Scenario |GT]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a wealthy Roman</h1> <p>Italy, 78 CE</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "pompeii-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "pompeii-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p>The sounds of building are a cacophany: sawing, hammering, chiseling, digging, the slow chant of slaves carrying timber and stone. You edge away from the burning sun, into the shade of your newly-constructed, empty <em>domus</em>. It's almost done. You sigh with a delicious sense of contenment. You reach out and touch the nearest wall, but frown as you notice that some of the wet paint has stuck to your fingertips, and you've smudged the foliar border framing a bright red frescoe of <<linkappend "a handsome woman playing a kithara.">><<include pompeii-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> This will be the <em>triclinium</em>. The floor is bare and empty, waiting for a tile mosaic. Maybe a lively Nile River scene? Or a colorful dockyard? And what about the other walls?</p> <p>You think of the frescoes and mosaics in your neighbor's house: <<linkappend "everything from stories of the gods to exotic African animals to flowers and fruit.">><<include "pompeii-link2">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> They're an old patrician family, though, and your grandparents were slaves. Well-educated, literate, and highly capable, your grandfather was freed by his owner, an old senator. Your grandfather prospered as a freedman within the political and financial network of his former owner. His son, and you and your children remain fiercely loyal to the old senator's heirs, and you grow richer all the time. Still, you'll never have the power or prestige of your patrician neighbors - and they'll never let you forget it. But there's no reason a pleb as rich as you should live in a hovel. You sigh, moving slowly back outside. What to paint on these walls? ...</p> <p>You look out toward Pompeii. Your home clings to the lovely slopes of Mount Vesuvius, just above the bustling town. It's 78 CE. Vespasian sits the imperial throne, carrying on the legacy of the Flavian dynasty. Life could hardly be better. What would this world be without the majesty of the empire? There would be no wine, clean water, law and order, schools and plays and libraries and baths, and the <<linkappend "grand colosseum Vespasian has begun building in Rome.">><<include "pompeii-link3">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p> That's it! Your walls will celebrate the beauty and splendor of Rome! Its heritage and power and everything it stands for. Everything <em>you</em> stand for. The patricians can look down their noses at you, but you are a true Roman. That's what will go on these new, blank walls.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Latin is truly the most undead thing in history. Not kidding.</p> <p>Here are some fun Latin terms we still use all the time. You probalby know these already, but maybe there's somehting new here.</p> <ul> <li><em>Modus operandi</em>, also known as an "M.O.," short for "mode of operation"</li> <li><em>Exempla gratia</em>, more familiar as "e.g." meaning "here's an example," or, "for example"</li> <li><em>Id est</em>, more familiar as "i.e." meaning "that is," or "in other words"</li> <li>A whole heap of legal terms like <em>de facto</em> ("in fact, but maybe not technically by law"), and its opposite, <em>de jure</em> ("technically by law but maybe not in reality")</li> <li>Ad hoc, meaning "for this," as in, this was just put together here on the spot for this very moment</li> <li><em>Prima facie</em>, or "on the face of it," as in, "at first glance," or "seemingly"</li> </ul> <hr> <p>Latin guessing game: <em>primus pilus</em> refers to:</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "The rookies of the legion who had not yet served a year.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Good guess, since <em>primus</em> means "first." But, no.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "The rank of first spear centurion.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Correct! A centurion was the leader of a century (a unit of 100 men), and first spear centurion was leader of the most important century of the legion - the one on the front right of the battle formation. Not only did a first spear centurion command this tactically critical position, he was also responsible for guarding the legion's standard and pay chest. The first century of the first cohort was the legion's elite, and its battle leader, first spear centurion, was a uniquely powerful rank within the Roman army.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <hr> <p>Modern politicians have a long history of interpreting and misinterpreting and borrowing from the Roman political scene. Rome is always in style, it seems, and on any given day, we needn't look far to find reinventions of pre-packaged Roman symbolism (and, one might argue, inherently cool Roman aesthetics). For instance, the American founders liked the eagles from the Roman legionnary standards. They liked the term "senate" from Rome too, (Latin <em>senex</em> means "old man").</p> <p>So, when Benito Mussolini founded the style of politics we now call "fascism" in 1919, he was hardly demonstrating creative genius when he borrowed symbolism from Rome. His party's emblem was the Roman <em>fasces</em> - the bundle of elm rods and an axe carried by the lictors, and representing the imperium (imperial power) wielded by the senate or a consul. He also adopted the Roman legions' salute of a raised palm. Hitler would famously follow suit - he was a huge Mussolini fan and wrote him sweet, adoring letters as a young man. (Fun fact: There's no evidence that the Romans used such a salute. Eighteenth-century artists kind of made it up, and by the twentieth century, people imagined it as a Roman thing. Big surprise, the founders of fascism weren't super interested in real history ...)</p> <p>Our English word "fascism," rooted in the <em>fasces</em> ancient Rome, was coined in the 1920s to describe Mussolini's supporters, and then Hitler's in 1930s Germany just across the Alps. Today, it's a word everyone can expect to encounter at some point.</p> <p><img src="images/fasces2.jpg" alt="stone bas relief of Roman officials, black flag with fasces graphic, Hitler giving Nazi salute" width="100%"></p> <p>Above left: Lictors bearing the fasces, from Trajan's Column (second century CE). Above upper right: Flag of Mussolini's Fascist Party, 1920s. Above lower right: Hitler giving the Nazi salute at the Berlin Olympics, 1936.</p> <hr> <p>Which of these was one of Mussolini's 1920s campaign slogans?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Drain the swamp!">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>That is correct. History does not repeat itself, but it often rhymes?<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Fatherland first!">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">><<set $Score to $Score +2>>No, but it sounds right.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What will you tell the artists to paint on your walls?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>Do you think the art in your new home will impact your life in any real way? How will it add to your sense of fulfillment or happiness at home? Will it boost your social status or economic status or the opportunities you encounter?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your favorite stories from Greek and Roman legend</li> <li>Your education and experience</li> <li>The kinds of social gatherings you plan to host at your home</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The Romans' favorite legends about themselves |roman-legends]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Frescoes and mosaics from Roman villas |villas]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Roman pleasures |romanitas]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Rome: Republic to Empire |Rome1]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<set $PlayerName to $PlayerName>> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> </div> <div class="container starthero"> <div class="title-sub"> <h1> Welcome, $PlayerName</h1> </div> </div> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <p>Find this week's time travel portal below. You will use the output from this game to build the weekly role play assignment due in Canvas.</p> <p>If you're already done with this week's role play assignment, you can check out what everyone else has written at [[Our History Rewrite]]. We will discuss these in class. (Note: You need a password to open the Rewrite portals. You will receive the weekly password in Canvas after submitting the role play response.)</p> <h2>Tutorial</h2> <p>This brief video will show you how to play the game and use the output to complete the weekly role play assignments in Canvas.</p> <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/QdsxxOqUrwI?si=tEO8yVTAQ1VDTAxm" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe> <h2 class="center">Role Play Game Learning Objectives</h2> <p>Wondering, "Why am I doing this? What's the point?" Well, here's the official run-down on the purpose of these weekly activities. You will achieve the following learning objectives, which align with the History Department's student learning outcomes:</p> <ul> <li>Identify primary and secondary sources.</li> <li>Analyze the significance of primary and secondary sources as historical evidence.</li> <li>Apply discipline-specific concepts and vocabulary to evaluate various interpretations of history.</li> <li>Construct valid interpretations of history using evidence from primary and secondary sources with appropriate references to historical context.</li> </ul> <h2 class="center">Time Travel Portals</h2> <p>Find this week's topic in the list below. Enter the portal to play the game and find the role play assignment prompts.</p> <div class="container center"> <div class="row portals"> <h3>[[In the Beginning |Beginning]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/pyramids_leonardo-ramos_unsplash.jpg" alt="pyramids in the desert" width="50%">' "Beginning">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Iron Age Empires |Iron]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/ironage.jpg" alt="archer in chariot" width="50%">' "Iron">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Ancient Greece |Greece]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/greece1.jpg" alt="hoplite warriors fighting with spears and shields" width="50%">' "Greece">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[The Hellenistic World |Hellenistic]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/greece1b.jpg" alt="ruins of circular, columned temple" width="50%">' "Hellenistic">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Rome: From Republic to Empre |Rome1]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/rome1.jpg" alt="statue of human babies nursing from wolf" width="50%">' "Rome1">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/darkages.jpg" alt="helmet with face plate and engraving" width="50%">' "Rome2">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[The Viking Age |Viking]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/viking-module.jpg" alt="viking ship with warriors" width="50%">' "Viking">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Medieval Knights |Knights]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/hma.jpg" alt="mounted knight receiving shield and helmet from two women" width="50%">' "Knights">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/peasants.jpg" alt="people shearing sheep and reaping wheat with castle in background" width="50%">' "Peasants">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Renaissance]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/newworlds.jpg" alt="Queen Elizabeth I wearing ornate royal regalia" width="50%">' "Renaissance">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> </div><<set $witchExplore1 to "">> <<set $witchExplore2 to "">> <<set $artExplore1 to "">> <<set $artExplore2 to "">> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row renhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>The Renaissance</h1> <p>In renaissance Europe, the brilliance of new art and science, and even a new map of the world, forms a striking contrast with the dark, apocalyptic landscape of witch hunts, religious persecution, failed states, and incessant war.</p> </div> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-ren.jpg" alt="knights and landsknecht in battle" width="80%">' "ren-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> <div class="row scenarios"> <div class="row transbox-arch"> <p class="big">[[A witch hunt |Witch]]</p> <p class="big">[[An African artist in Italy |Artist]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: The Renaissance</p> <p><img src="images/newworlds.jpg" alt="Queen Elizabeth holding the globe" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and secondary sources. <span class="bi">Use the copy button</span> to move this material into Canvas as the foundation of your role play assignment.</p> <p>If you want another look at the sources later, you can also find them in the Source Anthology on Canvas.</p> </div> <div class="row marginalia"> <div class="cite"> <div class="row copynotes" id="copyart"> <<if (def $arteqe1) and ($arteqe1 isnot onclick="cpyArt()">Copy text</button> <p>List the sources you used. Use the "copy text" button to place these citations in a "Works Cited" section at the end of your role play response.</p> <div class="copynotes" id="copyarts"> <<if (def $arteqe1) and ($arteqe1 isnot "")>><p>Equiano, Olaudah.<em>Interesting Narrative</em>. In Cal Poly Humboldt, HIST 104, Instructor: Queen. Accessed [date]. https://canvas.humboldt.edu/courses/75559.</p><</if>> <<if (def $artdave1) and ($artdave1 isnot "")>><p>Davis, David Brion.<em>Inhuman Bondage: The Rise and Fall of Slavery in the New World</em>. New York: Oxford University Press, 2006.</p><</if>> <<if (def $arteltise1) and ($arteltise1 isnot "")>><p>Eltis, David. <em>The Rise of African Slavery in the Americas</em> (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000)</p><</if>> <<if (def $artme1) and ($artme1 isnot "")>><p>Morgan, Jennifer. Kerber, Hane Sherron De Hart, Cornelia Huhes Dayton, and Karissa Haugeberg, 11 - 20. Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Renaissance Portal |Renaissance]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Building with Big Rocks</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>What do Stonehenge in England and the Pyramids in Egypt have to do with the neolithic site in Turkey? Well, all three were all constructed by neolithic or bronze age people (as in, humans and not aliens) using massive stones and relatively simple tools. There are interesting similarities in terms of construction methods, materials, the technologies, and the group dynamics involved. Here are a couple of interesting and informative (and short!) videos to help provide some wider context and suggest deeper insights into the feel of a neolithic construction project like Göbekli Tepe.</p> <p>Here's one about <a href="https://www.english-heritage.org.uk/visit/places/stonehenge/history-and-stories/building-stonehenge/" target="_blank">Building Stonehenge</a>from British Heritage.</p> <p>And here's a wonderful page about quarrying and transporting stones for the Egyptian pyramids from <a href="https://aeraweb.org/great-pyramid-quarry/" target="_blank">Ancient Egypt Research Associates.</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>What would it be like to work on a megalithic structure like Göbekli Tepe?</li> <li>What tools and skills would have been valued during the construction?</li> <li>How would this work impact social relationships?</li> <li>Environmental impacts of a project like Göbekli Tepe</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtrockse1" `$gtrockse1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtrocksa1" `$gtrocksa1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtrockse2" `$gtrockse2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtrocksa2" `$gtrocksa2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtrockse3" `$gtrockse3 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h3>Primary Sources</h3> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The pillars of Gobekli Tepe |Pillars]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h3>Secondary Sources</h3> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[A model of Gobekli Tepe |GT Model]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Foragers and agriculturalists at Gobekli Tepe |GT Curry]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Building monoliths and pyramids |Rocks]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-gt]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> <li>[[Back: Göbekli Tepe Scenario |GT]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<set $spartacusExplore1 to "">> <<set $spartacusExplore2 to "">> <<set $pompeiiExplore1 to "">> <<set $pompeiiExplore2 to "">> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row rome1hero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Rome I: From Republic to Empire</h1> <p>Fighting its way to dominance in the Hellenistic World and growing from a republic to an empire, Rome developed a culture characterized by contradiction - venerating tradition but embracing innovation, idolizing the citizen soldier but pauperizing him, elaborately superstitious but immanently pragmatic. Driven by the engine of the unstoppable legions, Rome spread across Europe to become the largest and longest-lasting empire in history.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-rome1.jpg" alt="Roman legion in battle with horses and shields" width="80%">' "rome1-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> <div class="row scenarios"> <div class="row transbox-arch"> <p>[[With Spartacus at the crossroads |Spartacus]]</p> <p>[[Interior decoration at Pompeii |Pompeii]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: Rome: From Republic to Empire</p> <p><img src="images/rome1.jpg" alt="babies nursing from wolf" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero!
