Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire |Rome1]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<set $adrianExplore1 to "">> <<set $adrianExplore2 to "">> <<set $askingExplore1 to "">> <<set $askingExplore2 to "">> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row rome2hero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Did Rome Fall?</h1> <p>Well, that's an impossible question. The story of Rome in late antiquity is not a linear "rise or fall" kind of narrative. It's more of a dynamic transformation So let's get know the Germanic tribes who will transform the Roman Empire into the kingdoms of modern Europe: Franks in France, Anglo-Saxons in England, and so on. It's an apocalyptic landscape littered with the ruins of an empire: crumbling roads and bridges, the odd hoard of old imperial coins, a few glass jars - the remnants of a great civilization that had fallen into memory, reminding everyone that life on earth is transitory and brief, that wealth and power are vain, and eternity awaits in heaven (or in that other place...).</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-rome2.jpg" alt="warriors in chain mail battle with axes and cavalry" width="80%">' "rome2-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> <div class="row scenarios"> <div class="row transbox-arch"> <p class="big">[[A barbarian |Barbarian]]</p> <p class="big">[[An Anglo-Saxon king |AS-king]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: Did Rome Fall?</p> <p><img src="images/rome2.jpg" alt="aqueduct" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and Cal Poly Humboldt HIST 104. Instructor: Queen. Accessed [date].</p><</if>> <<if (def $askinghroe1) and ($askinghroe1 isnot "")>><p><em>Beowulf</em>. Beowulf on Steorarume. https://heorot.dk/beowulf-rede-text.html. Accessed [date].</p><</if>> <<if (def $askingshe1) and ($askingshe1 isnot "")>><p>British Museum. "The Anglo-Saxon Ship Burial at Sutton Hoo." https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/death-and-memory/anglo-saxon-ship-burial-sutton-hoo. Accessed [date].</p><</if>> <<if (def $askingne1) and ($askingne1 isnot "")>><p>Naismith, Rory. <em>Early Medieval Britain, c. 500 - 1000</em>. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2021.</p><</if>> <<if (def $askingoe1) and ($askingoe1 isnot "")>><p>Orton, Peter. "Pagan Myth and Religion." McTurk, R., <em>A Companion to Old Norse-Icelandic Literature</em>. London: Blackwell, 2006. Pp. 302 - 319.</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyAsks()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div>a { text-decoration: bold; } a:hover { text-decoration: underline; } <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> <p>Flavius Aetius is one of several people honored with the title of <em>ultimum Romanorum</em>, "the last of the Roman." But his father was Scythian and he grew up with the barbarians, at the court of Alaric the Visigoth, and even at the court of Attila the Hun. Aetius grew up learning war from Visigoths, Huns, and Romans. No surprise, he became incredibly effective as a military leader, delivering his most famous victory at the head of a confederation of barbarian and Roman forces (who can tell them apart anymore, really?) against the infamous Attila the Hun (the Battle of Catalaunian Fields, 451).</p> <p>Aetius is similar to Stilicho in another respect. Both were slain by the emperors they had served so well. In Aetius' case, his retainers avenged him by stabbing the emperor soon after, while other soldiers stood by and watched - they too, felt more loyalty to Aetius than to the emperor.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <img src="images/aetius.jpg" alt="child's drawing of man on horse with blue armor" width="50%"> </div> </div> <p>Latin guessing game: <em>primus pilus</em> refers to:</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "The rookies of the legion who had not yet served a year.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Good guess, since <em>primus</em> means "first." But, no.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "The rank of first spear centurion">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Correct! A centurion was the leader of a century (a unit of 100 men), and first spear centurion was leader of the most important century of the legion - the one on the front right of the battle formation. Not only did a first spear centurion command this tactically critical position, he was also responsible for guarding the legion's standard and pay chest. The first century of the first cohort was the legion's elite, and its battle leader, first spear centurion, was a uniquely powerful rank within the Roman army.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p>Above: Below (North Africa, second century CE).</p> <p><img src="images/gladiators-mosaic.jpg" alt="mosaic of gladiators in combat" width="70%"></p> <p>Ever heard something (or someone) described as "antediluvian?" expression, "the writing on the wall?" As you probably know, it's from the Bible story about the Persian conquest of Chaldaean Neo-Babylon. The Babylonian king, Belshazzar, sees a disembodied hand writing on the wall. He summons Daniel, the Hebrew prophet, who is able to interpret the strange writing as a sign of immanent doom for the Babylonian dynasty.</p> <p>The Book of Daniel is a late addition to the Hebrew Bible, but that book, along with many earlier biblical tales (like the Tower of Babel or the fall of Jericho), and many other texts from ancient Mesopotamia (like the <em>Epic of Gilgamesh</em>) attest to the importance of walls and towers as symbols of power. Balshezzar's father, Nebuchadnezzar, gloried in the power and prestige of his mighty walls at his royal city of Babylon. To punish his hubris, God transformed him into a beast for a time.</p> <p><img src="images/neb-fields.jpg" alt="man with long hair crawling" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: English Romantic poet and artist William Blake painted this image of the great king transformed into a beast: "Nebuchadnezzar of the fields" (1795).</p> <hr> <p>What's another figure of speech from the story of Daniel?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "into the lion's den">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Yes! The Persian king's evil counselors trick him into throwing Daniel is into a pit of lions, but God miraculously "shuts the lions' mouths," so that Daniel is unharmed. There's poetry in the lines (King James Bible): "My God hath sent his angel, and hath shut the lions' mouths, that they have not hurt me: forasmuch as before him innocency was found in me; and also before thee, O king, have I done no hurt."<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "feet of clay">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Correct. Nebuchadnezzar dreams of a statue with feet of clay, symbolizing his dynasty's shaky foundations.<</replace>><</link>></p> .scenarios { background-image: url("images/hallway.jpg"); background-position: center; background-repeat: no-repeat; background-size: contain; height: 600px; display: flex; flex-direction: column; justify-content: space-between; } .transbox-scenarios { text-align: center; background-color: rgba(255,255, 255, .5); box-shadow: 0 0 10px 5px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); color: white; margin: 50px; } .transbox-scenarios a { font-size: 14pt; font-weight: bold; color: white; } question background color: background-color: #f3fefe; <<set $beginCombat1 to "">> <<set $ironCombat1 to "">> <<set $greeceCombat1 to "">> <<set $rome1Combat1 to "">> <<set $rome2Combat1 to "">> <<set $vikingCombat1 to "">> <<set $knightsCombat1 to "">> <<set $peasCombat1 to "">> <<set $renCombat1 to "">> /* stats */ .stats { line-height: 1; background-color: #e6f9ff; border: 2px solid #004d66; color: black; align-content: center; text-align: center; border-radius: 15px; margin: 20px; padding: 10px; } <p>As you play, you will:</p> <ul> <li><span class="bi">Save evidence</span> from primary and secondary sources. Paste these notes into your role play assignment in Canvas.</li> <li><span class="bi">Fight</span> fallacious statements about history.</li> <li><span class="bi">Explore </span> curious corners of history</li> </ul> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/codex-manesse_joust.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of knights jousting" width="80%">' "begin-combat2">><</link>> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/14pRTSYsukVY-_n1gP46wMUqavyVNAlHz/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This chapter</a> from the book, <em>Moment of Battle</em> provides an in-depth analysis of the Battle of Adrianople, setting it within the broader context of Rome's collapse in the fourth century and its relationship with the advancing barbarian tribes. Overall, the authors argue that the empire's epic loss at Adrianople results from two root causes: 1) the incompetence of the emperor Valens as a military leader, and 2) the fact that by this time, the Roman legions had lost the professionalism, rigorous training, discipline, and resulting tactical maneuverability that had been the foundation of Rome's success in past centuries.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the Romans and the Germans</li> <li>Key decisions and turning-point moments or events</li> <li>Technology, equipment, weapons used by each side</li> <li>Motivations and goals of the leaders on each side of the battle</li> <li>How the battle fits into the broader narrative of "the fall of Rome"</li> </ul> .arches { display: flex; flex-direction: column; justify-content: flex-end; text-align: center; background-image: url("images/hallway.jpg"); background-repeat: no-repeat; background-position: center; background-size: 100%; border: solid 4px black; } function cpyGT() { var copyText = document.getElementById("copygt").innerHTML; copyText.select(); copyText.setSelectionRange(0, 99999); navigator.clipboard.writeText(copyText.value); } <p>Some silly etymology related to this era</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> &#169; Copyright Abigail Queen. June 2024. .question { background-color: #e6f9ff; border: 2px solid #004d66; color: black; border-radius: 15px; margin: 40px; padding: 10px; } inventory grid <div class="container inv"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <<div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> </div> </div> old question/explore passage: <div class="container question"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-5 door"> <img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="300px"> </div> <div class="col-2" id="sourcedoorstext"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore and boost your score, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-5 door"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="300px">' "GT3">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <h3>Question text</h3> <<linkreplace"Correct response">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<set $win to true>>Correct response feedback<</linkreplace>> <<linkreplace"Incorrect response 1">>Incorrect response 1 feedback<</linkreplace>> <<linkreplace"Incorrect response 2">>Incorrect response 2 feedback<</linkreplace>> </div> </div> combat passage: <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Presentism Poltergeist!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/creeper1.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of demon with large ears" width="100%"> </div> <div class="row"> <p>It says: "Many neolithic forager societies rejected the new agraran, sedentary lifestyle because they disapproved of the negative environmental impacts resulting from agriculture and urban growth."</p> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this facile nonsense?</p> <label><<radiobutton "$beginCombat1" "A">> This is false. Forager societies eagerly embraced the innovations of the neolithic revolution.</label> <label><<radiobutton "$beginCombat1" "B">> While some forager societies persisted in their traditional lifestyle during the Neolithic Revolution, there is no evidence that they made this choice out of concern for human impacts on the environment.</label> <label><<radiobutton "$beginCombat1" "C">> This seems plausible, since evidence shows that people were concerned about the environmental impacts of rising human population density in neolithic settlements.</label> </div> </div> <<if $beginCombat1 is "B">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Presentism Poltergeist and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <<linkreplace "Longbow">><<run $Inventory.push("Longbow")>>\<</linkreplace>> <<linkreplace "Chain mail">><<run $Inventory.push("Chain mail")>>\<</linkreplace>> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 victory-link"> <p>Continue on. link to begin</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <<else if $beginCombat1 is "A">> <p>You have been defeated by the Presentism Poltergeist. Better luck next time.</p> <p>Continue on. link to begin</p> <<else if $beginCombat1 is "C">> <p>You have been defeated by the Presentism Poltergeist. Better luck next time.</p> <p>Continue on. link to begin</p> <</if>> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Presentism Poltergeist!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/creeper1.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of demon with large ears" width="100%"> <p>It says: "Many neolithic forager societies rejected the new agraran, sedentary lifestyle because they disapproved of the negative environmental impacts resulting from agriculture and urban growth."</p> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this facile nonsense?</p> <ul> <li><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombat1" "A">> This is false. Forager societies eagerly embraced the innovations of the neolithic revolution.</label></li> <li><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombat1" "B">><<set $Score to $Score + 5>> While some forager societies persisted in their traditional lifestyle during the Neolithic Revolution, there is no evidence that they made this choice out of concern for human impacts on the environment.</label></li> <li><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombat1" "C">> This seems plausible, since evidence shows that people were concerned about the environmental impacts of rising human population density in neolithic settlements.</label></li> </ul> <button to anchor id div spoils below </div> <div class="row" id="spoils"> </div> </div> .combat-box { background-color: #e6f9ff; border: 2px solid #004d66; color: black; align-content: center; text-align: center; border-radius: 15px; margin: 20px; padding: 10px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center; } .transbox h1 h2 p { opacity: 1; background-color: #ffffff; box-shadow: 0 0 10px 5px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); opacity: 0.5; color: black; text-decoration: none; } .table { background-color: #e6f9ff; border: 2px solid #004d66; } .table-intro { color: grey; font-style: italic; font-size: 10pt; } .ss { display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; text-align: center; height: 600px; background-image: url("images/manuscript_Sabina_Sturzu_unsplash.jpg"); background-repeat: no-repeat; background-position: center; background-size: 100%; border: solid 2px black; vertical-align: center; font-size: 20pt; line-height: 200%; } Inventory icon grid <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <<if $longbow is 1>><img src="images/icons/bow.svg" width="50px" height="50px"><</if>> <div class="col"> <<if $helmet is 1>><img src="images/icons/helmet.svg" width="50px" height="50px"><</if>> </div> <div class="col"> <<if $sword is 1>><img src="images/icons/sword.svg" width="50px" height="50px"><</if>> </div> <div class="col"> <<if $treasure is 1>><img src="images/icons/treasure.svg" width="50px" height="50px"><</if>> </div> <div class="col"> <<if $gold is 1>><img src="images/icons/gold.svg" width="50px" height="50px"><</if>> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <div class="col"> <<if $chalice is 1>><img src="images/icons/chalice.svg" width="50px" height="50px"><</if>> </div> <div class="col"> <<if $lyre is 1>><img src="images/icons/lyre.svg" width="50px" height="50px"><</if>> </div> <div class="col"> <<if $shield is 1>><img src="images/icons/shield.svg" width="50px" height="50px"><</if>> </div> <div class="col"> <<if $potion is 1>><img src="images/icons/potion.svg" width="50px" height="50px"><</if>> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <div class="col"> <<if $horse is 1>><img src="images/icons/horse.svg" width="50px" height="50px"><</if>></div> <div class="col"> </div> <div class="col"> </div> <div class="col"> </div> </div> </div> Source notes table <h2>Your evidence & analysis</h2> <p>Here's what you've collected so far. Remember that this assignment requires evidence from at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</p> <div class="container"> <table class="table table-striped table-bordered"> <thead> <tr> <th scope="col" class="top">Source</th> <th scope="col" class="top">Evidence: Detail, quote</th> <th scope="col" class="top">Analysis: Reflections, notes</th> <th scope="col" class="top">Citation</th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <th scope="row" class="table-intro">This will show the title of the source</th> <td class="table-intro">This column will show a quote or detail you collected in the "marginalia" panel</td> <td class="table-intro">This column will show the analysis or notes you paired with this qoute or detail in the "marginalia" panel</td> <td class="table-intro">This column shows how you can cite the source at the end of the sentence.</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td><<print $GTP_e1>></td> <td><<print $GTP_a1>></td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </div> <p>These quotes and notes will be displayed for you on the Victory! screen, along with a copy button so that you can drop them directly into your Canvas assignment as the foundation of this week's Role Play response.</p><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are Spartacus' romantic partner</h1> <p>Italy, 73 BCE</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "spartacus-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "spartacus-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p>It's nearly midsummer and the night is warm, even high on the peak of Mount Vesuvius. Spartacus and his captains sit around a dying fire. They've been here for hours, roasting quail, talking, arguing. A decision must be made. Spartacus wants to lead the slave army north and across the Alps, out of Rome. After all, the legions are busy with Mithridates in the East and Sertorius in the West. The mountain passes are all but deserted. But the others are delirious with victory and plunder. They want to stay in Italy and ravage the countryside. Camped on Vesuvius, surrounded by <<linkappend "the richest farmland in Italy,">><<include "spartacus-link1">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> your slave army grows bigger and richer every day. There are slaves to be liberated and plunder to be taken in every direction. The original farmers of Campania were the citizen soldiers who built Rome generations ago, but most are long gone, crowded out by rich patricians who live in the city and leave their country estates to be worked by slaves.</p> <p>You hear Crixus say (again) that the longer we stay, the stronger we get. He’s not wrong, but you know Spartacus wants to leave. You watch his face in the firelight, and see the memories marching behind his eyes. Back home in Thrace, he fought for the legions. <<linkappend "Romans know the worth of Thracian cavalry, of great horsemen like Spartacus.">><<include "spartacus-link2">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> And Spartacus knows the worth of the legions. The fugitive gladiators and laborers camped down below fight like demons, and last week, they got lucky and caught a small Roman force by surprise and scored an easy victory. But a real legion would roll right over them like a wave up a sandy beach - effortless and inexorable. Then they'd march back to Rome, nailing slaves to crosses along the Appian Way as an example to the rest.</p> <p>From the edge of the firelight, you silently watch their faces as they argue back and forth. They attack and deflect and position and strategize, just like they used to do <<linkappend "in the arena for the entertainment of their masters.">><<include "spartacus-link3">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> They’re using words this time, not blades, but the outcome of this skirmish is life and death nonetheless. Isn’t it always, for slaves of Rome?</p> <p>There’s a moment of silence, and a wolf howls nearby. They all freeze and you feel their gazes slide toward you. Another wolf howls, and another. It’s a sign. Vesuvius is sacred, a place of power. The wolf is sacred to Rome. You are a Thracian priestess, <<linkappend "a Bacchanate who serves Dionysus.">><<include "spartacus-link4">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> These men are lethal killers, but they fear your power. You rise in one smooth, swift movement, and spin, circling the fire, moving rhythmically. Your long robe swirls, your hair flies out. The vines tattooed along your arms seem to slither in the leaping firelight. The snake coiled around your arm bobs its head in the air. No one speaks as you spin and chant, moving slowly around the circle. The circuit complete, you sink down again in your place just within the circle of light now, closer behind Spartacus than you were before. The wolf song ends as you settle your robe around you. The faces around you are tense with religious fear. They won't decide anything now. Tomorrow.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Lots of vocabulary and expressions have come down to us from the Romans. I'm sure you've heard expressions like, "Time flies," (from <em>tempus volat</em>), or "Between a rock and a hard place" (from <em>a fronte pricipicium, a tergo lupi</em>, "A cliff ahead, wolves behind"). These living relics of Rome shouldn't surprise us, since Roman texts and the Latin language have served as common ground for writers from the Middle Ages to the Victorian Era. For centuries, educated people in the West learned Latin, becoming familiar with classic works of Virgil and Cicero and Ovid along the way.</p> <p>So how about the verb "decimate?" Have you ever heard something like, "That team decimated our junior varsity." The way people tend to use the word today is a bit anachronistic. They usually use it to mean "crushed, destroyed, annihilated," while it really meant "to remove 10%." Decimation was a punishment meted out to insubordinate or rebellious legions. They would be required to kill every 10th man. So, it really only meant a 10% loss, but we tend to use it today to mean something more like a major or total destruction.</p> <hr> <p>Does it bug you when people use terms with a historically specific origin, like "decimate," in a way that doesn't match their historical meaning?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Seriously, no. It's nice to know the historical meaning, but I would not lose sleep over this. First world problem.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Totally fair.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Yes. Words have power because people agree on what they mean. If people use words imprecisely, they lose their utility.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>That makes sense. But also, the meaning of words does change constantly and the world does not end. Maybe languages are dynamic systems of signification?<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey (score +2).</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>Hollywood loves gladiators, for obvious reasons. The Romans would totally understand. What I don't understand is why Hollywood consistently decides to get the "thumbs up or thumbs down" thing wrong. You know, when a victorious gladiator has fought his opponent into the ground but hasn't killed them yet, the victor looks up at the patron of the games for the signal to kill the vanquished or let them go. This is where Hollywood goes all sideways on us. In the movies, "thumbs down" means "Death!" ... which makes no sense at all if you think about the logistics of what's going on there.</p> <p><img src="images/spartacus.jpg" alt="gladiators fighting in the arena" width="50%"></p> <p>(Above: From the classic film <em>Spartacus</em> in 1960)</p> <p>To the Romans, thumbs down meant "no," as in, "stop," as in, "don't kill the person you've just defeated." This makes all kinds of sense (of course it does, right?), because the thumbing person is talking to the gladiator who's victorious, so they're giving a simple "green light or red light" message. Thumbs up is for go: "Kill!" Thumbs down is red for stop: "Stop." Easy. Why Hollywood consistently mangles this is beyond my meagre understanding. They're pretty good at what they do, so there must be a reason for it. I'm just not in on the secret, and that's fine.</p> <hr> <p>Why did the Romans enjoy blood sport? Well, they're certainly not alone in human history. Back in Greece, Aristotle argued that violent spectacle was healthy for society becuase it released some of those natural agro energies we humans generate. If we can't sate those dark desires by vicariously experiencing violence at the theater, we'd be more inclined to engage in actual violence against each other. That was Aristotle's thinking. Some of his contemporaries disagreed, arguing that seeing all that blood and violence fed, rather than relieved, people's readiness to commit violence. Does this sound just like 21st-century debates about violent games and movies? What's your opinion? Does viewing violence sate our natural need for such things, leaving us more tranquil? Or does viewing violence simply make us more violent?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Aristotle was right. Vicariously experiencing violence serves as a safe outlet for those natural urges, reducing individuals' need to perpetrate violence themselves.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Maybe?<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Aristotle got it all wrong. Viewing violence desensitizes and dehumanizes people, leading them them to think violent thoughts, which leads them to carry out violent actions.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>Maybe? Probably?<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt:</span>The stakes could hardly be higher. Death (a good one if you're unreasonably lucky) on one hand, and freedom on the other. What do you think Spartacus should decide to do at this moment? Leave Italy as soon as possible? Stay and build a bigger rebellion?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>What are your personal goals? What do you hope for in the future? How has your experience as a slave influenced your mindset, hopes, fears?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>If you have children or other family to care for</li> <li>Your network of relationships within the community of fugitive slaves</li> <li>Your experience in slavery</li> <li>Your physical aptitudes and limitations</li> <li>Your knowledge and skills</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Roman depictions of slavery |gladiators]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Plutarch's account of the rebellion |plutarch-spartacus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[A slave rebellion in Sicily |sicily-slaves]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Spartacus' rebellion |strauss]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Roman slave trade |bradley]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-s]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Rome: Republic to Empire |Rome1]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<set $PlayerName to "">> <<set $Score to 0>> <<set $Inventory to []>>[[About]]<<set $defenceExplore1 to "">> <<set $defenceExplore2 to "">> <<set $hastingsExplore1 to "">> <<set $hastingsExplore2 to "">> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row vikingshero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>The Viking Age</h1> <p>Key developments of the early medieval period include the birth of Islam, the Vikings, the unification (and conquest) of England, and the emergence of modern France and the Holy Roman Empire under Charlemagne. What a busy time! For now, let's focus on Vikings.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-viking.jpg" alt="illuminated manuscript illustration of ship full of warriors with spears and shields" width="80%">' "viking-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> <div class="row scenarios"> <div class="row transbox-arch"> <p class="big">[[A Viking defence plan |Defence]]</p> <p class="big">[[The Norman Conquest of England |Hastings]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: The Viking Age</p> <p><img src="images/darkages.jpg" alt="helmet" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Austin: University of Texas Press, 1964.</p><</if>> <<if (def $hastbte1) and ($hastbte1 isnot "")>><p>"Explore the Bayeux Tapestry Online," Bayeux Museum, https://www.bayeuxmuseum.com/en/the-bayeux-tapestry/discover-the-bayeux-tapestry/explore-online/. Accessed [date].</p><</if>> <<if (def $hastwe1) and ($hastwe1 isnot "")>><p>Wood, Michael. <em>In Search of the Dark Ages</em>. New York: Facts on File Publications, 1987.</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyHasts()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <div class="row"> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, a witch hunt is coming.</h1> <p>A rural village, c. 1600</p> </div> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "witch-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "witch-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row scenario"> <p><em>Note: The subject of this role play scenario is a real person. Thomasine Hall was raised in England in the early 1600s as a girl. As a teenager, they assumed a male gender identity, joined a mercenary company, and fought on the continent before immigrating to the Virginia colony as an indentured servant, sometimes with a male identity, and sometimes female (which considerably puzzled colonial leadership).</em></p> <p><em>And now, back to the role play scenario ... </em></p> <hr> <p>A storm is coming. You felt it in the heavy air as you rode toward the village this evening. The willows and elms writhed and heaved in the wind like souls roiling in hellfire. The ripe wheat rippled across the fields, an eerie, luminous green beneath the dark, streaming clouds.</p> <p>The rain caught you on the road before you reached the clothier's house. Now, <<linkappend "your finely-embroiedered clothing">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include witch-link3>><</linkappend>> is spread out to dry around the hearth. You savor the warmth of the fire, idly rubbing your sword with an oilcloth, sitting quietly with your friend in the companionable silence of old friendship. He's a tailor as well as a clothier, and he's fascinated by the seed pearls on your new doublet, and the stuffing from your pantaloons. They hang limply from a chair now, eviscerated and deflated, their stuffing strewn across the hearth and steaming in the heat, the satin slashing glowing softly in the firelight. Your friend is sketching a new design on a scrap of paper, glancing at your finery for inspiration. A taste for fine cloth and fashion was what brought you together as children. You sip your ale and lean back against the wall, listening to the rain. It's good to be home, safe and warm, your horse fed and dry in the clother's barn. You should sleep, but you know this feeling of safety is an illusion. The storm outside is nothing compared to the storm that's rising in the village. You felt it as you rode through the market square this evening, not quite deserted in the twilight: the furtive glances, the timing of the silences, the muttering, the too-loud declarations of loyalty to a friend or to God.</p> <p>When you asked the clothier for the local news just now, he shook his head. The neighboring village had half its ripe corn trampled by mercenaries. It's nearly June. No time to try for a second harvest. <<linkappend "Some houses were burned and a few people died.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include witch-link4>><</linkappend>> Then, a few days ago, two women in your village gave birth to dead children. Your mother was at both births. She's been a widow for twenty years and lives quite comfortably on the outskirts of the village, hiring laborers to farm her few acres of arable, renting her pasture to neighbors. Everyone knows she has special knowledge and special powers. They come to her for help with illness or death or birth or any number of the inevitable pains and humiliations of life in a human body. She is one of the "wise folk" or "cunning folk." Every village has one or two.</p> <p>Your mother is the reason you came home. Filial duty. And you actually like the old crone. You always learn something from her stories, once you sort out what's real from what she imagined. It was good to see the miller, too, and a few others. You should leave now, but you're worried about your mother. In hard times, more is expected of people like her. The impossible is expected - like bringing stillborn babies to life. The families will need someone to blame. They want to avoid the appearance of guilt, of deserving such punishments from God. The village will need someone to blame, for the same reason. They will reach for order and justice in this senseless world where <<linkappend "innocent babies die before drawing a breath.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include witch-link1>><</linkappend>> They need someone to blame.</p> <p>Once they go looking for witches, they always find them. They'll be looking for anyone outside the usual, anyone different. And you are ... different. Your name is Thomas now, and you've spent the last decade in Germany and the Low Countries serving as a mercenary. But you grew up here as Thomasine in long hair and dresses, standing with the women in church, making lace and selling it in that market square. (You still make lace when you're short of cash - no uncommon occurrence in the life of a mercenary.) But to most people, you are a man. A few folk here, like your old friend, the clothier, remember you as a little girl. They aren't bothered that you're different in this way. But that difference will be a deadly danger when they start looking for witches.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Etymologies are interesting. They can also be powerful. Sometimes people point to a word's origin or history as a persuasive, or even a conclusive, Q.E.D. case-closed piece of evidence in support of their argument or agenda. It's nothing new. Back in 1487 when the woman-hating (he was working through a bad breakup, actually) priest Heinrich Kramer and James Sprenger first published a book about how to find, torture, and kill witches (<em>Malleus Maleficarum</em>, or "The Hammer of the Witches"), they supported their argument that "women are often witches because women are evil" with false etymologies (and mis-quotations of the Bible, and all kinds of shoddy scholarship and bad logic that would be funny if the book hadn't helped kill and torture so many people). For instance, they pointed to the Latin word for woman, <em>femina</em>. "See!?" they said, "The very <em>word</em> "woman" comes from the words for "faith" (<em>fe</em>) and "less" (<em>minus</em>. So of course women are naturally faithless and evil. Ergo, women are witches! Q.E.D."</p> <hr> <p>"Weird" is an ordinary enough word, but there are witches in its history. We can find it way back in <em>Beowulf</em>, where Old English <em>wyrd</em> denoted "fate." Fate was important in these early Germanic societies, especially their ideas about masculinity and honor. As Beowulf himself explains it, "Fate will often save a man, if his courage holds." It's a kind of grim and stoic fatalism, a reliance on one's own courage in the face of irresistible and immutable fate.</p> <p>This is where the witches come in. Shakespeare's 1606 play, <em>Macbeth</em>, features witches who foretell the future. Shakespeare calls them "the 'weïrd' or 'weyard' sisters. Since "weird," like its ancestor Old English <em>wyrd</em> meant "fate or destiny," it makes sense to give this name to fortune-telling witches. Over the years, especially in the early nineteenth century when romanticism rekindled people's interest in Shakespeare, these weird sisters" transformed the meaning of the word in our language. People began using "weird" as we do today, to mean "odd," rather than in the Old English sense of "fate."</p> <p>Do you think the Englis noun "witch" is related to the English pronoun "which?"</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Negative. They're just homophones with no linguistic connection.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Just so. Like creek and creak or bare and bear, and many others.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Probably.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>It does look that way, but in this case, they are not linguistically related, even though they sound the same. Lots of words are like that (for instance, piece and peace, or knot and not).<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>Dan Brown's mass market thriller, <em>The Da Vinci Code</em> was enjoyed by millions of readers and vieweres in the early 2000s. Its delicious tale of conspiracies involving the Templar Knights, the Holy Grail, and the Vatican popularized the (quite imaginary) idea that the Catholic Church orchestrated the early modern witch trials in a deliberate attempt to enforce the patriarchal order and oppress "free-thinking women" (in the words of Brown's fictional characters). This narrative fits so neatly into popular culture today, that it has had a significant impact on most people's understanding of the witch hunts, in spite of the fact that it has little relation to the historical record or the findings of historians. As we've learned in this class (I hope!), women were active as aggressors in witch hunts, and men were often victims. The man vs. woman dichotomy does not fit the historical record. But it certainly sells paperbacks and movies...</p> <p>It's interesting to see these dynamics at work. When an interpretation of history (usually a big-picture metanarrative yielding convenient and feel-good "lessons") meshes with prevailing popular beliefs, it sticks and has power, even when it is not accepted by the academic community.</p> <hr> <p>We still use the term "witch hunt" today, typically as a pejorative term for unjust, illogical, biased attacks. Do you remember hearing the term recently, maybe in the news?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Yes, definitely.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Me too.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "No.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>I bet you will hear it soon, and now it will have deeper meaning since you know the historical background.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What will you do? Stay in the village or leave? Why?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>How will the nonbinary nature of your gender identity impact your situation in a rural village witch hunt?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your skills, knowledge, resources (such as money, weapons, transportation, status and social connections).</li> <li>Current social and economic conditions in your village (e.g., prosperity or hardship, stability or fragmentation).</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the role play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <p><span class="bi">You do not need to read every source listed here.</span> Once you have learned enough to dream up an answer to the role play prompts, you're done.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Images of witches |witch-images]]</li> <hr> <li>[[An English witch trial |scott]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Early modern masculinity |roper]]</li> <hr> <li>[[A non-binary person |thomasine]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-w]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance Portal |Renaissance]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $alexExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Alexandria]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Macedonia was the dominant Greek power during the:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$alexExploreQ1" "A">>Hellenistic period.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$alexExploreQ1" "B">>Mycaenean period.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$alexExploreQ1" "C">>Archaic period.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "alex-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($alexExploreQ1 is "A") and ($alexExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $alexExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Potion">><<set $potion to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Alexandria]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Alexandria]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $alexExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Alexandria]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Alexander the Great's military successes did NOT result from:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$alexExploreQ2" "A">>his army's high morale.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$alexExploreQ2" "B">>innovative tactics.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$alexExploreQ2" "C">>his army's numerical superiority.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "alex-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($alexExploreQ2 is "C") and ($alexExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $alexExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lance">><<set $lance to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Alexandria]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Alexandria]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>The conquests of Alexander the Great and the successor states they established, amplified the expansion of Hellenistic culture begun with Greek colonial expansion in the Archaic Period. Today, ruins of Hellenistic architecture like the hippodrome and theater below survive throughout the Middle East, North Africa, and the whole Mediterranean region.</p> <p>Greek colonial expansion:</p> <p><img src="images/map-greek-colonies.jpg" alt="map of Greek coastal expansion around Mediterranean" width="100%"></p> <p>The Hellenistic "successor states" which filled in Alexander's Empire in the third century BCE</p> <p><img src="images/map-successors.jpg" alt="map of Greek coastal expansion around Mediterranean" width="100%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>The symposium - the ancient Greek tradition of a dinner party centered around philosophical and literary debates - was one of the features of Hellenistic culture that spread with Alexander's conquests. The ceramic art below, from fifth-century BCE Athens, shows a symposium.</p> <p><img src="images/symposium.jpg" alt="ceramic art showing figures reclining and feasting" width="80%"></p> <p>The conquests of Alexander the Great and the successor states they established, amplified the expansion of Hellenistic culture begun with Greek colonial expansion in the Archaic Period. Today, ruins of Hellenistic architecture like the hippodrome and theater below survive throughout the Middle East, North Africa, and the whole Mediterranean region.</p> <p>Below: the Hellenistic "successor states" which replaced Alexander's short-lived empire in the third century BCE</p> <p><img src="images/map-successors.jpg" alt="map of Greek coastal expansion around Mediterranean" width="100%"></p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I would try to reason with my friends' criticisms to see both sides of our ideas. While he preaches on Epicurus's teachings, he fails to see that we need to build a stronger government. I believe him to be too idealistic, as he is blissfully unaware of the struggles that we face around us. He preaches that we need to be kind towards each other and that by living a more simplistic lifestyle will we achieve a fulfilling life. Being a believer in stoicism I believe that everyone has a role to play. While the ideology of being nice to one another is attractive, it is flawed. When one treats everyone as their friend it is only a matter of time before one “friend” begins to demand more from others. I am sure we can all agree that we have experienced an overbearing friend who demands we cater to their needs. This is why my friends' ideas are flawed. This is the reason why we should not allow a system of government like this to exist. Power corrupts and it would only be a matter of time before one “friend” controls all.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>My ideal political system would contain Epicurean and Stoic values because of their views on death, honor, society, and the self. The focus would be mainly on how to live a fair life and be good to others while we are alive, and not to focus on the afterlife because death means nothing to us (Epicurus). It is trivial to lament over death when there are opportunities to be the smartest, well rounded, just version of yourself everyday. The just man enjoys a peace of mind (Epicurus) because there are no regrets or worries when you do the right thing. I would also incorporate the Stoic values of not being driven to anger or irrationality easily by having self control.</p> <p>I would tell him that is a careless and bleak view of life.The idea of power corrupts is similar to Quintilian’s view on homosexuality, that older boys can corrupt younger boys (Hubbard, Homosexuality) because there is always a chance of corruption in any power dynamic, whether it be love or politics. With these Epicurean and Stoic beliefs, it is possible to remain disciplined, just, and difficult to be swayed by material possessions. Riches can not come with us when we die, and we will one day cease to exist, so what is the point of derailing a good life.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Epicureans believe in simplicity. Death to them is "the end". There is nothing after death, it is nothing to them. They believe that there is pleasure in many things, but simple things, there is no need to be excessive. And sometimes there is pleasure in pain and that pain is required to feel the pleasure.</p> <p>My partner is very adherent to Epicureanism, which is fine, he can believe what he wants to believe. I am not against this, but I do not think that there are only certain things to live and look for in life. And that is why I am writing this treatise about the ultimate purpose of life.</p> <p>Zeno's Stoicism is the belief that we should live the way the natural world intended. And in Epictetus it says, "In particular, its emphasis on a universal natural order governed by a divine plan greatly influenced the later development of both Roman imperial law and Christian thought." Stoicism has great influence and many follow this belief.</p> <p>Even though I am not against Epicureanism I do believe that it is incomplete and naive. I believe we should live according to nature which will help us align ourselves with reason and virtue, they key to inner peace and a good life. And my ideal political system would be one that runs by the ways of Stoicism. Living in a natural order to achieve inner peace and finally a good life.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Me and my partner are always arguing about our philosophical views and how the government should be run. He believes in Epicureanism which means that he thinks his biggest need is pleasure which I find to be self destructive. If all you’re concerned with is pleasure then how will you be able to make the hard choices that life throws at you. My belief, stoicism, is focused more on self control and how to focus on what we as an individual can do to improve our lives. “In our power are thought, impulse, will to get and will to avoid, and, in a word, everything which is our own doing.” I think this would be a good way to structure a government because it would be centered around what is realistic for our town rather than reaching for the stars and trying to become a new empire. I enjoy a simple life and thinking about what is in my control and would rather not have to worry about war and death and everything that comes with major ambition. One thing I think should be a staple in our new government is symposiums. “Symposium, or drinking party, was a locus of homosexual admiration, courtship, and even sexual acts” and while it kind of goes against my beliefs, it’s one of the one times me and my partner agree because it’s all about pleasure. If our government was something like that I think I’d live a very happy and prosperous life</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I’ve been thinking a lot about what my partner has been saying to me about his thoughts on what it means to live a good life. And maybe he’s right that I do all this thinking only to save myself from complete boredom. However, I feel like part of being able to live a good life goes hand and hand with being at peace mentally and physically in the society you live in. I’ve been pondering what my ideal political system would look like to bring up my ideas with my fellow philosophical comrades for next week’s symposium which is also a “drinking party, [which] was a locus of homosexual admiration, courtship, and even sexual acts”(Hubbard, "Homosexuality"). They are truly great fun and I love getting to mingle with my partner in that setting. Anyways, I’m trying to think of what kind of political system I would enjoy to live in and I have come up with the following ideas. I think that power does truly corrupt, it makes you greedy and clouds your judgment so I think the entire dream government would completely focus on the internal good of its people. Not concerned with expanding territory or material wealth or getting anything more that we do not need to survive. I agree with Zeno’s sentiment that “for the moment you must utterly remove the will to get; for if you will to get something not in man’s power you are bound to be unfortunate;”(Epictetus). My dream town everyone would be in living in a state of serenity because they know that everyone is doing things for the benefit of each other and the town. Instead of exhausting effort putting together a military we would focus on making sure we have pure drinking water, fertile soil, and safety among the citizens. There would be town meetings bi-monthly where we would all congregate and discuss the happenings of the town. There would be one elected mediator which would switch meeting to meeting. It all sounds great in theory but I know it’s not realistic and my partner will undoubtedly make fun of me for it but oh well.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>“How many times do I have to tell you, death is nothing to us; we live our lives and then eventually we die and become nothing. All of this talk of virtue and good leadership, is nothing but you stroking your ego.” my partner retorts. “Trying to become renowned will not solve your own insecurities.”</p> <p>“But it isn't,” I insist. “If the soul purpose of life was just for us to wait for it to end, then we wouldn’t spend all of this time writing and learning. Should we try to leave our mark on the world, or at the very least try to better society for our fellow man. The only thing that I am insecure about is our future, as greeks.”</p> <p>I look at my partner to see if anything I said struck a chord with them. “Even you must admit, the Epicureanism that you are, would agree that injustice is wrong, in so far as how it impacts others shouldn’t we try to do something about that?”</p> <p>My partner gives thought to my words.“Well, you are right, but even if you could, what could be done? No system of government will ever be perfect, or good enough to stop injustice. And if we made a government strong enough to control its citizens to prevent all injustice, the government itself would have to act in unjust ways” my partner says as a matter of fact.</p> <p>“You are right, but that doesn’t mean we shouldn’t try! What if we had a society whererather than one ruler there were many rulers. As Theophrastus argues no good comes from having just one ruler. What if we had some sort of representative government? Where the people made decisions and we chose what was right for ourselves as a collective rather than letting the whims of one man be the deciding factor for what is right and wrong.” I look at my partner's eyes full of passion and energy “wouldn’t that be a better world?”</p> <p>My partner sighs “It would but you are hopelessly idealistic, you know that right? Also don’t go thinking you have won this debate now.”</p> <p>I smile at them “I wouldn’t dream of it.”</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Looking at society through a detached lens can often help us compare and contrast the differences and similarities between modern day society and ancient times. We often tend to look at the past as other worldly, with customs and culture being strange and skewed from what we understand humans to be. But by treating our modern day with the same attitude that we treat history, we can become personal and knowledgeable with the inner workings and day to day feelings of those living in more ancient times. As a male philosopher studying at Alexandria I am higher up on the class system, meaning that close companionship with an equal, even male, is a perfectly respectable relationship. I could never have such intelligent conversations with a woman, as women are obviously missing half of their inferior brains and are unable to keep up with my sex's superior intellect. To put it simply, our relationship is societally accepted because we both have beards. Big, luscious beards that will never ever go out of style... (Hubbard, "Homosexuality") </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Some of the features of my Ideal political system for this time would have to be equality. I plan on creating a system were people wouldn't be judged for the sexual orientation, race, gender, and any other cruel way that people throughout history have discriminated against one another for. Instead I will build a system where there is no king or any dictator instead my system will be democratic. Where people vote who they would want to be in charge. In the text from Epicurus it states, “Ask not that events should happen as you will, but let your will be that events should happen as they do, and you shall have peace.” With this quote in mind, I will try and create a system that will bring peace among my people. For this shall have them happy and bring peace and prosperity among them for generations to come. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Plato, <em>Apology</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>With <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fAgEueC45hO1bTwueni7wAaivTLitJhf/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank"><em>The Apology</em></a>, Plato purports to reproduce the speech made by Socrates in self-defense during his trial for "impiety" and "corrupting the youth" in 399. Socrates' trial and execution occurred after Athens had lost the Peloponnesian War and was convulsed by violent civil strife as Spartan-supported oligarchic regimes vied for power with Athenian democratic factions. Plato was Socrates' student, and recorded the teachings of Socrates, who did not himself leave a written record. Plato was present at Socrates' trial. Xenophon also wrote a (quite different) account of the trial and speech, but was not present himself.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Key themes of the political, ideological, and cultural conflicts in Athens during the late Peloponnesian Wars</li> <li>Gender norms, especially power dynamics and ideals of masculinity</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoce1" `$periclessoce1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoca1" `$periclessoca1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoce2" `$periclessoce2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoca2" `$periclessoca2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoce3" `$periclessoce3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoca3" `$periclessoca3 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoce4" `$periclessoce4 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoca4" `$periclessoca4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Pericles' famous "Funeral Oration" |funeral-oration]]</li> <hr> <li>[[A popular, bawdy comedy about the Peloponnesian War |lysistrata]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Socrates' trial and execution |apology]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Military history of the Peloponnesian War |warry-sicily]]</li> <hr> <li>[[About Thucydides' account of Sicily and Alcibiades |nichols-thucydides]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Done collecting material?</h2> <p>Your notes from this source are saved. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pericles Scenario |Pericles]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $artExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Artist]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>While Columbus was an accomplished and experienced navigator and cartographer, his "Enterprise of the Indies" was flawed by:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$artExploreQ1" "A">>a miscalculation of the size of the Earth.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$artExploreQ1" "B">>his assumption (widespread in his day) that the Earth is flat.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$artExploreQ1" "C">>his goal of converting the Native Americans to Catholicism, while asking for sponsorship from a Protestant king.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "art-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($artExploreQ1 is "A") and ($artExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $artExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Artist]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Artist]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $artExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Artist]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Question</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$artExploreQ2" "A">>Permission to sin without punishment</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$artExploreQ2" "B">>Permission to skip church attendance</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$artExploreQ2" "C">>A waiver of the penance they needed to do </label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "art-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($artExploreQ2 is "C") and ($artExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $artExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Lance">><<set $lance to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Artist]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Artist]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>This is you.</p> <p><img src="images/carracci-clock.jpg" alt="African woman holding a clock" width="80%"></p> <p>Italian painter Annibale Carracci created this portrait of an African woman holding a clock c. 1583. Its subject and original context continue to puzzle art historians.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Renaissance European depictions of Native American and African women typically commented on the differences with European gender norms, especially social mores surrounding clothing, manners, sexuality and marriage, and gendered division of labor.
