Gender norms were centrally embedded in developing western ideas of race.</p> <p><img src="images/debry-african-women.jpg" alt="sketches of African women" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: Artist Theodor de Bry produced this engraving of African women in 1604. De Bry himself never traveled to the Americas, Africa, or Asia. Instead, he produced engraving plates based on the paintings and sketches of people who <em>had</em> been on European voyages to those places. Then, de Bry printed his engravings and sold many copies of books about European travels to the newly-discovered Americas, to Africa, and to Asia. His work exerted a powerful influence on Europeans' developing sense of "western" identity, and their ideas about other cultures around the world.</p> <p><img src="images/john-white-woman.jpg" alt="painting of Native American woman wearing skirt of animal skin" width="50%"></p> <p>Above: In 1585, English artist John White visited the Carolina coast with the ill-fated Roanoke expedition, and painted numerous images of the indigenous people he met there. Fortunately for historians, White chose to return to England with paintings like tihs one, while the other Roanoke settlers stayed behind and were eaten by aliens. (That's actually what happened. Just ask the internet.)</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>The printing press was the machinery that powered much/most of the progressive, innovative, disruptive discourse of the Renaissance. It began when German Protestant reformers invented and used the printing press to disseminate the Bible in the vernacular, and their criticisms of the Catholic church. As the Renaissance progressed, people used the same technology to push other agendas. For instance, when Spanish friar De las Casas spoke out in opposition to Spain's brutal treatment of Native Americans, Protestants picked up his reports of Spanish attrocities and wove them into their imperialist narratives with a propaganda project remembered by historians as "The Black Legend." The Black Legend used De las Casas' humanitarian messages for their own purpose, to present a contrast bewteen Catholic Spain as a uniquely brutal, evil empire on one hand, and the more progressive, liberal ideology of Protestant regimes of Elizabethan England and the Dutch Republic. Of course, the sad reality is that Protestant and Catholic kingdoms alike represented doom and disease for Native Americans. But the printing press was a powerful weapon in the arsenal of Protestant reformers who wanted to demonize Catholicism.</p> <p><img src="images/blacklegend.jpg" alt="cutting off hands and feet" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: One of Theodor de Bry's graphic scenes from his illustration of De Las Casas' book about Spanish atrocities in the New World (1590s).</p> <p><img src="images/reformation-pope.jpg" alt="caricature of demonic figure holding staff with ego sum papa title" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: The image on the left is one of the earliest Protestant prints, from sixteenth-century Paris. The version on the right is a later adaptation of the same motif, depicting the pope as a monstrous, predatory demon. (Remember the Babylon symbolism from our very first role play unit? Here it is again! The tower of Babel on the pope's head links back to the old symbolism of Babylon, and represents the worldliness and corruption of the Catholic church.)</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>In this role play scenario, I have imagined Artemisia Gentileschi running a successful portrait workshop like that of Raphael in the sixteenth century. I've placed her at the court of Grand Duchess Christina of Tuscany. In the 1620s, Christina's court was a hub of intellectual discourse with visitors and correspondents like Galileo Galilei. It was also a girl power nexus, ruled by the well-educated Christina (whose mother, Catherine de Medici, Queen of France, was one of the most powerful women in renaissance Europe) and her daughter in law, Maria.</p> <p>In reality, Artemisia Gentileschi is one of the masters of baroque art. While she did become the first woman in the prestigious Florentine Academy of the Arts, her career suffered greatly from patriarchal forces of oppresssion during her lifetime. Her paintings include the scene below, depicting the biblical heroine Judith beheading Holofernes - a classic Old Testament story everyone would have known in 17th-century Italy. But not many people would have known about Artemisia. The painting below was rejected by its patron and hidden away. As a young woman, Artemisia was sexually assaulted by her painting tutor. During the ensuing trial, she was tortured. He was acquitted.</p> <p><img src="images/judith-gentileschi.jpg" alt="two women killing a man with a sword" width="80%"></p> <p>As a woman, Artemisia stood outside the networks of patronage and institutions that supported male artists like Caravaggio. His version of Judith and Holofernes, below, was much admired and his career flourished in spite of a lifestyle of (lethal) violence and continual debt.</p> <p><img src="images/judith-caravaggio.jpg" alt="woman killing a sleeping man with a sword while another woman looks on" width="80%"></p> </div>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "art-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Renaissance Rewrite |renaissance-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "art-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Renaissance Rewrite |renaissance-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "art-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Renaissance Rewrite |renaissance-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "art-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Renaissance Rewrite |renaissance-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "art-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Renaissance Rewrite |renaissance-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><<if $askingExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |AS-king]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Wergild was:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$askingExploreQ1" "A">>a way to end a blood feud.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$askingExploreQ1" "B">>the original werewolf legend.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$askingExploreQ1" "C">>a core feature of Justinian's law code.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "asking-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($askingExploreQ1 is "A") and ($askingExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $askingExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Lance">><<set $lance to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |AS-king]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |AS-king]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $askingExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |AS-king]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>As Roman power receded, the Germanic Franks ________ the Celtic inhabitants of Gaul.</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$askingExploreQ2" "A">>were defeated by</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$askingExploreQ2" "B">>conquered and displaced</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$askingExploreQ2" "C">>conquered and integrated with</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "asking-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($askingExploreQ2 is "C") and ($askingExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $askingExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Right! In contrast with the Germanic people who migrated to Roman Birtain, <em>conquering and displacing</em> the native Celtic Britons.</p> <p>A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |AS-king]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |AS-king]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>Old English poetry revels in descriptions of "hall joys," with many poetic expressions for the hall, including mead hall, treasure hall, feast hall, gold hall. "Hall joys" are seen as one of the gifts a generous lord should give to his warband: music and songs, warmth, light, food and drink, a place at the benches with your comrades, gifts of treasure and valuable war gear. The high hall was also a safe, warm place to sleep (unless Grendel comes) in an otherwise cold and dangerous world. Here are a few examples:</p> <p>In <em>Beowulf</em>, Hrothgar's great hall Heorot epitomizes the motif of hall joys provided by a generous lord to his successful warband (although, the poet can't resist predicting its grim fate: destruction in future feuds): "Then to Hrothgar, success in battle was given, honor in war, so that his thanes served him eagerly, and the warband grew into a mighty troop. It came into Hrothgar's mind that he should have a hall built, a grand mead hall which men would tell of forever. Within, to young and old, he would share out all that God had given him (except the common land and the lives of men). Then I heard he commanded many people to work on building this best of royal halls, and he named it Heorot ("hart"). His words were trusted everywhere, and he did not lie when he boasted of what he would do: He gave out rings and treasure at the feast. The hall towered, high and horn-gabled. It awaited the cruel surges of hateful flames, when the furious sword-hate of son-in-law and father-in-law, arising from deadly hatred, would awaken - but that time had not yet come."</p> <p><img src="images/longhall1.jpg" alt="long timber hall" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: This reconstruction of a Viking Age long hall at Sagnlandet Lejre in Denmark resembles what an Anglo-Saxon ruler's hall would have looked like.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>While Old English poets delighted in portraying "hall joys" of warmth and friendship and treasure and song, they frequently reflected on the transience of all such earthly delights. One of their favorite themes was the inexorability of fate, the fact that none of us can control what the future holds for us, and even great civilizations like Rome are eventually brought low by the power of fate and time. They saw Roman ruins all around them, seeming to prove the wisdom of this view. Here's an example of this them from the elegaic poem, <em>The Wanderer</em>, in which the speaker bemoans his status as an exile. "Hall joys" represent the opposite of miserable exile: "Where has the horse gone? Where has the man gone? Where have the treasure-givers gone? Where has the place of banquets gone? Where are the joys of the hall? Alas the gleaming cup! Alas the armoured warrior! Alas the prince's glory! How the time has passed away, grown dark under the helm of the night, as if it never were. There stands now in the track of the dear thane a wall, wondrously high, adorned with serpent-patterns. The might of ash-spears snatched away noble men, weapons greedy for carnage, notorious fate, and storms beat the stone-heaps, falling snowstorm binds the earth, winter's chaos, then the darkness comes, night-shadows spread gloom, sending from the north fierce hailstorms to the terror of men. All is hardship in the earthly kingdom; the operation of fate changes the world under the heavens. Here, wealth is transitory; here a friend is transitory; here a man is transitory; here a kinsman is transitory. All this earth's foundation will become empty." (Text and translation from Elaine Treharne, ed., <em>Old and Middle English c. 890 - c. 1450: An Anthology</em> (London: Blackwell, 2009).)</p> <p><img src="images/wanderer.jpg" alt="text from above" width="100%"></p> <p>If you know your <em>Lord of the Rings</em>, and you think this sounds like Theoden's speech at Helm's Deep ("Who am I, Gamil? Where are the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?"), you are right. Tolkein lifted it exactly from this poem. The whole Kingdom of Rohan is inspired by Anglo-Saxon England. Below: Theoden at Helm's Deep.</p> <p><iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/xVEYcTyj1Do?si=-iEP_9JRB9kyOlxN" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>The motif of "the lady with the mead cup" was beloved by Old English poets. In <em>Beowulf</em>, for instance: "Wealhtheow went forth, Hrothgar’s queen, mindful of customs; Adorned with gold, she greeted the men in the hall, Then that courteous wife offered the full cup, First to the guardian of the East-Danes’ kingdom, Bid him be merry at his beer-drinking, Beloved by his people; with pleasure he received the feast and cup, victorious king. The lady of the Hemings then went about to young and old, gave each his portion of the precious cup … "</p> <p>And here's the theme in an Old English poem known as <em>Maxims I</em>, a collection of gnomic verses about "the way things are" in this world: "The woman must excel as one cherished among her people, and be buoyant of mood, keep confidences, be open-heartedly generous with horses and with treasures; in deliberation over the mead, in the presence of the troop of companions, she must always and everywhere greet first the chief of those princes and instantly offer the chalice to her lord’s hand, and she must know what is prudent for them both as rulers of the hall."</p> <p>In both of these examples (which are representative), we see that the women are more than waitresses. They take an active role in the political scene (an impression clearly and repeatedly reinforced by evidence outside of poetry (in chronicles and legal documents, for instance). A variety of evidence clearly shows that elite women were powerful players in the early medieval game of thrones.</p> <p>But "peace weaver" was one side of this coin. The other side was "inciter of violence." Ever wonder where the term "to egg someone on" comes from? It makes no sense, right? Well, it's not "egg" from our word "egg." It's from the Old Norse verb <em>eggja,</em> which means to "whet, to put an edge to a weapon," and the Old English noun <em>ecg</em>, "edge." Poetry, chronicles, and sagas from the early Germanic world frequently depict women as inciters of violence, "egging on" their menfolk by aggressively reminding them of revenge obligations or unsettled feuds. Like, "Get off the couch and go kill someone. Your list of people you're supposed to be killing is so long, why are you sitting here?"</p> <p>There's even an intriguing connection way back to Roman times, in the first-century account of Germanic tribes written by Tacitus. He notes that German women came to war with their men, not to fight in the front lines, but to yell at them from the sidelines and remind them of what would happen to their women if the other side was victorious. Here's what Tacitus says in <em>Germania</em> (c. 98): “Tradition says that armies already wavering and giving way have been rallied by women who, with earnest entreaties and bosoms laid bare, have vividly represented the horrors of captivity, which the Germans fear with such extreme dread on behalf of their women, that the strongest tie by which a state can be bound is the being required to give, among the number of hostages, maidens of noble birth. They even believe that the sex has a certain sanctity and prescience, and they do not despise their counsels, or make light of their answers.” Maybe the early medieval oral traditional poetry preserves something of these old gender norms recorded by Tacitus centuries earlier. Or maybe not. What do you think?</p> <p><img src="images/mead-cup.jpg" alt="silver female figures" width="50%"></p> <p>Above: These silver Viking Age ornaments present women carrying a horn or cup - a common motif that resonates with these depictions of women in the poetry.</p> <p>Below: Another example of this "lady with a mead cup" motif, from a memorial stone from Viking Age Sweden. In the top panel, Odin is shown on his eight-legged horse, Sleipnir, receiving a mead cup from a valkyrie.</p> <p><img src="images/gotland-odin.jpg" alt="painted stone carving of Viking ship and mythological figures" width="50%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>These are the famous opening lines of <em>Beowulf</em>. The poem was composed in the late 8th century, but survives only in a single manuscript from c. 1000. Here is the first page from that precious manuscript.</p> <p><img src="images/beowulf.jpg" alt="manuscript page" width="50%"></p> <p>Below: Here is what it might have sounded like.</p> <p><iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/0zorjJzrrvA?si=Y0j69Yr9J8lMzYEU" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Conversion involved a mixture of pagan and Christian practices and beliefs. For instance, popes were ready to make space for pagan festivals in the Christian calendar. They advised missionaries to keep pagan shrines intact, simply replacing the idols with a cross, and sacrifices with sacraments. Beowulf says, "Fate will often save a man if his courage holds," while another poet writing a life of Saint Andrew around the same time and in the same heroic-traditional style, uses the same familiar formulaic phrase to describe the saint's bravery in his battle with demons. He simply changes "Fate" (Old English, <em>wyrd</em>) to "God." Easy. The three artifacts from the seventh-century Germanic kingdoms illustrate this kind of religious and cultural syncretism.</p> <p>Below: "The Coppergate Helmet" from York features ornamental boar heads matching a description from <em>Beowulf,</em> which tells us that pagans believed the board heads would protect the wearer. The helmet is also decorated by a Christian prayer, "In the name of the Lord Jesus, Holy Spirit, and God ..."</p> <p><img src="images/york-helmet.jpg" alt="helmet with cheekplates" width="50%"></p> <p>Below: This ornament from Anglo-Saxon England depicts Odin, and closely resembles the figure of Christ as the warrior on a funerary plaque from Francia. Poetic depictions of Christ often present him this way - as a warrior, fighting demons, surrounded by his loyal warband (the disciples).</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> <p><img src="images/woden-ornament.jpg" alt="ornament engraved with figure wielding spear" width="50%"></p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p><img src="images/woden-funerary.jpg" alt="engraving of warrior with spear" width="50%"></p> </div> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>After hearing the words of those who have preached their Christian beliefs and have tried for me to accept this new faith, I cannot help but laugh.While I do understand the allure of Christianity with its promises of new alliances and trade opportunities, this new religion turns everything that we have believed on its head. Our strength lies in our traditions, in the gods who have guided us through countless battles and blessed our harvests. While I do know that some of my subjects will question this decision as many of these new christians have been persuasive, I know that we must stay true to who we are. Our Pagan beliefs have stayed with us for hundreds of years, and to turn our backs on our gods now would be almost treason. Christianity is simply a test of our gods to see what we will do, and we must not displease them. These new followers challenge our beliefs, making us question why we worship our many gods. They believe us to be in the wrong for celebrating those who have guided us believing there to be only “one true god”. Christianity is slowly spreading to other kingdoms but I must lead with conviction, balancing the old and the new, to ensure the prosperity and unity of our kingdom.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>As I am sitting here taking in the livelines of my great hall, I notice the camaraderie between men. My warband could not be more united. We are strong. Seeing all of this I could not imagine what the Roman Christ could do for me that we can not accomplish ourselves. The Roman Pope keeps sending me gifts over the past year to try and convince me to convert . I would never give in to bribery. My kingdom has been self-sufficient this far and we are happy and prosperous. Nothing lasts forever but that’s up to fate to decide. My only worry is as more and more people and kingdoms start converting to Christianity, they will be less inclined to trade with me and respect me and everything I’ve built. I had recently spoken to the Edwin king of Northumbria, who had just built this massive church in his kingdom. Edwin had been converted by Cofi, a noble priest who felt like, “ he had been cheated by the gods who rewarded others over him with earthly success, despite his more devoted worship of them” (Naismith, Britain). King Edwin had told me in regards to knowledge about eternity, “If this new doctrine (Christianity) brings us more certain information, it seems right that we should accept it.” (Bede, History) I just don’t believe my kingdom needs more unifying or a cohesive religion to be content with life. But if more of my own people follow my wife and daughters lead and start converting, will they even respect me as their leader? Will they continue to trust my word? I hope my decision will not come back to bite me.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I’ve been approached by so many missionaries trying to convert me and my kingdom to Christianity. I’m starting to think it might be the right choice for my people. I don’t have all the answers about the universe, but Christianity definitely answers a lot of them. My advisor told me that “if this new doctrine (Christianity) brings us more certain information, it seems right that we should accept it,” and I think that makes sense. Having all the answers will definitely help my popularity as king and help with my approval from my kingdom’s citizens. It will also probably help with my relationships with neighboring kingdoms because they all seem to be converting to Christianity as well. I think it will be easy to convert all our citizens, most of them are not very educated and will probably just believe whatever I say, but for the ones who don’t, the missionaries told me that “they must be asked whether they think this universe had a beginning or was always in existence. If it had a beginning, who created it?” After that kind of thought provoking question they’ll have no choice but to convert, but if they still won’t, I think I’ll just threatened to banish them until they do. After all, I am the king and I can do whatever I want. I think Christianity will be good for our community and I will definitely be converting.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $assyriaExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Assyria]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>The Hittites, Kassites, and Mitannians:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$assyriaExploreQ1" "A">>Seem to have been more interested in plunder than establishing a lasting hegemony</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$assyriaExploreQ1" "B">>Ruled Mesopotamia as a joint confederation based at Babylon</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$assyriaExploreQ1" "C">>Fell quickly before Assyrian expansion because they lacked iron technology</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "assyria-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($assyriaExploreQ1 is "A") and ($assyriaExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $assyriaExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Bow">><<set $bow to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Treasure">><<set $treasure to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Assyria]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Assyria]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $assyriaExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Assyria]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>The Hebrews' religion:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$assyriaExploreQ2" "A">>allowed them to assimilate easily into different societies.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$assyriaExploreQ2" "B">>created a uniquely pacifist society totally averse to warfare.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$assyriaExploreQ2" "C">>created a strong national identity that survived conquest and displacement.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "assyria-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($assyriaExploreQ2 is "C") and ($assyriaExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $assyriaExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Potion">><<set $potion to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Assyria]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Assyria]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>Friezes from the Assyrian palaces at Nimrud and Nineveh, c. 800 - 600 BCE (note: originally they were painted)</p> <p>The Assyrian army crossing the Euphrates with the help of some impressive Phoenician galleys</p> <p><img src="images/assyria-galleys.jpg" alt="stone carving of double-decker galley ship with shields" width="100%"></p> <p>Here they are on the river again, transporting lumber and surrounded by a wealth of natural resources.</p> <p><img src="images/assyria-river.jpg" alt="stone carving of ships towing logs across water full of aquatic creatures" width="100%"></p> <p>And here are some of their enemies fleeing Assyrian archers by crossing the river on flotation devices made of inflated goat skins.</p> <p><img src="images/assyria-goatfloaties.jpg" alt="stone carving of men crossing a river to a fort, pursued by archers" width="100%"></p> <p>So: goat floaties or double-decker galleys? Hmmm ... it's pretty clear who has more style on the water. This was a favorite theme for Assyrian artists and authors.</p> <p>You can find these images of the Assyrian palace friezes at the British Museum (if you're ever in London, a visit to the the museum's Assyria gallery is an absolute must).<a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/galleries/assyria-nimrud" target="_blank">The British Museum</a></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Friezes from the Assyrian palaces at Nimrud and Nineveh, c. 800 - 600 BCE (note: originally they were painted)</p> <p>Gore and glory: Ancient art and literature often reflects a keen awareness of the dichotomous nature of victory and death. Success appears alongside failure. One side must lose if another is to win. The Assyrian palace friezes show no concern for whitewashing the grim realities of military success. The gore appears alongside the glory. They are one and the same.</p> <p><img src="images/assyria-vulture-cavalry.jpg" alt="chariot with vulture grasping entrils above" width="100%"></p> <p><img src="images/assyria-corpse-margins.jpg" alt="chariots fighting with decapitated corpses decorating margins" width="100%"></p> <p>The fruits of victory</p> <p><img src="images/assyria-feast.jpg" alt="people reclining and feasting" width="100%"></p> <p><img src="images/assyria-victory.jpg" alt="troops presenting captives who kneel before the ruler" width="100%"></p> <p>You can find these images of the Assyrian palace friezes at the British Museum (if you're ever in London, a visit to the the museum's Assyria gallery is an absolute must).<a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/galleries/assyria-nimrud" target="_blank">The British Museum</a></p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Oswald came from a small village that had recently come under military siege. He was one of the first to leave with them, wanting to spare his family. He had heard of other towns going through similar conflicts, some not so lucky and being destroyed in the process. He wanted to avoid this. If he went along easy, surely they wouldn’t destroy his home. His family complained as he was leaving but his resolve was firm. He promised them he would be back. In ten years, if he was lucky to still be alive, he would wish to come home to the same village he left. The violence and bloodshed that awaits him is something he isn’t looking forward too. Even the friezes that his comrades are making on the walls seem violent. Pictures of people being slain and the men committing such acts dancing and relaxing in the fruits of their victory. How many of those slain people were innocent? Would he soon be committing the same horrendous acts? He’s never enjoyed violence, but he will do what he has to to survive. He is determined to make it home, as safely as possible, to his family and see them again.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>In ten years of service to the Assyrian military I would have done everything in my power to rise in the ranks. This would offer me power, wealth and most importantly safety. This is the best option because if I run I die and if I choose to be a foot soldier for my entire military career the likelihood of me dying is equally high. Through rising in the ranks and making friends in high places I would secure my safety and use my newly acquired wealth and power to live out a long life to a ripe old age of 30 probably since life expectancy wasn’t the greatest back then.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Assyrians have an artsy side too. They make artwork like detailed carvings and fraizes. The art might be a little violent but thats still art. The examples of the Assyrian art shown showcases more of the culture and ways of the Assyrian people (Friezes). Before going into the Assyrian Army, I had worked on a fair few pieces of artwork that showed how the Assyrian people lived, the culture, and sometimes the violence too. Many of the carvings that I worked on depict what we wear, what we built, ceremonies, and the things we worship. But now that I am in the army I won't be able to create much art anymore. Maybe in 10 years the fighting will be over and I can go back to making art (Friezes).</p> <p>Shalmaneser II and his god Assur were praised with a black limestone obelisk inscribed with their achievements and stories. Showing tribute to them on each face of the obelisk. Each face showcases/represents and different achievement or story (Obelisk). One of the obelisk faces shares this achievement of our king: "I crossed the upper part of the Euphrates. / I received the tribute from all the kings of the Hittites. / In those days Rimmon-idri of Damascus, Irkhulina of Hamath, and the kings of the Hittites and of the coasts joined together and came against me in battle. / By command of Assur, the great lord, my lord, I fought them. I destroyed them. / I took their chariots, their war wagons, their war gear."</p> <p>As I said before we Assyrians do have an artsy side, and we create for the things we worship, like our mighty king Shalmaneser II and his god Assur. The obelisk we constructed mentions how our king crossed the mighty Euphrates river numerous times and came back with goods and resources from the other lands. I crossed the Euphrates, and took part in the artistic side of the obelisk helping with the inscriptions, all because of my artistic past. These actions that I took helped me gain trust and value in the army. Even though I knew my life had little to no value, I was determined to have a future beyond this. Maybe I will make art again, go back home, or see where else this "new life" will take me. (Obelisk)</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>As a poor hungry young civilian, I had no choice but to join the army. I needed a place to sleep, eat, and to carry my future into a path of change for the better. As I was immediately taken in, I had to watch as my town was thoroughly looted and partially destroyed in the process. My thoughts of myself having to do this later burn my mind with uncertainty and the amount of apathy this army contains. I notice that the soldiers of this army are merely loyal dogs to their commander, making me further doubt my decision to join this army. I think to myself that I must put myself out there and stand on top to be seen as more than just a subservient warrior. I plan on providing better defense and attack tactics to the commander and to suggest faster routes for our destinations. Hopefully this will move me up in the army and give me a better label. During my first few months of serving in the army, I was brought to the palace to examine and to absorb the info of The Black Obelisk Of Shalmaneser. Supposedly I was assigned to do this to further understand the background and importance of the military under the king of Assyria. I observe the graphics of the Obelisk and notice how the military greatly benefits society by providing protection and bringing back new technology. I read the words “The great ones who determine destinies, making my kingdom great!”(Colonial Press, 1901). This was sure to give me a sense of placement in the army and as to how I was determined to make changes for my new kingdom. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>After doing all of the research and looking at different sources you can see how intense the Assyrian army “ killed 20,500 of their soldiers with arrows.” (Obelisk). You did not want to get on these people's bad side. You see them come and attack people in your community and take you away from your family. Now in these types of situations the best type of way to survive in these situations is to join them. Now I would not want to join them but for my survival I think I would. As a woman they wouldn’t let me do a lot with the military. My job would proably be to please the men. Just saying that grosses me out but it is the reality of the situation. I would probably have to sleep my way to the top. Sleep with the most powerful men to be successful and survive in this environment. I would like the idea of being able to go home but the reality of the situation is that my home would probably not be there. They are destroying everything in sight and they also would probably kill me if I tried to leave so I proably won’t ever go home.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>In this role play game I decided to role play as a soldier in the Assyrian Army. The reason why I picked this was because I want to know what life was like during this brutal time. Military life wasn't easy and I want to see through the eyes of a soldier during this time to what they had to endure. The way that I plan on building my status in the army is becoming a leader. People often need someone to guide them when it comes to something such as war. For instance during the fight with the south President Abe Lincoln was the leader of the North and during the Napoleonic was Napolean was General and later appointed himself king. I will stand out by showing my fellow soldiers that I will fight with them and lead them to victory. The text states, “And we aren't wrong. But (you knew that was coming, right?) ... but... they had a softer side, reflected in their obvious appreciation of beautiful artwork. Their stone walls of their palaces were alive with vibrantly painted, intricately detailed bas-relief carvings (or friezes). Of course, their favorite themes were grim and gruesome (war, hunting, domination), but still ... they were a little artsy” Another way that I can rise in the ranks in the Army is by showing depictions of me as the leader in these art works. I could also tell them that I was appointed by God as their leader,” Assur, Great Lord, King of All the great gods! Anu, God, Lord of the world, King of the spirits of heaven and spirits of earth! Bel the Supreme, Father of the gods, the Creator! Hea, King of the deep, determiner of destinies, the king of crowns, awash in brilliance!”. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I had no choice but to join the Assyrian army. While dejected at the thought of my livelihood being subjected to the wants and whims of the king, I can’t help but admire the artwork that covers wherever we go. “Black limestone obelisk of Shalmaneser III; glorifies achievements of king and minister; (Obelisk)” Achievements of the king are a top priority to the assyrian empire. The role of a soldier is not to take credit for the achievements and conquests that one may have achieved, but to dutifully credit the king to all accomplishments. “Seeing that, as far as I am concerned, neither my father nor my mother put me in this place, but the strong arm of the king brought me into my father's house, why should I of all people commit a crime against the king, my lord? As truly as the king, my lord, lives, I say to the commissioner of the king, [my] lord, "Why do you love the 'Apiru but hate the mayors?"” As a soldier in the army, I understand that I am a pawn for the king to use. While appeasement may be seen as cowardly as I am a young strong man with a rather large ego, I am smart enough to understand that to the king appeasement is a means of survival.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1><em>Fighting Techniques of the Ancient World</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1B0ThpyziLnMWirjnCrGuYQ8H1jnCH71K/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This section</a> of Anglim et al., <em>Fighting Techniques of the Ancient World, 3000 BC - AD 500: Equipment, Combat Skills, and Tactics</em> focuses on Assyrian siege warfare, with a case study of Lachish.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Options for surviving the siege</li> <li>Methods employed by the Assyrian forces</li> <li>Possible outcomes of the siege</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas.</p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$assyse1" `$assyse1 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Assyrian Army Scenario |Assyria]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $babylonExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>The longevity and importance of Babylon can be traced to its geostrategic location:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$babylonExploreQ1" "A">>where the Tigris and Euphrates rivers come close together.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$babylonExploreQ1" "B">>at the shore of the Persian Gulf, facilitating trade with the Indus Valley civilization.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$babylonExploreQ1" "C">>high in the mountains, making the city nearly impregnable to armed assault.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "babylon-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($babylonExploreQ1 is "A") and ($babylonExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $babylonExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Babylon]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Stories from ancient Mesopotamia frequently reflect a respect for __________ as a symbol of power?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$babylonExploreQ2" "A">>access to water</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$babylonExploreQ2" "B">>official royal coinage</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$babylonExploreQ2" "C">>city walls</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "babylon-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($babylonExploreQ2 is "C") and ($babylonExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $babylonExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice.
