Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Fur cloak">><<run $Inventory.push("Fur cloak")>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lance">><<run $Inventory.push("Lance")>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Babylon]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Babylon]]</p> <</if>><div class="row link"> <p>An artist's impression of the great ziggurat of Ur. Ziggurats in Old Babylon would have looked like this.</p> <p><img src="images/ziggurat-ur.jpg" alt="ziggurat" width="100%"></p> <p><a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/image/12890/ziggurat-of-ur-artists-impression/">World History Encyclopedia</a></p> </div><div class=" link"> <p>A surviving fragment of the <em>Epic of Gilgamesh</em>, recorded in cuneiform script on a clay tablet.</p> <p><img src="images/gilgamesh-clay.jpg" alt="clay tablet inscribed with cuneiform script" height="70%"></p> <p><a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/image/107404001">British Museum</a></p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>After I completed becoming a scribe, I was finally able to learn to read and write. I chose this route as the thought of battle and the sights of warriors coming back home tired and ill gave me a sense of fear. Gaining this new knowledge has shocked me and caused me to see my hometown differently which sparked curiosity in what else could be out there. I have been told by my family that nothing but emptiness and war awaits outside the walls. Once heavy laws were upon the people by Hammurabi, my decision on my future has changed. I have decided to pack my things and leave. Before I left I stole a few trinkets and weapons from the court to either sell or to use along my travels. The main things I take with me are my 8 year old donkey, food, grains, water, and a few pieces of cloth. I have sold the rest of my belongings for extra grains at a reasonable price. Not too sure where I will end up but I plan on wondering until I find something interesting or worth staying at. My main goal is to hopefully find a new civilization where I can blend in and trade my scribe skills in return for a better life.</p> <p> My group consists of three other people I have helped in the past. Only one other person is a scribe as well. We both decided that we will teach the rest of the group how to read and write by using humane ways unlike the multiple beatings by the reeds we’ve received. Additionally, I was able to convince the group to steal a few extra things from the court to partake in this journey as we will not be returning and more items will help. Our short term outcomes will be preparing for this journey and to be able to enjoy our time out from the walls and discovering sights. Our long term goal is to find a nice place to settle where there are no overwhelming laws and no harsh punishments or forces of payment for smaller things. We also plan on running a farm where we can teach more people how to read and write in exchange for help around the farm. </p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I will no longer idolize this idiot and put up with the suffering of my people. For years I have put up with the demands of others, forced to do the same things everyday. The people and their precious “Gilgamesh” are idiotic, refusing to see that they themselves are the problem. “Gilgamesh” and his doings have only hurt my people and yet they glamarize him. How could we forget that he fought the Bull of Heaven and his idiocracy cost the lives of hundreds of the settlement's residents? For our perceived hero he could care little for us. Now with these clay tablets and the backing of the other scribes we will put up with it no longer. Each and every one of us scribes come from the higher classes of our societies. With our combined influences we will take our grievances to the palace and demand change. This retelling will show the people that we do not need to rely on the power of a single man but instead that it is the people themselves that should lead and control each othe <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I would try to leave Babylon and flee to lower Egypt. It would be hard but with most likely above-average intelligence being a scribe I could try to find work writing things as a record keeper for the pharo. In the Papyrus Lansing it says that only a few know how to write and it is possible to be a record keeper in Egypt. With the knowledge of how to read and write hieroglyphs, it would be a waste of talent and knowledge to not attempt to use it. And if that failed I would try to learn how to make tools out of bronze in an apprenticeship anything to avoid being a solider.</p> <p>I am most likely the son of a Babylonian noble or someone with money according to “a supervisor's advice to a young scribe” and I would have a few years of learning how to write. Writing is something that was much harder to do at this time and it would have been a great help to have someone who knows how to write come to you looking for work. Being a bookkeeper is something that is in the realm of possibility for me in this scenario. If this doesn't work I feel that I would know I don't want to be a soldier because their lives have much more hardship than I would want to put on myself so picking up a trade would be the next best thing.</p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>They even went as far as to make sure that the ships that are sailing are protected from any fault. This just shows how important this is to them and really starts to create a sort of civilized population and make their power over the waters even stronger.</p> <p>Interesting evidence:</p> <ul> <li>If a man hire a sailor and his boat, and provide it with corn, clothing, oil and dates, and other things of the kind needed for fitting it: if the sailor is careless, the boat is wrecked, and its contents ruined, then the sailor shall compensate for the boat which was wrecked and all in it that he ruined. (Hammurabi)</li> <li>There are a lot of laws in Hammurabi's code that talk about the ocean because they believed that it was extremely important to have water access due to trade. The whole idea of being able to have a power over water was so important to the ancient peoples that they made a variety of laws to protect the water from crime and other things. (Hammurabi)</li> <li>If a shipbuilder build a boat for some one, and do not make it tight, if during that same year that boat is sent away and suffers injury, the shipbuilder shall take the boat apart and put it together tight at his own expense. The tight boat he shall give to the boat owner. (Hammurabi)</li> </ul> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Seizing power, while originally my dream under further thought is insane. Even the mere mention of this plot would lead me and everyone else to our deaths. Even just accusing the elders and nobiles of such offenses, or even just of our anger could be reason alone to end us. Seizing power would require fighting the army directly and we could never. While our beatings are harsh and our teachers strict they are nothing to what those in the army deal with every day. Running is better, we could settle somewhere far from the city and run a better settlement.</p> <p>I think we’d rather build a better society, one run by those that knew the knowledge of our world, not just those with money. Even during peace those above us sit and drink while we work, either those in the fields or us in the scribe homes relentlessly writing away. Why be done by one selfish man? Why have laws punish us all so harshly, saying something the elders dislike shouldn't come with death, thievery shouldn’t come with death. Perhaps those criminals get sent to work instead, providing something instead of just culling them. Here we could have a more just society.</p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I would feel like I would have been in over my head and run. An academic revolution probably wouldn’t have worked back then due to the violent nature of the time. The only ones I really have behind me are scribes and they can't fight that well. In order to have an actual revolution I would first need to be in a high position in the current political structure, or have friends in high positions in the current political structure or some I would need some kind of military presence despite how modest it may be to get the ball rolling. I don’t believe this is possible with a scribe background. As scribes I feel like our ideas would relate to many of the people we would need to get behind us in order for a full scale revolution to occur back then. </p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I decided for this era I would be a scribe. The reasoning behind this was because I thought that it would be very interesting to see what life was like at this time writing and documenting everything down. In this play through I decided to rebel against my peers and teachers who were doing wrong by me. In order to succeed in a rebellion you need followers, I will try and convince my peers that who their God is isn't a good person and why it shouldn't be their “Leader”. The text states, “However, is young and immature; he oppresses his people and treats them harshly. So the people cry for help to Anu, the sky god and chief deity of Uruk, their city. In response to their pleas, Anu creates a wild man, Enkidu, in the wild and terrifying forests that surround Uruk. Enkidu is more like an animal than a man. He has the strength of dozens of wild animals” This passage shows how bad of a God he is and hopefully others listen to me. If this doesn't work I will try to incorporate new ways of communication. For instance this was one of the very first civilizations to use writing as a form of communication. I could write plans of a rebellion and have them posted around the city so others could see. The text states, “The cultures of ancient Mesopotamia and Egypt were the first in world history in which some people knew how to write, a skill that remained limited to very few indi- viduals within each culture.” Lastly I could even get some of my peers to join/ spread word of the rebellion I am planning the text states, “These schools were firmly established by the Early Dynastic Period and spread throughout Sumer.” I could start teaching at these schools to spread word of the rebellion to my peers. </p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $barbExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Barbarian]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>The term "dark ages" refers to:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$barbExploreQ1" "A">>The period between the fall of Rome and the early Middle Ages. It's also known as late antiquity or the sub-Roman period. Historians don't like the label very much.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$barbExploreQ1" "B">>Historians use the term "dark ages" to classify periods of intense violence when people's everyday lives were exceptionally difficult.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$barbExploreQ1" "C">>It's a useful label because it can be properly used to classify the entire medieval period, which was a time of cultural and technological stagnation.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "barb-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($barbExploreQ1 is "A") and ($barbExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $barbExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Correct. "The Dark Ages" has been used so widely and imprecisely in popular culture that it has become problematic as a chronological label. It also has pejorative connotations, implying that the time period was bad in some way. It's just not a very useful phrse for historians, most of the time. Your score has increased by 2! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Barbarian]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Not quite. Try again? Or [[turn back |Barbarian]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $barbExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Barbarian]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Under Constantine:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$barbExploreQ2" "A">>Christianity became the official state religion of Rome./label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$barbExploreQ2" "B">>the Roman imperial government and the church merged into a single, nearly seamless administrative unit.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$barbExploreQ2" "C">>Christianity became legal in the Roman Empire.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "barb-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($barbExploreQ2 is "C") and ($barbExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $barbExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Treasure">><<set $treasure to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Barbarian]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Barbarian]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>Below: The reconstructed gates of the Roman fort at Vindobona.</p> <p><img src="images/vindobona-gate.jpg" alt="stone gateway with two arches" width="70%"></p> <p>Below: The barbarian tribes of late antiquity, with the location of Vindobona.</p> <p><img src="images/map-vindobona.jpg" alt="map of Germanic kingdoms and Vindobona" width="80%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Some very intriguing personalities strode the turbulent landscape of late antiquity. As the Roman imperial apparatus crumbled and Germanic tribes ricocheted around Europe, driven westward by the Huns, the lines between barbarian and Roman blurred and disappeared. The legions seemed inseparable from the <em>foederati</em>, the barbarian troops who fought for Rome as allies. Romans sometimes resented this amalgamation, and there were waves of horrifying anti-barbarian violence, including massacres of <em>foederati</em> wives and children. But many of most successful and memorable Roman leaders of this period were themselves barbarian.</p> <p>Alas, few records survive from these centuries, and we know know very little about these individuals. Often, their afterlives in legend far overshadow the stick-figure portraits presented by the written records of their own day. King Arthur is a good example. We know somebody remebered as King Arthur achieved great things as a military leader defending the Britons from Saxon invaders during the late fifth century. While he enjoyed an active and well-documented afterlife as legend, we know hardly anything about his real fifth-century life.</p> <p>Here are a few other notable examples of barbarians who rose to dizzying heights of power in the last days of Rome. Incredibly, I have discovered original portraits of each of these people. As you can see, these realistic and intimate impressions attest to the masterful genius of fifth-century artists, and were almost certainly drawn from life.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Fritigern the Goth</h2> <p>There was a Gothic king named Fritigern who led his people to a stunning victory over the Romans at the Battle of Adrianople in 378. The Roman emperor himself was obliterated, along with something like 20,000 of his soldiers (and by "obliterated," I mean they looked for his corpse in the general location where he was seen last, but couldn't find it amid the carnage). Fritigern wasn't "King of the Goths" in the sense we might expect. He was simply one of several young tribal leaders whose successes put him in a position the Roman historians identified as "king." He was also, at least nominally, an ally (<em>foederati</em>) of Rome ... for a while, anyway.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <img src="images/fritigern.jpg" alt="child's drawing of man on horse with blue armor" width="50%"> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Alaric the Visigoth</h2> <p>Alaric the Visigoth also started out as <em>foederati</em>, commanding a Gothic force loyal to the empire. Long story short, when he and his troops felt a grievance against Rome, they turned against the empire. They wrecked Greece for a while, until the Romans made Alaric military governor there. In 410, he invaded Italy and sacked the city of Rome itself - the first time Rome had suffered such an insult in 800 years.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <img src="images/alaric.jpg" alt="child's drawing of man with sword and chain mail" width="50%"> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Stilicho</h2> <p>Stilicho was another barbarian who rose to become the most powerful ruler in the western empire. He fought alongside Alaric and against him at various times. Historians speculate that if the emperor Honorius hadn't executed Stilicho (in a sleazy court power play) in 408, he would have provided the leadership necessary to defend Rome from Alaric in 410.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <img src="images/stilicho.jpg" alt="child's drawing of man on horse with yellow armor" width="50%"> </div> </div> <hr> </div><div class="link"> <p>Barbarian society was fairly democratic. Assemblies of free people met frequently to make decisions as a group. Kings did not weild absolute power, and were selected by the elite, not born into the position directly. However, these societies were far from egalitarian. Classes of slaves and serfs existed, and the law codes reflect stark differences in the rights and status of these groups. Any number of behavioral norms articulated these socio-economic divisions as well. For instance, fishing and trapping were viewed as lower-class activities, while the elite took pride in more active forms of hunting using horses and dogs.</p> <p>Weapons were an important indicator of rank. Ordinary free people carried spears and shields. The elite had swords and some bits of body armor, as well. A fortunate few had helmets. These items were symbols of power and prestige. The sword, in particular, came to represent elite status during the medieval period. By the end of the Middle Ages, most European law codes included clauses that punished any non-noble who carried a sword. One particularly harsh law stipulated that peasants must wear only black or gray, and should "spend six days at the plow. On Sunday he is to go to church, carrying his animal goad openly in his hand. If a sword is found on a peasant, he is to be tied up in the churchyard and flayed, hide and hair. If enemies threaten him, let him defend himself with a pitchfork." (<em>Kaiserchronik</em>, Germany c. 1150)</p> <p>Below: This seventh-century funerary plaque from Francia combines elements of paganism with early Christian symbolism, depicting Christ as a warrior triumphing over evil (the snake). He wields ordinary weapons of spear and round shield, as well as the more prestigious sword, along with some kind of headgear, a neck ring, and something that looks like armor.</p> <img src="images/woden-funerary.jpg" alt="bas relief of figure with weapons, walking over snake" width="70%"> <p>Below: This drawing from the richly illustrated Utrecht Psalter (c. 830 Francia) depicts the typical gear of non-elite troops: spears and round shields, with no armor or helmets to be seen.</p> <img src="images/utrecht-warband.jpg" alt="group of men with spears and round shields" width="70%"> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I will follow my father’s advice and become a smith. Although war and combat is exciting and tempting, our lack of iron (D. H. Green) and our reliance on Roman battle strategies (Tacitus) will make battle hard and unpredictable. Since we have learned our strategies from the Romans, who’s to say other armies we battle haven’t studied their ways as well? Who knows how much iron or other resources come plentiful in their land? Fighting with my friends is a nice escape, a way to blow off steam, but I do not want to commit my life to this. As my father said, as a smith I will always have food on the table and still get to help the soldiers in the battlefield. Since there is not typically a lot of time and effort put into defensive equipment (D. H. Green) I want to change this through my work. I will ensure greatness for my land and my people through my efforts. A lucky event that may shape my success in my path is if we were to earn iron from pillaging the defeated in our battles. Using this precious resource in my work would bring me great honor and pride. Whoever receives the iron weapon will most likely be a highly ranked fighter, or a well respected chief. An unlucky event in my path would be if we were to be defeated in battle too often, this would mean a great many weapons to repair or even have to make all over again. Although it is good to always have work, being at that caliber and amount would take a toll on me and my business. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I have grown up around warfare and the military so it is nothing new. In my everyday life there is always a need for military action, like a tribal conflict that was just dealt with the other day two of the Germanic tribes fighting each other over resources. In all this there could be instances where my life is in danger while training or during warfare. But those risks come with the job and I am prepared, I have been training my whole life for this. (Green, Language and History) Even though I am a member of a household, I will soon be a member of commonwealth and I will need to decide what I want to do. Become a smith? Learn to read and write? Or become a part of the military. After listening to what my parents had to say and listening to their arguing, I decided to continue with my training, working towards the military. Being in the military will give me opportunities to travel and excel in my training. Maybe I will be able to move up the ranks. (Tacitus)</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I will probably follow my father and become a blacksmith due to the importance of that type of work back then. I will focus on trying to make as much money as I can so that I will be able to provide for my family and myself. It is a craft that is sought after for the weapons meaning that I will severe a purpose in my community. I wouldn’t choose my mothers advice due to how strict the church rules were during that time. With these rules in place I won’t be able to do certain things and I will always have to listen to the popes and priests who are in charge of me. I like the idea of training to get combat experience and even potentially making a career out of the military however I would rather make money then give my life for what I see as pointless wars. In the text, Green, Language and History in the Germanic World it states,” To retain his power a leader had to tie his followers to himself through a bond of loyalty, which he earned through his generosity”. As a blacksmith I can give gifts in my community and to the king so that I can be liked and loved among the people and maybe even be given other gifts like land from the king for my generosity. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>As I continue fishing, I think about what my options are. My father wants me to quit playing around and become a smith; follow the family tradition. On the other hand, my mother wants me to become a Roman administrator and to end up doing work for the church. I don’t like either as those options are something I can’t see myself doing. There's no way I can be stuck in the city slaving away doing mindless tasks. I want something fun, adventurous, and rewarding. I want to be out. I soon pack up my fishing gear and head to the training yard. I set up a dummy using any leftover fort materials from when me and my friends built it. I then spend a couple of hours training my swordsmanship and improving my stamina and endurance. Now only if I could get the attention of a soldier then surely I will secure my place in the military. As I take a short break from training, I remember the stories some of the elders would tell me and all the other children back then. They would tell us about the writings of Tacitus and how his perceptions of our people were a bit problematic due to him not actually ever being here to experience it for himself. I recall upon my favorite statement from Tacitus of how he depicted our military: “On the whole, one would say that their chief strength is in their infantry, which fights along with the cavalry; admirably adapted to the action of the latter is the swiftness of certain foot-soldiers, who are picked from the entire youth of their country, and stationed in front of the line”(Tacitus). Hearing this as a child gave me a sense of pride in our military and due to how strong we are seen in the eyes of outsiders. This was just the start of my dream to join the military. I soon pick up my sword and go back to training. I go on for hours until I cannot swing my sword anymore.</p> <p> As I train, the statement, “To abandon your shield is the basest of crimes; nor may a man thus disgraced be present at the sacred rites, or enter their council; many, indeed, after escaping from battle, have ended their infamy with the halter”(Taticus) replays in my mind as I know that if I want to fulfill my dream I must push myself and make myself an exceptional warrior</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>There are so many different ways that I go and I think your gender plays a huge role in this scenario. As a woman, going into the army would not be my first choice. In some of the resources it showed the importance of women and how women were very much valued. “Close by them, too, are those dearest to them, so that they hear the shrieks of women, the cries of infants. They are to every man the most sacred witnesses of his bravery-they are his most generous applauders.”(Tacitus) So I think as a woman I would take my mothers advice and try to work in some sort of administrative role as that way I could still be at home and watch over my kids and my husband can come home to me. Now if I was a man that would be a different story. You don’t really see barbarians inside of the Empire, “The terms by which barbarian groups were settled within the Empire were rarely if ever recorded in any detail.” (Halsall, Barbarian Migrations). I think my best option would be to listen to my father and become a smith and work on making weapons for the army as the army was very valuable for them. Armies and protecting their Empire was very important to them so weapons will always be needed and you will always have a job which in those days can be hard to come by. I think there are multiple different outcomes you can decide and your gender role plays a huge part of it. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>[Note: This response compares the notes from the barbarian readings with the kind of "What will you do with your life?" choices we face as young adults in the 21st century. A creative approach!]</p> <p>I’ve had many moments where I realize how lucky I am to be in this life that I have. One of them was being lucky enough to be in a CSU. Many don’t have the opportunity to go to a CSU, due to it being too expensive or not wanting to leave home which is such a tough decision to make. It was something that was super hard for me to do and that I didn’t want to do. Especially since I was thinking about money and all the what if’s. I am so lucky to be able to have this opportunity and to be able to spend such a happy time in a college I love with some of my closest friends here. I think to plan ahead for this lucky path is to always be grateful for this opportunity that I have and for me not to take it for granted. One last thing my mom always tells me to do is make good decisions. This is something that will stick with me throughout college, because I am so far away from home and always in the back of my mind I just want to be able to go back home to see my family.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Despite my lofty ambitions, I find myself thinking about my fathers proposal more and more. Becoming a smith is something that offers a lot of security. While it doesn’t offer a lot of opportunities to rise in social classes, in these turbulent times it ensures I have a place inside my clan. Whether it be for warfare or for more domestic purposes people are going to need tools, and a smith to make and upkeep said tools, especially when we have so little. The Romans or at least what is left of them frequently use pawns in petty wars fighting over the little that they have left, clinging on to their old ideas of how things should be, much like my mother. There is no future for me in being a wandering brigand trying to bring about the death knell of what is last of the Roman empire nor is there any benefit to trying to revive it. We need to accept that the lush land which could grow rich fruits and the gold and silver which we once clung to so desperately is now gone. We need to create a new path for ourselves, and while being a smith not bring out the radical change I oh so desire it will ensure that I and my family have a future. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>While making my parents happy is certainly something I strive for, in this scenario it’s only possible to make one of them happy. Either I carry on the legacy of my family as a smith and make my father happy, or study towards a position of power, which would make my mother happy. Both of these options have me helping to maintain the sanctity and power of the “old” Roman world. Is that something I care about? Not really. I have a better idea. I’ll join the military. If there’s anything that change has a hard time touching, it’s the military. While our weapons and tactics may change over the years, at it’s core it the same as it’s always been. And I want to be a part of something that I know will stick around.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>They are less able to bear laborious work. Heat and thirst they cannot in the least endure; to cold and hunger their climate and their soil inure them. (Tacitus)</p> <p>I will become tired easier, so a military position may not be the greatest idea for me. They also carry with them into battle certain figures and images taken from their sacred groves. And what most stimulates their courage is that their squadrons or battalions, instead of being formed by chance or by a fortuitous gathering, are composed of families and clans. (Tacitus)</p> <p>My passion for the military is formed around where my family stands on becoming a soldier, and due to the fact that they would rather I join my father's work as a smith, this further reiterates that I would not flourish becoming a military soldier.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome2-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Roman Genocide</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In this series of "Behind the Bastards," podcaster and journalist Robert Evans talks with historian Joe Kassabian about "Ancient Genocide and the War on Carthage:" <a href="https://podcasts.apple.com/nz/podcast/part-one-ancient-genocide-and-the-war-on-carthage/id1373812661?i=1000564661837" target="_blank">Part I</a> and <a href="https://podcasts.apple.com/ca/podcast/part-two-ancient-genocide-and-the-war-on-carthage/id1373812661?i=1000564948691" target="_blank">Part II.</a></p> <p>Here is <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ywBgXJABRt0xVMXiddWRngalbPGrlwW6/edit?usp=sharing&ouid=107960520722717944293&rtpof=true&sd=true" target="_blank">the transcript</a>, in case you prefer text to audio.</p> <p>Be it known that this is not a particularly academic work, but it fact-checks very well, makes careful use of a variety of solid sources, and is generally well-informed and accurate. I think it's a fun and informative approach to the military, political, and economic systems of republican Rome. As such, it can enrich our understanding of the character in this role play scenario.</p> <p>Warning: There's some strong language and lewd humor, along with political views you might not agree with. This podcast tends to have a strong ideological bent, and I am not sharing it here to suggest that you should agree with the podcasters in their political views. I just think it can offer useful and accurate insights into Roman military, political, and economic history at the time of Rome's wars with Carthage. If it's not to your taste, it's totally fine to skip this one. It is <em>optional</em> content.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Prevailing attitudes toward violence in republican Rome (politically, militarily, and in daily life)</li> <li>Roman military traditions, strengths, and weaknesses</li> <li>The wider context of Rome's struggle with Carthage</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannba4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Livy: Cannae and Zama |punic]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Punic Wars |warry-hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[A podcast... |bastards]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-mdvictory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-c]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[Back: Attacking Rome Scenario |Cannae]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Bede, <em>Ecclesiastical History</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Bede was an erudite and scholarly Northumbrian monk who wrote his monumental <em>History of the Church of the English People</em> around 730 . It is one of our most important primary sources for the history of Anglo-Saxon England, and it's full of marvelous stories. Well worth a read. <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ErQlHyQoueSsjRZcFTumL5yUI6wT12u86yIUVdNUJBc/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Here are some excerpts relating to the conversion of the English kings.</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Important features of early Germanic religious belief and practice</li> <li>The nature of the surviving evidence about the history of early medieval Germanic paganism, and the debates about how to intepret it</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingbedee1" `$askingbedee1 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-k]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Anglo-Saxon King Scenario |AS-king]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if ($beginCombat1 is "done") and ($beginCombat1 isnot "")>> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Beginning]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-md"> <img src="images/mobs/mobb.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of demon with large ears and fangs" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p>Here is your opponent. To win this fight, choose a good response to its questionable statements about history.</p> <p>It says, "During the Neolithic Revolution, people switched from a forager lifestyle to an agrarian lifestyle because farming provided more food, leisure, and safety."</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>How will you respond to this creature's hysterical history?</p> <div class="row scenario"> <p><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombatQ1" "A">> There's so much wrong with this statement. Perhaps most glaring is this conflation of "people" with "a person." It's classic, old fashioned positivism. In an effort to cobble together a grand metanarrative with convenient "lessons" about humanity, it makes unwarranted generalizations about individuals' decisions. It's a teleological mess with very shaky foundations in the actual evidence.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombatQ1" "B">> Honestly, it doesn't sound that wrong. Agrarian societies <em>did</em> have more food than forager societies, and probably more leisure and safety too, in various ways. The statement seems plausible as it stands.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombatQ1" "C">> Based on current scholarship, this statement is simply wrong. First, neolithic agrarian societies were as violent (i.e., dangerous) as forager societies. Second, for a neolithic individual, farming was more laborious than foraging. Food shortages were common. So, a typical neolithic farmer had <em>less</em> food and leisure than a typical neolithic forager.</label></p> </div> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "begin-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($beginCombatQ1 is "A") and ($beginCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $beginCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <p>Quite so! Nice work! Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Beginning]]</p> <<elseif ($beginCombatQ1 is "B") and ($beginCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>You are right that agrarian societies produced more food than forager societies, overall. However, on an individual basis, farming often offered less food and more work. Current scholarship supports the idea that, "The Agricultural Revolution certainly enlarged the sum total of food at the disposal of humankind, but the extra food did not translate to a better diet or more leisure. Rather, it translated into population explosions and pampered elites. The average farmer worked harder than the average forager, and got a worse diet in return. The Agricultural Revolution was history's biggest fraud." (Harari, <em>Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind</em>). That's a fairly extreme thesis, but even more moderate positions fall short of imagining that daily life for individual neolithic farmers was easier or more bountiful than life for of a neolithic foragers.</p> <p>Better luck next time! [[Onward! |Beginning]]</p> <<elseif ($beginCombatQ1 is "C") and ($beginCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $beginCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <p>Absolutely. Scholarship on this history changes dramatically and rapidly, so we can expect to hear new theories soon. But, as of today, you are quite correct. Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Beginning]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Beginning]]</p> <</if>><<if $beginCombat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Beginning]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: (some dumb circular logic about neolithic rev)</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "begin-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($beginCombatQ2 is "A") and ($beginCombatQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $beginCombat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Tautology Troll and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Armor">><<set $armor to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Beginning]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the Tautology Troll. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Beginning]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <h1>Bible Storiesh</h1><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The early books of the Hebrew Bible are rich historical sources, when they are used judiciously. It is a complex, composite text - far from a transparent window onto the past, but richly illuminating nonetheless. Have a look at <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1oJptUGRw4oS4-v99-qXiKLsLrcWiJQUJt2g8lUn0jkw/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">these excerpts</a> from the oldest parts of the Bible, committed to text around 1,000 BCE.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Daily life in ancient Israel and Judah</li> <li>Religious, cultural, and political views in Hebrew society</li> <li>A developing Hebrew national identity</li> <li>The Hebrews' relationship with neighboring groups</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. It engages in a broad comparison between slavery in ancient Rome and slavery in the American South, with sustained commentary on the challenges posed and lessons suggested by these parallel histories.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. He shows that the poet's depictions were realistic and purposeful (for instance, reflecting the English defenders' chronic lack of decent helmets and armor, compared to the well-equipped Viking invaders).</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-d]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Defence Scenario |Defence]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Bayeux Tapestry</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>After the Norman Conquest of 1066, Norman Archbishop Odo of Bayeux (participant in the Battle of Hastings) had a massive tapestry created, embroidered by English women. Across its 244 feet, the tapestry tells the story of the Norman Conquest of England, including incredible detail such as Halley's Comet, building the invasion fleet, the iconic (often misinterpreted) clash between the Anglo-Saxon shield wall and the Norman heavy cavalry, and of course, poor Harold getting shot in the eye (spoiler, sorry).</p> <p><a href="https://www.bayeuxmuseum.com/en/the-bayeux-tapestry/discover-the-bayeux-tapestry/explore-online/" target="_blank">At the Bayeux Museum here</a>, you can view the whole glorious tapestry and zoom in to see every stunning detail. Have fun! (Really, it's incredible.)</p> <p>Fun fact: It's not a tapestry (which is woven). It's an embroidery (the scene is stitched onto plain cloth). We should call it the Bayeux Un-Tapestry.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the English and the Normans at the Battle of Hastings</li> <li>Key moments at the Battle of Hastings</li> <li>The relative situations of Harold and William as claimants to the English throne before the Battle of Hastings</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastbte1" `$hastbte1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastbta1" `$hastbta1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastbte2" `$hastbte2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastbta2" `$hastbta2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastbte4" `$hastbte4 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastbta4" `$hastbta4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Viking poetry |skaldic]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Ring-giving |rg]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Battle of Stamford Bridge |snorri]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Bayeux Tapestry |bt]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Battle of Hastings |conquest]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Battle of Hastings Scenario |Hastings]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $cannaeExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Cannae]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>In the Roman republic, plebeians were:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$cannaeExploreQ1" "A">>The common people</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$cannaeExploreQ1" "B">>The aristocracy and ruling elite</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$cannaeExploreQ1" "C">>Italian allies who were not Roman citizens</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "cannae-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($cannaeExploreQ1 is "A") and ($cannaeExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $cannaeExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Chalice">><<set $chalice to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Cannae]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Cannae]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $cannaeExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Cannae]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>In the Roman republic, what represented the voice of the aristocracy?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$cannaeExploreQ2" "A">>tribune</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$cannaeExploreQ2" "B">>assembly</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$cannaeExploreQ2" "C">>senate</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "cannae-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($cannaeExploreQ2 is "C") and ($cannaeExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $cannaeExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Treasure">><<set $treasure to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Cannae]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Cannae]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>Below: A map showing Carthagenian and Roman positions during the Second Punic War.</p> <p><img src="images/map-punic.jpg" alt="map of Roman and Carthagenian territories" width="80%"></p> <p>According to Livy, when Hannibal chose not to advance on Rome after his stunning victory at Cannae, his general told him, "You know how to win victory, but you do not know how to use is." History seems to have justified that assessment.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>An egineer preparing for a siege like this might have been designing and building ballistas, catapults, battering rams, siege engines. They would be using math and scrolls to design each machine, finding building materials and labor, and overseeing construction.</p> <p>Below: Detail from Trajan's Column (113 CE) shows a mobile ballista mounted on a cart.</p> <p><img src="images/trajan-ballista.jpg" alt="Roman soldiers with a horse-drawn cart" width="60%"></p> <p>Below: Various siege machinery from the Hellenistic period, including ballista and catapult. From John Warry, <em>Warfare in the Classical World</em>.</p> <p><img src="images/hellenistic-catapults.jpg" alt="designs of wooden and metal siege machinery" width="60%"></p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I have lately been developing many unique and deadly weapons. The main problem we have to think about when fighting the Romans is how to get past their seemingly impenetrable walls. Taking some inspiration from our enemies, I have developed some weapons. The first being the Onager. This is basically a large slingshot operated by two people. Another is the ballista, which is similar to the onager, but can throw javelins and spears as well. Surely we will be able to do some damage on the other side of the wall with these. We anticipate the Romans will defend their city much like they have done in the past, using weapons like the hasta and pillum.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>There is a lot that we need to do to prepare for to besiege of Rome. There were many mixed emotions when it came to this besiege. “Hope and anxiety daily and simultaneously increased”(Livy, History). We all hope for a good outcome but there is so much fear and anxiety that it could go wrong. We have to get prepared to be successful. We need to make sure that we have battering rams so we can ram into the walls of the city. We also need many weapons to fight because we know that the Romans will fight back as they don’t want us to take over their city. The leaders are making sure that we are all ready to fight. “Issued orders that their soldiers should get their arms in readiness and prepare their mind”(Livy, History). The Romans will have artillery and be ready to fight back so we have to be more prepared than them. They are not going to go down without a fight so we are going to have to fight back strong. I am nervous for it to begin but I know that I need to do this for my people and I will do what I have to do.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>The Romans gigantic wall stands before us in our battle. We must figure out a way to get over it. It really is a feat like no other. We can only hope what we build will be able to do it’s job. We already know they have the high ground. They’ll be able to shoot down at us from the walls, we are at a massive disadvantage. With 13 foot wide walls, you can imagine the damage our weapons will do, or lack of. We must think of other strategies, we can’t take down an entire army with just catapults and ballistas. They won’t do the trick, we need to get inside.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I do not imagine an optimistic future of triumph, despite the position I have been placed in. Though the siege on Rome itself may prove to be effective and progress with much success, I would find myself weary of the remaining Romans and their allies- for we are far from home, in a foreign land that has made clear it does not welcome us. Yet, I imagine regardless of how bad it gets, Carthage will triumph. Our successes of recent have been excellent and pressing by all definitions of the word. The Roman's are well on the run and Carthage is in a position of unrivalled power. Naturally, we will have to subdue the Celts, but just as we have subdued the Iberians this should not be challenging. Regardless of the outcome of this war, Carthage will prevail and rise strong from it!</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I prepare for the siege by modifying and perfecting each machine and large artillery. I mainly focus on long distance weapons as I think that would be effective and more efficient for the army. One of my best pieces I have been working on is a mobile ballista. A big part of it is making sure that the horse is armoured to prevent early failure. Ideally, I hope that the army will use this for long distance combat rather than close combat. As I continue to fine tune my creations the thought of the offense of the Romans swarm my mind. The thoughts make me doubt my creations and think of all the ways the siege could go wrong. I think of how they will counter our attacks with similar equipment or breaking the artillery with ease. This makes me doubt everything even more. I imagine the Romans having better gear and more durable weapons which leads to our ultimate demise. Soon enough, all I am thinking about is the failure of the siege. To get my mind off of this, I remember my collections of scrolls back home. Surely there has to be an idea in one of the scrolls that can convince me otherwise. I rush back home to dig up my scrolls. I suddenly stumbled across a copy of a scroll by the historian Livy. With my preparation time limited, I decided to take the risk and read the scroll in hopes that it will be a turning point. I read about the developed battle plans and how effective they could've been if Hannibal actually showed up. As I read through a proclamation catches my eyes. “It seemed so great an indignity, that now even the camp of the Romans should be terrified by a tumultuary band of auxiliaries, that this cause alone kept back the Romans from crossing the river forthwith, and forming their line”(Livy 45). Knowing that my current creations seem to fit this description, I think of how the placement of larger artillery should be clustered and spread out far from each other to prevent major losses. This plan should be quite effective. I soon head back to my work site and quickly finish up my creations. I make sure that they are suitable for the land that will become the next battlefield.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I would primarily construct and use catapults in the siege of rome. Ballista can be used to great effect on the battlefield and are much weaker against fortifications. Due to the “constant refinements and technical improvement in hellenistic times” to catapults they would be greatly effective at targets rome's defensives from a far as well as their ability to soar over its walls deep into the city. I would probably set them up on a nearby hill if applicable to get a height advantage and increase the range of my ongagers even more. By targeting Rome's defenses from afar, I would wear down their defenses which would in turn limit the losses to my men when I would eventually send them in to take the city. During this time also due Rome's devastating defeat at Cannae, Rome's defenses would be low. No one would say I didn’t know how to use a victory. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hellenistic-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Cartledge, <em>The Spartans</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rBGcJIpy6D3J_BD1s8Pni2g2nWHtkhcK/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">These excerpts</a> from Paul Cartledge's wonderful book, <em>The Spartans: An Epic History,</em> provide insights into the situation of the Helots under Spartan rule.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Forces of oppression faced by Helots</li> <li>Methods of resistance the Helots employed</li> <li>The role of the Helots in Spartan society</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal|Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Helot Scenario |Helot]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Cartledge, <em>The Spartans</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1aoC5XmlKl6jql0Od_si9b5AT0widOKEV/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This chapter</a> from Paul Cartledge's wonderful book, <em>The Spartans: An Epic History,</em> examines the situation of women in Sparta.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Forces of oppression faced by Helots</li> <li>Methods of resistance the Helots employed</li> <li>The role of the Helots in Spartan society</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Tyrtaeus (c. 625 BCE) |tyrtaeus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Xenophon (c. 380 BCE) |xenophon]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Helots in Sparta |cartledge-helots]]</li> <hr> <li>[[About women in Sparta |cartledge-women]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Done collecting material?</h2> <p>Your notes from this source are saved. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal|Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Helot Scenario |Helot]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>William the Conqueror</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1kwMGLK4jETCb8SVyPXczcKmbuOUgJKea/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This wonderful chapter</a> from Michael Wood's lively book, <em>In Search of the Dark Ages</em> provides an in-depth analysis of the Battle of Hastings, focusing on the figure of William "the Bastard," Duke of Normandy, who defeated King Harold at the Battle of Hastings and became the first Norman French king of England. That event has long been viewed as a major turning point in history, at which the Battle of Hastings was an epic clash of cultures (old fashioned, nationalistic, democratic Anglo-Saxon vs. new, feudal, hierarchical Norman). This paradigm has numerous logical and methodological flaws, and is no longer espoused by modern historians. Still, it reverberates through much of the popular perceptions of the Norman Conquest, including the many re-tellings of the Robin Hood legends. So it's an interesting moment in the history of Western Civilization. Wood's chapter on William is a valuable source of well-researched detail and commentary.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the English and the Normans at the Battle of Hastings</li> <li>Key moments at the Battle of Hastings</li> <li>Turning points or contingencies that could have turned out differently or been handled differently by Harold</li> <li>The relative situations of Harold and William as claimants to the English throne before the Battle of Hastings</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastwe1" `$hastwe1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastwa1" `$hastwa1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastwe2" `$hastwe2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastwa2" `$hastwa2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastwe3" `$hastwe3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastwa3" `$hastwa3 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastwe4" `$hastwe4 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastwa4" `$hastwa4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Viking poetry |skaldic]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Ring-giving |rg]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Battle of Stamford Bridge |snorri]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Bayeux Tapestry |bt]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Battle of Hastings |conquest]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Battle of Hastings Scenario |Hastings]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Pope Urban II's Call for Crusade</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In 1095, Pope Urban II began the crusades with <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1rCqitG0fRUtIUSXwNTG4_MSm7ay3VeBYyOeIKAIP90o/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this speech</a> at the Council of Clermont, calling for knights from western Europe to defend Byzantium from the advancing Muslim armies.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How the medieval elite understood the crusade movement</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elcre1" `$elcre1 ??
