Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-e]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: Eleanor of Aquitaine |Eleanor]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Crusaders</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Seccondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fihNdu1Ak3pBjTlnSlNmwuxSxrRRfPaF/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This chapter</a> of the <em>Cambridge History of War</em> offers a close and scholarly examination of the motivations and methods of the crusaders, including details about the nature of crusade warfare. It provides a rich sense of the wider political, ideological, economic, and military context of the Battle of Hattin, as well as reflections on the historical significance of the crusades more broadly.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Typical features of crusade warfare (e.g., weapons, tactics, strategy, advantages and disadvantages when facing Muslim armies)</li> <li>The kinds of concerns that would have shaped Gui de Lusignan's decisions and outlook at the Battle of Hattin</li> <li>How a different outcome of the Battle of Hattin might have altered the course of the history of the crusades</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knce1" `$knce1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knca1" `$knca1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knce2" `$knce2 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: King of Jerusalem |Hattin]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $defenceExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Defence]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>When Viking invaders took over most of England, who mounted a successful resistance and negotiated a peace settlement?:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$defenceExploreQ1" "A">>King Alfred the Great</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$defencexploreQ1" "B">>Archbishop Wulfstan</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$defenceexploreQ1" "C">><<Aethelred "the Unready"</label></p> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "defence-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($defenceExploreQ1 is "A") and ($defenceExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $defenceExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Potion">><<set $potion to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Defence]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Defence]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $defenceExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Defence]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Kiev and Novgorod were founded by:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$defenceExploreQ2" "A">>the Huns.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$defenceExploreQ2" "B">>a Shi'ite faction.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$defenceExploreQ2" "C">>the Vikings.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "defence-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($defenceExploreQ2 is "C") and ($defenceExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $defenceExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Defence]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Defence]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>As in Roman times, slavery was a common feature of early medieval society. The church prohibited enslavement of Christians, but of course this didn't stop the pagan Vikings. Slaves were a significant portion of the plunder taken by Viking raiders. Most of the goods traded to the Muslim world were humans. The slavers were typically pagan Vikings raiding western Europe or Christian Franks raiding the pagan Slavs.</p> <p><img src="images/ema-slave-value.jpg" alt="chart showing high value of slaves in the Islamic world compared to the Christian West" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Historian Michael McCormick's massive study, <em>The Origins of the European Economy: Communication and Commerce, AD 300 - 900</em> (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002), includes original archival scholarship on the early medieval slave trade. In this chart, McCormick provides a dramatic demonstration of the wide profit margin to be obtained by trading slaves from western Europe to the Islamic world.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Monasteries were basically Viking candy: Typically near a river or coast, full of treasure and beer, defended by monks rather than fighting men. The map below shows Viking, Magyar, and Muslim invasions in Europe, c. 800 - 1000 (from Bennett and Bardsley, <em>Medieval Europe: A Short History, Twelfth Edition</em> (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2020)</p> <p><img src="images/map-viking.jpg" alt="map of Europe" width="80%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p><img src="images/viking-module.jpg" alt="painted stone carving of viking ship with sail and vikings"></p> <p><img src="images/viking-oslo.jpg" alt="remains of viking ship in a museum"></p> <p>This is what you don't want to see on the horizon. The Anglo-Saxon nobleman, Athelweard, recorded this poetic description of a Viking crew in his <em>Chronicle</em>: "They drove their oars, laid down their gear, their weapons glittered red on the churning wave …" (Images above: First, a Viking ship on a rune stone (or "picture stone") from seventh-century Sweden. Second, the reconstructed remains of a Viking ship in Oslo Viking Ship Museum (Norway).)</p> <p>There are no Vikings without Viking ships. These were incredible vessels, powered by oars and sails, with innovative construction like a sharp keel to bite into the waves, enabling a skilled helmsman to tack close to the wind. There were large ships for long-distance colonization, like Lief Erikson's voyages to (briefly) North America and Greenland. And there were smaller ships that could carry small warbands far inland, up shallow rivers.</p> <p><img src="images/vikingships1.jpg" alt="viking ship replicas at a dock" width="80%"></p> <p><img src="images/vikingships2.jpg" alt="view of viking ship interior showing rolled up sails and rock ballast" width="80%"></p> <p><img src="images/vikingships3.jpg" alt="viking ship " width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Many years ago, as a grad student at Cambridge, I attended a training event about Old Norse paleography in Copenhagen, Denmark. One field trip took us to the <a href="https://www.vikingeskibsmuseet.dk/en/" target="_blank">Roskilde Viking Ship Museum</a>, where we set sail in one of these Viking ship replicas and rowed around the bay. The stones you see served as ballast.) The experience got me thinking about the strong group cohision Vikings developed as a team of rowers. This would have been incredibly useful in a combat situation. No surprise they usually won.</p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>The Vikings are crafty and we must all be ready. Just because they have not shown up yet does not mean they are not too far off. We all have heard or witnessed first hand the horrors of their raids. They strike without warning, relying on tricks and schemes when they are not taking up arms. The people in this village must be armed and ready to fight at any given time. Those closer to the shores need to be vigilant, keeping a constant eye on the waters around us, ready to give a signal when they arrive. When the Vikings appear (and they will) we must greet them cautiously. We do not want any more bloodshed so hiding our treasure and having the women and children flee seem to be our only choices. In the rare case that they come to negotiate, we will listen to what they have to say, but we will not blindly trust them.The moment they have us fooled is the moment they will strike. These bloodthirsty ravagers in their own twisted minds believe themselves to be good natured. They do not understand that by not accepting God, they are condemned. Yet they proudly boast of tales of battles as if they are heroes in their own minds, but it “is wise not to believe all the Vikings tell you about Vikings.” Our village would be much safer if they converted and baptized, to finally see the errors of their ways. It is wishful thinking but I doubt that “...the holy bath (would) do the evil, treacherous Vikings any good.”</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>With a raid looming over there is much to do to prepare for what is to come. My first priority would be to keep my family safe, and away from all of this. If I had the money and resources I would send my family far away in a place I know they will be safe. Next I would prepare for battle. I would need to prepare and stock up on weapons. “Weapons of offense are limited to spears and swords”(Brooks.“Arms and Armour). Once I have weapons to use I would wait. The vikings always have a plan, “They would attack at night, slaying those lying buried in the calm of a deep sleep.(Dudo,History). Knowing that they would come at night I would get together with others in the village and we can take shifts staying up at night watching and waiting. If we see the ships heading our way we can get started on an attack while they are still on water. We can use bows and arrows and start an attack then maybe they will turn back as they don’t like to fight battles they can’t win. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>The first thing we have to think about is how we’re going to prevent them from getting in. It’s easier said than done. They often attack at night, so we should push for more guards at the shores during the nighttime hours. They also prefer short range weapons, which is an advantage for us. If we can strike before they even make it ashore we should have victory. Especially since they rely on their shields for defense. They don’t use spears as much as the sword or ax. I wonder, is it to make their pillage more personal that way? Them wanting to get up close to their opponent is a brutal thought. They don’t wear much armor, especially not on their heads. We should strike where they’re weakest; they are fools for not protecting the most important part of their bodies. But then again, maybe it’s to get personal with their enemy. Helmets often block the face, they want the villagers to see who's destroying their village. They’re also smarter than they look. We must be wary, especially if they make it ashore with words of peace. They are not to be trusted. They wouldn’t quickly throw away their love for battle for some simple reason.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>As I sip my wine, I clear off my side of the dining table. I pull out a map displaying our village and the surrounding areas. I explain to the table how our home is quite defended from the natural landscapes and water barriers but we can't rely on it as our attackers now have boats. I examine the map and try to find possible escape routes or hiding spots if the time comes. I fret that there will be no way to truly defend our village and the only option would be to gather our things and abandon home early before we are attacked. A breeze of cold air enters the hall and I shiver. Fear suddenly fills me as I remember a story about a village facing the same situation. The worst part being that it was windy and caused the vikings’ boats to sail faster. I remember the story explaining how the vikings preferred to attack at night and use the shadows to kill without causing a scene (Dudo c.1020). I quickly come up with an idea and announce it to the table. My idea to prevent the raid is to trade with the vikings or possibly make a deal with them. My father is quick to shut me down by saying it's the most stupid idea and we all will die within minutes. He then gets everyone to join him and pressure me to give up on finding a solution. I pack up the map and feel hopeless of any plan while everyone else goes back to socializing, eating, and drinking. I step outside in the frigid air and glance over the darkness of the shore. I rethink an excerpt of the story in my head: “Hasting boasts to his followers that they have captured Rome, the head of the world, mistress of nations. Eventually, he finds out that it is not Rome. In his anger, he leads his band on many raids throughout the countryside and reduces Luna to ash and rubble. Great slaughter occurs. Captives are taken back to the ships. By sword and fire they destroy everything they see” (Dudo c. 1020). I now can see how screwed we are and how we might as well just give up. A figure of a long black shape on the night horizon captures my gaze and I am startled. I think it must be my mind tricking me as I am tired at the moment but as I do a double check, I notice the shape is slowly moving closer. I panic and before I can tell the whole group, I grab my wife and take her aside and explain that they are here. I tell her that I'm going to confront them and try to talk to them. In the meantime I want her to gather our belongings from our home and run off and hide in the old abandoned well and I will come find her. I tell her that if I don’t find her by morning that she should run off to the next village and live on without me. She seems quite shocked and worried but I try ressasure her. I then hug her one last time and run off to the stables and saddle up my horse. I ride off into the dark towards the shore. As the shoreline and the dark outline of a ship gets closer, I begin to worry that my plan will fail and all that I know and care for will be long gone</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>response</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Those Pagans are coming sooner rather than later and time is off the essence. In order to ensure that me and my fellows do not fall victim to the vikings the most important thing for us to do is to adjust our sleep schedules and set up a night watch. The Bastards will strike at the dead of night and kill us in our sleep. No amount of preparation matters if we are asleep and unaware of their assault. Once a night watch and our sleep schedules have been adjusted, the wisest thing to do would be to train our men as archers. When those Pagans are on their boats it is impossible to harm them through any other means other than arrows. And considering they are advancing on to our ground, having ranged weaponry would allow us to pick off a few of them before they would be able to get close to us. It may also be wise to relocate our treasure. If we move our riches to the front of the city and give those dragons easier access to it, they may be less inclined to wade deeper into the city and harm the denizens of this town. Another idea although I have no idea if it would work would be to make our forces seem stronger than they are. If we use wooden pylons and hay bales maybe we can trick the barbarians into thinking we have more than we actually do, and seeing that we might have numerically superior numbers they may very well leave. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Since the Vikings are a savage and dangerous group of people, it will be hard to defend myself. The first thing I will do is arm the village that I am living in and teach the people how to protect themselves. This will make the village similar to a small army which will help protect us from the Vikings. I also wanted to maybe set up traps around the village so that if any Vikings try to attack, they will fall into these traps that we created. A quote from the source Weapons and Armor by Nicholas Brooks states, “ In contrast with Brunanburh, where the poet placed the main emphasis on the English warriors fighting with swords, in Maldon the emphasis in the descriptions of combat is on the use of spears.”. These are the types of weapons that were used by the Vikings which given their effectiveness or raiding villages my army will also adopt these weapons due to the fact that the Vikings were able to be so successful with them. The last source that I will use is called Dudo, A Viking raid this source states, “These Dacians [a group of Vikings] sail far out on the ocean, and voyaging out from their camp, they would raid and pillage the lands nearby. They would attack at night, slaying those lying buried in the calm of a deep sleep. After they had looted everything their eyes could find, they would return to their ships, taking everything as booty. They never actually met and fought with anyone, in all of Francia.” Given the fact that the Viking will attack a night I will set up a night outpost which will be a lookout and we will also have an alarm bell that will be rung in times of danger such as a potential raid. Given all these tactic's that I will use, hopefully I will be able to protect my village and my family from these raids. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Our village is in a prime location, so I know that eventually the Danish will come to raid us. We could stay and fight, but our odds don’t look too good for that situation. Our numbers are low due to previous raids. It’s also the winter months and all of us are cold and hungry. Not to mention the children we have to care for, both our own and those of the nearby village. We could stay and fight, or we could flee. We could cross over the mountains to another village, and hope they will take us in. The journey will be hard though, and no doubt we’ll lose at least a few people to the elements. But is it better than staying and having us all die to the danish? I think so. I don’t want to spend the rest of my life wasting energy futilely defending this place.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>"They would attack at night, slaying those lying buried in the calm of a deep sleep. After they had looted everything their eyes could find, they would return to their ships, taking everything as booty." (Dudo, History)</p> <p>We don't know many things about the Vikings and how they attack, but we need to prepare a plan. We know little but we do know that they attack during the night, sneaking into towns and murdering everyone in their sleep. To do as much as we can to avoid this kind of attack or be aware of one, we will use a nightwatch. People will be stationed on lookouts during the night, and possibly the day. (Dudo, History)</p> <p>"And how do you translate such phrases as plebs immunda (‘that filthy race’?) squalidæ turmæ (‘disgusting squaddies’?), lues immunda (‘a filthy pestilence’?), and rex. . .foetidus (their ‘stinking king’?)" (Page, "Vile People"). Those phrases are some of the different sayings, and words people call the vikings. We call them this because those things are what they are. They steal and kill for no reason, just for the treasures. So another part of our plan for the raid that is coming is to hide away as best as we can anything that is extremely important, then leave out other "valuables" as a distraction. (Page, "Vile People").</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>A Viking raid c. 860</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Norman monk Dudo de Saint Quentain, writing his <em>History of the Normans</em> c. 1020, recorded <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1IrD6FsboCIZdoL7yRTgeKXcWsoFX6LNy9qIiabWAlPY/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this story of a Viking raid</a> on an Italian town c. 860. </p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Techniques Vikings used when attacking a town</li> <li>Viking goals and strategies</li> <li>Potential biases in the chroniclers whose works tell us about the Vikings</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defde1" `$defde1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defda1" `$defda1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defde2" `$defde2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defda2" `$defda2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defde3" `$defde3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defda3" `$defda3 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defde4" `$defde4 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defda4" `$defda4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[A Viking raid |dudo]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Battle of Maldon |maldon]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Arms and armor at the Battle of Maldon |brooks]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Slave Raiding and Slave Trading |slave-raiding]]</li> <hr> <li>[[A Most Vile People |vile]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-d]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Defence Scenario |Defence]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $elExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Hastings]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Flying buttresses, pointed arches, rib vaulting, and stained glass are features of which architectural style?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$elExploreQ1" "A">>Gothic</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$elExploreQ1" "B">>Romanesque</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$elExploreQ1" "C">>Germanic</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "el-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($elExploreQ1 is "A") and ($elExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $elExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Book">><<set $book to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Eleanor]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Eleanor]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $elExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Eleanor]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Christians and Jews who lived in areas conquered by the Muslims:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$elExploreQ2" "A">>were executed if they refused to convert to Islam.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$elExploreQ2" "B">>were deported to Christian Europe.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$elExploreQ2" "C">>enjoyed special privileges and a low tax rate.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "el-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($elExploreQ2 is "C") and ($elExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $elExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Bow">><<set $bow to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Chalice">><<set $chalice to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Eleanor]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Eleanor]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>Hildegard of Bingen led a brilliant career as a church leader. A powerful player in twelfth century high politics, she corresponded with, negotiated with, debated, and occasionally chastized figures as powerful as popes and bishops, and the charismatic Cistercian Bernard of Clairvaux. She published widely on medicine, natural history, saints' lives, heresies, crusades, and contributed to the current debates of the twelfth-century academic scene. In her intellectual achievements, Hildegard stands alone. But the power she wielded as a woman in the medieval church was not anomalous. Though medieval society was patriarchal, many women acted with as much autonomy and wielded as much power as their male contemporaries. A career in the church could free women from some of the constraints and sources of inequality they would have faced in the secular world. (For instance, a couple of Merovingian princesses who resented being put into nunneries led the nuns in all-out military rebellions that were not unsuccessful (for a time...).</p> <p>Hildegard was a mystic and a visionary whose prophetic connection to God was acknowledged and legitimized by the pope. (I wonder if he ever regretted doing that, when he received some of her stinging rebukes, spoken as a prophet of God in the thundering style of Isaiah!) She wrote about her visions and the theological systems they inspired her to formulate, accompanying these texts with magnificent, complex illustrations, including the examples below.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> <p><img src="images/hildegard-vision1.jpg" alt="circular composition of angels singing" width="80%"></p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p><img src="images/hildegard-vision2.jpg" alt="abstract diagram of creation" width="80%"></p> </div> </div> <p>And when she got bored, Hildegard created her own secret language. So, the lady was basically a genius. We might call her a polymath, I guess? Today, Hildegard is most widely remembered for the music she composed. People continue to savor and to record it today. Here is her <a href="https://youtu.be/puAOTgq3Wkc?si=udVp1XgGycJL-Caw" target="_blank">"Columba aspexit"</a> (one of my favorites), and <a href="https://youtu.be/5TdkOE3-vMQ?si=F9Oln_bTx3j6kxAI" target="_blank">an antiphon,</a>, and <a href="https://youtu.be/zUlRIqu-74E?si=q8jEPiBCNOfyBRkz" target="_blank">"O ecclesia"</a> (also incredible, if you like this kind of thing).</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>As a teenager, Eleanor married the French king Louis VII, later known as Saint Louis (not to be confused with Louis the Pious, who was a very French king). Eleanor's Louis did become quite saintly. But he didn't start out that way. He wasn't the oldest son, and he was raised for a career in the church, while his elder brother was groomed for the throne. But his brother died in a hunting "accident" at the age of 15, and everyone except Louis heaved a sigh of relief because (the older brother seems to have been pure evil). But Louis was disappointed. He didn't want to be king! Yuck. He was totally into his church career and hated the sudden pivot toward a career of chivalry.</p> <p>Big surprise, Louis wasn't totally amazing at being king. And then he had a really bad experience. It happened when he went to war against some of his vassals at Eleanor's instigation. Her sister wanted to marry a dude who was already married, and Eleanor got Louis involved on her sister's side. Anyway, long story short, Louis finds himself on a hilltop just outside a town that's being sacked by his mercenaries. The mercenaries are everything on fire. The townsfolk are fleeing to the (stone) church for sanctuary and safety. But the wind shifts and the fires spread to the church. The wind is blowing toward the king on the hilltop. He can smell something like 1,500 people cooking, and he can hear them screaming. He's trying to send orders to stop it, but the flames don't listen, and neither does anyone else. This incident causes something to snap in the already emotionally battered young man's mind. What the chroniclers describe is what we would call PTSD. From then on, Louis starts living like an aescetic saint. Among other things, this means he's not going to beget a child. When he hears Bernard's call for holy crusade at Vessaly, it's like a rope thrown to a drowning man in a storm. He finally has something to live for: a martyr's death on holy crusade.</p> <p>Eleanor goes with Louis on crusade. It was a military disaster, but Eleanor seems to have enjoyed luxury and adventure on the trip, including (probably) an affair with Raymond, the French crusader king of Anthioch. (She asks to be left behind with Raymond, instead of going home with Louis. She doesn't get away with that, but when they get home from crusade, her marriage with Louis is annulled. This was fairly common for aristocratic marriages, because the rules were kind of impossible: Marriage was forbidden within 4 degrees of affinity. Since the noble houses of Europe were tangled together like a nest of snakes, most aristocratic marriages had some kind of technical impediment (usually involving consanguinity), and could be annulled if people wanted to do that.</p> <p><img src="images/eleanor-chinon.jpg" alt="fresco of medieval nobles on horseback" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: Louis and Eleanor with other nobles on crusade (13th-century fresco from a chapel at Chinon, France).</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>What most people know about Heloise is her relationship with Abelard. As a young woman, Heloise was widely known for her intellectual ability. Abelard was an ambitious young monk with a promising career as a leading intellectual ahead of him. When Heloise's relatives let Abelard stay at their house in exchange for his tutoring services for Heloise, the pair became sexual partners. Heloise became pregnant but refused a traditional marriage with Abelard because it would end his brillian career as a scholar. Instead, they married in secret. Heloise's relatives became abusive and castrated Abelard (it's a miracle he survived this, considering medical care in twelfth-century Europe). Heloise and Abelard took monastic vows at separate establishments and each continued to flourish in their scholarly careers. Abelard in particular, became something of a celebrity, feuded with Bernard of Clairvaux (and other powerful people), and was convicted of heresy. This illustration (below)from a 15th-century French manuscript shows Heloise and Abelard in earnest conversation.</p> <p><img src="images/heloise-abelard.jpg" alt="man and woman talking" width="80%"></p> <p>The two exchanged letters throughout their lives. These letters, along with Abelard's autobiography called <em>The History of Calamaties</em>, have somehow survived through the centuries, and can tell us a good deal about the lives and outlook of the twelfth-century intellectual elite (male and female). Of the many memorable lines is one in which Heloise tells Abelard that women are better suited to monastic life than men, because women's bodies are naturally "wet" (according to the medieval science of bodies and "humors"), and monks drink a lot, so it's a perfect life for women. And here's Abelard recalling their early romance in his autobiography: "We exchanged more kisses than learned propositions. My hands returned more often to her bosom than to our books."</p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>My monastic order would accept all women, regardless if they are a virgin, have been married, or have been widowed. Our goals are to not only become closer to God but become closer to ourselves, to serve the community through charity, and to create our own community and share knowledge and advice amongst ourselves. Some of our rules would be that everyone shares the work evenly, there is no judgment or shaming of other women, no bringing men to the convent, and to help those less fortunate in any way we can. Chivalric romance will have no place in our interpretation of Christianity because if I have the power to create my own monastic order I will free other women from the suffering that comes with love. Our dedication to Christ and dedication to discovering our potential, our values, and our highest spiritual selves will nourish us more than any romance could.</p> <p>My advice to Bernard of Clairvaux would be to not go through with a third crusade. But since that will likely not happen, I would say to see humanity in others despite their relationship with God. Perhaps they are not as vile as we think they are, their lives just simply have not allowed them to discover the power of Christ. Hopefully, the results from this conversation would be that he condones less violence and instead offers teachings of Christ.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "knights-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Dear Bernard of Clairvaux, I have been thinking over your idea for a prospective third crusade. I, and everyone else in europe, have seen what the first two crusades have done to our world. Funds have been depleted, spirits have been low, and religious morale has never been as low as it is now. I understand the role of the crusades is to provide the world with an explanation as to why christianity is the only way to be - but I fear the wars are too disheartening to do much good. The places we are fighting and imposing christianity on are becoming less and less receptive. Shall I suggest another solution instead? Perhaps a series of ultimatums - Tell these countries that they must follow christianity or else have us come down on them tenfold.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "knights-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Well as a woman myself my monastic order would be women only. The goals of my monastic life would be to make sure that women get educated. Women normally didn’t have access to education but they would be able to in this monastery. Many people who wanted to become nun did so because “ they desired to live a life which brought them closer to God”(Cartwright, “Daily Life”). There were also some other more not as desirable reasons to become a nun, “Only had two options, marry someone who could support you or become a nun” (Cartwright , “Daily Life"). Now I feel bad for those women because being a nun you can’t marry and as someone who is a chivalric romance that would be hard. Although not all monasteries are just women you could have mixed monasteries which I definitely am open to the idea. I would love to see some secret romances happening, Now how would I afford all of this. Well I am a rich woman and would be able to provide most of the funds that I would need to run a well established monastery. I could also receive donations which I would always welcome with open arms so I could spend more money on myself. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "knights-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>A third crusade? As a Christian I do agree to reclaiming the holy land, but there’s a human cost to it. Yes it is increasing our land and trade, however the cost of human life should be above all else. Even serving God. I am conflicted. I feel a need to serve my God in any way possible, but should that include more violence and death for those who oppose. I know there is no peaceful solution, I am no fool. However, if there is a way to prevent this horrific violence. This is not what God would want. I must talk to Heloise more about this, the conflicting nature of this is intense.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "knights-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Before a third crusade should happen, it is my duty to suggest that Bernard of Clairvaux should evaluate the standing of the Holy Land at this moment. Following the first two crusades, while we have built up many alliances we also have created many rivalries, and we must take this time to form a better plan of control.The progress that has been made in the Holy Lands are vital for any future attempts, and our unity among the other Christian kingdoms will determine our success overall. Bernard should work towards uniting the other Kingdoms first, and appeasing any political problems we have with our neighboring territories before he even considered another crusade. While his speeches alone can inspire many to join his cause, it is also important to remind those rallied of the reasons and religious duties that they must hold themselves to. Too many are eager to enlist and sail off to the Holy Lands only to find themselves ill equipped in supplies, training, and knowledge of what they are about to face. The previous crusades have shown us that this fight will not be easy to win and that it is vital to learn from our previous failures in order to avoid more defeats. Another defeat in Jerusalem would lead to instability, showing the world that we are not as powerful as we once thought ourselves to be.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "knights-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I search around the edges of the courtyard before I wander onto the paths towards the center. I find the centerpiece surrounded by brush and another path leading to a small flower garden. I head towards the garden and am glad that I have found Heloise. I approach her and we speak for a bit about some of the stuff that happened in our day. I then bring up the topic of crusades, the church, and pope Eugene. I mention how the pope wants Bernad to make a third crusade despite his previous failure and how this has caused Bernad to ask me out of all people for advice. I tell her my worries about my lack of guidance and how I need help with forming an idea to give Bernard. Heloise speaks so calmly about the topic which just further worries me. She brings up the past failed crusade and the current status of Europe. She lets me think about it before I look at her in confusion. She then leaves me the words: “All who die by the way, whether by land or by sea, or in battle against the pagans, shall have immediate remission of sins”(Francos c.1095). I question her for a more clear answer but she doesn't budge. She ends up leaving me in the courtyard in curiosity of those words. Later on, I repeat those words over and over until my mind tries to make sense of it. Suddenly a thought hits me. I believe that the words are telling me that no matter what happens in the crusade, whether we die or not, we are all still devoting our worth to the church, therefore we will not die in vain. When the time comes I write out my letter. I draft it with the words and I encourage Bernard to go on with the crusade as we will be further proving our loyalty to the church no matter what happens. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "knights-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Gender and Slavery</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1HAZCueVok58Ye-f2-fOxMaePBXnNV6t-/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This chapter</a> from David Eltis, <em>The Rise of African Slavery in the Americas</em> makes extensive use of original archival research to explore the intersections of gender, capitalism, and racism in the emerging Atlantic economy of the early modern West. It's not an easy read, but you might enjoy its stimulating and incisive distillation of primary source data into (sometimes surprising) profound conclusions.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>item</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Few texts by Stoicism's founder, Zeno of Citium, have survived, and the <em>Enchiridion</em> was written in the second century CE.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[Back: Alexandria Scenario |Alexandria]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>An African Boy is Enslaved</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-FmyX3SJaMUZIJEIMuplVz0Lpxl7ptp5Y2wJ9eMUIcc/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This excerpt</a> from the autobiography of Olaudah Equiano was written about a century after our course ends. However, very, very few first-hand accounts of the experience of enslavement in the Atlantic slave trade have survived. Equiano's autobiography is precious indeed. Keep the chronological distance between this role play scenario (c. 1615) and Equiano's enslavement (c. 1770s) in mind as you approach this incredibly powerful, informative source.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The experience of enslavement in the Atlantic slave trade system</li> <li>The impact of the Atlantic slave trade on African societies, culture, communities, families, individuals</li> <li>Important dynamics in the development of antiblack racism in the early modern West</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div "Marginalia" boxes? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance |Renaissance]]</li> <li>[[Back: An African Artist |Artist]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $forExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Forester]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Question text</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$forExploreQ1" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$forExploreQ1" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$forExploreQ1" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "for-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($forExploreQ1 is "A") and ($forExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $forExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Potion">><<set $potion to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Forester]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Forester]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $forExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Forester]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>In a medieval village, the common lands:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$forExploreQ2" "A">>were cultivated by everyone and the harvest was used to support the poor.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$forExploreQ2" "B">>belonged to the serfs, but not the free peasants.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$forExploreQ2" "C">>were used for grazing livestock by the free peasants of the village.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "for-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($forExploreQ2 is "C") and ($forExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $forExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Lance">><<set $lance to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Forester]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Forester]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>A margrave was basically a count or duke of a marcher county in the Holy Roman Empire, since Charlemagne. A marcher county was on "the marches," or the frontiers, so a margrave (English equivalent of "marcher lord") had to have a certain amount of competence as a military leader. Swabia, bordering troublesome old Lombardy, and near the rising power of the Italian states, was a marcher county.</p> <p><img src="images/hre1200.jpg" alt="map of central Europe" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Map of the Holy Roman Empire, c. 1200.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Your trap is a bow trap. The hidden bow fires its arrow when an animal (ideally, a wolf) trips the cord at ground level. Royal law requires that a bow trap be protected by neck-level cords as well, across the path before and after the armed trap. This way, only something the height of a wolf could trigger the deadly bow.</p> <p><img src="images/stuttgart-bow.jpg" alt="man in cloak with drawn bow" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: A drawn bow in the Stuttgart Psalter (Germany, c. 820) shows the type of bow this forester probably used.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Jealous of his hunting rights, Charlemagne used his royal power to kick the peasants out of the forests. His aggressive new legislation privatized the forests and criminalized various forms of hunting and trapping. The new laws even forbid peasants to defend themselves from predatory wolves, a task the emperor delegated to royal appointees called the <em>luparii</em>.</p> <p>Controling the wolf population was also a task of the local foresters. Foresters were appointed by the king or emperor to enforce forest laws, and they occupied an unusual place in medieval society. They were peasants, but they regularly interacted with the nobility and enjoyed special legal and economic privileges, like exemptions from court meetings and military service. They tended to be more competent with horses and weapons, and have a higher income than most peasants. The position tended to be hereditary. (Why do you think that would that be?).</p> <p>People were terrified of wolves (as reflected in oral traditional fairy tales like Red Riding Hood, or legends of werewolves). According to a learned 9th-century text based on Isidore of Seville's <em>Etymologies</em>, "With a greedy fury the wolf kills whatever it finds. … It is a ravenous beast eager for blood. Peasants say that a person loses his voice if a wolf sees him before he sees the wolf. For this reason people say when there is a sudden lull in a conversation, ‘Just like the wolf in the story…’ Wolves endure hunger for a long time, and after a long fast they devour everything.”</p> <p>In English, the term "wolf's head" was slang for "outlaw." Legally, everyone was required to kill or harm an outlaw if they could. That's what "outlaw" status meant, technically, and people felt the same way about wolves. It's hard to find any positive or sympathetic references to wolves from the Middle Ages. In the medieval French tales of Reynard the fox, the wolf represents the greedy and violent nobility, pitted against the smarller but resourceful fox (the peasants). (Although the Germanic motif of the beasts of battle and wolves' vague association with berserks could be seen as "positive" inasmuch as it's part of a common stock of traditional heroic themes and aesthetic.)</p> <p><img src="images/stuttgart-predators.jpg" alt="predators across a river from livestock" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: This image from the Stuttgart Psalter (Germany, c. 820) captures the peasants' attitude toward forest predators (boar, wolf, bear), who threaten their livestock.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Huntsmen and foresters occupied a liminal space in medieval society. They were commoners, but they worked closely, even intimately with the nobility. They held their positions by birthright, much like their aristocratic bosses. Stories in medieval chronicles often reflect this ambiguous status of huntsmen and foresters, who were regarded with trepidation ordinary peasants. After all, they peasants too, but more free and privileged (and heavily armed) than everyone else.</p> <p><img src="images/huntsmen.jpg" alt="hunters pursuing game in the forest" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: This scene from a fourteenth-century French hunting manual gives some idea of the close connection between the nobility and their peasant huntsmen.</p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>My plan is to take a large group of us for hunting, including the margrave. We will start at the break of dawn by a source of water, to get the best hiding places and view of animals coming to drink. I will then take a windy, nonsensical path through the forest to disorient and confuse the margrave. Sure, he may have hunted before but there’s no way he has this forest memorized like I do. If they object or are confused by my navigation, I’ll simply explain that I have been tracking the various paths and territories of the different animals for a while now. We will hunt late into the night and stay deep in the forest, that way he will rely on me to get back home. During this time, I will keep the margrave close to me, and accidentally take a wrong turn, isolating us from the rest of the group. I will lead us to a spot that is known for being populated by bears, and quickly stab him. I will leave him by a den and return to the group, telling a terrifying tale of the gigantic bear that has taken the margrave back to its awful den.</p> <p>My community has benefited from his death. The monks and kings are satisfied. The emperor is saved from deposition. My wife has her child and is able to be blessed. Those at the market keep with their rumors and snide remarks, but the life of my child means more to me than their words ever would. They knew the margrave was a traitor, and the community is satisfied that his death seemed accidental and out of anyone’s control, simply an act of nature.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "peasants-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "peasants-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>If I was to kill the margrave I would first try to separate him away from anyone else in the hunting party. Because I am a forester and have had a lifetime in the forest I should know where there is a high chance of there being wolfs and where there shouldn't be. If I can get the margrave to come with me to the spot where I killed the wolf before I could shoot the horse that he was on, that would probably cause him to get stuck under it. According the the hunting-fact-fancy, there would be more hunters there so I would probably have to get the help of another guy but I don't think that would be too hard. But if he wasn't stuck he would still be on the ground where we could stab him to death. One in the armpit and one in the stomach just like how Gregory of Tours was killed. I would say a wolf spooked his horse and he fell and died. I would also have a wolf corps to show so I could say I avenged his death.</p> <p>This death would prevent the Margrave from supporting a new anti-king. The emperor would not be deposed, which would make the monks happy. I don't believe that the emperor would have been excommunicated without it being a big deal that was made public knowledge, so I believe that these are just rumors.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "peasants-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Once I make it back home, I eat a nice meal before thinking of my plans. The village needs a change in margrave so I need to kill him; no questions asked. I finish my meal and feed my table scraps of meat to my dog before I head to the gear room. I look over the various traps and hunting gear I usually take during hunts. I think that this will need to look like a freak accident or else my head will be put on display. I think about some previous tales I've heard about kings dying in ways that may or may have not been accidental. One truly stands out to me and goes something like this: “King Louis set out for the city of Reims to stay there for a while. Before reaching the River Aisne he saw a wolf running ahead of him. He urged on his horse and chased it, but he fell. He was badly injured and carried to Rheims. He lay there in great pain for a long time and was overcome with serious swelling. Worn down from suffering he ended his days [on September 10] and was buried in the church of St.-Remigius” (Annales c. 966). This tale helps me shape my plan to cause an “accidental” death of the margrave.</p> <p>I grab some snares and the stuff needed for a bow trap. I go deep into the thicket and find a place that doesn't get much traffic. I set up my snares and bait them, I hope to capture wolves or even possibly a few bears. I then move a bit south of these traps and set up my bow trap. I then rig the trap to set off where it will either spook or not do too much harm to the mangrave’s horse. Ideally, I want the horse to buck the mangrove off and leave him down on the ground. I then remove the warning cable off the trap to increase my success.</p> <p>Now all I gotta do is wait for the snares to catch. Once they catch, I will follow through with the rest of my plan: have my dog lead the margrave through the armed trap to the snared animals (hopefully wolves and bears). Once the margrave is knocked down off his horse, I will then release the snared animals and let nature do the rest. More than likely the animals will either drag him off or leave him once they are finished, leaving little to no evidence of my plan. This is where I shall go in “late” and act all shocked in surprise before running back to the village to break the devastating news.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "peasants-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "peasants-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Assyrian Palace Friezes</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>When we think of the Assyrians, we tend to think of a brutally harsh regime built on unstoppable military might. And we aren't wrong. But (you knew that was coming, right?) ... <em>but...</em> they had a softer side, reflected in their obvious appreciation of beautiful artwork. Their stone walls of their palaces were alive with vibrantly painted, intricately detailed bas-relief carvings (or friezes). Of course, their favorite themes were grim and gruesome (war, hunting, domination), but still ... they were a little artsy. Given a choice, maybe they'd go for impaling people on spikes and shooting lions, but they were also capable of appreciating beautiful artwork (also, they were enthusiastic bibliophiles with massive libraries! Wow!). Human nature is so complex, eh?</p> <p>Here are some images from the ruins of the great palaces, mostly from Nineveh and Nimrud, c. 800 - 600 BCE.</p> <iframe src="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1YtPPI5dYNsCfUpsWVAEVcf9MvXXPYPHl/embed?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000" frameborder="0" width="1280" height="749" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Tools, technology, wepons used by the Assyrian military</li> <li>Organization, specialized units, and hierarchy in the Assyrian military and state</li> <li>Assyrian imperialist methods of control</li> <li>Military tactics (battlefield maneuvers) and strategies (big picture things like logistics, communication, finance, international relations)</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. .</p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$assyfe1" `$assyfe1 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Assyrian Army Scenario |Assyria]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Pericles, "Funeral Oration"</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Thucydides was the second earliest historian (after Herodotus), and an Athenian general during the Peloponnesian War. His <em>History of the Peloponnesian War</em> is our most important primary source for studying that event. It includes Thucydides' reproduction of <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1jUWlqTNHqsqotvJKxDg63OWmT0AZ9oCGFpo69N_p-GQ/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Pericles' famous "funeral oration."</a> Athens held an annual funeral ceremony commemorating its soldiers who had died in the war. Pericles' speech at the 431 ceremony had a deep impact.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Key themes of the political, ideological, and cultural conflicts in Athens during the late Peloponnesian Wars</li> <li>Gender norms, especially power dynamics and ideals of masculinity</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesfoe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesfoa1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesfoe2" `$periclesfoe2 ?? If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pericles Scenario |Pericles]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>From <em>Sir Gawain and the Green Knight</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>One of the finest surviving chivalric romances is <em>Sir Gawain and the Green Knight</em>, composed in England c. 1380. It contains three hunting episodes which you can find in <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rx3CAGUKZzVeVioxhBSX1iCBKmeGHDCV/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this translation of the poem</a> at pages 33-39, 40-46, 47-53. Here's a guide to find other interesting events in the story, in case you feel like exploring the fantastical landscape of <em>Gawain</em> more extensively.</p> <ul> <li>Sir Gawain accepts the Green Knight's challenge at the feast in Camelot: Part I, Stanzas 3 - 20 (pages 5 - 16)</li> <li>Sir Gawain travels to Bercilak's castle: Part II, Stanzas 3 - 19, 23 - 24 (pages 18 - 29, 32-33)</li> <li>The deer hunt: Part III, Stanzas 1 - 9 (pages 33 - 39)</li> <li>The boar hunt: Part III, Stanzas 12 - 20 (pages 40 - 46)</li> <li>The fox hunt: Part III, Stanzas 23 - 31 (pages 47 - 53)</li> <li>Sir Gawain meets the Green Knight at the chapel: Part IV, Stanzas 9 - 20 (pages 60 - 67)</li> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Aristocratic hunting practices</li> <li>The roles of huntsmen and foresters in such events</li> <li>Sources of danger on a hunt</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forgge1" `$forgge1 ?? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-f]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> <li>[[Back: Forester Scenario |Forester]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Interesting things about Gladiators</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The World History Encyclopedia has <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/gladiator/" target="_blank">a wonderful page about Roman gladiators</a>, with lots of good information and some interesting primary source images. (Note: that primary source material can count as your "primary source" for this assignment, even though it's in a secondary source).</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The experience of being a gladiator, and how it would shape Spartacus' and his army's outlook, motives, skillsets</li> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the rebels' force compared to the Roman authorities and legions</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source.
