You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-s]]</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Roman depictions of slavery |gladiators]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Plutarch's account of the rebellion |plutarch-spartacus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[A slave rebellion in Sicily |sicily-slaves]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Spartacus' rebellion |strauss]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Roman slave trade |bradley]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-s]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Portal |Rome1]]</li> <li>[[Back: Spartacus Scenario |Spartacus]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Goldberg, "Peasants and Poaching"</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Jl92j6Sq3weIrvTbNAlVHGomR7ej_h0_/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">In this chapter called "Peasants and Poaching"</a>, Eric Goldberg investigates the roles of peasants as hunters for their own gains, as well as their roles as huntsmen and foresters working for their feudal lords. The book's chronological focus is the early Middle Ages, and its geographical focus is France and Germany (pretty much, the Franks). It is one of my favorite books about medieval history. I hope you enjoy it too!</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How peasants used forest resources in early medieval Europe</li> <li>How the aristocracy strove to assert their authority and ownership over forest resources, and what that would have felt like for the peasants</li> <li>How we can view the forest as a locus of class conflict and resource competition, and how that struggle played out in early medieval Europe (If anyone out there hunts or fishes, I bet you'll be thinking that things haven't changed much here.)</li> <li>The role, experiences, and social and political position of huntsmen and foresters</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forppe1" `$forppe1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forppe2" `$forppe2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Books of the Hunt |ms-hunts]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Hunting "accidents" |hunt-death]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Sir Gawain and the Green Knight |gawain]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About hunting in the Middle Ages |orme]]</li> <hr> <li>[[About peasants, poaching, and foresters in early medieval Europe |goldberg]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-f]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> <li>[[Back: Forester Scenario |Forester]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if ($greeceCombat1 is "done") and ($greeceCombat1 isnot "")>> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Greece]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-md"> <img src="images/mobs/mob2.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of grotesque creature with large ears" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p>Here is your opponent. To win this fight, choose a good response to its questionable statements about history.</p> <p>It says, "We know that Homer composed the <em>Iliad</em> and <em>Odyssey</em> during the Mycenaean Period because the type of weapons and combat he describes resemble artifacts archaeologists have dated to the Mycenaean Period. Archaeologists recognized these objects as Mycenaean because they matched the descriptions in Homer's epics."</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Let's play "name that logical fallacy" with this one!</p> <div class="row scenario"> <p><label><<radiobutton "$greeceCombatQ1" "A">> Anachronism</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$greeceCombatQ1" "B">> Correlation/causation fallacy</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$greeceCombatQ1" "C">> Circular reasoning</label></p> </div> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "greece-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($greeceCombatQ1 is "C") and ($greeceCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $greeceCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <p>Right! The risks of such circular reasoning are particularly high for historians studying early civilizations that left few written records, because archaeologists often use those records while analyzing physical artifacts, while philologists and historians use archaeological scholarship to nuance their own interpretations of textual sources. In this way, interdisciplinary can increase the risk of circular reasoning.</p> <p>With oral traditional texts like Homer's poems, linguistics, rather than content, is a better method of dating. Homer worked in the Dark Age era, but his poems are <em>about</em> the Mycenaean Period. Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Greece]]</p> <<elseif ($greeceCombatQ1 is "B") and ($greeceCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>This is a good guess! A correlation/causation fallacy would identify something as the necessary and only cause of an outcome, without considering other possible causes of that outcome. As you would imagine, it's rare to be able to accurately formulate such simple statements about something as chaotic as history. Instead, historians analyzing a "cause and effect" situation would consider a more nuanced range of factors such as:</p> <ul> <li>Efficient cause: Prior events and conditions required for an event to occur</li> <li>Formal cause: Background causes of the efficient cause</li> <li>Final cause: The will or purpose of the agent</li> <li>Necessary cause: The minimum requirements necessary for an event to occur (a question of probability)</li> <li>Sufficient cause: The conditions that will certainly produce the event (i.e. making the outcome inevitable)</li> </ul> <p>More than you wanted to know. Sorry. Better luck next time. [[Onward! |Greece]]</p> <<elseif ($greeceCombatQ1 is "A") and ($greeceCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>Anachronism (inserting our own 21st-century desires or biases into a historical situation where they didn't exist) is a common pitfall. But it doesn't describe what this monster has done here. Better luck next time!</p> <p>[[Onward! |Greece]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Greece]]</p> <</if>><<if $greeceCombat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Greece]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: (some dumb circular logic)</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$greeceCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$greeceCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$greeceCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "greece-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($greeceCombatQ2 is "A") and ($greeceCombatQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $greeceCombat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Tautology Troll and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Chalice">><<set $chalice to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Greece]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the Tautology Troll. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Greece]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <div class="row greecehero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Ancient Greece</h1> <p>You and your comrades have written a new history of the ancient Greece. Open the branching pathways to explore it.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center space"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Spartan Helot Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/spartan-woman.jpg" alt="statue of woman running" width="50%"> <p>You are a young Helot woman. It’s 465 BCE, and another Helot rebellion is raging ... You let yourself fantasize about a home without Spartans. A new polis will rise here. Your polis. What will its constitution be like? Which gods will it honor? What kinds of people will be free, and how free? Will women be better off, or will they still be ruled by the men?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[After a few years, our Polis has grown, and is faring to be a strong one. My husband now holds a high position in our government. Little do they know, my husband has simply been recounting what I tell him to say. |helot-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[When our rebellion is finally successful and we escape from the Spartans grip things will change. Men will not be the only ones in power, and we will all be equal. |helot-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[There will be no slavery. Men will be forced to learn practical skills and manual labor instead of pointless war tactics. |helot-rewrite3]]</li> <hr> <li>[[It is my duty to let the Athenians know that although they freed us from spartan captivity, we are people ourselves and deserve to be heard. While the future of our fate is uncertain, anything that comes next will always be better than servitude to the Spartans. |helot-rewrite4]]</li> <hr> <li>[[After freeing myself from Spartan slavery I think my first priority would be figuring out a way to provide for myself. Now in Sparta women do have more power than in other places and so if I was able to become a spartan woman I don’t think that would be a bad idea. |helot-rewrite5]]</li> <hr> <li>[[After being shut out from the meeting, I know the chances of change will either be completely withdrawn or carried out in the worst possible way. I can’t take the risk of facing a beatdown or worse if the revolution doesn't go as planned. I find my husband out and about working in the fields and quickly drag him away. I quickly speak to him about us leaving Sparta immediately. |helot-rewrite6]]</li> <hr> <li>[[And for once and for all we will abolish slavery. We fought so many years to be free why would we enslave others like we were. I think this new polis has the potential to become one of the best in the entire world. |helot-rewrite7]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I am worried about what will happen to me and my sisters. That pig Aristotle claims that we are inferior to men... |helot-rewrite8]]</li> <hr> <li>[[When creating a new society, the small things are what’s most important. How to run a house, how to do simple things, how to be patient and create a home. |helot-rewrite9]]</li> <hr> <li>[[My polis, also like the spartans would be “craftsmen of war” but without the authoritarian government. |helot-rewrite10]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I will give women as much freedom as the men have, although this could result in anger and frustration from the men half of the population will agree with me. |helot-rewrite11]]</li> </ul> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Pericles Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/thebes-vase-trireme.jpg" alt="vase painted with trireme" width="50%"> <p>You are Pericles, and you didn’t die of plague in 429 BCE. It is now 414, and as <em>strategos,</em> you have kept Athens mostly on top of this conflict with Sparta and her Peloponnesian League. Just barely. But now Persia has built Sparta a navy. ... Tonight the city will gather to hear your annual funeral oration. You want to make this one count. You <em>need</em> to make it count, like that one at the beginning of the war that people still quote at symposia and the theater. What can you say this time to steer your city toward survival, and break the spell of Alcibiades?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[It is an honor to give your life for Athens, let this speech serve as a reminder of that. Their deaths are not in vain. |pericles-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I would speak about what the common man does in his free time. ... The common man doesn't want this war to go on or to die in it they want to be at home with their wives. |pericles-rewrite2]]</li> <li></li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Start the Role Play Game |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Green, <em>Language and History in the Germanic World</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>D. H. Green's monumental work, <em>Language and History in the Early Germanic World</em> draws on a lifetime of studying medieval Germanic philology. It's an old fashioned book, harking back to the historiographical style of last century, but it's a treasure trove of historical detail, and a steadfast classic - an excellent starting point for any exploration of the history of the Germanic societies of late antiquity and the early Middle Ages. Here are two chapters: <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/19AgofRLGUBmFi6N2B0X7cKYBdUtTC-Fz/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Chapter 4, "Warfare,"</a> and <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Nd7a5QuEENZq3jZbLl3aMjP6hRLSvnUR/view?usp=sharing" target="blank">Chapter 5, "People and Army."</a></p> <p>And here's a story, just for fun. At grad school in the UK, I heard from someone who had attended a presentation by D. H. Green. Green told how while traversing some Norman hedge country as a British officer in World War II, he suddenly came face to face with a German officer. They both drew their pistols and fired hastily at one another. They both missed. Grinning sheepishly, Green addressed his foe in excellent German: "I'm glad our men didn't see that." And they both turned around and went in opposite directions.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The role of warfare in Germanic society, life, culture</li> <li>The tactics and equipment Germanic societies tended to use in late antiquity</li> <li>What individuals might adopt a warrior identity in German frontier societies, and why</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriange1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianga1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriange2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianga2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriange3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianga3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriange4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianga4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Tacitus, Germania |tacitus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Jordanes, History of the Goths |jordanes]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Germanic tribes |green]]</li> <hr> <li>[[On the late empire's frontier |law]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Barbarian Scenario |Barbarian]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $gtExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |GT]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Based on the evidence available today, it seems most likely that the Egyptian pyramids were built by:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$gtExploreQ1" "A">>Ordinary Egyptians</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$gtExploreQ1" "B">>Aliens</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$gtExploreQ1" "C">>Hebrew slaves</label></p> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "gt-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($gtExploreQ1 is "A") and ($gtExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $gtExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <hr> <p>Good choice!</p> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |GT]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |GT]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $gtExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |GT]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Based on the evidence available today, text was first developed to:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$gtExploreQ2" "A">>Record mythology and religious beliefs</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$gtExploreQ2" "B">>Preserve historical records</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$gtExploreQ2" "C">>Record business transactions</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "gt-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($gtExploreQ2 is "C") and ($gtExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $gtExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Yes. You don't need writing to pass down legends, myths, or history (at least not in ancient times). Oral traditions work fine for that. But you <em>do</em> want a physical record as proof of business transactions. Nice work! Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Potion">><<set $potion to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |GT]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |GT]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> An artist's impression of construction work at Gobekli Tepe <p><img src="images/gobekli-tepe_natgeo.jpg" alt="neolithic people building a monolithic structure" width=100%></p> <p><a href="https://www.nationalgeographic.com/travel/article/150120-gobekli-tepe-oldest-monument-turkey-archaeology" target="_blank">A. Curry. "The World's Oldest Temple to be Restored." <em>National Geographic</em>. 2016.</a></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Pillar 43, Gobekli Tepe</p> <p><img src="images/gobekli-tepe-pillar.jpg" alt="large monolith inscribed with animals" width="60%"></p> <p><a href="https://tepetelegrams.wordpress.com/2016/10/14/of-animals-and-a-headless-man-gobekli-tepe-pillar-43/">O. Dietrich. "Of animals and a headless man. Gobekli Tepe, Pillar 43." <em>The Tepe Telegrams.</em> October 14, 2016.</a></p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>After looking at all the information given I would personally not stay. Now I would see why people would want to stay, in some of the sources we see that they are starting to create agriculture centers and hunting and gathering together. We also see that they started to create these structures that could be the center of the community. My concern would be though that at any minute they could change their minds and all leave. I think that even though they were creating a community you still have to fend for yourself and I would rather not have to compete with people and just go somewhere else. I am not a fan of conflict personally so that's what I would do. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>My crew and I decided to stay and help for a while. We talked to some of the guys there and they said they were hunters and gatherers (Like us!). They shared our sentiments that people were not appreciating our way of life anymore and what is “agriculture” anyway? Why would we want to live in a stinky crowded village getting sick all the time when we could roam the plains and fill ourselves with wild grain and game? The people at the structure assured me this was not one of those settlements and instead was a place us hunter gatherers could meet up once and a while to have feasts and drink beer. My crew and I helped the people construct some new pillars and even helped dig some old ones out of the ground (apparently they had been doing this for a while). After about a month of work we had a huge feast. They brought us some beer which we enjoyed immensely. The next day we parted ways, promising to meet back up here soon in a few seasons.</p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I want to be a part of this amazing project. The work is hard, but the labor is worthwhile. The feasts they staged to attract us and convince us to work (Archaeology Magazine) were tempting enough to get me on board. There is enough beer and porridge for us all, and I have never seen so much food at one time. They have grindstones, mortars, and tools made of flint (Archaeology Magazine) that make carving out these pillars possible. My grandparents’ knowledge of herbs can help me heal injured or sick workers since I will most likely not be allowed to participate in the manual labor. Perhaps I can even grow a supply in these rich fields. For now, I will do what I can: gather water, help prepare food, and meet the other women. The depictions of spiritual myths and legends will live on beyond us. The powerful cattle, birds of prey, and foxes carved in these pillars (Tepe Telegrams) show the amazement of the animals of our world. Each season is a gamble on being able to find consistent food and water, and if we work to complete this job we will earn steady meals and beer. The detail in the faces of our gods (Tepe Telegrams) will live on and tell our stories when we are gone.</p> <p>I am grateful my group has followed my advice to stay and work. In the near future, I predict some will get sick and tired of following orders and working hard in the sun. They will most likely leave us and determine that the food and beer is simply not worth it. I also think that in the short term I will be able to establish connections with workers who are sick or injured, and learn to use the local herbs and plants to heal them. It is my pride and honor to be able to aid the construction of this holy site in any way I can. In the long term, I hope to be the town healer just like my ancestors before me. I hope to have a steady patch of herbs to use as medicine and healing aids. I also think in the distant future my group will feel fulfilled by the work. Each day we get closer to a feast and celebration of our work. I think there will be more nomads joining the group to help with making food and building.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Odetta [player name], despite the very tempting offer of beer, does not want to do any manual labor. If she had the job of preparing food or retrieving water or firewood she might have taken the offer. Unfortunately they want her and her team to carry the big stones and she doesn't want too. The secondary source, "Göbekli Tepe: Last Stand of the Hunter-Gatherers?" suggests "In 2006, after a decade of work at Göbekli Tepe, a team led by German Archaeological Institute (DAI) archaeologist Klaus Schmidt reached a stunning conclusion: The buildings and their multiton pillars, along with smaller, rectangular structures higher on the slope of the hill, were monumental communal buildings erected by people at a time before they had established permanent settlements, engaged in agriculture, or bred domesticated animals." She doesn't like where this new form of life is going. She's a free spirit. She just wants to travel. With the settlements being formed she fears the free style of life is going out of style. She is going to pack up and head for the hills. </p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I would pack up and head for the hills. As a forager, steady everyday manual labor would most likely make me restless. However, it would be nice to stay for a bit and see what the community is working on, and maybe help out a little bit as it would be fun to hang out with people who aren’t in my troupe, and we may become useful as hunters able to bring the community large animals to eat. Using one of the carvings from the temples, we can assume that “The tiny human figures encircling the large (dead?) animals clearly indicate how awe-inspiring big cattle must have been for Neolithic people. The size of the animal is emphasized also in the new depiction from Göbekli Tepe – by the smaller animal depicted alongside the large bull.” ("Tepe Telegrams") Before farming and raising cattle for milk and flesh was the norm, larger animals that haven't yet been bred for human consumption must've been a sight to marvel. ("Tepe Telegrams") Along with these depictions of animals there are tons of statues that seem to represent humans, although there is something uncanny in their nature that makes me and my troupe uncomfortable. “They seem to represent something more, supposedly something beyond the self-referential depiction of human beings. Together with the obviously narrative character of other depictions on these T-pillars which clearly exceed simple decorative purposes, this perception feeds the impression that we are confronted here with a complex iconography – with mythological narrations probably even”. ("Tepe Telegrams") Stories and folklore in early settlement communities were more than likely extremely important in the societal impact of these beer loving settlements. After trading a couple of these stories with the community, we head off. </p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I hate my job in our new town. All I do all day long is make these stupid giant T-pillars “with a height of about 5.5 m it is” so hard to get all the way on top of them to make them look good and I’m sick of it. I’ve been thinking for a long time about leaving and I think now might be the time. I really don’t have anything keeping me here and I feel like I’m wasting my life staying in the same place for so long. I liked life better “before [we] had established permanent settlements, engaged in agriculture, or bred domesticated animals,” because I was free to roam the plains and do what I wanted. The only reason I wouldn’t want to leave is because of my friend Gabe who works with me but he doesn’t want to come with me. For some reason he is content with his boring life and nothing I tell him will change his mind. I feel like if I leave I will be letting him down and I’ll be alone, but at the same time it’s what’s best for me so I think I will. I don’t mean to have an ego but I know the community will be very upset with my leaving because I am by far the best sculptor here. If only I actually liked my job I would stay and help but I just can’t do it anymore. Not even the beer is enough to make me stay, and I love beer.</p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I am so tired of wandering around and never really having a place to call my own. These people have a permanent residency and irrigated gardens so they don’t have to wander all over the place looking for something to eat like we do. Even though it is a toss up of what’s more exhausting- migrating from place to place or spending every drop of energy towards building some huge establishment that I have no idea what to make of. We are helping build these massive pillars with symbols engraved with a “mixture of animals, phallic and other symbols, and pillars resembling humans does not appear to be random or merely decorative. Some pillars, such as the one that combines a vulture, a fox, and a severed human head, seem to tell a story.” (“Features - Last Stand of the Hunter-Gatherers?) I don’t really understand what’s going on in these stories but I kind of want to stick around to find out. My girlfriend got really hooked on trying to create stories from these carvings so she's really adamant on staying. She told me long distance would never work so my options are - I either stay here with her or break up and leave. Although nothing gets on my nerves more than people ordering me around, it turns out I am exceptionally good at using flint picks “to dig channels in the form of the desired workpiece into the limestone” ("Tepe Telegrams") and after I tasted beer it was really a no-brainer to stay.</p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>If I was living in the Gobekli Tepe despite all of the rowdiness that would have taken place I would have wanted to stay. Trying to strike it out on your own or even as a small band of individuals in 11000 BCE is hard, maybe even near impossible. By staying with the group we would be increasing our numbers and increasing our chances of survival. Using the archaeological evidence provided to us we can see evidence of “carved channels in bedrock” which were likely “used for collecting rainwater.” Having reliable access to water is important for survival, and having consistent and easy access to it is a very big pull factor. Furthermore, there is “vast ethnographical evidence for big game hunting.” While big game hunting is something that can be accomplished in smaller groups, having more numbers makes it easier and safer to do. Lastly, having access to a roof over our heads or at the very least a safe place to sleep every night is a life savior.</p> <p>Outside of these survival benefits, there are also personal benefits. Humans are social beings and being able to be surrounded by them even if disagreement occurs is important. It also keeps your family together and or increases your prospects of having a family. While I don’t know if ideas like love or even the idea of a “family” really existed back then, being close to people meant it was more likely for young to survive and more likely for young to be birthed. Lastly, being able to work on these art pieces is something that is truly amazing and is a way for those in the future to know that we were here. </p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>My observations are mostly going to draw critique about the seeming primitiveness of the humans during this period. As I observed in my other set of notes, humans are incredibly resourceful even in this period: the construction of projects like Stonehenge and Tepe required large moves of stone and quarrying them into blocks with what were state of the art technology. Of particular interest to me was the designs on the Tepe steles: there is a clear knowledge and working of advanced techniques and story being told here!</p> <p>Dead Aurochs on the Pillar ("Tepe Telegrams")</p> <p>A clear conflict with nature.The Aurochs show an animal often interacted with in our world. ("Tepe Telegrams")</p> <p>intentionally abstract depictions of man ("Tepe Telegrams")</p> <p>this is an artistic choice and not just a lack of proficiency! ("Tepe Telegrams")</p> <p>Creating these artifacts was a herculean effort in their own time- stone shaping is difficult, and raising several ton stones is difficult as well. ("Stonehenge" or "Pyramids")</p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I would choose to pack up and leave. I do not want any part of it. If there are already signs of a growing dangerous environment, then it would not seem wise to stay. We are also not certain that everyone in our group is able to, or has, worked with making sculptures and building structures before. It mentions using limestone, "which means that it is a first raw material for sculpting and masonry" (Dietrich). Taken into account of my age and gender of that time frame, I do not believe a female would be taken seriously or even wanted there. With the already growing tension, I would not want to take my chances. Especially since I doubt I would have known any masonry skills to begin with. Even if I somehow knew that there were feasts for, "those who gathered for these periodic monumental building projects scattered before coming back decades or centuries later to do it all again", I still would not stay. I do not feel it worth the possible risk and harm. I do not believe that it is a safe decision to stay if we would be treated poorly. Things could simply go horribly wrong physically.</p> </div> <hr> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "Begin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $hastingsExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Hastings]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>In Germanic societies like Carolingian Francia, Anglo-Saxon England, or Viking Age Scandinavia, political leaders acquired power by:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hastingsExploreQ1" "A">>winning plunder for their war band.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hastingsExploreQ1" "B">>inheritance through the paternal bloodline.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hastingsExploreQ1" "C">>free democratic election by all members of society.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "hastings-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($hastingsExploreQ1 is "A") and ($hastingsExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $hastingsExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Bow">><<set $bow to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Treasure">><<set $treasure to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Hastings]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Hastings]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $hastingsExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Hastings]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>The medieval knight was possible because of the invention of:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hastingsExploreQ2" "A">>horseshoes.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hastingsExploreQ2" "B">>the lance.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hastingsExploreQ2" "C">>stirrups.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "hastings-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($hastingsExploreQ2 is "C") and ($hastingsExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $hastingsExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lance">><<set $lance to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Hastings]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Hastings]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>York, known to the Vikings as Jorvik, was the administrative and economic center of northern England. This region was known as the Danelaw and was ruled by Viking kings from about 850 to 950. York Minster is an awe-inspiring cathedral. I took these photos while working on my Master's degree at University of York. I passed by the minster nearly every day on my way to the Centre for Medieval Studies. The city of York is well worth a visit, if you ever venture over to the UK. Its medieval city walls still stand, and you can walk along the tops and pass through the gates.</p> <p><img src="images/york-minster1.jpg" alt="gothic cathedral tower" width="60%"></p> <p><img src="images/york-minster2.jpg" alt="interior of gothic church with tall stained glass windows and pillars" width="60%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Herald Hardrada was the ultimate Viking. He fought in full-scale battles as a teenager, and became a powerful warband leader whose adventures included service as a mercenary in the Rus kingdom of Kiev (where he married a Kievan princess), and in Byzantium as leader of the Eastern Roman Emperor's elite Varangian Guard. He built a strong power base in the old fashioned way, by winning plunder and providing effective battlefiled leadership. But he was modern and innovative too. For instance, he played the game of thrones adroitly to shoulder his way onto the throne of Norway (and nearly England, too), and he incorporated the latest tactics of heavy cavalry and archers alongside the old fashioned Germanic shield wall at the Battle of Fulford, and introduced the first royal mints (i.e., national coinage) in Norway when he became king.</p> <p><img src="images/viking-hoard1.jpg" alt="treasure" width="60%"></p> <p><img src="images/viking-hoard2.jpg" alt="treasure" width="50%"></p> <p><img src="images/viking-hoard3.jpg" alt="treasure" width="50%"></p> <p>Vikings like Hardrada plundered and traded with treasure like the collections shown above. Archaeologists found these in various Viking Age caches around northern Europe.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Sometimes, treasure turns people into monsters. Treasure used property (i.e., generously) is the core of ideal kingship. A dragon, whose greed renders treasure useless, is the antithesis of good kingship. This dichotomy pervades early Germanic legends and poetry. For instance, the image below outlines the engraving on a Viking Age rune store (picture stone) from Sweden which tells the well-known story of the legendary hero Sigurd. The artist shows Sigurd slaying the dragon Fafnir, whose lust for gold had transformed him into a dragon. Sigurd has also slain Fafnir's brother, Regin, who was a treacherous and cunning smith (note the smith's tools near Regin's severed head). Regin's and Fafnir's greed for treasure was their doom. Before dying, Fafnir warns Sigurd that the treasure hoard is cursed and will bring him death and misery. (There's a cursed hoard in <em>Beowulf</em> too).</p> <p><img src="images/sigurd-fafnir.jpg" alt="runic inscriptions and stone carving of dragon slain by figure with sword alongside smithing tools" widgh="80%"></p> <p>Clearly, in these early medieval Germanic cultures, treasure was not just money. Treasure had a heavy symbolic weight, signifying the history and character of its bearer. Legends such as the dragon Fafnir and the legendary hero Sigurd who killed him (just one example of many) reflect the deep histories embodied by specific items or hoards of treasure. In the oral traditional poetry exmplified by <em>Beowulf</em> and skaldic verse, we see that treasure items are often military (swords, helmets, armor) or items worn by individuals to display their status and history (neck and arm rings, in particular). Such personal treasure items had functional and symbolic value.</p> <p>Importantly, treasure articulated bonds of loyalty in a dynamic historians have called "reciprocity." Treasure was the life blood of a warband, flowing between warriors and leaders, expressing and creating obligations of service and loyalty. The ideal of the "generous lord" ossified in familiar kennings found throughout poetic traditions of the Viking Age. For example, a king or lord was "breaker of rings" or "gold friend" or "ring-giver," while gold was called "the strife metal of princes," or "fire of the waves" (in reference to Fafnir's legendary hoard, ultimately hidden in the Rhine River). I could go on and on (I know, that's what I'm doing. Sorry.)</p> </div><div class="link"> <p><img src="images/bt-cav-arch.jpg" alt="embroidery of cavalry and archers attacking" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: A scene from the Bayeux Tapestry (c. 1070) showing Norman cavalry and archers coordinating in an attack at the Battle of Hastings (1066).</p> <p><img src="images/bt-cav-shieldwall.jpg" alt="embroidery of knights fighting infantry with axes" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: A famous scene from the Bayeux Tapestry (c. 1070) showing the classic confrontation of "new and modern" Norman cavalry fighting the "old fashioned" Anglo-Saxon shield wall at the Battle of Hastings (1066). While the battle can justly be viewed as a watershed event in the downfall of the old fashioned Germanic shield wall, and the ascendancy of the knight, the reality was more complex. Harold Godwinson may have fought like his ancestors in this battle, but he was no stranger to the concept of modern knights. In the years before 1066, he actually visited William the Bastard in Normandy (the visit was accidental, resulting from a shipwreck), and joined him hunting, raiding, feasting - basically like any knight. The two are seen (below) hunting with dogs and falcons on the Bayeux Tapestry.</p> <p><img src="images/bt-hunt.jpg" alt="embroidery of knights hunting with dogs and falcons" width="80%"></p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>The ghost says to put care into strategies, to have a plan you believe in and to try to come up with a backup. Although you can never predict what will happen in battle, it is good to think it through as well as you can. He knows his greatest mistake was being impulsive and impatient, to let the temptation of victory take over rational thought. Although it was something that seemed so achievable and would feel so satisfying, it ended up just feeling like an arrow in the neck. He says to motivate the men by reciting verses, taking time to craft them and think them over. It reminds the men of who they are, what they fight for, and their legacy beyond death and time. To bring victory, scout out a vantage point. Find potential places and pick the best one based off visibility. Have your men go on the opposite side to see if you are visible. Once you have a spot dug out, brief your men on the strategy. Stay together and do not separate, it will leave them vulnerable even if charging the enemy seems like an easy victory.</p> <p>To deal with William I plan on keeping my men as strong and motivated as I can. I will do this by reciting verses, keeping both the men and the horses well fed, and reminding them of what victory entails. As we travel I will issue an order for my men to keep a low profile and stay together, one stray soldier can quickly alert William’s army. I believe diplomacy and force both have their place in battle. I think the treasure is a good reminder of mortality and self-control, but it can’t do anything for me. Its most important feature is to teach me and my men about why victory isn’t always promised and anger should be managed even in the deepest trenches of war. Works Cited Sturlusson, Snorri. Heimskringla: History of the Kings of Norway. Hollander, Lee, Transl. Austin: University of Texas Press, 1964. Wood, Michael. In Search of the Dark Ages. New York: Facts on File Publications, 1987.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>The Ghost of Harald Hardrada may give me some respect, as I march south. However, much to my horror, he would probably encourage me to not back down or employ underhanded means to gain victory. I need to show my courage and valor. If I try to find some underhanded conniving means of victory, it will simply make me an unworthy king, because I would not be a courageous leader. I would stick with my guns, the Shield Wall, and bravely lead my men from the Frontline, inevitably taking an arrow to my face, and meeting a premature death.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p> </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>response</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>response</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "viking-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Battle of Hattin in Context</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The Battle of Hattin may be viewed as a turning point in history. It ensured the loss of the crusader kingdom of Jerusalem, and triggered the next wave of (unsuccessful) crusades. <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1eFvpcDEFMiRwpzpGeOJqfxQl6zGr2Kk3/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This section</a> of the <em>Cambridge Atlas of Military History: The Middle Ages</em>, takes a close look at the battle and its significance for the First and Second Crusades.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the crusader and Muslim forces at the Battle of Hattin</li> <li>Motivations and outcomes of the decisions made by Gui de Lusignan and the other crusader leaders</li> <li>Weapons and armor used by both sides in the battle</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knate1" `$knate1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knata1" `$knata1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knate2" `$knate2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knata2" `$knata2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knate3" `$knate3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knata3" `$knata3 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knate4" `$knate4 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knata4" `$knata4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Crusaders take Jerusalem |sack]]</li> <hr> <li>[[An ideal knight |warewic]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Battle of Hattin in context |hattin]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Crusader warfare |crusader]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: King of Jerusalem |Hattin]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $hattinExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Hattin]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Which was the most successful crusade, from the crusaders' perspective?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hattinExploreQ1" "A">>The First Crusade</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hattinExploreQ1" "B">>The Second Crusade</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hattinExploreQ1" "C">>The Third Crusade</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "hattin-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($hattinExploreQ1 is "A") and ($hattinExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $hattinExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Hattin]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Hattin]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $hattinExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Hattin]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Islam and Christianity share all of the following EXCEPT:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hattinExploreQ2" "A">>belief in Mohammad's status as a prophet.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hattinExploreQ2" "B">>the requirement to perform charity.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hattinExploreQ2" "C">>a foundation in the Hebrew Old Testament.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "hattin-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($hattinExploreQ2 is "C") and ($hattinExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $hattinExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Hattin]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Hattin]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>Gui de Lusignan grew up in the lap of luxury. His family, the House of Lusignan, had a well-earned reputation for defying authority, waging petty wars, and doing whenever pleased them, in (often violent) defiance of royal commands. Several found themselves - like Gui here - commanding crusader armies, and even kingdoms, in the Holy Land. At home in Poitou (France), they spent their days hunting, or in tournaments, or raiding. They enjoyed a vibrant court culture including troubadours who sang and wrote a wide variety of chivalric literature. These included cultured and courtly <em>chansons de geste,</em> ("songs of deeds") full of heroic quests, tournaments, epic battles, true love and fair maidens and fairies in enchanted forests. They also included utterly trashy, scattalogical tales called <em>fabliaux</em>, featuring dirty jokes and sexual assault of peasant women. Such was the life of the medieval male aristocracy.</p> <p><img src="images/gui-de-warewic.jpg" alt="knights on horses talking" width="50%"></p> <p>Above: Gui de Lusignan would have felt at home surrounded by the green fields and richly-dressed knights of this scene from this fifteenth-century French manuscript of the popular <em>chasons de geste, Gui de Warewic</em>.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p><img src="images/hattin-map.jpg" alt="map of the crusader states with Hattin circled" width="50%"></p> <p>This map shows the location of the crusader states at the time of the Battle of Hattin (1187), and the location of Hattin and Tiberias (on the shores of "Lake Tiberias," better known as the Sea of Galilee).</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>In 1186, near the Kingdom of Jerusalem, 140 crusader knights, led by a group of Templars, met a force of Muslims numbering around 7,000. Ignoring a truce that had been agreed to between the two armies, the crusaders attacked, crying, "Christ is our life, and death is our reward!" Only four survived, one of whom was the Templar Grand Master, Gerard de Ridefort, who had ordered the suicidal charge. He was also among the leaders at Hattin. And again, he survived an otherwise bloody defeat for the crusaders.</p> <p>The graphic below represents the numerical disparity between the 140 crusaders and the 7,000 Muslims at the Springs of Cresson in 1186.</p> <p><img src="images/cresson.jpg" alt="pie chart showing few crusaders and majority of Muslims" width="50%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Crusader armies were typically vastly outnumbered by their Muslim opponents. However, their heavy cavalry was formidable. Muslim cavalry was lighter, relying primarily on bows rather than swords and lances. Muslim leaders like Saladin soon learned to develop their own form of heavy cavalry, modeled on that of "the Franks," as they called the crusaders. This scene from the Maciejowski Bible (France, c. 1240) conveys some sense of how physically overwhelming a crusader cavalry charge might be.</p> <p><img src="images/maciejowski-battle.jpg" alt="knights in battle" width="100%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Saldin was highly respected for his mastery of strategy. Like the crusader elite and other Muslim leaders, Saladin made use of diplomacy, espionage, and secrete alliances with enemy players. It's no surprise that the game of chess was popular among the Christian and Muslim elite during the Middle Ages.</p> <p><img src="images/chess-christian-arab.jpg" alt="two men play chess" width="80%"></p> <p><img src="images/chess-spain.jpg" alt="two men play chess in a tent" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: These two images from 13th-century Spain show Christian and Muslim men playing chess with each other.</p> <p><img src="images/manesse-chess.jpg" alt="man and woman playing chess" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: German Margrave Otto IV of Brandenbur playing chess with a woman (Codex Manesse, c. 1300).</p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Knights enjoyed fighting, they liked to prove themselves and show they are the better and stronger knight. Which is good because that means they are competitive, in war or battle, or not (Warewic). A part of my plan for this unfortunate event will be to, secretly, without the knowledge of Raynald and Raymond and Gerard and the rest, form a strong group of knights, for protection. Even though Saladin knows I know I will still want protection just in case of any tricks. I will also hire some very good lookouts to make sure again, we aren't being snuck up on and can defend ourselves (Warewic).</p> <p>"Even this was inadequate, and Saladin had to resort to private loans and extortion to pay his troops, for when the money failed, so did their loyalty" (Hooper et al., Atlas 1). Another part of my plan could be to try and out pay Saladin's troops. He relies on money and loyalty for them to stick fighting for him. But what happens when the money is coming from somewhere else and there is more of it? So maybe this plan could work, but it could also backfire and I would be in danger, exactly where I don't need to be. I am not sure what I will do... (Hooper et al., Atlas)</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "knights-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "knights-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "knights-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "knights-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "knights-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if ($hellenisticCombat1 is "done") and ($hellenisticCombat1 isnot "")>> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Hellenistic]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-md"> <img src="images/mobs/mobc.jpg" alt="naked man riding many-legged creature" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p>Here is your opponent. To win this fight, choose a good response to its questionable statements about history.</p> <p>It says, "Something..."</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>How will you respond to this creature's hysterical history?</p> <div class="row scenario"> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hellenisticCombatQ1" "A">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hellenisticCombatQ1" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hellenisticCombatQ1" "C">>Correct response</label></p> </div> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "hellenistic-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($hellenisticCombatQ1 is "C") and ($hellenisticCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $hellenisticCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <p>Feedback</p> <p>Congratulations! Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Hellenistic]]</p> <<elseif ($hellenisticCombatQ1 is "B") and ($hellenisticCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>Feedback</p> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Onward! |Hellenistic]]</p> <<elseif ($hellenisticCombatQ1 is "A") and ($hellenisticCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>Feedback</p> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Onward! |Hellenistic]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Hellenistic]]</p> <</if>><<if $hellenisticCombat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Hellenistic]] <<else>> ​ <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: (some dumb circular logic)</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hellenisticCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hellenisticCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hellenisticCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> ​ <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "hellenistic-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> ​ </div> ​ <</if>><<if ($hellenisticCombatQ2 is "A") and ($hellenisticCombatQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $hellenisticCombat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Tautology Troll and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Armor">><<set $armor to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Book">><<set $book to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Hellenistic]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the Tautology Troll. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Hellenistic]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <div class="row hellenistichero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>The Hellenistic World</h1> <p>You and your comrades have written a new history of the Hellenistic World. Open the branching pathways to explore it.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center space"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Alexandria Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/symposium.jpg" alt="ancient Greek vase painted with feast scene" width="50%"> <p>This evening, you're reclining on your couch, in a cloud of sweet music and savory aromas. This symposium-style dinner party has become a kind of weekly ritual for your group of philosophical comrades. You're sharing some of your new ideas about human virtue, and what it means to live a good life. ... What's the ideal system of government? How do you respond to your partner's criticism that there really is no good system of government because power corrupts?</p> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[Power corrupts and it would only be a matter of time before one “friend” controls all. |alex-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The idea of power corrupts is similar to Quintilian’s view on homosexuality, that older boys can corrupt younger boys (Hubbard, Homosexuality) because there is always a chance of corruption in any power dynamic, whether it be love or politics. |alex-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[And my ideal political system would be one that runs by the ways of Stoicism. Living in a natural order to achieve inner peace and finally a good life. |alex-rewrite3]]</li> <hr> <li>[[ If all you’re concerned with is pleasure then how will you be able to make the hard choices that life throws at you. |alex-rewrite4]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I think that power does truly corrupt,it makes you greedy and clouds your judgment so I think the entire dreamgovernment would completely focus on the internal good of its people. ... It all sounds great in theory but I know it’s not realistic and my partner will undoubtedly make fun of me for it but oh well. |alex-rewrite5]]</li> <hr> <li>[[How many times do I have to tell you, death is nothing to us; we live our lives and then eventually we die and become nothing. All of this talk of virtue and good leadership, is nothing but you stroking your ego. |alex-rewrite6]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I could never have such intelligent conversations with a woman, as women are obviously missing half of their inferior brains and are unable to keep up with my sex's superior intellect. |alex-rewrite7]]</li> </ul> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Attacking Rome Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/war-elephant.jpg" alt="elephant with warriors in castle, calf behind" width="50%"> <p>Your army has defeated legion after legion in northern Italy and dirven the Romans back to the city itself. The walls are 30 feet tall and 13 feet thick. You have a leading role in planning and carrying out the siege. You're just an engineer, but as you plan the minutiae of your siege machinery and tactics, you're thinking about the bigger picture of this war too. ... What kinds of machines will you built to besiege Rome? How will you use them? How do you imagine the Romans will defend their city? What do you expect will happen during or after the siege? What will the Italians do? The surviving Romans? ... Mighty Carthage? ... </p> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[I have lately been developing many unique and deadly weapons. The main problem we have to think about when fighting the Romans is how to get past their seemingly impenetrable walls. |cannae-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[We all hope for a good outcome but there is so much fear and anxiety that it could go wrong. |cannae-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[They’ll be able to shoot down at us from the walls, we are at a massive disadvantage. |cannae-rewrite3]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Though the siege on Rome itself may prove to be effective and progress with much success, I would find myself weary of the remaining Romans and their allies- for we are far from home, in a foreign land that has made clear it does not welcome us. |cannae-rewrite4]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I think of how the placement of larger artillery should be clustered and spread out far from each other to prevent major losses. |cannae-rewrite5]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I would primarily construct and use catapults in the siege of rome. Ballista can be used to great effect on the battlefield and are much weaker against fortifications. |cannae-rewrite7]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Start the Role Play Game |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $helotExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Helot]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>As historical sources, Homer's <em>Iliad</em> and <em>Odyssey</em> tell us most about:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$helotExploreQ1" "A">>Dark Age and Archaic Greece</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$helotExploreQ1" "B">>Bronze Age and Mycenaean Greece</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$helotExploreQ1" "C">>Persia</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "helot-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($helotExploreQ1 is "A") and ($helotExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $helotExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Helot]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Helot]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $helotExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Helot]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy.
