What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Hoplite culture included:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$helotExploreQ2" "A">>an emphasis on the role of cavalry in battle.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$helotExploreQ2" "B">>equality for women.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$helotExploreQ2" "C">>citizen soldiers.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "helot-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($helotExploreQ2 is "C") and ($helotExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $helotExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Helot]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Helot]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>Spartan warriors were legendary for their military invincibility. The city of Sparta proudly stood without defensive fortifications - an anomaly in the Greek world - because (the Spartans liked to boast) its army was the only defense it needed. But Sparta depended on the labor of a large class of slaves called Helots. These indigenous inhabitants of the Peloponnese had been enslaved by the Spartans when they conquered the region during the Archaic Period.</p> <p><img src="images/hoplites-lycia-c390.jpg" alt="frieze of hoplite soldiers in combat" width="100%"></p> <p><a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/image/3012/greek-hoplites-fighting/" target="_blank">World History Encyclopedia</a></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Athens was developing a more includive, democratic political culture, while Sparta was staunchly conservative and oligarchic. These differences coincide with the differing military and economic orientation of each city state. Athenian power increasingly depended on maritime trade and naval power - in other words, merchants and rowers whose humble economic status might have barred them from political participation in prevoius generations, but who now demanded an equal say in keeping with their importance to their polis' wellbeing. Spartan power, on the other hand, remained tied to the invincibility of its traditional hoplite phalanxes. Their conservative, oligarchic system produced this unstoppable fighting force. Sparta began to view Athenian democracy as a threat to its survival - especially these ideas about expanding the franchise to people who did not serve in the army. So when Athens showed up to help Sparta crush (yet another) Helot uprising in xx, Spartan leaders thanked them and sent them home immediately, fearing the spread of democratic ideas.</p> <p><img src="images/thebes-vase-trireme.jpg" alt="vase painted with trireme" width="100%"></p> <p>A trireme on a ceramic bowl from Thebes, c. 735 BCE (<a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/G_1899-0219-1" target="_blank">British Museum</a>)</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>The Spartan system depended on the active role of Spartan women. Stories, artwork, laws, and religious ceremonies reflect the Spartans' respect for the role of women in their unique society. For instance, Spartan women were encouraged to be physically strong by exercising and playing sports, in order (in Spartan logic) to be physically strong and produce strong boys to fill the ranks of the Spartan army. Compared with women elsewhere in Greece, Spartan women enjoyed compratively higher status and more freedom - partly because the men were totally devoted to armed service and barred from ordinary civic pursuits like business and trade. And, well, <em>someone</em> has to run the country while the men are training and fighting, so Spartan women wound up moving more freely in public life than other Greek women, who were more confined to the domestic sphere. One story in Herodotus' History tells how a Persian emissary was offering Sparta's king bribes, striving to bring Sparta into the Persian hegemony. During the meeting, the king's daughter said, "Father, this visitor is going to corrupt you if you don't get up and leave." The king took her advice.</p> <p><img src="images/spartan-woman.jpg" alt = "sculpture of woman in dress running" width="70%"></p> <p>Bronze figure of a running girl from Sparta, c. 520 BCE. Image from the <a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/G_1876-0510-1" target="_blank">British Museum.</a></p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>With the help of the Athenians, we successfully drive off the Spartans. For now. They did put up a good fight. Afterall, “For not man ever proves himself a good man in war unless he can endure to face the blood and the slaughter”. A group of us Heliots take charge and make up the new government of our new polis. There is one other woman other than me in this group. Our ideas are usually ridiculed and mocked. Sometimes I feed my husband things to say. When he says them, he is greeted with praise for being so intelligent. “[we] clearly [find] other ways to make [our] views known and felt”. After a few years, our Polis has grown, and is faring to be a strong one. My husband now holds a high position in our government. Little do they know, my husband has simply been recounting what I tell him to say. When the time is right, I will reveal myself as the mastermind behind his genius. Until then, i’ll have him advocate for better treatment of our women citizens.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I would create a polis that would mimic the military strength of Sparta while having the democratic government of Athens. I would create some sort of checks and balances type system to keep the military from just taking power and removing the democratic government that my polis would have developed. I would take major inspiration from the democratic government of Athens because I feel as a slave despite Athens attempting to “help” Sparta in the scenario, as a slave I would probably see Athenians as having the ultimate type of freedom with their political system that I and my fellow Helots would want to replicate. My polis, also like the spartans would be “craftsmen of war” but without the authoritarian government. The women of my polis would be treated also like how the spartans treated their women in the sense that they would “not [be] regarded as categorically inferior” to the men of my polis. As a woman I would strive to help create a polis where men and women would be treated much more equally for the time period. I also would not want slavery to exist in my polis because of my background as being a slave under Sparta. My polis would probably offer refuge to runaway’s. Quotes were taken from WOMEN AND RELIGION source. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>The type of Government that I will decide to pick would have to be something that is more democratic. This is due to the fact that I would want the people to have a say in political matters and be able to elect their leader. In the text Xenophon-Sparta its states,” Lycurgus, who gave them the laws that they obey, and to which they owe their prosperity, I do regard with wonder; and I think that he reached the utmost limit of wisdom” I will try to pick laws that are fair to all people regardless of race and gender identity. I will give women as much freedom as the men have, although this could result in anger and frustration from the men half of the population will agree with me. On top of the fact that I will have soldiers “police” that will adhere to the law. I will have no slavery of any kind. People will no longer be allowed to own people. Instead everyone will be able to have an opprotunity. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Women in Sparta weren't "used" in the same way as other states or systems. The most important job a freeborn woman could do was be a mother and give birth. Non-freeborn women in Sparta were used primarily for the making of clothing. (Xenophon, Constitution)</p> <p>For almost my whole life I have been enslaved in Sparta, working to make these Spartans their clothes, every day. It is the only work I do. The only thing I am seen as important for. But that will change. We are meeting with the Athenians to strategize our revolt. The Athenians don't want me or any other woman in this meeting, but I stood up and told them that this is for everyone, and we all need this revolution. We will all help and we will succeed, but we can only succeed together. (Xenophon, Constitution)</p> <p>"These Helots are the single most important human fact about ancient Sparta." Helots basically provided Sparta with their lifestyle and were the economic base of this lifestyle. Without the Helots Sparta would almost be nothing. (Cartledge, Spartans)</p> <p>Us Helots who have given our lives to the Spartans are finally done. We want to be free from our over three centuries of enslavement. This revolt will be another of our continuous acts of rebellion over the years to finally free ourselves. And Sparta in turn would struggle without us holding them up. When our rebellion is finally successful and we escape from the Spartans grip things will change. Men will not be the only ones in power, and we will all be equal. (Cartledge, Spartans)</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I will craft a polis in which men and women are equal. Women will be autonomous and fully free to make financial decisions, marital decisions, buy and own property, and will no longer be viewed as an ugly abomination. There will be laws to protect women, their property, and their children against the violence of men. If men want to delve into chaos and violence, women should not be affected. There will be no slavery. Men will be forced to learn practical skills and manual labor instead of pointless war tactics. The greatest value in a Spartan man is his ability to “endure to face the blood and the slaughter, and go close against the enemy and fight with his hands” (Tyrtaeus) meanwhile women have been educated from a young age, and even learned skills like how to prepare and clean food, which herbs to use for medicine, and how to have a true sense of community without perpetual violence. If men are apt to continue feeding into this perpetual war, they are using women’s “gossip” as an excuse to belittle women. If Spartan women were so incompetent, how were they able to rule over their men? (Cartledge). Women have learned from a young age how to share space with others, how to communicate, how to resolve conflict without violence, and how to form a community. It is the men who are so easily willing to die in battle, giving their life andleaving behind their family over whatever disagreement is going on.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>It is so frustrating to hear that these Athenians do not take me seriously. After observing how the Spartan women had more influence in their society, I expected to be met with the same respect. While grateful to have been rescued and saved from a life of servitude to the Spartan population, I feel like there needs to be a change. Women in Athenian society are only supposed to play minor roles and raise children. Unlike the Spartan women, women are not allowed to own land or voice their opinions. The men here are more philosophical and insightful but less threatening and war-like. The Athenian men would rather complain to themselves then to hear their women’s truths. They would never truly adopt the same practice as the spartans. But the time to change is now. We need this revolution in order to gain our independence. I have witnessed first hand the power of the spartans and how their women’s roles in their culture had only strengthened the Spartan territories. It is my duty to let the Athenians know that although they freed us from spartan captivity, we are people ourselves and deserve to be heard. While the future of our fate is uncertain, anything that comes next will always be better than servitude to the Spartans.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>After freeing myself from Spartan slavery I think my first priority would be figuring out a way to provide for myself. Now in Sparta women do have more power than in other places and so if I was able to become a spartan woman I don’t think that would be a bad idea. “He believed motherhood to be the most important function of a freeborn woman. (Xenophon, Constitution)” Spartans believed that motherhood was a very pivotal role in their society and they respected their women for that. “Spartan women did not only control their men within the confines of the household, but also somehow exercised a decisive influence over affairs of state. (Cartledge, Spartans)”. Spartan women also had the opportunity to have more control and power in not just household chores. Now on the idea that I leave sparta territory all together I will try to create a society where women have the same rights and powers that they do in sparta but I wouldn’t have slavery as that is exactly what I would be escaping from in the first place. If I go over to Athens I think I would be frustrated with the fact they don’t respect women like they do in Sparta and for that reason I don’t think I could be in Athens.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>As I rest there in the grass under a shady tree with my lover, I begin to think of the various changes and the freedoms I’d like to have if we revolt and break away from Sparta. I think of the community thriving and the system put in place to make sure everyone has decent lives without major issues occurring. I think for a while before waking my lover from his nap to tell him my thoughts. I tell him how I am sick of how our people are being treated by the Spartans and how change is needed quickly. I explain how despite our people being divided up we are all still ‘Homoioi’ and that together we greatly outnumber the Sparatans (Cartledge 2). I explained to him how my ideal polis would be a place in large open rangelands with lots of animals. There would be no crazy strict laws and we would be a neutral community that mainly focused on the good and forming allies. We would trade with others and help others in need. We would have a few people in charge but they would not be above anyone else, everyone would get equal treatment regardless of their status in the community. This meant that women would finally be able to make major decisions as well as pick what they would like to do within the community. We definitely would not resort to slavery as we want to break that. Although the thought of crime and related issues do flood my mind, I think that there has to be consequences. I think that banishment would only be for the extreme cases such as murder or intentional harm to others. After being shut out from the meeting, I know the chances of change will either be completely withdrawn or carried out in the worst possible way. I can’t take the risk of facing a beatdown or worse if the revolution doesn't go as planned. I find my husband out and about working in the fields and quickly drag him away. I quickly speak to him about us leaving Sparta immediately. He is quite hesitant as this is such a sudden change and quite abrupt. I have to re-explain to him how unfair life is in Sparta and how the rules and expectations for women like me are even worse. I think of some excerpts from Xenophon and hastily speak to further convince my husband. “The rest of the Greeks expect their girls to imitate the sedentary life that is typical of handicrafts men -- to keep quiet and do wool-work. How, then, is it to be expected that women so brought up will bear fine children?”(Xenophon). I can now only hope that I picked the right choice of words to get him to understand my eagerness to flee Sparta. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Our rebellion was finally successful! The Helots are free and we can finally create a polis of our own with our own rules. Finally us women will not be oppressed like we were under spartan and athenian rule. In Sparta they “believed motherhood to be the most important function of freeborn woman. Therefore, in the first place, [they] insisted on physical training for the female no less than for the male sex: so [they] instituted races and trials of strength for women competitors as for men, believing that if both parents are strong they produce more vigorous offspring.” This cannot be how it is in our new society. At least it’s better than how the Athenians treated us, to them we were nothing more than objects that produce more men for them. In Athens, “an Athenian girl would receive no formal education beyond training for the domestic duties required of a good Athenian wife and mother - weaving, food-preparation, childcare, household management.” In our new Helot polis men and women will be equal. We are more than just mothers and wives, we want to have real jobs and real lives l ike the men! I think we need to have both genders equally represented in our government so that all peoples’ voices are heard. We will also give any land owning person, including women, the right to vote. And for once and for all we will abolish slavery. We fought so many years to be free why would we enslave others like we were. I think this new polis has the potential to become one of the best in the entire world. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>With the fall of Sparta and the rise of the Athenians, I am worried about what will happen to me and my sisters. That pig Aristotle claims that we are inferior to men, that our bodies and... minds [are] categorically...inferior to men’s.” But what does he know? He thinks of us as weak yet, I know many Atheanian men who are not only smaller but much weaker than I in both body and mind. Without us the men of Sparta and many men in Athens would not be the men that they are today without us Helots. We raised their children, fed them and gave them clothes on their back, and this is how they treat us? Even now after all the help we provide the Athenians in the fight against Sparta they tell us that we should return to our homes, that we would ruin the revolution that we helped fight for. Rather than freeing ourselves from the Spartans I worry that we may have chosen new masters for ourselves, new masters who will limit our freedoms even more than the Spartans did. While I may have been a slave, at least under Spartan rule I was given many liberties that I know for a fact that I would not have had under Athenian rule. Maybe if enough of us Helots get together we might be able to have our voices heard and the Athenians may let us live our lives as we intended, but I worry me may end up as just another squashed rebellion. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>As a freed sparta slave, I would attempt to make a life for myself and my fellow helots. In this new polis no man could rule over us as we could be strong and lively. “so he instituted races and trials of strength for women competitors as for men, believing that if both parents are strong they produce more vigorous offspring.” (Xenophon, Constitution) Being physically fit has many benefits, most prominently being improved health and well being. But being strong, especially as a woman, improves confidence significantly. The knowledge that I can defend and fight for myself if needed makes me more confident in my ideas, more steadfast and strong in my mind. (Xenophon, Constitution) [undefined] (Cartledge, Spartans) While Spartan women are the ones seen as strong and powerful, us Helot women were the ones doing most domestic work (aka making sure that Sparta was running behind the scenes). When creating a new society, the small things are what’s most important. How to run a house, how to do simple things, how to be patient and create a home. Therefore, we will be successful and triumphant in creating a polis that respects what makes a society true and good. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Homosexuality in Ancient Greece and Rome</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>This <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1d1tvdMkKDBHXhTG5EXM18fntELi1CNc6/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">book chapter</a> from Thomas Hubbard, <em>Homosexuality in Greece and Rome: A Sourcebook of Basic Documents</em> (2003) introduces the wide and complex landscape of historians' attempts to understand homosexuality in ancient Greece and Rome.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How homosexual behaviors and relationships were viewed in the Hellenistic World</li> <li>The limits of our knowledge about homosexuality in the Hellenistic World, including past and present scholarly debates</li> <li>Homosexuality and ideals of masculinity in the Hellenistic World</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexsexe1" `$alexsexe1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexsexa1" `$alexsexa1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexsexe2" `$alexsexe2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexsexa2" `$alexsexa2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexsexe3" `$alexsexe3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexsexa3" `$alexsexa3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexsexa4" `$alexsexa4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Epicureanism |epicurus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Stoicism |epictetus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[People |theophrastus]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Homosexuality in Ancient Greece |homosexuality]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Done collecting material?</h2> <p>Your notes from this source are saved. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[Back: Alexandria Scenario |Alexandria]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>King Hrothgar in <em>Beowulf</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The Old English poem, <em>Beowulf,</em> was composed c. 800, but survives only in a single manuscript copy from c. 1000 (which almost burned in a library fire, but was saved by the statue on top of it). The poem tells of many old Germanic heroes and legends, but principally follows the adventures of Beowulf: an unpromising youth who becomes a mighty warband leader, rips the arms off monsters with his bare hands, wins epic heaps of treasure, avenges his king's death, swims across the North Sea carrying the plundered weapons and armor of 30 slain enemies (no big deal), turns down an offer of kingship, becomes king later, and kills a dragon.</p> <p>Here's <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/15gPxrceFyfzSqHrVqODuI9jKbhw6pcRc/edit?usp=sharing&ouid=107960520722717944293&rtpof=true&sd=true" target="_blank">a synopsis of the whole poem</a>, in case that's of interest (seriously, what could <em>possibly</em> be more interesting??). The poet presents Hrothgar, king of the Danes, as the ideal king. Have a look at the text here: <a href="https://heorot.dk/beowulf-rede-text.html" target="_blank">(Old English and modern English side by side)</a>. No, don't read the whole thing (at lesat not right now). Read the parts about Hrothgar, listed below. Have fun with the Old English! See if you can recognize some of the words. The lines about Hrothgar are:</p> <ul> <li>Hrothgar is a good king: Lines 64 - 98</li> <li>Feast after Beowulf fights Grendel: Lines 837 - 1062</li> <li>Feast after Beowulf fights Grendel's Mother: Lines 1651 - 1962</li> <li>Beowulf tells his king, Hygelac, about his adventures in Denmark: Lines 1999 - 2031, 2101 - 2141</li> </ul> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Aspects of good kingship: What was a good king expected to do in Anglo-Saxon England?</li> <li>How did a king weild power? How did he motivate or direct various groups of people?</li> <li>What benefits might Christianity have offered an early Anglo-Saxon king?</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askinghroe1" `$askinghroe1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Converting the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms |bede]]</li> <hr> <li>[[King Hrothgar |hrothgar]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Sutton Hoo ship burial |suttonhoo]]</li> <hr> <li>[[About the arrival of Christianity in Anglo-Saxon England |naismith]]</li> <hr> <li>[[What we can and can't know about Germanic paganism |orton]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use class lectures and your textbook.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-k]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Anglo-Saxon King Scenario |AS-king]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Hunting "Accidents"</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Medieval chronicles are peppered with stories about hunting accidents that are obviously not accidental at all. Like, "Oh, sorry, I didn't see you there when I ran you through with that boar spear." Such power plays seem to have been commonplace when members of this power-hungry and militaristic aristocracy enjoyed blood sport in the forest. "Let's all go play with our war toys together!" is obviously a great way to open a space for settling differences of opinion or establishing a pecking order. And they didn't do it gently. The hunt was also an ideal setting for an assassination, especially if your target happened to be a member of the upper elite, like a king or a bishop, who rarely appeared outside his swarm of thuggish toadies. In a fast-paced woodland chase, anybody can become vulnerable for a moment. <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/10-xCaDHrHTLUC0UJPlRexjJtUzqbzty0Sn1fso9seO8/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Here are a few examples</a> of various hunting "accidents" and all-out murders, from medieval chroniclers and historians.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How medieval aristocrats carried out political violence while hunting</li> <li>The roles of huntsmen and foresters in such events</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forace1" `$forace1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$foraca1" `$foraca1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forace2" `$forace2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$foraca4" `$foraca4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Books of the Hunt |ms-hunts]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Hunting "accidents" |hunt-death]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Sir Gawain and the Green Knight |gawain]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About hunting in the Middle Ages |orme]]</li> <hr> <li>[[About peasants, poaching, and foresters in early medieval Europe |goldberg]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-f]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> <li>[[Back: Forester Scenario |Forester]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if ($ironCombat1 is "done") and ($ironCombat1 isnot "")>> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Iron]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-md"> <img src="images/mobs/mob8.jpg" alt="wolf-like creature eating a ring" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p>Here is your opponent. To win this fight, choose a good response to its questionable statements about history.</p> <p>It says, "Civilizations in environments with the correct amount of environmental stress factors were able to develop new technologies which led to growth and advancement. Civilizations in overly harsh environments (like the Arctic) or overly comfortable environments (like the tropics) failed to innovate and grow. Those in difficult environments had no leisure to take risks or invest resources in innovation; they were struggling to simply survive. Those with too bountiful an envirnoment had no reason to take risks or invest resources in innovation. The correct amount of environmental stress is necessary for civilizations to advance."</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>So first, stop laughing. Be serious. Distinguished persons with alphabet soups after their names and ponderous academic titles have written stuff like this in the past - titanic, towering scholarly figures like Toynbee and von Ranke, and we owe them much respect and gratitude for their contributions to the study of history. <em>However</em> ... this kind of "big history" will strike most of us as ... naive? Old fashioned? Overconfident in the clairvoyance of the historian? There's an almost childlike faith in our ability to know the past and predict the future. Shall we simply call it Victorian?</p> <p>So, let's keep this simple. Briefly, can you identify one of the fallacies in this creature's thesis?</p> <div class="row scenario"> <p><label><<radiobutton "$ironCombatQ1" "A">> Confirmation bias</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$ironCombatQ1" "B">> Eurocentrism</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$ironCombatQ1" "C">> Anachronism</label></p> </div> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "iron-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($ironCombatQ1 is "A") and ($ironCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $beginCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <p>Absolutely. A thesis like this opens the door to confirmation bias, because it's easy for a researcher to find examples supporting it, while ignoring or misinterpreting evidence to the contrary. For instance, it would be easy to ignore the civilizations that developed in favorable environments, but ultimately failed to thrive or grow.</p> <p><<linkreplace "Chalice">><<set $chalice to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Armor">><<set $armor to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Iron]]</p> <<elseif ($ironCombatQ1 is "B") and ($ironCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>Eurocentrism can fit here, since there's a tacit assumption that "advances" and "civilization" and "progress" resemble the modern west (i.e., global industrial capitalism and liberal democracy). Historians try to avoid this kind of bias (especially when done tacitly, as here).</p> <p>Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Chalice">><<set $chalice to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Armor">><<set $armor to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Iron]]</p> <<elseif ($ironCombatQ1 is "C") and ($ironCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>Anachronism doesn't really fit here. You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Iron]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Iron]]</p> <</if>><<if $ironCombat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Iron]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a (some mob)!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: (something wrong)</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this farcical gibberish?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$ironCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$ironCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$ironCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "iron-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($ironCombatQ2 is "A") and ($ironCombatQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $ironCombat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Presentism Poltergeist and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Armor">><<set $armor to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Iron]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the (some mob). Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Iron]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <div class="row ironhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Iron Age Empires</h1> <p>You and your comrades have written a new history of ancient Mesopotamia! Open the branching pathways to explore it.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center space"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Assyrian Army Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/assyria-horse.jpg" alt="frieze of soldiers with horse" width="50%"> <p>You have decided that you are more than meat to be fed into the imperial war machine. ... There’s opportunity, as well as horror and death, all around you here. What do you do?</p> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[He’s never enjoyed violence, but he will do what he has to to survive. He is determined to make it home, as safely as possible, to his family and see them again. |assyria-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Through rising in the ranks and making friends in high places I would secure my safety and use my newly acquired wealth and power to live out a long life to a ripe old age of 30 probably since life expectancy wasn’t the greatest back then. |assyria-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The obelisk we constructed mentions how our king crossed the mighty Euphrates river numerous times and came back with goods and resources from the other lands. I crossed the Euphrates, and took part in the artistic side of the obelisk helping with the inscriptions, all because of my artistic past. ... Maybe I will make art again, go back home, or see where else this "new life" will take me. |assyria-rewrite3]]</li> <hr> <li>[[As a poor hungry young civilian, I had no choice but to join the army. I needed a place to sleep, eat, and to carry my future into a path of change for the better. |assyria-rewrite4]]</li> <hr> <li>[[As a woman they wouldn’t let me do a lot with the military. My job would proably be to please the men. Just saying that grosses me out but it is the reality of the situation. I would probably have to sleep my way to the top. |assyria-rewrite5]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Another way that I can rise in the ranks in the army is by showing depictions of me as the leader in these art works. I could also tell them that I was appointed by God as their leader. |assyria-rewrite6]]</li> <hr> <li>[[While appeasement may be seen as cowardly as I am a young strong man with a rather large ego, I am smart enough to understand that to the king appeasement is a means of survival. |assyria-rewrite7]]</li> </ul> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Siege of Lachish Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/assyria-siege2.jpg" alt="frieze of siege machines" width="50%"> <p>The Assyrian army spreads like a lake of ants around the city of Lachish, smoke from its cooking fires rising up around you like the walls of a cage ... Wouldn’t it be better to surrender now?</p> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[We both want the best for the baby, and want to breathe clean air. I keep telling myself there will be wool and fresh herbs somewhere along the way. There will be a way to survive, to once again find a living. |lachish-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The walls are a good defense but if they make it in the lives of my and other children would be at a much higher risk of horrible things... |lachish-rewrite3]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I think the best course of action would be to sneak out of the city at night and head for the hills. It sounds very risky though so I need to get my girlfriends’ opinions because they are the smartest people I know. |lachish-rewrite4]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I don’t want to raise my kids in fear of this environment full of death and destruction, is that even living or just trying to survive? I think I would rather try to survive getting out of the city so we can live. |lachish-rewrite5]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Upon overhearing about the siege of the Assyrians from my husband and the brutality that was exhibited I became unable to fall asleep for the rest of the night. The thought of my babies being implied and skinned is simply too much to bear. |lachish-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[We ultimately decide to escape the city that night and flee back into the hills that we came from years ago. City life never suited us anyway. |lachish-rewrite6]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Saying goodbye to loved ones and friends that refuse to leave, we head towards the Assyarian camp to embrace our new lives as part of the Assyrian rule. |lachish-rewrite7]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Start the Role Play Game |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Jordanes, <em>History of the Goths</em> (c. 551)</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Jordanes was an administrator and historian in sixth-century Constantinople. His <em>History of the Goths</em> is based on a now-lost work by Cassiodorus. <a href="&quot;https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Ve-sZC-ak5kwMfjO-_wr-oQAGFbEjoRuiXQELxs2_Mc/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This section</a> presents the Goths' perspectives on their situation under pressure from the Huns at the time of the Battle of Adrianople (378). </p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Germanic ideas of kingship and national identity</li> <li>Germanic perspectives on Rome and the Huns</li> <li>Military strengths and weaknesses of the barbarian tribes</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriangete1" `$adriangete1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriangeta1" `$adriangeta1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriangete2" `$adriangete2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriangeta2" `$adriangeta2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriangete3" `$adriangete3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriangeta3" `$adriangeta3 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriangete4" `$adriangete4 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriangeta4" `$adriangeta4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Tacitus, Germania |tacitus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Jordanes, History of the Goths |jordanes]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Germanic tribes |green]]</li> <hr> <li>[[On the late empire's frontier |law]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Barbarian Scenario |Barbarian]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if ($knightsCombat1 is "done") and ($knightsCombat1 isnot "")>> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Knights]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-md"> <img src="images/mobs/mob6.jpg" alt="man with animal body kneeling" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p>Here is your opponent. To win this fight, choose a good response to its questionable statements about history.</p> <p>It says, "The class struggle between the aristocracy and peasants of medieval feudal society evolved into the class struggle between the capitalist bourgeoisie and the proletariat of modern industrial society. This dialectic of class struggle is the history of a natural and inevitable progression toward a stateless, classless communist society of the future in which all will have an equal share of the goods produced."</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>What's the best way to counter this Marxist nonsense?</p> <div class="row scenario"> <p><label><<radiobutton "$knightsCombatQ1" "A">> Why counter it? Marx said it best: "The history of all hitherto existing society is the history of class struggles." No more, no less. History is inherently radical and revolutionary. Trying to separate it from politics is misguided and futile. There's no nonsense here.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$knightsCombatQ1" "B">> This is another example of the kind of deterministic, speculative analysis that's fallen out of favor in these postmodern times. Marx's faith in his ability to conceptualize and predict the wide sweep of all human experience far into the future would be deemed childlike and naive to most historians today.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$knightsCombatQ1" "C">> History and historiography should not be politicized this way. Creating an analysis of history that serves a political agenda, as Marx did, is irresponsible, methodologically problematic, and ultimately invalid. It's more suited to a political debate than a history class.</label></p> </div> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "knights-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($knightsCombatQ1 is "A") and ($knightsCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $knightsCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <p>You have an opinion. This is permitted. The creature loves your response and awards you victory (5 points) and loot: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Illuminated codex">><<set $book to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Knights]]</p> <<elseif ($knightsCombatQ1 is "B") and ($knightsCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $knightsCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <p>Excellent response. Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose some loot for your inventory:</p> <p><<linkreplace "Illuminated codex">><<set $book to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Knights]]</p> <<elseif ($knightsCombatQ1 is "C") and ($knightsCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $knightsCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <p>Agreed. This opinion is not universal, but it's the prevailing outlook among professional historians today. Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Illuminated codex">><<set $book to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Knights]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Knights]]</p> <</if>><<if $knightsCombat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Knights]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: "some dumb circular logic"</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$knightsCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$knightsCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$knightsCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "knights-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($knightsCombatQ2 is "A") and ($knightsCombatQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $knightsCombat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Tautology Troll and boosted your score by 5! Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Knights]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <div class="row knightshero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Medieval Knights</h1> <p>You and your comrades have written a new history of the medieval aristocracy! Open the branching pathways to explore it.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center space"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Eleanor of Aquitaine Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/eleanor-chinon.jpg" alt="fresco of men and women on horses" width="50%"> <p>The pope let you establish a new monastic order. After all, you are the richest woman in Europe. ... The pope fell all over himself setting his seal to your new order’s charter as fast as he could, and he’s let you do as you please ever since. Deep in thought, you move slowly through the cavernous space toward the scriptorium. You need to write a letter. Pope Eugene has asked Bernard of Clairvaux to call for a Third Crusade ... and Bernard has written to you to ask your advice. ... What is your monastic order like? ... What is your advice to Bernard of Clairvaux regarding a prospective third crusade? What are the results?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[Our goals are to not only become closer to God but become closer to ourselves, to serve the community through charity, |eleanor-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Wars are too disheartening to do much good. |eleanor-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The goals of my monastic life would be to make sure that women get educated. |eleanor-rewrite3]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I am conflicted. I feel a need to serve my God in any way possible, but should that include more violence and death... |eleanor-rewrite4]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Our unity among the other Christian kingdoms will determine our success overall. |eleanor-rewrite5]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I encourage Bernard to go on with the crusade as we will be further proving our loyalty to the church no matter what happens. |eleanor-rewrite6]]</li> </ul> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Battle of Hattin Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/crusader-departing.jpg" alt="knight in armor kneeling" width="50%"> <p>Saladin has taken Tiberias. ... You know it's suicidal folly to pursue Saladin toward Tiberias, into the hills at Hattin. That's obviously what he wants, for equally obvious reasons. He'll have the heights and the water, and you'll have no room to maneuver. ... So, what do you do? What are some results of your choice? For yourself, for the crusades, for history more broadly?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[Secretly, without the knowledge of Raynald and Raymond and Gerard and the rest, form a strong group of knights, for protection. |hattin-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li></li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Start the Role Play Game |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Matty, <em>Sennacherib's Campaign</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dY0W4xaNuurj1Thj1bDyLo1bhNCb6_5R/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This book chapter</a> from Matty, <em>Sennacherib's Campaign Against Judah and Jerusalem in 701 B.C.: A Historical Reconstruction</em> (2016) examines archaeological and artistic evidence about the Assyrian campaign against Judah in 701 BCE.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Item</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas.</p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachme1" `$lachme1 ??
