''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Assyrian depictions of the siege |lachish-friezes]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Bible stories |bible-stories]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Archaeological and artistic evidence |lachish-evidence]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Ancient Israel and Judah |miller-israel]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Assyrian siege warfare |lachish-sieges]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Lachish Scenario |Lachish]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $lachishExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Lachish]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Who were notable seafarers centered in the ports of Tyre, Sidon, and Byblos?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$lachishExploreQ1" "A">>The Phoenicians</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$lachishExploreQ1" "B">>The Minoans</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$lachishExploreQ1" "C">>The Hyksos</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "lachish-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($lachishExploreQ1 is "A") and ($lachishExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $lachishExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Chalice">><<set $chalice to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Book">><<set $book to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Lachish]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Lachish]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $lachishExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Lachish]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Which group did not develop iron technology?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$lachishExploreQ2" "A">>Africans</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$lachishExploreQ2" "B">>Chinese</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$lachishExploreQ2" "C">>Native Americans</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "lachish-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($lachishExploreQ2 is "C") and ($lachishExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $lachishExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Lachish]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Lachish]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <h1>Assyrian Friezes of the Siege of Lachish</h1><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> </div> <p>This article from <a href=https://etc.worldhistory.org/photos/siege-lachish-reliefs-british-museum/" target="_blank">World History Encyclopedia</a> contains secondary source and primary source material about the Assyrian siege of Lachish.</p> <p><span class="bi">Primary and secondary source? </span> How can this item be both primary and secondary? Well, it depends on what part you are using. You can use the material written by the World History Encyclopedia contributors as a secondary source (something written in our own times), and use details from the Assyrian palace friezes a primary source. It's a two-for-one!</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Assyrian strengths and weaknesses</li> <li>Methods, tools, strategies utilized by Assyria during the siege</li> <li>Motivations and options of the people in Lachish</li> <li>What actually happened to the people when Assyria won</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfre1" `$lachfre1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfra1" `$lachfra1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfre2" `$lachfre2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfra2" `$lachfra2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfre3" `$lachfre3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfra3" `$lachfra3 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfre4" `$lachfre4 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfra4" `$lachfra4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Assyrian depictions of the siege |lachish-friezes]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Bible stories |bible-stories]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Archaeological and artistic evidence |lachish-evidence]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Ancient Israel and Judah |miller-israel]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Assyrian siege warfare |lachish-sieges]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Lachish Scenario |Lachish]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="link"> <p>Assyrian king Sennacherib decorated his palace walls at Nineveh with these scenes depicting the siege of Lachish (c. 701 BCE).</p> <p><img src="images/lachish-siege.jpg" alt="soldiers and siege engines attacking city walls defended by soldiers" width="100%"></p> <p><img src="images/lach-ramp.jpg" alt="stone carving of archers and siege engine attacking city walls" width=100%></p> <p><a href="https://etc.worldhistory.org/photos/siege-lachish-reliefs-british-museum/" target="_blank">World History Encyclopedia</a></p> </div><div class="link"> <p><img src="images/map-levant-830bce.jpg" alt="map of Levant c. 830 BCE" height="100%"></p> <p>A map showing the political situation of Lachish c. 830 BCE (the tan color is the Assyrian Empire), from <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/image/285/map-of-the-levant-circa-830-bce/" target="_blank">World History Encyclopedia</a></p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I would tell my girlfriends of what was seen and heard the night before. I feel like they have the right to know because I care for them deeply, but what their decision may be is up to them. There is great and terrible power approaching and is starting to feel like an oppressive cloud over all of our heads. I would look at them and their children with fondness and love, although we are very close this looming danger could cause us all to divide. I want to do what is best for my baby, and although this isn’t my home, this place has allowed us to survive and make a living at the market. But will the people even be brave enough to have the next market? Should we start to save away our supplies and money? My skills and wares can only go so far in times like these. My heart tells me to head for the hills, and even in the face of danger God will allow me to either escape or die trying to provide the best life for my son as possible. Their technology may be powerful (Miller and Hayes) so it is best to move swiftly and not be on the receiving end of it. A life of oppression (Amin, “Siege”) entails suffering and misery we don’t know will ever end. I tell my husband this, and he mournfully agrees. We both want the best for the baby, and want to breathe clean air. I keep telling myself there will be wool and fresh herbs somewhere along the way. There will be a way to survive, to once again find a living. God may be merciless and powerful (Amin, “Siege”) but he looks after us.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Upon overhearing about the siege of the Assyrians from my husband and the brutality that was exhibited I became unable to fall asleep for the rest of the night. The thought of my babies being implied and skinned is simply too much to bear. We stand no chances against the Assayrians and their war machines. The walls which protect us from them will only keep us safe for so long and eventually, they will find some way to topple them over or create ramps to climb over our walls. Upon waking up I would inform my husband that I overheard him last night, but that I wholeheartedly supported him and what he was saying. I would try to urge him to speak with leaders in Lachish to see if they could find some way to agree to a surrender to avoid being brutalized by the Assayrians, to avoid becoming just another city whose people have become forgotten and displaced after the Assyrians conquered them.</p> <p>Regardless if my husband is receptive to what I am saying, I would then go and talk to the other women within Lachish to try and to see if they can convince their Husbands to surrender. If that is something we can not do I would also see if we could get together to formulate some plan of escape. While we may have no ties to this land our survival and the survival of my children is of the utmost importance to me. People need to know that we exist and I want to be more than a city of people conquered by the Assyrians. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>The next morning after hearing people whispering in the night I would ask my girlfriends if they think we should surrender the city and try to convince others to join in this effort. I know that the Assyrian empire wanted this city because of its location in Mesopotamia and the Mediterranean. (Assyrian depiction of the siege, I fell I would know this if I lived in the city) I would hear what they had to say but if they thought we should fight I would talk about their greater and better-prepared army outside our walls. The walls are a good defense but if they make it in the lives of my and other children would be at a much higher risk of horrible things happening to them.</p> <p>Just as I would have thought the city fell. They took 200,156 people as well as many animals. My family and I, if we hadn't died in the siege would have been sent into exile or into a different part of the Assyrian empire and the heads of the rebellion would have been executed if they hadn't already died again according to the Assyrian depiction of the siege. The people defending my city were just not prepared for the overwhelming force of the Assyrian army as well as the better tools that they had like iron weapons and armor(Assyrian siege warfare).</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I overheard my husband and his friends talking last night and it sounds like the situation outside of the walls is getting really bad. I’m scared that if a full siege of the city happens that something might happen to my baby and my son. I think the best course of action would be to sneak out of the city at night and head for the hills. It sounds very risky though so I need to get my girlfriends’ opinions because they are the smartest people I know. I told them my concerns about how risky it would be to try to escape and one of them told me that “the military forces of Lachish [are] composed mostly of local militias and mercenaries and therefore [is] very insignificant when compared with the Assyrian army.” This really made me think that trying to escape would be worth it because there is no way our army is strong enough to defeat the Assyrians. One of them also said her husband, the one who was in the Assyrian camp, overheard the soldiers talking about these big ramps to get over our walls and that “it is obvious that the artificial ramps [are] the main technique that the Assyrians,” are using to siege the city. All the more reason to leave, I think I will tell my husband all of this and we will start planning our escape from these cursed walls as soon as possible for the sake of our children and our own lives.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Girls I’ve gotta talk to you - there's a lot on my mind right now. I couldn't sleep last night and around two in the morning I woke up to the sound of voices. I could make out my husband talking to his friends - one just returning from an Assyrian camp. He was warning the men of what he’s heard of cities who resist the empire. He thinks it would be better if we surrender now but come on, what is the likelihood of that happening with our divided city?? I also overheard him say that most folk find a way out of the city walls if they want to. The hushed voices following him saying that made me think they are trying to figure out a way to leave. The thought of plotting a way out of Lachish makes me so nervous. The Assyrian army is so strong and their “mud-brick ramps in order to transfer their war-machines and warriors to the city gate and walls” is genuinely so terrifying. I’ve heard rumors from people who live near the walls surrounding the city that the Assyrians are now trying to break it down by using, “wall-breakers and battering rams were used in order to dig into the walls” (Matty, Sennacherib's Campaign). The Assyrians are coming and they will quickly be in the city. If we leave there is so much that could go wrong. And we’ve built our life here and it’s stable. I have my beautiful children and my husband all under our roof. It’s such a dangerous risk but I’m starting to think it’s worth it. I don’t want to raise my kids in fear of this environment full of death and destruction, is that even living or just trying to survive? I think I would rather try to survive getting out of the city so we can live. We can go back home to the hills and practice the religion I grew up with. What do you guys think? Is it a death wish and I am absolutely crazy for thinking we can pull this off or will you be on board to escape with your husbands?</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I wake up early the next morning, planning on getting out of the house before my husband wakes to have some time to think for myself. I meet up with my two good friends at the market, both new mothers like myself. We take our children to a secluded spot by the river and talk while they play. I recount to them what I heard our husbands talking about last night. We talk about what we would do if we fled. If we did we would be surrounded by “Language barriers, religious differences and cultural conflicts”. If we stayed and fought, we might stand a chance. Even the Assyrians understand how our city walls “were constructed to protect the city”. We ultimately decide to escape the city that night and flee back into the hills that we came from years ago. City life never suited us anyway. All this talk about Yaweh has made me nervous for months. The way the officials are pushing it down our throats does not sit right with me. I want my children to grow up following the gods of our ancestors, not this new uncertain god.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Seeing the smoke from the camps in the distance, a chill runs down my spine. The city that we have resided in has been split. The city, while divided, is familiar and kind. None of that matters however if you end up dead by the next morning. Seeing the children, I know that it is my duty to keep them safe so that they too will have their own lives someday. The arrival of the Assyrians are not just for peaceful negotiations as more arrive each and everyday. The Assyrians too are building ramps and structures, clear weapons of siege warfare. Their armies consist of well trained warriors, and their new weapons are strong and sharp. If what the others are saying are true about the Assyrians after visiting their camp, then come tomorrow morning it will be a slaughter. While this city has been a home to me for years I know now that it is my duty to protect my family and my children from tragedy. After talking it out with my family and weighing our options, we both set a plan to leave. Under the cover of the night we gather our belongings and hastily leave the city. Saying goodbye to loved ones and friends that refuse to leave, we head towards the Assyarian camp to embrace our new lives as part of the Assyrian rule.</p> <p>Sources Osama S. M. Amin, "The Siege of Lachish Reliefs at the British Museum," World History Encyclopedia, https://etc.worldhistory.org/photos/siege-lachish-reliefs-british-museum/</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "ironage-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1><em>Fighting Techniques of the Ancient World</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1B0ThpyziLnMWirjnCrGuYQ8H1jnCH71K/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This section</a> of Anglim et al., <em>Fighting Techniques of the Ancient World, 3000 BC - AD 500: Equipment, Combat Skills, and Tactics</em> focuses on Assyrian siege warfare, with a case study of Lachish.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Options for surviving the siege</li> <li>Methods employed by the Assyrian forces</li> <li>Possible outcomes of the siege</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Lachish Scenario |Lachish]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Halsall, <em>Barbarian Migrations and the Roman West, 376 - 568</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Here are two chapters from the excellent book by Guy Halsall, a leading historian of early Germanic society: <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/13Ut-wyjpcYToI1t-ba-GLXw7Wz8Zr8-x/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Chapter 4</a> on "Society beyond the Frontier" (suggestion: start at page 118), and <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/13Ut-wyjpcYToI1t-ba-GLXw7Wz8Zr8-x/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Chapter 5</a> on "Romans and Barbarians before 376." This book is a treasure, written by one of the foremost authorities on the subject, rich in supporting source material, and offering numerous nuanced analyses of past and present scholarly debates. Enjoy!</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The real and conceptual functions of the Roman borders and fortifications</li> <li>Relations between Romans and barbarians on the frontier</li> <li>Aspects of material culture, especially technology and warfare, that might impact people's daily lives on the late empire's frontier</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Barbarian Scenario |Barbarian]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Scenes of Peasant Life</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Nobles may have sneered at the "lower orders" and regarded them as sub-human bovine clods, but they do seem to have been aware, on some level, that their entire economic system depended on the peasants. The nobility would have no castles or feasts without the 90% who did the actual work. This knowledge may have informed the late medieval aristocratic fad for decorating valuable manuscripts with lavish illustrations of the peasants. Noblemen wanted these illuminations to reflect their wealth and status, the prosperity of their rich estates. And they had (just?) enough sense to realize that peasants could not be left out of such narratives. Have a look at these examples of peasant scenes from psalters and books of hours in 14th to 15th-century England, France, and the Netherlands.</p> <iframe src="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vS0tUmBRM_F8GqmZgm_a3s1lyaw3YP7xgsm7szLghma27tx0kpgs3ULoyCtlRoczB3YZCF7fBMuwP5K/embed?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000" frameborder="0" width="960" height="569" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Typical everyday activities of peasants</li> <li>Tools and technology commonly used in peasant life</li> <li>Relationships, gender norms, community</li> <li>Peasant skills and knowledge</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lovele1" `$lovele1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lovela1" `$lovela1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lovele2" `$lovele2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lovela2" `$lovela2 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Misummer Bonfire Scenario |Love]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $loveExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Love]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>In a medieval village, one third of the arable land would be planted with spring crops, one third with fall crops, and one third:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$loveExploreQ1" "A">>would be left empty.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$loveExploreQ1" "B">>would be planted with winter crops.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$loveExploreQ1" "C">>would be planted with crops for the church.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "love-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($loveExploreQ1 is "A") and ($loveExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $loveExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Book">><<set $book to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Love]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Love]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $rebelExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Love]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Serfs:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$loveExploreQ2" "A">>had more personal freedom than most peasants, ultimately evolving into the middle class.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$loveExploreQ2" "B">>had no legal rights and were treated like slaves.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$loveExploreQ2" "C">>had to do more work on the lord's demesne than free peasants did.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "love-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($loveExploreQ2 is "C") and ($loveExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $loveExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Treasure">><<set $treasure to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Love]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Love]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>Medieval people enjoyed a giant party around summer solstice, which coincided with the Feast of Saint John the Baptist. Festivities involved competitions and sports (archery, ball games, wrestling, etc.) known as <em>somergames</em>, and lots of fire: torches everywhere and a giant bonfire big enough to last all night (not too tough on summer solstice...). People sang and danced in circles. They also staged plays and pageants that included a lot of audience participation and unscripted yelling of insults. Typically, someone would play the role of Christ being tortured and crucified, while others played the demons, Romans, and Jews who did the torturing. As you can imagine, things often got a bit out of hand. The medieval church was generally tolerant of pagan influences in Christian festivities, but they started to draw the line at the violent and chaotic somergames that the Feast of St. John became. It probably didn't help that this all took place in the churchyard or very close by - right in their faces, sort of, with people sometimes dancing around in the graveyard. By the later Middle Ages, the church was beginning to disapprove.</p> <p><img src="images/medieval-dance.jpg" alt="people dancing and holding hands, some wearing animal masks" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Fourteenth-century English manuscript illumination of people dancing and wearing masks.</p> <hr> <p>Summer solstice was also the peak of the hay harvest, and everyone was exhausted from scything and raking and stacking all day. The survival of the village depended on a good harvest, so this was physically demanding as well as emotionally stressful work. Somergames no doubt provided an outlet for some of that energy, and a vector for letting loose some of the aggression that built up as people worked together for a common goal (a good harvest) in spite of personal grievances and grudges (some people are hard to get along with, hard to work with, and generally make others feel violent, maybe?).</p> <p><img src="images/trh-june.jpg" alt="peasants harvesting wheat with scythes and rakes" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Harvest scene from the month of June in the calendar page of a French Book of Hours, c. 1415.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Medieval plays centered on religious stories, but told in a popular, crowd-pleasing style with plenty of audience interaction and crude comedy. For instance, the play about Noah's ark focuses on the figure of Noah's wife, who refuses to listen to anything her husband says and will not get on the ark, sitting outside it spinning on er spinning wheel and ridiculing everything her holy husband does. Another popular play told the story of a doctor peddling dubious medicines to Mary Magdelene (with only the sketchiest ties to the biblical story), while his servant seduces his wife and runs off with her. Sometimes plays were performed by traveling actors called "mummers," and sometimes they were staged and performed by locals as part of the important Church festivals (Christmas, Easter, Shrovetide, Midsummer).</p> <p><img src="images/mummers.jpg" alt="people holding hands and wearing animal masks" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Fourteenth-century English manuscript illumination of a troupe of actors dressed in their masks.</p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Fueled by the drink in my hand I know that I must make a mov. After all this time I need to finally confess my feelings. It is my duty to be honest about my feelings for them as there is always the slim chance that they feel the same way. I chuckle with that thought in my mind. Lets pretend that everything is going to work out. If she confesses her feelings towards me the first thing to do is discuss ways for us to get around our families. A meeting with the family could be disastrous, as our family's feuds have gone back generations. A compromise must be made if we were both to ever fully get married. I pause and look at her again to truly weigh the options of what I am about to do. Perhaps I could seek help from a priest or the town elder to hear their advice about this situation. No, I think to myself, that would take too much time. This must be done here and now. There is of course the idea that we could elope together, marrying each other in secret. Though this would be a much higher risk as abandoning our families is the abandonment of our inheritance, and we would have to find a way to support each other. Step by step I'm slowly making my way over and I begin to realize that I’m overthinking it. I’m being stupid I say out loud, as I haven't even heard her answer yet and I’m letting our family's feud overshadow my feelings for her. With a deep breath and a final swing of the drink I call out to her and confess my feelings. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "peasants-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>When you love someone you forget about everything else. You want everyone to get along and parents to like each other but that isn’t always the case. As a woman falling for someone that your parents don’t want you to be with could dishonor your family (Karras,Sexuality). Women don’t get the same tolerance that men receive when committing sexual activities outside of marriage. You could do your best to try and hide your romance but if you get caught you must know that you will get punished more than then man. If your man was an honorable and noble man and had good status I would marry him even if my parents didn’t approve because it is worse to be a single woman than a married one. If you are concerned about what your parents would say then just run off with the guy and marry him. You just have to remember though that men did like to have control over their wives and could try to keep you from others(Chaucer, Miller's Tales”). I would say though overall you have to follow your heart and if you love the guy then go for it. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "peasants-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Just like tales from older times, I am still quite young, I just turned 18 a few months ago. My love, from the rival family, is a little bit older. They are older, wiser, and have money to take care of me. I have known them for a while now but have only spoken few words to them in that time. The reason why I fell in love with them was because of their presence, composure, demeanor, and well, they're rich!</p> <p>As I gazed at my love through the fire I couldn't help but think, 'How could we ever be together?'. It's not so easy. Our families are rivals, I am young, they are not, but I love them and I want to be with them. I thought about this for a while entranced by the dancing of the fire and, them. I come to the conclusion that to make this love successful I will need to try and mend the rivalry between our two families, and starting with "I am in love with you", is probably not the best option.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "peasants-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "peasants-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "peasants-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Aristophanes, <em>Lysistrata</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Here are <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/13G-aQEn6ql5jl6dMVlUjjMCHhFPbOm9s/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">some excerpts</a> from Aristophanes' popular comedy, <em>Lysistrata</em> (Athens, 412 BCE). The play tells the story of Athenian women who come up with a plot to force the men to end the Peloponnesian War. They barricade themselves in the acropolis and (try to) refuse to have sex until the war is over.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Tastes and expectations of an Athenian audience</li> <li>Popular perspectives on the Peloponnesian War</li> <li>Athenian views on Sparta</li> <li>Gender norms, especially power dynamics and ideals of masculinity</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pericles Scenario |Pericles]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Battle of Maldon (991)</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>At the Battle of Maldon in eastern England (991), a large force of Vikings defeated a small English army. The story is told this way in the terse entries of the <em>Anglo-Saxon Chronicle</em> (a record kept up to date and in several versions in monasteries across England, and in vernacular Old English rather than clerical Latin): "Here Ipswich was raided. Very soon after that, ealdorman Byrhtnoth was killed at Maldon. And on that year it was decided to pay tax to Danes for the great terror which they made by the sea coast; that first [payment] was 10,000 pounds. Archbishop Sigerīc decided first on the matter."</p> <p>The story is told more fully in <em>The Battle of Maldon</em></a>, an Old English poem probably composed shortly after the actual battle. The <em>Maldon</em>-poet presents the English leader (his rank is that of "ealdorman," basically like a duke or a count), Byrhtnoth, as a brave hero but it also seems to criticize his bravado in intentionally allowing the Vikings to approach his army by crossing the causeway.</p> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1p0oN5dpTNd0a9sDmGGZFKOAcDWc4ipvU/view?usp=sharing" target="blank">Here's the poem</a>, in Old English with a modern English paralell translation.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Viking goals and strategies</li> <li>Challenges and methods of defending against a Viking attack</li> <li>Military leadership in Anglo-Saxon England, especially the challenge of motivating people to fight the Vikings</li> <li>Values, identities, and ideas of masculinity in Anglo-Saxon England</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defme1" `$defme1 ?? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-d]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Defence Scenario |Defence]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Medieval Noblewomen</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The remarkable Codex Manesse, created in Germany c. 1300, holds a treasury of medieval romance and courtly songs and poetry. It is also graced with numerous illuminated pages, depicting the high medieval nobility as they liked to imagine themselves, the height of chivalry. Have a look at these <a href="https://heidicon.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/search?p=243&ot=objekte&input=%7B%22query%22:%5B%7B%22class%22:%22QueryElementField%22,%22data%22:%7B%22field%22:%7B%22class%22:%22StringColumn%22,%22mask%22:%7B%22name%22:%22objekte_standard_maske%22%7D,%22field%22:%7B%22name%22:%22objekte.obj_sig%22%7D%7D,%22_ot_name%22:%22_objekte_standard_maske%22,%22data%22:%7B%22obj_sig%22:%22%5C%22cod.%20pal.%20germ.%20848%2C%5C%22%22,%22obj_sig:mode%22:%22fulltext%22,%22obj_sig:type%22:%22fulltext%22,%22obj_sig:unset%22:false%7D%7D%7D%5D%7D" target="_blank">illuminated pages</a> in their full, fantastical, digitized and zoomable glory.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Gender ideals among the high medieval aristocracy, especially roles and activities of women</li> <li>The chivalric ideals, court culture, and romance Eleanor of Aquitaine enjoyed so much during her life as patron of poets and singers</li> <li>Really, how different are the men and women? When are they depicted differently? How? What does this suggest about gender and sexuality among the medieval aristocracy? How can this help us understand Eleanor of Aquitaine's beliefs about gender and sexuality?</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elmane1" `$elmane1 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Assyrian Army Scenario |Assyria]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>From Chaucer's <em>Canterbury Tales</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Geoffrey Chaucer is often considered the father of English literature. He was active at the court of Richard II in England, turing tumultuous time of peasant rebellions, the Hundred Years' War, and dynastic conflict between rival aristocratic factions that would ultimately blossom into the Wars of the Roses between the houses of Lancaster, York, and Tudor. Not a boring time! Chaucer's best-known work is <em>The Canterbury Tales</em> (c. 1390), a frame narrative in which a group of pilgrims on a journey to the shrine of Saint Thomas Becket at Canterbury pass the time by telling stories. <a href="https://chaucer.fas.harvard.edu/pages/millers-prologue-and-tale" target="_blank">"The Miller's Tale"</a> is a bawdy, even scattalogical, story about a young wife, her old husband, and her two rival suitors. Maybe it's not what you'd expect from "the father of English literature" ... or maybe it is.</p> <p>Note that the story appears at the Harvard Chaucer website in alternating lines of Middle English and modern English translation. You can ignore the Middle English (or mess around with trying to understand it, just for fun). Here's a synopsis of the story to get you started, again from <a href="https://chaucer.fas.harvard.edu/pages/millers-tale-0" target="_blank">the Harvard Chaucer site</a>:</p> <p><em>"John, a rich old carpenter of Oxford has a young wife, the eighteen-year-old Alisoun, whom he guards carefully, for he is very jealous. He has a boarder, the clerk Nicholas, who makes advances to Alisoun; she quickly agrees and they determine to consummate the affair. Absolon, the parish clerk and village dandy, also lusts for Alisoun, but he woos her in vain, for Nicholas is there first. Nicholas tricks John into thinking that Noah's flood is coming again; John rigs up three kneading tubs, in which he, Nicholas, and Alisoun can float until the waters recede. When the flood is due, all three climb up into the tubs. John goes to sleep, Alisoun and Nicholas go back to the bedroom. They are interrupted by Absolon, who has come to woo Alisoun at the window. She promises him a kiss and puts her backside out the window. Absolon kisses it. He soon realizes his mistake. He gets a hot coulter (plow blade) from Gervase, the smith, and returns to ask for another kiss. Nicholas puts his backside out, Absolon strikes it with the red-hot coulter, Nicholas yells for water; the carpenter awakes and thinks the flood has come, cuts lose his tub and falls and breaks his arm. The neighbors rush in, and all are convinced old John is mad."</em></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Marriage and community relationships</li> <li>Romance, courtship, and attitudes toward sex</li> <li>Religious practices and beliefs</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$loveche1" `$loveche1 ?? It served various practical purposes (like honing horsemanship and battlefield skills) as well as serving to reinforce cultural and societal norms (like terrorizing the peasantry by riding around like maniacs on huge horses with packs of aggressive dogs). So they hunted <em>all the time</em>. They put it in their art and literature too. Couldn't get enough of it. In the later Middle Ages, some of them commissioned artists and writers to create books about it: hunting manuals known as "books of the hunt." Historians are quite pleased that they did this! Here are some excerpts from these fascinating (and often quite beautiful) books.</p> <iframe src="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vRRY-TA4AouIRDlzOslgqHhq8M1-UsF-kAUAsxcmoqnXa6RlREap35eyFV9SBaw_N9HXemBWBeOPI9p/embed?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000" frameborder="0" width="960" height="569" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How medieval aristocrats hunted</li> <li>The roles of huntsmen and foresters</li> <li>The purpose of hunting for aristocrats</li> <li>Sources of danger for medieval aristocrats and their huntsmen and foresters while hunting</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forbe1" `$forbe1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forba1" `$forba1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forbe2" `$forbe2 ?? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-f]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> <li>[[Back: Forester Scenario |Forester]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Naismith, <em>Medieval Britain, 500 - 1000</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ixKlV1utPcUvLQ4-YJV1lvx7vmKgQa5W/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This chapter</a> from historian Rory Naismith's book, <em>Early Medieval Britain, 500 - 1000</em> examines the growth of Christianity in early medieval Britain.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Coming just after Herodotus, his is the earliest surviving written history in the world. <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dq0xwM2O57VbyoZ-T6NYLyVtMveG9Ei8/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">In this chapter </a> of her book about Thucydides' <em>History of the Peloponnesian War,</em> historian Mary Nichols examines Thucydides' treatment of Alcibiades and the Sicilian Expedition.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Details of the military, political, and ideological conflicts in Athens at this time</li> <li>Limits and uncertainties in our knowledge of Alcibiades' character, motives, and actions</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesnte1" `$periclesnte1 ?? If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pericles Scenario |Pericles]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="row"> <h1>Life as a Nun</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>To us today, the phrase "living like a nun" implies "boring, no fun, no sex, no gold or glory or fashion." As you might guess, this is very far from the truth for medieval women who chose to become "brides of Christ" and live in a monastery ("nunnery" or "abbey"). In fact, these women could wield immense power, and enjoy delights of intellect as well as body. <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/article/1298/the-daily-life-of-medieval-nuns/" target="_blank">This informative article</a> from World History Encyclopedia gives us a glimpse into the (unexpectedly?) fascinating lives of medieval nuns.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>What Eleanor of Aquitaine's new monastic order might look like, in terms of its goals, daily life (its rules), and the kinds of women who would want to join</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elne1" `$elne1 ?? We are unsurprised that descriptions of conquest and dominion predominate. Also, crossing the Euphrates was a <em>really</em> big deal and is mentioned as frequently as possible.</p> <p><a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/W_1848-1104-1">View the obelisk</a> at the British Museum here.</p> <p><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/e/2PACX-1vQ-FT5C94ih1hN9CexBwH9iE63ekfcXiKTF-kCFjna0YtorBrf0Csavn5VjtecXeo-LdyCGhYiAydRm/pub">Read the inscriptions here.</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Leadership in the Assyrian empire and military</li> <li>Typical activities and goals of the Assyrian military</li> <li>Tools and technology used by the Assyrian military</li> <li>Assyrian religious outlook</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. .</p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. This is a dense and detailed piece about a complex topic. Enjoy! (That was sarcasm there. Sorry. This article is a challenging read. In an uncharitable humor, one might almost say that it makes a fascinating subject as boring as possible. But perhaps this has great value? With early medieval Germanic paganism, the historiography is so complex, the sources so tenuous and interrelated and unstable, and the material so innately fascinating and alive ... "boring" has value here.)</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Important features of early Germanic religious belief and practice</li> <li>The nature of the surviving evidence about the history of early medieval Germanic paganism, and the debates about how to intepret it</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingoe1" `$askingoe1 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-k]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Anglo-Saxon King Scenario |AS-king]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if ($peasCombat1 is "done") and ($peasCombat1 isnot "")>> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Peasants]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-md"> <img src="images/mobs/mobd.jpg" alt="monkey falconer riding goat" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p>Here is your opponent. To win this fight, choose a good response to its questionable statements about history.</p> <p>It says, "The English longbow, once hailed as a core component of the late medieval military revoluiton and a catalyst for progressive social change, had very little real impact and probably never even existed."</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Oh, great. Thanks a lot, creepy creature, for kicking over a hornet's nest. Let's just throw in some gasoline and a blowtorch and some dynamite while we're at it. Prepare yourself for an academic catfight of epic proportions, involving not only timid archive researchers but also crazy reinactors who risk life and limb to experience medieval battles first hand.</p> <p>So, what will you offer to this very active and heated debate?</p> <div class="row scenario"> <p><label><<radiobutton "$peasCombatQ1" "A">> Revisionism has gotten way out of control here. Just because previous generations have viewed the English longbow as a prominent feature of the late medieval military revolution, that doesn't mean they were wrong. Maybe the old narratives merit review, and new analysis of the evidence can offer nuance, but completely discarding the traditional theory about the impact of the English longbow in the late Middle Ages is unwarranted and reactionary.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$peasCombatQ1" "B">> Revisiting these old narratives seems like a good idea. Ultimately, there's no way to know how much impact longbows had on medieval battlefields, because very few accounts of the battles were written by eyewitnesses.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$peasCombatQ1" "C">> Longbows were definitely real and they absolutely sparked the late medieval military revolution. There's no need to challenge that well-known fact.</label></p> </div> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "peas-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($peasCombatQ1 is "A") and ($peasCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $peasCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <p>Yes, this is one risk of revisionism. Skepticism and empiricism are the bedrock of history as a discipline. We must question and critique old (and new) interpretations. But sometimes revisionism becomes overzealous, and its logic undermined by inherent bias against old interpretations. We can certainly see this dynamic in the current debate about the English longbow. Some revisionist arguments go way, way too far in their zeal to dismantle the traditional narrative. This has sparked vigorous debate, yielding new evidence and new conclusions, drawing in new perspectives from archaeology, art, comparative ethnography, even real experiments measuring velocity, etc. It's a beautiful thing.</p> <p>So, yes. Let's scrutinize these old notions about the revolutionary nature of the longbow. By all means. But let's not toss them out the window altogether. Victory has boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Bow">><<set $bow to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Peasants]]</p> <<elseif ($peasCombatQ1 is "B") and ($peasCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>Hooray for debate! Skepticism and empiricism are the bedrock of history as a discipline. We must revisit and critique old (and new) interpretations. Recent challenges to the old "longbow hypothesis" have produced some quite radical revisions, sparking vigorous disagreement, and revitalizing the whole topic with new evidence and conclusions. For instance, historians have gained awareness of how specialized these weapons were, and how few people could really be considered true longbowmen. They're also learned a lot more about what exactly makes a true longbow so deadly compared to other bows (e.g., what kind of arrowhead is used and what kind of target is struck and from what angle and range). This is how it should work.</p> <p>Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Bow">><<set $bow to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Peasants]]</p> <<elseif ($peasCombatQ1 is "C") and ($peasCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>For the most part, yes, the traditional interpretation of the longbow is holding, but not without some adjustments, caveats, nuance, generated by the renewed scholarship. For instance, historians have gained awareness of how specialized these weapons were, and how few people could really be considered true longbowmen. They're also learned a lot more about what exactly makes a true longbow so deadly compared to other bows (e.g., what kind of arrowhead is used and what kind of target is struck and from what angle and range). It's probably best to welcome this kind of challenge to old historiography. Debate (in theory) leads to a wealth of new evidence and insights.</p> <p>[[Move on through this time travel portal. |Peasants]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Peasants]]</p> <</if>><<if $peasCombat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Peasants]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: "some dumb circular logic"</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$peasCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$peasCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$peasCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "peas-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($peasCombatQ2 is "A") and ($peasCombatQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $peasCombat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Peasants]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <div class="row peashero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Medieval Peasants</h1> <p>You and your comrades have written a new history of the medieval peasantry! Open the branching pathways to explore it.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center space"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>German Forester Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/stuttgart-predators.jpg" alt="livestock and forest predators meet at a river" width="50%"> <p>You have decided to kill the margrave. ... You look back at your dog, seeing again her resemblance to her grandfather, old Boar Bane. A few months ago, Boar Bane was gored to death by a boar the size of a bear, and it was the Margrave's doing. ... The margrave will hunt here soon. You will attend the hunt, telling the huntsmen where to find what they want - fox, bear, boar, wolves, deer. How will you make sure the margrave doesn’t survive the day’s sport? And make sure you are never suspected? What are the results of your choices? For you, for your community, or for the broader sweep of history?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[I will lead us to a spot that is known for being populated by bears, and quickly stab him. I will leave him by a den and return to the group, telling a terrifying tale of the gigantic bear that has taken the margrave back to its awful den. |forester-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I would say a wolf spooked his horse and he fell and died. I would also have a wolf corps to show so I could say I avenged his death. |forester-rewrite3]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Have my dog lead the margrave through the armed trap to the snared animals (hopefully wolves and bears). Once the margrave is knocked down off his horse, I will then release the snared animals and let nature do the rest. |forester-rewrite4]]</li> </ul> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Midsummer Bonfire Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/mummers.jpg" alt="people playing music and dancing with animal masks on" width="50%"> <p>You lounge in the shadows, avoiding the heat of the flames. Carefully cradling a cup brimming with good mead, you watch the one you love. Jostling against their friends, laughing and singing, they dance around the roaring bonfire. They're like a spirit, like a flame. You take another drink, feeling miserable and excited at the same time, desperate to make something happen before dawn. ... What do you say to your beloved? What are they like? Why do you love them? How will you achieve some kind of romantic union with this person? How will you deal with the family problem? Is marriage possible? Or desirable?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[With a deep breath and a final swing of the drink I call out to her and confess my feelings. |love-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[You have to follow your heart and if you love the guy then go for it. |love-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[To make this love successful I will need to try and mend the rivalry between our two families. |love-rewrite3]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Start the Role Play Game |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Peasant Life</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Leading medievalist and feminist historian Judith M. Bennett wrote a wonderful microhistory about a 14th-century English peasant woman named Cecilia Penifader. In <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1zVF-N3qWCA1GM6LVK9jzyWvKvxTZMr-_/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this section</a>, Bennett takes on on a tour of a typical year in a medieval village. And in <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1k2HAmWDS3hwEEzPfBwIzP9sLSVejfVuq/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank"></a>, she covers relationships, marriage, and gender.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How peasants lived, worked, and played in a typical year</li> <li>Relationships, especially overlapping networks and obligations among community, family, and marriage</li> <li>Religious practices and beliefs</li> <li>Medieval farming</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Pericles]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>In the Classical Period, a Greek polis was ruled by:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$periclesExploreQ2" "A">>a theocracy.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$periclesExploreQ2" "B">>the votes of all people.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$periclesExploreQ2" "C">>a constitution.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "pericles-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($periclesExploreQ2 is "C") and ($periclesExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $periclesExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done!
