Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Pericles]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>This year, I only hope that the funeral speech goes as well as last years. I have been re-elected year after year, I’m still favorable in their eyes. This funeral speech must inspire the men being sent to this endless war. Not only that, but Persia has decided to build Sparta a navy. I can only hope ours is superior. It is an honor to give your life for Athens, let this speech serve as a reminder of that. Their deaths are not in vain. Our ancestors bestowed upon us this tradition of the funeral speech. It is common sense that I must be the one to present it. Our ancestors must be mentioned and thanked first, they were the ones who gave us this traditional honoring. For surviving members, they must still look up to Athens and with the same bravery that she bestows up you, shall also put your life on the line for her. To the families, sympathy, however death is seen as an honor. Those who can still bear children, should, as they will aid you in this grieving process. To those sons and brothers, look up to those who have fallen in the name of Athens. Aspire to be as brave as them.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="row scenario"> <p>I would speak about what the common man does in his free time. I would speak to these people about how in this war that has no end in sight people look for a distraction and a way to try and escape the harsh realities of the war that they are in. The people go out and watch plays made by Aristophanes. He's popular for a reason and Lysistrata is popular for a reason. The common man doesn't want this war to go on or to die in it they want to be at home with their wives and their wives and other ladies want them there too. The play is a comedy and absurd but it is something that people can relate to.</p> <p>Honestly, I feel that Sparta and Persia would laugh at Athens if they heard about this but if the people of Athens could be convinced to try to sue for peace it wouldn't matter. If the people don't want to think about this war and want to speak about it ending and make a play speaking about how observed it is that this is still going on. Athens cant beat Sparta on land and they would no longer have that big of an advantage over the sea like they usually did(John Warrys’ Warfare) because of the ships that Persia gave to Sparta I think that if Athens can see that people do not want to leaves there wives to go die in a losing war they could start negotiations on a stronger foot.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div></footer><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "greece-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Plutarch, <em>Lives</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The primary source text with the most detail about Spartacus' rebellion is Plutarch's <em>Lives</em>. Although Plutarch was writing in Greece and over a century after Spartacus' death, he used sources now lost (such as Sallust). You can <a href="https://www.livius.org/sources/content/plutarch/plutarchs-crassus/plutarch-on-spartacus/" target="_blank">find Plutarch's account of Spartacus here.</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Roman attitudes toward slaves and the uprising</li> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the slave army and the Roman forces</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprpe1" `$sprpe1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprpa1" `$sprpa1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprpe2" `$sprpe2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprpa2" `$sprpa2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprpe3" `$sprpe3 ?? [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Pompeii]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>The Rubicon and Pomerium were:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$pompeiiExploreQ1" "A">>boundaries a Roman general could not cross with his army.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$pompeiiExploreQ1" "B">>special offices held by plebians during the republican period.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$pompeiiExploreQ1" "C">>punishments inflicted upon rebellious slaves.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "pompeii-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($pompeiiExploreQ1 is "A") and ($pompeiiExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $pompeiiExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Bow">><<set $bow to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Pompeii]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Pompeii]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $pompeiiExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Pompeii]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Which list places the Roman emperors in chronological order from earliest to latest?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$pompeiiExploreQ2" "A">>Constantine, Augustus, Trajan</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$pompeiiExploreQ2" "B">>Augustus, Constantine, Trajan</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$pompeiiExploreQ2" "C">>Augustus, Trajan, Constantine</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "pompeii-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($pompeiiExploreQ2 is "C") and ($pompeiiExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $pompeiiExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Potion">><<set $potion to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Pompeii]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Pompeii]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>This fresco decorated the wall of a house near Pompeii in the first century BCE. From the <a href="https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/cubi/hd_cubi.htm" target="_blank">Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>.</p> <p><img src="images/fresco-lyre.jpg" alt="woman plays kithara" width="80%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Here are a couple of examples of interior decorating in Roman villas.</p> <p><img src="images/pompeii-vettii.jpg" alt="room with walls brightly painted with many scenes" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: A "picture gallery" style room from a house in Pompeii (House of the Vettii), from <a href="https://www.pompeiiinpictures.com/pompeiiinpictures/R6/6%2015%2001%20exedra%20ne%20p2.htm" target="_blank">Pompeii in Pictures</a></p> <hr> <p><img src="images/mosaic-nile.jpg" alt="tile mosaic of busy Nile River scene" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: A tile mosaic from a house near Rome c. 100 BCE. Nile scenes like this were very common. From <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/image/8268/nile-mosaic-of-palestrina/" target="_blank">World History Encyclopedia</a>.</p> <hr> <p><img src="images/fresco-banquet.jpg" alt="man and woman recline on couches while feasting" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: A fresco from a house near Rome c. 50 BCE. Scenes of leisure and feasting were common. From <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/image/14139/roman-fresco-of-a-banquet-scene-herculaneum/" target="_blank">World History Encyclopedia</a>.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>The great colosseum in Rome was built in the 70s CE</p> <p><img src="images/colosseum.jpg" alt="ruins of the colliseum"></p> <p>Image from Cole and Symes, <em>Western Civilizations, Volume One, Sixth Brief Edition</em> (New York: Norton, 2020)</p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>In the theme of Rome for my frescoes, I have thought up many beautiful and interesting designs for the walls of my house. Firstly, I plan to have scenes depicting everyday life. Perhaps a man selling bread, or slaves working in a field (I don’t want to forget my roots, afterall). I am also a big fan of stories. One of my favorite stories being that of Romulus and Remus. In the entryway to my house, I plan to have a fresco of them painted there along with the she wolf. What better way to honor the creation of Rome? In my dining hall, I also plan to have a fresco painted of people enjoying a feast.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Flicking on the specs of paint that I got on my hand, I wonder what stories should decorate my walls, how will I demonstrate that I am more than just the descendant of a freedman, but a Roman! Then it struck me, “Wolves!” I say aloud! “Wolves would make perfect decor!” Without Lupa, the she-wolf, who raised Romulus and Remus the founders of Rome, we would not be the great city that we are today. Suddenly a whirlwind of thoughts come to my head as the idea for my decor becomes more and more elaborate. The pictures should not just be of Wolves, but a reenactment of the deaths of Sextus and his father Tarqiun, with all of the men being replaced with Wolves, and the event happening within the roman colosseum itself. The imagery paints a picture of Roman strength. We are strong like wolves who strike down those who dare abuse their power to take advantage of our fellow citizens, as well let all of those around us see the spectacle that is our strength. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>As I ponder what I will depict on my new mural, I see a stray dog run across the road near where I am standing. It reminds me of the story of Romulus and Remus, the brothers raised by a wolf. “Eventually the brothers quarrel and Romulus kills Remus with a shovel. Rome becomes a safe haven for the outcasts of society: runaway slaves, convicts, and other fugitives. It flourishes and grows strong under the rule of Romulus.” (Legends) This story is a great example of how we Romans view ourselves. The empire of Rome is a great nation, accepting of all those that need aid, no matter what background they have come from. (There are many similarities to how Romans view themselves and how Americans view the U.S.A). This legend is perfect for the mural. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container scenario"> <div class="row"> <p>I would tell the artist to depict Tiber river along with the cradle of Romulus and Remus resting on the mud flat (Roman Legends). I would also tell the artist to show the she-wolf nursing them to health. This is to signify how fate is unchangeable, and how King Amulius failed because he dared to change it. He feared death but faced a gruesome one anyways. I would also tell the artist to depict a smoking funeral pyre behind Aeneas weeping face, to signify how Dido’s death and betrayal is forever in his memory. This will signify the utter importance of following the mission the gods give you, no matter how difficult it may be. I will also ask the artist to depict two armies charging towards one another, with a line of women in between with outstretched hands. This will show the Sabine women and their influence and how they brought peace when least expected. For the last wall, I will tell the artist to paint a portrait of Lucretia surrounded by flowers, a common symbol of rejuvenation. Through her death, she avoided great shame and made sure no Roman woman would have an excuse for adultery. I think my remodel will impact my social life greatly. When I host others for a banquet, I can show them around and they can marvel at the beautiful art (Pleasure and Excesses in the Roman Empire). They will also know that I am patriotic and uphold the values needed to be successful. These paintings will invite many discussions with many sorts of wealthy people interested in politics, military, art, and philosophy.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Looking around my new place I recall the glory of Rome. I want something elegant, bold, and a great conversation piece. First and most importantly I would want to put up a painting of Bacchus, so that I could remind myself to live my life free of conflict, and a reminder to enjoy all the little things in my life. For my other scene I would put up a stunning mural of Romulus and Remus. As a man who has grown in wealth since arriving in this city, I want to honor their story of the birth of Rome and the haven that welcomes all walks of life. No Kings will be able to control my life anymore. I plan on designing these in the dining room where I know many conversations will occur. The story of Romulus and Remus will be great conversation pieces among my guests as we can talk philosophy and about the great city of Rome.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>There is just so much possibility! Every wall, ceiling, and floor could be covered in frescoes and mosaics. I want them all to be my favorite things. I want this house to be a symbol of me and what I enjoy. I greatly enjoy the banquets that are thrown every once in a while. Maybe I’ll even include my dearest friends in the banquet along with myself. Maybe I’ll even save some room for portraits of them on my wall, just them. Oh! And I can’t forget about the Gods. I must honor them in this new household. I also greatly enjoy the theater, I’ll have a fresco honoring it. The great amphitheater outside would look lovely in the west wing. There’s so much space and so much I could do with it. It’s going to take a long time to complete, but I have time. Surely, living next to Mount Vesuvius was a great choice! What if we get a mosaic of Mount Vesuvius? It will surely be the biggest one too. On the biggest wall, it will cover the entire space and be the most important piece! I cannot wait to see the finished project!</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>As I stand back looking at the newly painted walls, I am satisfied with the outcome of my art choices. The walls are covered in designs and prints of plants, animals, architecture, and some landscapes. I was able to form these decisions by wandering around Rome and keeping things in mind that drew my attention. As for the plants, I decided to wander outwards into the wilderness and gather flowers and other plants that resonated with my choices. I wanted to display the nature that can be found outside of Rome. I also decided that the paintings on the vases I've seen would look good if they were put onto a wall and were shown off in a much larger aspect. I go into the market and look at the vases for inspiration and to find which art piece would fit the theme of my house. I settled on a vase that contains the god Dionyrus. He is depicted on the saddleback of a panther while wearing an ivy wreath. Additionally he is followed by a few other people who seem to be celebrating and enjoying the moment (Theoi 2000). This surely will fit with my theme of my house as I want it to be welcoming and a bit surreal in a way of showing the greatness of what's out there to be explored. This greatly fulfills my happiness of my home as it showcases my interests of the world and to what I perceive as art within Rome. As the paint dries, I think about how others will view my choices. I do not worry too much as I would rather have people enjoy the art and get a sense of the beauty of nature rather than the importance of social or economic status.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>If I were to decorate the walls of my home with paintings I would want ones that show how Roman I am. I personally would want at least a section of a wall to have the Roman men who killed Sextus and Tarquin. This is one of the legends that many Romans like and It would be quite something to see in my living room. To keep on theme I feel that some fresca paintings of some battles and gods would look nice, maybe one of a Roman legion marching on Gaul. because my previous family was slaves I would like to get a bust of myself made and have that on display as well and when my son comes of age I would get one made of him as well. I want to show my pride in being Roman and with my wealth, I can.</p> <p>The paintings in my home wouldn't affect my life on a day-to-day basis outside of pride that I could afford to live in my lavish home. If I were to invite my grandfather's former patrons' grandkids to my home they may enjoy it and think more positively about me and my family which could help in the future but my loyalty to their family would most likely be sufficient. If I needed to have any future business partners come over it would be better to have a nice lavish home to invite them to.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>Romans enjoyed frescos that represented their way of living, their gods, and their people. These frescos are specially selected and professionally painted onto walls of wealthy romans homes. Many of these frescos contain carefully painted images of the city, the roman people, and the ones they worship.</p> <p>And I want to put exactly that into my new home. I could not find it more fitting to celebrate the beauty and splendor of Rome, than to paint it on my walls. I am not sure where I will paint each image yet, but I will need one wall to bel Mt. Vesuvius, the beautiful mountain I live on. And I also must have a large landscape of my city Rome on my walls.</p> <p>There are many stories of Rome and how it came to be. Many of those stories are told by painting them on walls and displaying them in one's home as their decoration. This display shows how Romans are proud of their accomplishments and how they came to be as a city and a people.</p> <p>I will be putting many pieces in my home representing the stories my city has to tell, how my city grew and developed through years and years. I don't think that this art will really affect my life in huge ways, but I do think I will feel a sense of fulfillment from having these pieces of my beautiful culture in my home. I don't know if others will like it or not, but I am a Roman and I love this city and want to celebrate its beauty.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>My new house is complete in the beautiful city of Pompeii upon the slopes of Mount Vesuvius. What a wonderful location to build my new family. Me and my wife are so excited to finally move in now that it’s complete, but when we arrived the house felt so barren. The walls were completely empty and we needed to have artwork painted on them. “The villas of Pompeii [are] richly decorated with wall paintings depicting all manner of subjects such as mythology, erotica, architecture, trompe-l'oeil, religious practices, sports and family portraits,” so we can’t be the only ones without them. The first painting I think should go in our main living area is a beautiful family portrait of me and my wife. We will most definitely leave space on either side to add our children when we have them. Another fresco that I would really love to add would be one of my favorite legends, The abduction of the Sabine Women. Lots of “pagan art consisted of momentary images — snapshots — of legends that presumably everyone” knows so I think it would be a great addition to our home. The last piece of art I would like to have would be a landscape of Mount Vesuvius with the city below it. Because we live on the mountain we will hardly get to see it and it’s so beautiful that I would like to have that be apart of our domus. I’m so excited for our new home and how our family will grow and thrive here. I really hope no awful natural disaster happens to ruin our new beautiful abode!</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>I’ve done a lot of thinking about what type of art I’d like to have done up on my walls in my new place. It’s obviously something that needs to be timeless because having it repainted every other year when I get sick of looking at it everyday seems like such a hassle. I also specifically planned the open concept layout of my domus to be able to see this masterpiece from anywhere when I am hosting. I want people to come into my space and immediately respect me as a Roman civilian. From going to countless open houses in my area on Vesuvius to get inspiration from, I’ve decided I will have a fresco dedicated to the Roman art of banqueting (Veyne, "Pleasures and Excesses”). “More than a feast, the banquet was a festival” (Veyne, "Pleasures and Excesses"). I’d like to accentuate this celebratory feeling by depicting an array of the most prominent figures in Roman history sitting around a banquet table all wearing wreaths, dining on meat and drinking wine . Paying tribute to Rome’s idols from our most famous legends seems like a must so I am telling the artist I would like to see Aeneas and his son Ascanius, Romulus, Lucreita, Virginia just to name a few- in the painting (Legends). I can not wait to see my vision come to life - I will surely have the entertaining home of every host’s dream.</p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Battles of Cannae and Zama</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Early in the first century CE, the Roman historian Livy produced a ponderous mass of scrolls known as his <em>History of Rome</em> (completed by Livy's death in 17 CE). In <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/10ni3IOU8lK-Qw69tCw5RgKHm7GofljDCbiw6qhlQqcU/edit?usp=sharing " target="_blank">Books 22 and 30</a>, he relates the history of the Rome's epic defeat at the Battle of Cannae in 216 BCE, and its success against Hannibal at the Battle of Zama in 202 BCE.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The political, economic, ideological context of these battles</li> <li>Strategic and tactical options for the Romans and Carthaginians</li> <li>Rome's relationship with its allies</li> <li>The long-term significance of the battles in the evolution of a Roman political or national identity</li> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of Rome and Carthage</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannle1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannla1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannle2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannla2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannle3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannla3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannle4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannla4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Livy: Cannae and Zama |punic]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Punic Wars |warry-hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[A podcast... |bastards]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-mdvictory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-c]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[Back: Attacking Rome Scenario |Cannae]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if ($renCombat1 is "done") and ($renCombat1 isnot "")>> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Renaissance]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-md"> <img src="images/mobs/mob1.jpg" alt="three demons with claws and horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p>Here is your opponent. To win this fight, choose a good response to its questionable statements about history.</p> <p>It says, "During the Neolithic Revolution, people switched from a forager lifestyle to an agrarian one because farming provided more food, leisure, and safety."</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>How will you respond to this creature's hysterical history?</p> <div class="row scenario"> <p><label><<radiobutton "$renCombatQ1" "A">> This statement has little meaning, since there was no feudal system.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$renCombatQ1" "B">> This is a gross oversimplification. Gunpowder is just a tool, and technology cannot be the sole driver for social and cultural change.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$renCombatQ1" "C">> Gunpowder was a game-changer, sure. But this statement ignores other similarly or equally impactful technologies such as the printing press or the stern-post rudder.</label></p> </div> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "ren-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($renCombatQ1 is "A") and ($renCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $renCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <p>I mean, it is perfectly sound to be skeptical or even dismissive of any statement about "the feudal system." This mob should certainly clean up its diction. But it is not wrong in its assertion that a medieval socio-economic and cultural paradigm, characterized by past historians and readily identifiable as (loosely) "feudal" <em>did</em> come to an end in the early modern or renaissance period. A major transition from "medieval" to "modern" did occur. Personally, "gunpowder" feels more problematic than "feudal" here. What does it even mean by "gunpowder?" As in, projectile weapons? As in, explosive? As in, massed infantry wielding matchlocks? Either way, this thing is sloppy with its speech. It loses this battle. Choose an item for your inventory and enjoy 5 points added to your score!</p> <li><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <p>[[Onward! |Renaissance]]</p> <<elseif ($renCombatQ1 is "B") and ($renCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $renCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Nice work flagging technological determinism! This naughty mob. Technology is obviously a huge driver of change on many levels. However, historiographical agruments that technology is the sole direct cause of change are unsound at worst, unfashionable at best. Gunpowder undoubtedly catalyzed the transition from medieval to modern. But we would be miss much if we myopically fixated on gunpowder as the <em>only</em> (or even the main) cause.</p> <li><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <p>[[Onward! |Renaissance]]</p> <<elseif ($renCombatQ1 is "C") and ($renCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $renCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Agreed. This fellow is probably right to point to gunpowder as <em>one of</em> the most important technological catalysts for Europe's transition from medieval to modern. But others have a strong claim to rank among these late medieval technological MVPs as well.</p> <li><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <p>[[Onward! |Renaissance]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Renaissance]]</p> <</if>><<if $renCombat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Renaissance]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: "some dumb circular logic"</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$renCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$renCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$renCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "ren-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($renCombatQ2 is "A") and ($renCombatQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $renCombat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Presentism Poltergeist and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <li><<linkreplace "Chalice">><<set $chalice to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <p>[[Onward! |Renaissance]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the Presentism Poltergeist. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Renaissance]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <div class="row renhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>The Renaissance</h1> <p>You and your comrades have written a new history of renaissance Europe! Open the branching pathways to explore it.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center space"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Witch Trial Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/witches-grien.jpg" alt="engraving of witches flying and sitting around a fire" width="50%"> <p>The neighboring village had half its ripe corn trampled by mercenaries. It's nearly June. No time to try for a second harvest. Some houses were burned and a few people died. Then, a few days ago, two women in your village gave birth to dead children. Your mother was at both births. ... She is one of the "wise folk" or "cunning folk." ... They need someone to blame. Once they go looking for witches, they always find them. They'll be looking for anyone outside the usual, anyone different. And you are ... different. What will you do? Stay in the village or leave? ... How will the nonbinary nature of your gender identity impact your situation in a rural village witch hunt?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li></li> <hr> <li></li> </ul> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Artist in Florence Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/carracci-clock.jpg" alt="portrait of Black woman holding gilded clock" width="50%"> <p>You're at peace here in the busy workshop run by your friend, Artemisia Gentileschi, at the court of the Grand Duchess Christina of Tuscany. ... What can you create to fight against that system whose grasp you felt in court? The system of the world these learned men are imagining, which will place some people in slavery and some in liberty, simply because of where they were born or what they look like? The system that suddenly made you feel like an alien in the place you call home? ... What kinds of imagery, symbolism, and text will you use? Describe one of your pieces in detail, and explain what impact you hope it will have.</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li></li> <hr> <li></li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Start the Role Play Game |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Ring-giving in <em>Beowulf</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The Old English poem, <em>Beowulf,</em> was composed c. 800, but survives only in a single manuscript copy from c. 1000 (which almost burned in a library fire, but was saved by the statue on top of it). The poem tells of many old Germanic heroes and legends, but principally follows the adventures of Beowulf: an unpromising youth who becomes a mighty warband leader, rips the arms off monsters with his bare hands, wins epic heaps of treasure, avenges his king's death, swims across the North Sea carrying the plundered weapons and armor of 30 slain enemies (no big deal), turns down an offer of kingship, becomes king later, and kills a dragon.</p> <p>Here's <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/15gPxrceFyfzSqHrVqODuI9jKbhw6pcRc/edit?usp=sharing&ouid=107960520722717944293&rtpof=true&sd=true" target="_blank">a synopsis of the whole poem</a>, in case that's of interest (seriously, what could <em>possibly</em> be more interesting??). A central theme is ring-giving: Basically, a ring-giver is a military leader who provides victory and tresaure to his warband. It's a concept that's built into the Old English poetic register, its oral-traditional tectonics and aesthetic, and is a very old part of early medieval Germanic culture. It's just all over the place in Old English poetry (and easily adapted to a Christian context, for instance, to conceptualize Christ as a generous and victorious warband leader leading his saints or disciples as his loyal warriors). This treasure was often military in nature: helmets, swords, armor. It was a token of the lord-retainer bond, both expressing and creating the warrior's obligation to provide loyal service to his lord. Have a look at the text here: <a href="https://heorot.dk/beowulf-rede-text.html" target="_blank">(Old English and modern English side by side)</a>. No, don't read the whole thing (at lesat not right now). Read the parts describing this ring-giving dynamic, listed below. Have fun with the Old English! See if you can recognize some of the words.</p> <ul> <li>Hrothgar is a good king (e.g., offering victory and generously sharing out treasure): Lines 64 - 98</li> <li>Wiglaf tells his timid (cowardly?) companions that their obligation to help Beowulf fight the dragon is represented by the gifts of weapons and armor Beowulf has given them: Lines 2596 - 2662</li> </ul> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The role of treasure in early medieval military leadership or kingship</li> <li>How a king should use treasure to motivate his followers</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastrge1" `$hastrge1 ?? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Battle of Hastings Scenario |Hastings]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Roman Legends</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The first-century CE Roman historian, Livy, begins his massive (seriously, soooo long) <em>History of Rome</em> with some of the Romans' favorite legends about themselves. <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1egA_jzLJLpw8Foc2QeTvZtowYhEDGux_BKdc4HIzNEs/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">You can read some of them here.</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The Roman worldview, values, gender norms, political ideology</li> <li>Roman patriotism and national identity</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pomple1" `$pomple1 ?? We have the ladies of the court to thank for the splendid proliferation of these fantastical stories that have fueled creative writers for centuries - from Shakespeare's plays to <em>Lord of the Rings</em> to <em>Game of Thrones</em>. Without women like Eleanor of Aquitaine, we may never have known about these tales of Arthur and the knights of Camelot, of tournaments and quests, powerful queens and courtly love, magic and fairies, Merlin and Morgan le Fay. <a href="" target="_blank">This chapter</a> from Derek Pearsall's <em>Introduction to Arthurian Romance</em> explains the role of women in the production of medieval romance.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Aspects of Arthurian romance that were meaningful or appealing to noblewomen</li> <li>Ideas of gender and sexuality prevalent among the nobility, as reflected by this popular genre</li> <li>Ways in which aristocratic women wielded power at court</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elre1" `$elre1 ?? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-e]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: Eleanor of Aquitaine |Eleanor]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Being Roman></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Romans had a strong sense of patriotism and pride in being Roman, or <em>Romanitas</em>. At the core of <em>Romanitas</em> were virtues like patriotism, gravity, piety, courage, fortitude, chastity or sexual virtue, etc. But all this striving for Roman virtue occurred alongside a robust appetite for Roman luxury, opulence, and pleasures. This article on <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rZ6GgqNm2e1vdNuVZxOtkH4oR9bHJX0L/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank"> "Pleasures and Excess in the Roman Empire"</a> explores Roman notions of living the good life.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Lifestyle and leisure of wealthy Romans</li> <li>The practical, social, and symbolic functions of a Roman villa</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompre1" `$pompre1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompra1" `$pompra1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompre2" `$pompre2 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Portal |Rome1]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pompeii Scenario |Pompeii]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if ($rome1Combat1 is "done") and ($rome1Combat1 isnot "")>> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Rome1]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-md"> <img src="images/mobs/mob4.jpg" alt="demon with claws and horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p>Here is your opponent. To win this fight, choose a good response to its questionable statements about history.</p> <p>It quotes Toynbee, the great Victorian scholar, asserting that the rise and fall of civilizations follows a set pattern. When a creative minority of the population overcomes a challenge, civilization grows and advances. When the minority's innovation becomes normalized and the minority disappears, the civilization begins to fall. History shows that this is a consistent and predictable pattern.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Fight off this creature by choosing a strong response to this antiquated (yet very much alive) historical analysis.</p> <div class="row scenario"> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome1CombatQ1" "A">> This analysis might be old fashioned, but it is not wrong. The rise and fall of civilizations does consistently follow this pattern of challenges, innovation, and decline.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome1CombatQ1" "B">> This is completely wrong. It would be easy to find (or invent) historical narratives to suit this hypothesis, but there are numerous counterexamples disproving it.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome1CombatQ1" "C">> While this kind of speculative determinism has fallen out of fashion (for good reason), these patterns are prominent in the historical record. While it would be unsound to insist on their uniformity, or to use them to predict the future, they can (when used judiciously) help us understand the past, present, and future.</label></p> </div> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "rome1-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($rome1CombatQ1 is "A") and ($rome1CombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>The pattern is evident, certainly. But it would be problematic to insist that the pattern is constant or universal, or that it can be used as proof of speculations about the future.</p> <p>[[Onward! |Rome1]]</p> <<elseif ($rome1CombatQ1 is "B") and ($rome1CombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>Good points. But we aren't quite able to call this analysis "completely wrong." There's a lot of truth in it, and plenty of supporting evidence, although, as you say, there are also plenty of outliers and counterexamples. So, it's not all wrong. The problem is when it's used too dogmatically or in a deterministic mode to offer firm predictions about the future.</p> <p>[[Onward! |Rome1]]</p> <<elseif ($rome1CombatQ1 is "C") and ($rome1CombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $rome1Combat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <p>Right! These old fellows might not have practiced historiography in the way we like to do it today, but their contributions and theories have immense value, as long as we tread carefully. Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Rome1]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Rome1]]</p> <</if>><<if $rome1Combat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Rome1]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: (some dumb circular logic)</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome1CombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome1CombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome1CombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "rome1-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if $rome1CombatQ2 is "A">> <<set $rome1Combat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Tautology Troll and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Rome1]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the Tautology Troll. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Rome1]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <div class="row rome1hero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Rome: From Republic to Empire</h1> <p>You and your comrades have written a new history of Rome! Open the branching pathways to explore it.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center space"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Spartacus Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/maenad1.jpg" alt="vase painting of dancing maenad with staff and leopard" width="50%"> <p>Spartacus and his captains sit around a dying fire. They've been here for hours, roasting quail, talking, arguing. A decision must be made. Spartacus wants to lead the slave army north and across the Alps, out of Rome. After all, the legions are busy with Mithridates in the East and Sertorius in the West. The mountain passes are all but deserted. But the others are delirious with victory and plunder. They want to stay in Italy and ravage the countryside. ... The stakes could hardly be higher. Death (a good one if you're unreasonably lucky) on one hand, and freedom on the other. What does Spartacus decide to do? Why? How does it turn out? Do you win your freedom? How and where? Do you build a new society? Or does Rome win, as usual?</p> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[As a former slave my main goal would be freedom as soon as possible. |spartacus-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[If he stayed he proably would be okay but his army would not and it appears that he cares about his army |spartacus-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I hope that I can abolish slavery and make it where no one will have to endure being owned by another human being ever again. |spartacus-rewrite3]]</li> <li></li> </ul> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Pompeii Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/fresco-lyre.jpg" alt="fresco of women playing a lyre" width="50%"> <p>The sounds of building are a cacophany: sawing, hammering, chiseling, digging, the slow chant of slaves carrying timber and stone. You edge away from the burning sun, into the shade of your newly-constructed, empty <em>domus</em>. It's almost done. ... The paintings on your walls will celebrate the beauty and splendor of Rome! Its heritage and power and everything it stands for. Everything <em>you</em> stand for. ... What are some of the scenes you tell the artist to depict on your walls? ... Do you think your remodel will impact your life in any real way? Your social status or economic status or the opportunities you encounter?</p> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[I have thought up many beautiful and interesting designs for the walls of my house |pompeii-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[These paintings will invite many discussions with many sorts of wealthy people interested in politics, military, art, and philosophy. |pompeii-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I want something elegant, bold, and a great conversation piece. |pompeii-rewrite3]]</li> <hr> <li>[[It’s going to take a long time to complete, but I have time. Surely, living next to Mount Vesuvius was a great choice! |pompeii-rewrite4]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The walls are covered in designs and prints of plants, animals, architecture, and some landscapes. |pompeii-rewrite5]]</li> <hr> <li>[[If I needed to have any future business partners come over it would be better to have a nice lavish home to invite them to. |pompeii-rewrite6]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I will be putting many pieces in my home representing the stories my city has to tell, how my city grew and developed through years and years. |pompeii-rewrite7]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The first painting I think should go in our main living area is a beautiful family portrait of me and my wife. We will most definitely leave space on either side to add our children when we have them. |pompeii-rewrite8]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Paying tribute to Rome’s idols from our most famous legends seems like a must. |pompeii-rewrite9]]</li> <hr> <li>[[We are strong like wolves who strike down those who dare abuse their power to take advantage of our fellow citizens... |pompeii-rewrite10]]</li> <hr> <li>[[As I ponder what I will depict on my new mural, I see a stray dog run across the road near where I am standing. It reminds me of the story of Romulus and Remus |pompeii-rewrite11]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Start the Role Play Game |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if ($rome2Combat1 is "done") and ($rome2Combat1 isnot "")>> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Rome2]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-md"> <img src="images/mobs/mob3.jpg" alt="demon with claws and horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p>Here is your opponent. To win this fight, choose a good response to its questionable statements about history.</p> <p>It says, "Druids were members of a Celtic priesthood responsible for administering justice, arbitrating disputes, foretelling the future, and preserving oral history. They practiced human sacrifice, including the notorious 'wicker man,' a huge human shape built of wicker which was filled with sacrificial animals and people and then burned as an offering to the gods."</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>What do you think? Is he right? Or is something a little off here? Choose the best reply below.</p> <div class="row scenario"> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome2CombatQ1" "A">> The wicker man thing is definitely not real. It was in a movie, but there's zero historical evidence for such practices happening in ancient or medieval Celtic society.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome2CombatQ1" "B">> This is mostly nonsense with only the shakiest foundations in the existing historical record. It's the product of the over-active imaginations of nationalistic British Victorian scholars, who were excited about bringing the druids to life as a vivid emblem of ancient British national identity.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome2CombatQ1" "C">> Textual sources from ancient Greece and Rome support these statements. However, it is important to note that all of these ancient sources were written by non-Celts whose knowledge about the Druids was second or third hand. </label></p> </div> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "rome2-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($rome2CombatQ1 is "A") and ($rome2CombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>It is in a movie! The Wicker Man (1973) is a cult classic. The movie is unforgettably weird, but these statements about druids offering sacrifices in a wicker man are supported by ancient texts.</p> <p>Try again? [[Onward! |Rome2]]</p> <<elseif ($rome2CombatQ1 is "B") and ($rome2CombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>Well, this is not exactly wrong. The imaginations of those nationalistic Victorian British historians did go wild with the druids as an emblem of ancient British nationalism. They cobbled together source material from even the least reliable oral traditions, setting early modern Welsh ballads on a par with Hellenistic travel narratives and seeming to believe all of it at face value. Much of what popular culture believes about druids is their doing. But the monster's statement did not fall into this camp of romantic, ideology-driven historiography. It was accurate.</p> <p>Better luck next time! [[Onward! |Rome2]]</p> <<elseif ($rome2CombatQ1 is "C") and ($rome2CombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $rome2Combat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score +5>> <p>Good choice! Yes, these statements about druids have solid basis in ancient Roman and Greek texts. It is wise to interpret these texts carefully, since they were written by outside (sometimes quite biased) observers, not by Celts themselves.</p> <p>Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Armor">><<set $armor to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Rome2]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Rome2]]</p> <</if>><<if $rome2Combat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Rome2]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: (some dumb circular logic)</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome2CombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome2CombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome2CombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "rome2-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($rome2CombatQ2 is "A") and ($rome2CombatQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $rome2Combat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Rome2]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <div class="row rome2hero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Did Rome fall?</h1> <p>You and your comrades have written a new history of late antiquity! Open the branching pathways to explore it.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center space"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Barbarian Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/woden.jpg" alt="gold ornament with image of horned warrior with spear" width="50%"> <p>Your mother wants you to spend a year or two at Vindobona learning to read and write, to navigate the imperial bureaucracy, building on your family's connections as members of the local elite. ... You father wants you to focus on learning his trade. He's a smith. ... You want to be great general like Fritigund or Alaric or Stilicho. The smithy is as dull as the scriptorium. Where do you really belong? ... Will you follow your father's advice and work on becoming a smith? Or will you follow your mother's advice, and work toward a role in the Roman administration or the church? Or will you focus on the training yard and try to get some combat experience, hoping for a military career? What opportunities will this choice bring you in the future? What are some lucky or unlucky events that might shape your success in your chosen path?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[I will follow my father’s advice and become a smith. Although war and combat is exciting and tempting, our lack of iron (D. H. Green) and our reliance on Roman battle strategies (Tacitus) will make battle hard and unpredictable. |barb-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Being in the military will give me opportunities to travel and excel in my training. Maybe I will be able to move up the ranks. |barb-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[As a blacksmith I can give gifts in my community and to the king so that I can be liked and loved among the people and maybe even be given other gifts like land from the king. |barb-rewrite3]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Hearing this as a child gave me a sense of pride in our military and due to how strong we are seen in the eyes of outsiders. This was just the start of my dream to join the military |barb-rewrite4]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I think as a woman I would take my mothers advice and try to work in some sort of administrative role as that way I could still be at home and watch over my kids and my husband can come home to me. |barb-rewrite5]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I’ve had many moments where I realize how lucky I am to be in this life that I have. |barb-rewrite6]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Becoming a smith is something that offers a lot of security. While it doesn’t offer a lot of opportunities to rise in social classes, in these turbulent times it ensures I have a place inside my clan. |barb-rewrite7]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I want to be a part of something that I know will stick around. |barb-rewrite8]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I will become tired easier, so a military position may not be the greatest idea for me. |barb-rewrite9]]</li> </ul> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Anglo-Saxon King Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/sutton-hoo-helmet.jpg" alt="decorated helmet with face covering" width="50%"> <p>You are Cwichelm, King of Wessex, feasting with your warband in your high hall. Do you convert to Christianity or remain pagan? How does your decision impact your warband and kingdom?</p> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[Our strength lies in our traditions, in the gods who have guided us through countless battles and blessed our harvests. |asking-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[ I just don’t believe my kingdom needs more unifying or a cohesive religion to be content with life. But if more of my own people follow my wife and daughters lead and start converting, will they even respect me as their leader? |asking-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[After all, I am the king and I can do whatever I want. I think Christianity will be good for our community and I will definitely be converting. |asking-rewrite3]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Start the Role Play Game |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Roper, "Blood and Codpieces"</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In the <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/135VoJTSMNVheuML-lA_Y0UD1vtLcN5Tz/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">"Blood and Codpieces"</a> chapter of her book, <em>Oedipus and the Devil: Witchcraft, Religion and Sexuality in Early Modern Europe</em>, Lyndal Roper analyzes ideas of masculinity in the gendered power structures of early modern civic society.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Typical behaviors and activities of men in early modern towns</li> <li>How early modern ideas of gender would shape people's sense of self and relationships with others</li> <li>Links between ideas of masculinity and witchcraft or evil</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-w]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance |Renaissance]]</li> <li>[[Back: A Witch Trial |Witch]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Royal Standard of Ur (c. 2,500 BCE)</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>This small chest from ancient Sumer is decorated with precious metals and stone depicting scenes of war and peace. Images are from the <a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/W_1928-1010-3" target="_blank">British Museum.</a></p> <p>The War Side</p> <img src="images/ur-war.jpg" alt="stone ornament showing an army and captives" width="100%"> <p>The Peace Side</p> <img src="images/ur-peace.jpg" alt="stone ornament showing a banquet" width="100%"> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Tools and technology in Sumerian and Akkadian Mesopotamia</li> <li>Symbols of social status or hierarchy</li> <li>Behavioral norms</li> <li>Commodities, food, wealth</li> <li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$brse1" `$brse1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$brsa1" `$brsa1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$brsa2" `$brsa2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$brsa4" `$brsa4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The Royal Standard of Ur (c. 2500 BCE) |royal-standard]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Epic of Gilgamesh (c. 2200 BCE) |Gilgamesh]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Advice to a Scribe (c. 1880 BCE) |scribe-egypt]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Code of Hammurabi (c. 1790 BCE) |Hammurabi]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[A Scribe's Life |scribe-meso]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook or class notes.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-b]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Crusaders Sack Jerusalem</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In 1087, the First Crusade achieved captured Jerusalem, beginning the process of founding crusader states in the Holy Land (where the rest of the crusades would be fought ... and, without exception, lost). The bloody fall of Jerusalem in 1099 stands as one of the most shameful episodes in the history of the West. Eyewitnesses frequently describe blood covering their feet and their horses' legs from the victorious crusaders' slaughter of civilians. Historians have explained it in various ways, from deliberate, methodical genocide to berserk religious fervor. French cleric and historian Fulcher of Charters was present, and wrote <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1F6Zsb7oSacBFDlLZXb1YjUlgfUJwQ-NBFH0Nwon-U5Y/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this account of the fall of Jerusalem in 1099</a> in his history of the first crusade, <em>Deeds of the French on the Journey to Jerusalem</em>.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Crusader siege and battle tactics and technologies</li> <li>Crusader attitudes toward Muslims</li> <li>Challenges facing the crusaders in their attempt to conquer the Holy Land</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knje1" `$knje1 ?? In 1584 wrote <em>The Discoverie of Witchcraft</em> criticizing the illogical and unjust nature of witch trials. In <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/15-2frEYhQJHCf_1R9YATpk4-1ijuK4Z9f0Yd28DuCXQ/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this excerpt</a> from <em>Discoverie of Witchcraft</em>, Scott tells the story of one witch trial he encountered in the course of his duty as a magistrate.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The role of gender and power dynamics might impact a witch trial</li> <li>What motivated people to make witchcraft accusations</li> <li>How did people view witches?</li> <li>Who would be vulnerable to witchcraft accusations?</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Although it is from Egypt, much of these concepts would apply to Mesopotamian scribes as well. Open the translation of the <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1h3A3jdz2ORptbXYUtKf6MqNFiQ_F797N/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Papyrus Lansing</a> here.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Challenges and opportunities facing a young scribe in the ancient West</li> <li>Scribes' position in ancient society and political structures</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source.
