Well, it depends on what part you are using. You can use the material written by the World History Encyclopedia contributors as a secondary source (something written in our own times), and use the quotes from the Mesopotamian text as a primary source. This is quite common!</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The social status of scribes</li> <li>The education of scribes</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Misummer Bonfire Scenario |Love]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Sicilian slave revolts</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In the first century CE, the Greek historian Diodorus Siculus wrote a massive "universal history" focused on Rome. He included <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1cD45AslLbO-vBm-ZwyGetjymqw-Qdk5N/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this account </a> of a large slave uprising in Sicily in 135 BCE. It's an interesting comparison with the events of Spartacus' rebellion.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Roman attitudes toward slaves and the uprising</li> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the slave army and the Roman forces</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprde1" `$sprde1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprde2" `$sprde2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprda4" `$sprda4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Roman depictions of slavery |gladiators]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Plutarch's account of the rebellion |plutarch-spartacus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[A slave rebellion in Sicily |sicily-slaves]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Spartacus' rebellion |strauss]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Roman slave trade |bradley]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-s]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Portal |Rome1]]</li> <li>[[Back: Spartacus Scenario |Spartacus]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Skaldic Verse</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Vikings were great poets. (Maybe this is a surprise, like the Assyrians being great patrons of the arts?) Viking poetry typically praises an individual for adherence to a kind of Germanic heroic ethos, which is deeply embedded in the oral-traditional poetics of pre-Christian Germanic society. The Vikings' skaldic poetry and runic inscriptions take delight in ornate, elaborate kennings (metonymic expressions) based on pagan religion, myth, and legend. This poetry is a rich source of insight into early Germanic paganism, as well as Viking notions of leadership, warfare, and ideals of masculinity.</p> <p>Viking poetry is not what we expect in our post-romantic outlook today. It is not introspective or pensive or deeply contemplative. It is outward- rather than inward-facing. It is a public speech act with political force. And it's not easy to read. But we're doing it all wrong! It wasn't meant to be <em>read</em> at all, but to be spoken and heard and chanted and shouted. See how you do with these examples.</p> <ul> <li>The famous Viking skald Egill Skala-Grimssonr composed <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Qi7BH_pThjlYew-fRCiyf5gfBpjyHemS/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this poem</a> for the Viking king of York, Erik Blood Axe, as an apology to the king for having stayed a while at the rival court of the English king Aethelstan. He called the poem "Head Ransom;" apparently Erik was not amused at Egill's little fling at the English court. It's basically a standard classic skaldic poem: "oh king, you are a great warrior and your dudes are great warriors too and they love you and Odin loves you and you have done many great things like killing people and being generous with treasure." Text from S. Nordal, <em>Egils saga</em> (1933) and J. Carroll.</li> <li><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/106GeawWK5GQDx8Vg-VhPdKWc5Cg28on9/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">These verses</a> were composed by Viking poet Arnorr jarlaskald about Harald Hardrada's invasion of England in 1066. Text from G. Turville-Petre, <em>Skaldic Verse of the Scandinavian Middle Ages</em> (1951).</li> </ul> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Military leadership and ideals of masculinity in Viking Age England</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastske1" `$hastske1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastska1" `$hastska1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastske2" `$hastske2 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Battle of Hastings Scenario |Hastings]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Pelteret, "Slave Raiding and Slave Trading" </h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Sure, Vikings would pick up treasure whenever they could. But how much treasure do you think they actually found in villages? Yeah, it wasn't common for ordinary folk to have chunks of silver and gold strewn around their houses (although, as shown by the hoards of coins found buried beneath the remains of burned Viking Age houses, people sometimes did keep caches of silver and gold buried under their floors). Really, the most common form of plunder picked up by the Vikings was human. The slave trade was a key sector of the early medieval economy, just as it had been in ancient times. <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1m7tq7ov_d4GHONiJWrVkrARe9vNUtjvR/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">In this article</a>, David Pelteret analyzes evidence about Viking slave-trading activity in Anglo-Saxon England.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The status and experiences of slaves in Anglo-Saxon England</li> <li>The methods of Viking slave raiders</li> <li>Ideas about how to defend against Viking slave raids</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defslavee1" `$defslavee1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defslavea1" `$defslavea1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defslavee2" `$defslavee2 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-d]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Defence Scenario |Defence]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Snorri Sturluson, <em>Heimskringla</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Snorri Sturlusson (1179 - 1241) was an Icelandic nobleman and poet (poetry and politics go together in the Viking world, remember?). He wrote a lot about Scandinavian history, myth, and legend. He's an MVP of medieval history, because without Snorri's works, we would know much, much less about early Germanic myth, legend, religion, and about the Vikings and their worldview and their poetry. <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1IVhbVnMLbf60llpgDtw0vjL6cOg8MXM8/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Here, in his <em>History of the Kings of Norway</em></a>, (<em>Heimskringla</em>), Snorri includes the story of the last battle of old Harald Hardrada, or "Hard Ruler", (Note: Snorri uses his proper name, Harald Sigurtharson). It is the Battle of Stamford Bridge, fought just outside York in northern England. Harold Godwinson won, defeating Harald Hardrada and his English allies (including one of Harold Godwinson's brothers, Earl Tostig). Harald Hardrada was the archetypical amazingly successful Viking all the other VIkings wanted to be.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Military and political strengths and weaknesses of Harold Godwinson</li> <li>The wider international political and diplomatic situation of the contested English crown in 1066</li> <li>The nature of warfare and military leadership in northern Europe in 1066</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hasthke1" `$hasthke1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hasthka1" `$hasthka1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hasthke2" `$hasthke2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hasthka2" `$hasthka2 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Battle of Hastings Scenario |Hastings]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $spartacusExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Spartacus]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Roman religious practices can best be described as:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$spartacusExploreQ1" "A">>diverse and eclectic.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$spartacusExploreQ1" "B">>narrow and exclusive.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$spartacusExploreQ1" "C">>separate from politics.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "spartacus-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($spartacusExploreQ1 is "A") and ($spartacusExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $spartacusExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Lance">><<set $lance to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Spartacus]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Spartacus]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $spartacusExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Spartacus]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>A pilum:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$spartacusExploreQ2" "A">>served for one year before entering the senate.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$spartacusExploreQ2" "B">>proved useless after it was adopted by the Roman legions.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$spartacusExploreQ2" "C">>was designed to disable an enemy's shield.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "spartacus-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($spartacusExploreQ2 is "C") and ($gspartacusExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $spartacusExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Illuminated codex">><<set $book to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Treasure">><<set $treasure to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Spartacus]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Spartacus]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>Roman slaves did grueling labor on the <em>latifundia</em> of wealthy patricians, producing commodities such as olives, grapes, wheat, cattle, sheep. The experience of enslavement differed widely in Rome. Some slaves lived in appallingly brutal, dehumanizing conditions. While an owner could legally kill their slaves, stoic philosophy made it fashionable for elite Romans to treat their slaves humanely. As the philosopher Seneca wrote to a friend in the first century CE: "You say, 'But I have no master.' You are young. Things change. Perhaps you will have one. Do you not know how old Hecuba was when she became a captive? Or Croesus?..." (In other words, treat others as you wish to be treated because anyone can become a slave at any time.)</p> <p>Below: A Roman mosaic showing enslaved agricultural laborers.</p> <p><img src="images/roman-slaves-ag.jpg" alt="scantly-clad people work with livestock while a fully-clothed figure gives direction" width="80%"></p> <p>Seneca was speaking of a lofty ideal. Reality was often unimaginably brutal, especially in the mines. Bloody revolts broke out frequently. On the other hand, some slaves lived very well (especially the literate and well-educated), and many were freed by owners who realized it was more useful to have a loyal client who could vote and do business, than a slave with no legal identity of his own. People typically fell into slavery through debt, crime, or conquest. It was common for a Gaul to sell one of his countrymen to a Roman in exchange for an amphora of good Italian wine. A human life was (is?) sometimes heartbreakingly cheap.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Thrace's aristocracy had a strong tradition of hunting on horseback. Thracian horsemen had a reputation for excellence on the battlefield, and were sought after by Roman generals for service as auxilliaries. Ancient sources suggest that Spartacus was a Thracian cavalryman who had served in the auxilliaries and fought under Roman command. One story says that Spartacus' passion for horses led him to slaughter his own favorite horse at the beginning of his last desperate battle with Rome, as a symbol of his commitment to victory or death. Nobody's sure about that story ... who knows?. Spartacus did fight on foot in that last battle, and his body was never found.</p> <p><img src="images/thracian.jpg" alt="carving of horseman with spear above dog attacking boar" width="50%"></p> <p>Above: Relief of Thracian hunter on horseback with spear and dogs, pursuing boar</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Numerous depictions of gladiators survive from ancient Rome.</p> <p>Below: Marble bas relief (Rome, c. 30 BCE).</p> <p><img src="images/gladiators-marble.jpg" alt="carving of gladiators in combat" width="70%"></p> <p>Below: Marble bas relief (Rome, first century CE).</p> <p><img src="images/gladiators-marble2.jpg" alt="carving of gladiators in combat" width="70%"></p> <p>Below: Mosaic (Germany, second century CE).</p> <p><img src="images/gladiators-trident.jpg" alt="mosaic of gladiators in combat" width="70%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Spartacus' female consort was Thracian, like himself. She was a priestess of Dionysus and had some role in leading the slave rebellion, making various prophecies about Spartacus' leadership. Bacchante rituals typically involved frenzied dancing, snakes, tattoos, a long staff topped with a pinecone, and long robes.</p> <p>Below: Maenads or Bacchante appear frequently on Greek and Roman art. It's interesting to think about the reasons why this motif was so attractive to them.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> <p><img src="images/maenad2.jpg" alt="dancing figure" width="80%"></p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p><img src="images/maenad-dance.jpg" alt="dancing figure" width="80%"></p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p><img src="images/maenad-dance2.jpg" alt="dancing figure" width="80%"></p> </div> <div> <p>It's interesting that Mount Vesuvius, where Spartacus and his army camped, was sacred to Dionysus. The fresco below, from a villa near Pompeii, shows Dionysus with his symbols, and Mount Vesuvius in the background.</p> <p><img src="images/dionysus-vesuvius.jpg" alt="figure wearing grape cloak, with attendant panther, near mountain with snake in foreground" width="50%"></p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>As a former slave my main goal would be freedom as soon as possible. I would advise Spartacus and his men to flee North. I would back up Spartacus in this and prevent his unruly men who were on a victory high from making the inferior of two choices which would be trying to take Rome on. Up to this point all other slave revolts such as Capuan revolts which “were quickly suppressed”, Spartacus and his men should/would hopefully feel good about the success that they had and know where to walk away. It is true that Spartacus and his men were great in number but it was even more true that Rome would eventually steamroll them. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p> Spartacus was a gladiator, “ Spartacus had grown to be a great and formidable power, but he showed no signs of losing his head”(Plutarch, Lives). Gladiators were very important in Roman culture. Gladiator fought in big battles and they were viewed by many people. “Roman gladiator games were an opportunity for emperors and rich aristocrats to display their wealth to the populace, to commemorate military victories, mark visits from important officials, celebrate birthdays or simply to distract the populace from the political and economic problems of the day.”(Cartwright, "Gladiators"). Now Spartacus was not your normal gladiator; he had created a rebellion army that was trying to escape. He is a very powerful man and many people knew that he would be hard to defeat but the word had gotten out and he was concerned for his people. “His view was that they should cross the mountains and then disperse to their own homes, some to Thrace and some to Gaul.”(Plutarch, Lives). If Spartacus was concerned about his people and their safety I think he should flee Italy. If he stayed he proably would be okay but his army would not and it appears that he cares about his army in these readings. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p>My personal goal is to build wealth and make a better life for my family. I could also possibly join politics as well as make changes in my community since becoming a free person. I hope that I can maintain a good life for myself and my family. I can also try and make sure that my family will never suffer through slavery by making laws to establish the abolishment of this. I will also educate my family to the best of my ability so that I can try and establish and bloodline of wealth. My life as a slave will influence my decisions on making others feel equal to me and that we have the same opportunities in life as each other. I hope that I can abolish slavery and make it where no one will have to endure being owned by another human being ever again. I fear that slavery will continue or change forms where people aren't owned in a sense but they don't have free will which I plan on making for all. In the text Bradley_ Slave-trade states, “Presumably, however, there can have been nothing humorous in the transaction of sale as it was actually experienced in antiquity by slaves, the social category to whose low level Lucian's philosophers are amusingly reduced.” which highlights my key points in this essay. </p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row scenario"> <p></p> <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "rome1-rewrite">><</link>></p> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Strauss, <em>The Spartacus War</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1vwskneZ2wgMzljVzvzgYvpaIRg7sQDKl/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This chapter</a> from leading classicist Barry Strauss's book, <em>The Spartacus War,</em> breathes life into the enigmatic character of Spartacus, parsing the scant evidence to build a remarkably detailed portrait of the gladiator whose slave rebellion defeated legions threatened Rome itself.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The life of a gladiator</li> <li>Spartacus' background, outlook, motivations</li> <li>The context of the intial uprising at Capua</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-s]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Portal |Rome1]]</li> <li>[[Back: Spartacus Scenario |Spartacus]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Sutton Hoo Ship Burial</h1><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> </div> <p>The eighth-century English poem <em>Beowulf</em> begins with a king's funeral, in which the king's body is put in a ship along with his treasure, and sent out to sea. Historians and archaeologists were ecstatic when the remains of just such a ship burial were unearthed. It was a bit like what happened to Homer's <em>Iliad</em> and <em>Odyssey</em> when archaeologists discovered the remains of the Trojan War. An epic poem long assumed to be fictional was suddenly granted a foundation in historical reality.</p> <p>The Sutton Hoo ship burial resembles the funeral in the poem (except that the ship and its contents were buried rather than launched out to sea). You can view and learn about the artifacts from this fascinating archaeological site at <a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/death-and-memory/anglo-saxon-ship-burial-sutton-hoo" target="_blank">this page from the British Museum.</a> Note that this is another source that contains both primary and secondary material: The Sutton Hoo artifacts themselves are primary sources, while the information provided by the British Museum is secondary source material.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Symbols of kingship in early medieval England</li> <li>Forms of treasure used by the Anglo-Saxon elite</li> <li>Pre-Christian English ideas about the afterlife</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the role play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your role play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingshe1" `$askingshe1 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-k]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Anglo-Saxon King Scenario |AS-king]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Tacitus, <em>Germania</em> (c. 98 CE)</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The Roman historian Tacitus wrote <em>Germania</em> c. 98 CE, describing the barbarian tribes in the province of Germania. Tacitus himself never visited the region, but drew on works such as Caesar's <em>Gallic Wars</em>, and Hellenistic histories by Strabo and Diodorus. While <em>Germania</em> has been foundational to our modern understanding of the barbarian tribes and the history of the Germanic peoples in late antiquity, the text is extremely problematic as a primary source. For one thing, Tacitus wrote with a clear ideological agenda: His presentation of Germanic society was designed partly as a critique of his own Roman society. He was not writing objectively or as a trained ethnographer or anthropologist. It is also problematic that Tacitus was writing c. 100 CE at the height of Roman power, but we tend to use this text as a source about the Germanic tribes c. 500 CE. It is so rich, and there aren't many others, so it's attractive to us as historians. But it also has numerous problems as a source.</p> <p>In <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1jAoWq785AM6BPSCM09ASy60ZLOjgdv1RmwFecPEdoW0/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">these excerpts</a> from <em>Germania</em>, Tacitus discusses various aspects of Germanic society.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Beliefs and customs of barbarian society</li> <li>Everyday life, family and gender norms in barbarian society</li> <li>Military strengths and weaknesses of the barbarian tribes</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriante1" `$adriante1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianta1" `$adrianta1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriante2" `$adriante2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriante3" `$adriante3 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Barbarian Scenario |Barbarian]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Theophrastus, <em>Characters</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Theophrastus was an influential Athenian philosopher, and successor to Aristotle in the school of philosophy (Lyceum) at Athens. In <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1DB8vD42mIHLN1mGOFF6rCnXDmHmLXFAQ/view?usp=sharing " target="_blank"><em>Characters</em> (c. 280 CE)</a>, Theophrastus descends from the rarified heights of metaphysics and science to discuss some of the types of people he commonly encounters. This is only an excerpt of the longer work, but it is representative: It includes no "good" characters, no females, and nobody from lower socio-economic strata. If you're interested, you can find the whole book with a full list of "characters" at <a href="https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/58242/pg58242-images.html" target="_blank">Project Gutenberg</a>.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How do Hellenistic philosophers and scholars interact? How do they judge each other?</li> <li>What kinds of people aren't represented here? Who is important, and who is invisible?</li> <li>How should people behave and live?</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexthe1" `$alexthe1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexthe2" `$alexthe2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Epicureanism |epicurus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Stoicism |epictetus]]</li> <hr> <li>[[People |theophrastus]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Homosexuality in Ancient Greece |homosexuality]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Done collecting material?</h2> <p>Your notes from this source are saved. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[Back: Alexandria Scenario |Alexandria]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Case of Thomas(ine) Hall</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In 1629, an indentured servant called Hall recently arrived from England appeared in a Virginia courtroom. The problem? Hall's fellow colonists couldn't agree on whether Hall was male or female. Hall had been raised as a female and had female skills (like embroidery). But they had also fought as a mercenary in Europe (a male thing). Hall had sexual encounters with females. Hall sometimes dressed as a woman, and sometimes as a man. They had male and female skillsets. People felt quite confused, and the problem found its way to court and into the historical record. <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ux7EZ6q0UL6HltVPdG5wqKPIS0ckv7VL/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This article</a> examines the court case in which the Virginia authorities attempt to issue a verdict on Hall's gender identity and sexuality.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Seventeenth-century attitudes toward sexuality and gender</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchhe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchha1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchhe2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchha2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchhe3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchha3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchhe4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchha4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Images of witches |witch-images]]</li> <li>[[An English witch trial |scott]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Early modern masculinity |roper]]</li> <li>[[A non-binary person |thomasine]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-w]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance |Renaissance]]</li> <li>[[Back: A Witch Trial |Witch]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container tips"> <div class="row"> <p>Historians works within certain ideological parameters and make use of discipline-specific methodologies and terminology. These tips and suggestions will help you approach this role play assignment as a historian.</p> <p>These same role play prompts might be approached differently in a different class (like an English or Creative Writing class, or Psychology or Sociology) or for a different purpose. This is a History class, so we will be using an approach defined by discipline-specific standards that align with how historians work today.</p> <hr> <h3>Tip 1: Historical Realism</h3> <p>Strive for historical realism by avoiding presentism and anachronism.</p> <ul> <li><span class="bi">Avoid presentism:</span> Your character wouldn't have your foreknowledge of what happened next in history. Try to avoid basing their decisions or feelings on knowledge of the future they would not have had.</li> <li><span class="bi">Avoid anachronism:</span> Your beliefs and values in the 21st-century U.S. are often very different from those of your historical character. (For instance, we tend to have strong beliefs in ideas of social justice, equality, the intrinsic value of a human life, the importance of environmental stewardship. Such ideologies were rare in the past.) Try to avoid basing their decisions or feelings on your own values and beliefs, which may not have existed back then. I know this is basically impossible, but give it a try?</li> </ul> <hr> <h3>Tip 2: Get Creative!</h3> <p>Be creative and authentic! Bring your own genuine personality into this adventure. For instance: "I tend to enjoy working with others, so I would ...", or "I am a good artist, so ...", or "I am physically strong, so I would ...", or "As a cisgender woman, I would probably ..." Alternatively, you could just go wild with role play and completely re-imagine yourself with different skills, personality traits, gender identity, sexuality, age, etc.</p> <p>If you feel drawn in to the world-building aspect of all this, you might want to give your role play character a background that imparts special skills or knowledge, or even a challenge to overcome. For example:</p> <ul> <li>Reading or writing: We tend to take this for granted in our 21st-century text-saturated lives, but in most of human history, these were specialty skills.</li> <li>Second languages: Maybe they were raised at a trading post and picked up a few languages.</li> <li>Hunting or fishing skills</li> <li>Fighting: Maybe they are physically big and agile. Maybe they grew up in a community in which violence was normal, and they're used to physical fights. Maybe they were a mercenary for a while.</li> <li>Metallurgy: Maybe their father was a smith</li> <li>Medicine or poison: Maybe they were raised by their grandmother who was the community's healer.</li> <li>A different ability: Maybe they were born with physical or mental limitations that are unusual.</li> </ul> <hr> <h3>Tip 3: Step-By-Step</h3> <p>Here's a suggested workflow for completing these weekly assignments.</p> <ol> <li>This is the part you've already done: Start playing the Role Play game! Enjoy learning some new things and thinking some thoughts.</li> <li>Next, look through the primary and secondary sources. Use the "maginalia" panels to save evidence and analysis.</li> <li>Copy and paste your marginalia notes into a document or directly into the Canvas assignment text editor. Edit. Proofread and revise. Submit. Celebrate.</li> <li><span class="bi">It doesn't have to be perfect! </span> If you look at the grading rubric in Canvas, you'll notice that you can an ok score on the assignment just by submitting the Victory! page screenshot and your marginalia notes.</li> </ol> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Tyrtaeus</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The Spartan Tyrtaeus composed <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vBHxpRmMv0SfMD8UyVHjFX-I9ldwAca016-LMeTYOKY/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this poem</a> about ideal masculinity, honor, and hoplite culture c. 625 BCE.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The Spartans' outlook, values, military strengths (and weaknesses?)</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$helottyre1" `$helottyre1 ?? You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal|Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Helot Scenario |Helot]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if ($vikingCombat1 is "done") and ($vikingCombat1 isnot "")>> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Viking]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-md"> <img src="images/mobs/mob7.jpg" alt="horned demon crawling" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-md"> <p>Here is your opponent. To win this fight, choose a good response to its questionable statements about history.</p> <p>This creature is in a happy mood and it's letting us off easy here. It gives you a list of representations of the Middle Ages in popular culture today. Which one is historically accurate?</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Can you find it? Which one of these representations of medieval history is factual?</p> <div class="row scenario"> <p><label><<radiobutton "$vikingCombatQ1" "A">> Crowds including children attended gruesome public executions.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$vikingCombatQ1" "B">> Vikings wore horned helmets.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$vikingCombatQ1" "C">> <em>Jus primae noctae</em> allowed a nobleman to have sex with a peasant woman in his domain on her wedding night.</label></p> </div> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "viking-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($vikingCombatQ1 is "A") and ($vikingCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $vikingCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>You got it! This is actually realistic. Medieval people were generally much more familiar with death and violence on a daily basis than we are today.</p> <p>Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose some loot for your inventory:</p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Treasure">><<set $treasure to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Viking]]</p> <<elseif ($vikingCombatQ1 is "B") and ($vikingCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>They did not. There are some horned helmets on artifacts from various other early medieval Germanic societies, but the Vikings specifically did not seem to have favored this kind of headgear.</p> <p>Better luck next time! [[Onward! |Viking]]</p> <<elseif ($vikingCombatQ1 is "C") and ($vikingCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>Nope. This is fiction. Ancient legends like the Sumerian epic of Gilgamesh or the Roman story of Tarquin reflect anxiety about elite men abusing their power by sexually assaulting women belonging to lower social strata. And there's plenty of evidence that medieval knights sexually abused peasant women. However, this was illegal.</p> <p>Better luck next time! [[Onward! |Viking]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Viking]]</p> <</if>><<if $vikingCombat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Viking]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: (some dumb circular logic)</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$vikingCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$vikingCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$vikingCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "viking-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($vikingCombatQ2 is "A") and ($vikingCombatQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $vikingCombat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Tautology Troll and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Viking]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the Tautology Troll. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Viking]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <div class="row vikingshero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>The Viking Age</h1> <p>You and your comrades have written a new history of the Viking Age! Open the branching pathways to explore it.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center space"> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Viking Defence Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/ema.jpg" alt="viking ship in museum" width="50%"> <p>Since last week’s Danish raid on the neighboring village, you’ve all been on edge, constantly scanning the horizon, jumping at the sound of a cry. ... You called this meeting to make a plan for when the Northmen come. Because they will. Your village is large, stretching from the docks in the bay to the monastery on the hill. ... Describe the plans you come up with. How will you defend yourselves from the raid you know is coming? How does this situation impact your community’s socioeconomic dynamics? What individuals or groups are empowered? Who loses status and who gains?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[We will not blindly trust them.The moment they have us fooled is the moment they will strike. These bloodthirsty ravagers in their own twisted minds believe themselves to be good natured. |defence-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[My first priority would be to keep my family safe, and away from all of this. If I had the money and resources I would send my family far away... |defence-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[They’re also smarter than they look. We must be wary, especially if they make it ashore with words of peace. They are not to be trusted. |defence-rewrite3]]</li> <hr> <li>[[I grab my wife and take her aside and explain that they are here. I tell her that I'm going to confront them and try to talk to them. In the meantime I want her to gather our belongings from our home and run off and hide in the old abandoned well and I will come find her. |defence-rewrite4]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Having ranged weaponry would allow us to pick off a few of them before they would be able to get close to us. |defence-rewrite6]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The first thing I will do is arm the village that I am living in and teach the people how to protect themselves. |defence-rewrite7]]</li> <hr> <li>[[... or we could flee. We could cross over the mountains to another village, and hope they will take us in. |defence-rewrite8]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Hide away as best as we can anything that is extremely important, then leave out other "valuables" as a distraction. |defence-rewrite9]]</li> <hr> </ul> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>The Battle of Hastings Rewrite</h2> <img src="images/bt.jpg" alt="tapestry scene of knights and infantry in combat" width="50%"> <p>Harold: "We have to march south. Now. Yesterday. Again. We just did this, like <em>just now</em> raced here 300 miles from London to wreck your shit. The Bastard will have dug in by now ... He’s here now, and after my crown. What will I do, old man?" ... What plans do you form for dealing with William at the coast? ... Is there a role for diplomacy as well as force? ... How does the battle go (if there is one)? What are the results for England and France? For your favorite person, Harold Godwinson? What would the ghost of old Harald Hardrada have to say?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[To deal with William I plan on keeping my men as strong and motivated as I can. I will do this by reciting verses, keeping both the men and the horses well fed, and reminding them of what victory entails. |hastings-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Ghost of Harald Hardrada ... would probably encourage me to not back down or employ underhanded means to gain victory. I need to show my courage and valor. |hastings-rewrite2]]</li> <hr> <li>[[|hastings-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> <li>[[|hastings-rewrite1]]</li> <hr> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Start the Role Play Game |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Page, "A Most Vile People" </h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Textual sources like chronicles and histories provide crucial evidence about the Vikings. But who wrote these chronicles and histories? The Vikings' victims! (The Vikings did leave plenty of textual accounts of their activities abroad, but it's far outweighed by the volume written by angry monks in fear of Viking attacks.) Honestly though, after writing the above, I kind of randomly flipped through my dog-eared old copy of <em>Heimskringla</em>, and not kidding literally in under 30 seconds I found a Viking-authored account of "their activities abroad." It was as expected. Have a look (from the Saga of Magnus Barelegs): "During the winter King Magnus continued east to Vik. And when spring came he sailed south to Halland and harried there far and wide. He destroyed Viskar Dale and a number of other districts by fire. He made large booty [stop laughing, he means "took much plunder")] and then returned to his own kingdom. As Bjorn the Cripple-handed says in his Magnussdrapa: 'Far and wide the war-lord wasted Halland's homesteads - swift he followed the fleeing foe - with sword and fire. Burned the thane of Thronders thatched farms many in Visk Dale - soundly slept not women south there - and other shires.'" So yeah, the monkish chroniclers are hardly an unbiased voice, but they aren't all that different from Vikings' own version of events.</p> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WnnH_ayZ2G4Gh9JPHGmxqSf8U2hN56z7/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">In this article,</a> R. I. Page tackles the problem of forming an objective, unbiased understanding of the Vikings when most of the written records were created by very anti-Viking people.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Features of typical Viking raids</li> <li>How people typically responded to a Viking raid</li> <li>The challenge of interpreting the evidence of clerical chroniclers as a source of information about Vikings</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilee1" `$defvilee1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilea1" `$defvilea1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilee2" `$defvilee2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilea2" `$defvilea2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilee3" `$defvilee3 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilea3" `$defvilea3 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilee4" `$defvilee4 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilea4" `$defvilea4 ?? ''`>></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[A Viking raid |dudo]]</li> <hr> <li>[[The Battle of Maldon |maldon]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Arms and armor at the Battle of Maldon |brooks]]</li> <hr> <li>[[Slave Raiding and Slave Trading |slave-raiding]]</li> <hr> <li>[[A Most Vile People |vile]]</li> <hr> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-d]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Defence Scenario |Defence]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Roman Interior Design</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Wealthy Romans loved to decorate their homes with frescoes and tile mosaics and ornate lamps and furniture. I guess when you have slaves to do all the domestic labor, a house crammed full of dust-catching bric-a-brac is ... well, anyway. Suffice it to say that interior decorating was important to the Romans, and their taste was not minimalist.</p> <p>Here is a beautifully curated sample of <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/collection/228/20-frescoes-from-pompeii/" target="_blank">twenty frescoes from Pompeii</a> at the World History Encyclopedia. And here is a wonderful collection of <a href="https://www.theoi.com/Galleries.html" target="_blank">Greco-Roman frescoes and mosaics</a> representing mythological subjects at Theoi.com. In the list of galleries on this page, scroll down and browse through the three "Greco-Roman Mosaics" galleries and the "Greco-Roman Frescoes" gallery.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Themes and aethetics that wealthy Romans enjoyed</li> <li></li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompve1" `$pompve1 ?? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Portal |Rome1]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pompeii Scenario |Pompeii]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>An Ideal Knight</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Knights loved story time. They often quoted parts of their favorite stories, especailly the gross and bawdy ones with raunchy jokes. These stories were typically about guys like themselves (or as they liked to imagine themselves), so these stories are very useful to historians in telling us about how knights viewed themselves, what they wanted to be like, how they wanted others to see them <em>as knights</em>. Of course, these ideals of chivalry were just that - <em>ideals</em>. So these stories don't tell us a lot about what knights knew they <em>should</em> do, and a little bit about what knights <em>actually did</em> do. <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1JJySNOhF2p90RQvZCb1U0m1LM8g2SCTt/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">These excerpts</a> are from a very popular story about a knight called Gui de Warewic. This story was written c. 1200 and survives in many manuscripts and fragments throughout Europe (a testament to its popularity). Knights just loved this dude. Probably little boy knights had posters of Gui in their bedrooms (I'm imagining). Gui's adventures include fighting dragons and giants, fighting lots of other knights in tournaments, skirmishes, and battles, going on crusade, having fun with his guy friends, a super sweet bromance that's really the heart of the whole story, rescuing high-status women, falling in love with the local lord's daughter at his hometown, who refuses to return his love until he has proven himself to be the best knight in the world (but then, of course, she continually moves the goalpost on him, and they get together only very briefly and only at the very end of the story when he's almost dead). Anyway. They loved this stuff. Enjoy (if you can).</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The chivalric ideal</li> <li>What knights liked to do, or wanted to be known to do</li> <li>How knights fought (weapons, tactics, codes of behavior or rules of war)</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$kngwe1" `$kngwe1 ?? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: King of Jerusalem |Hattin]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Punic Wars</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>These section of John Warry's book, <em>Warfare in the Classical World</em> focus on siege warfare in the Hellenistic period, and republican Rome's wars <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1jIReIxsyOMkyFQ8uKiRlYuUw6QS0NVet/view?usp=drive_link" target="_blank">with Pyrrhus</a> and <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1R1TUEP7BGTeMlF_uf2-X2NUp4FyAVsNO/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">with Carthage.</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Question text</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$witchExploreQ1" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$witchExploreQ1" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$witchExploreQ1" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "witch-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($witchExploreQ1 is "A") and ($witchExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $witchExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Bow">><<set $bow to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Potion">><<set $potion to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! [[Turn back |Witch]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $witchExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Witch]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Many Europeans attacked the ________ for causing the Black Death.</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$witchExploreQ2" "A">>Muslims</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$witchExploreQ2" "B">>aristocracy</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$witchExploreQ2" "C">>Jews</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "witch-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($witchExploreQ2 is "C") and ($witchExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $witchExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Book">><<set $book to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Witch]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Witch]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <h1>Imagining Witches</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Look through these images (and a few chunks of text) from early modern and renaissance-era depictions of witches.</p> <iframe src="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vRgz4qPwGmrxPihvfA0w7ysMMUEsj7YbmSZFNDAPzCVgfxlTShPQEsZXq-FiiSIXcAl_tNISkqN_-uP/embed?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000" frameborder="0" width="960" height="569" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>item</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchwe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchwa1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchwe3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchwa3" "">></div>
