<p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchwa4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Images of witches |witch-images]]</li> <li>[[An English witch trial |scott]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Early modern masculinity |roper]]</li> <li>[[A non-binary person |thomasine]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-w]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance |Renaissance]]</li> <li>[[Back: A Witch Trial |Witch]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="link"> <p>Popular beliefs about witches varied across space and time in the early modern West. Causing infant mortality was at the core of these beliefs. This widely-circulated engraving from late 16th-century Germany illustrates what witches typically did, according to popular belief.</p> <p><img src="images/binsfeld.jpg" alt="engraving of witches and demons" width="100%"></p> <p>caption</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Early seventeenth-century men's clothing was complex and ornate. The design aimed to emphasize the wearer's wealth and status with displays of opulence and costly materials such as rich dye, silk, fur, embroidery. This can be seen in the portrait of Sir Walter Raleigh and his son, below, created by an unknown artist c. 1602.</p> <p><img src="images/raleigh.jpg" alt="man and boy posing in fine seventeenth-century clothing" width="50%"></p> <p>We can see the intricacy of masculine dress in the image below as well. This baroque masterpiece by Dutch painter Rembrandt van Rijn, called <em>The Night Watch</em>, depicts the civic militia employed by a prosperous city to enforce law and order.</p> <p><img src="images/nightwatch.jpg" alt="men in bright clothing hold weapons, surrounded by dark crowd" width="80%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>The time of the European witch craze was also a time of nearly constant war, fought primarily by mercenary companies. They were notorious for profit-driven attacks on ordinary people. Villages were devastated by repeated waves of violence, diseaes, famine. In the engravings below, French artist Jacques Callot draws on his own experience of the Thirty Years' War. They were published in his 1633 series, "The Great Miseries of War."</p> <p><img src="images/callot1.jpg" alt="mercenaries raiding a farmhouse" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: Mercenaries raiding a farmhouse. Callot's caption reads: "See the fair deeds of these bestial hearts. They look everywhere and nothing escapes their grasp. Here one tortures in search of gold. There another who's done it all before urges on his friends. And all of them together kidnap, rape, murder, and steal."</p> <p><img src="images/callot2.jpg" alt="mercenaries raiding a farmhouse" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: Mercenaries being executed by local authorities. Callot's caption reads: "In the end these hateful and damned thieves hang on this tree like bad fruits - showing that horrible crimes and dark acts are also tools of shame and revenge, that the fate of men so vicious is simply to prove (sooner or later) the justice of heaven."</p> </div>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "witch-rewrite">><</link>></p> choices)" "witch-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Renaissance Rewrite |renaissance-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="container"> <h1>Xenophon, <em>On the Spartan Constitution</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Xenophon was a well-educated mercenary and statesman who led troops in Persia and the Greek city-states, including Sparta. <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1GA1sXFZYQIl8M9l7FvRA3-bS2fVjUhF8KcLED1hJ3Wc/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Here are some excerpts</a> from his description of Sparta's laws and political system (written c. 380 BCE).</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The situation and role of women in Spartan society</li> <li>The situation and role of Helots</li> <li>Spartan military training</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$helotxe1" `$helotxe1 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$helotxa1" `$helotxa1 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$helotxe2" `$helotxe2 ?? ''`>></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$helotxa2" `$helotxa2 ?? ''`>></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$helotxe3" `$helotxe3 ?? If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal|Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Helot Scenario |Helot]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div>
